item.body:
This was my first ever play of this game. I have played [thing=133437][/thing] a few times on my lunch break with colleagues but that plays completely differently to this.
I played with the [thing=104590]Wizard's Tower[/thing] expansion.
The game lasted about 2 hours (mainly because I had to keep referring to the rules) and came down to the final possible move of the game. All the walls were destroyed and 5 of the six towers were destroyed. The only one left was the wizard's tower. There was one enemy left on the board and he was in the castle and one space away from the tower.
I drew my cards and had nothing useful so discarded one of them and picked up a wizard card. This card allowed me to deal one damage to one enemy even inside the castle. So with my last attack I killed the enemy and won the game. I'm not sure in real life it would be classed as a victory if you only have a 6th (or 12th if you include the walls) of your castle left standing.
The three additional mega boss monsters didn't really pose too many problems. The Dragon was killed off with one card. The Chimera moved into an area that I had plenty of cards for so only lasted 2 turns. The Necromancer was also killed on 1 turn with the use of a couple of cards. The biggest problem actually came from the original boss monsters. I hadn't seen any of them for the first three quarters of the game so when I drew the Goblin King I knew something bad was about to happen. The first additional card drawn was Orc Warlord, the second was a general monster, and the third was the Healer. Having these on the board at the same time made things much harder and caused most of the damage to my castle.
:thumbsup: - It is a challenging game and with different combinations of cards in my hand with monsters drawn it could have been a different result. :thumbsdown: - I prefer the mechanics of Dead Panic. I like that the players only get cards when they are in the middle but that they can go out to attack zombies that are too far away to hit otherwise. The only thing that game is missing are bosses. :thumbsdown: - Archers and knights should be able to attack in all rings leading out to their ring. What kind of knight runs past a monster that poses an immediate threat to the castle just to hit one that cannot do any damage to the castle.
item.comment:
[q]What kind of knight runs past a monster that poses an immediate threat to the castle just to hit one that cannot do any damage to the castle.[/q]
A charging one with restricted vision due to the narrow slit in his helmet? :D
I am hoping to get some plays of this game in this year, too. I have the Wizard's Tower expansion, and the "any color" promo card, but have only played the base game so far, and only co-op. It is on my tentative list for the Normal (non-hardcore) 10 x 10 challenge.

The any colour cards are very useful and I can only imagine how beneficial an any colour hero card would be.
Don't forget if playing solo you can discard and draw 2 cards instead of 1. On a few of my turns the second card was more useful than the first and saved my walls from taking damage.

item.body:
The [thing=159503]Captain is Dead[/thing] is a co-op game, but it can be played solo if using 3 or more characters. The theme is that the ship is surrounded by hostile aliens, is badly damaged, and only a few of the crew members have survived (not the captain). They must try to repair the jump drive and escape before the ship is destroyed. Unfortunately, the ship continues to take damage...
There are a lot of options in this game: having many different characters with different skills and abilities to choose from (or randomly select); deciding which ship systems to use with the limited actions available; deciding which repairs are more imperative; and whether to spend skills and actions on gaining tools, more skills, and/or upgrades or to try to make do with what you have and concentrate on fixing the jump drive and shields. With the randomness of the Alert cards causing more problems for the ship and crew, I suspect that this game will have a lot of replayability!
[COLOR=#FF0000]February 1, 2015[/COLOR]
:d10-1: I played [b][thing=159503]The Captain Is Dead[/thing][/b] for the first time, using three characters (Chief Engineer, Tactical Officer, Scholar) while playing solo. I lost horribly, losing my shields and then taking another hit to them. Boom.
It didn't help that the 5 initial Alert cards (not defendable) disabled my teleporter, computer, and external sensors, injured two of my crew members, plus damaged the shields. Shortly afterwards, my torpedo tubes were disabled plus aliens were crawling all over my ship!
Planning to try again soon.
:d10-2: For my second solo game of [thing=159503]The Captain Is Dead[/thing], I decided to play with 4 crew members. I chose the Chief Engineer and Tactical Officer again, plus the Soldier and the Janitor. I found that the Soldier was surprisingly useful for many things, like getting Battle Plan cards, launching torpedos, and also using the security station, while the Janitor came in handy for fixing systems, especially after I got him a tool so that he got an extra action.
I think I got lucky this game because the 5 initial Alerts didn't damage the Comm, Teleporter, or Computer (that came later ;) ). Life on a spaceship is so much easier when those systems are functioning! I never did manage to get any upgrades, but the Battle Plan cards really came in handy.
[b]I managed to win, barely fixing the Jump Core with my shields completely down.[/b] One more shield hit and that would have been the destruction of my ship.
========
:thumbsup: I like the theme. The game is hard to win, but it is suspenseful rather than frustrating.
:thumbsup: There are many strategies to consider and try. Also, there are many different characters to try so it should have a lot of replayability.
:thumbsdown: The rules, especially for the Kickstarter edition I got needed some clarification. But there is an errata sheet on the company website, and a PDF of the updated rules. And the designer is very quick to answer all questions here on BGG. :thumbsup:
:thumbsdown: This is a minor quibble, but the small cards are just a bit too wide. They almost didn't fit in the FFG mini-sleeves.

Got it to the table and played the Viral side again.
I was progressing really well, managing to find cures for multiple viruses on the board. This made for a good level of funding throughout the whole game. Famous last words: "So close, so close ..."
Keeping to my usual remarks for the game: :thumbsup: Still a fun puzzle game with sufficient randomness to create tension. :thumbsdown: Some turn order info on the board would be really helpful. :thumbsdown: Would like to see a different randomizer for the advancement of the death toll marker.
---------------------------------------- Update 8-2-15:
Played another game on viral mode, still with the die-roll for the death toll. This time mankind was saved! Dr. Foster and Marvin to the rescue! The die was kind enough to lead me into Pandemic right when I needed it to put Marvin to good use. :whistle:

Lol, thank you for saying so. Now I know I'm not the only one who is bad at this game on BGA. My first game on the site, where I thought I had a clue how to string some combos together, ended suddenly with me in last place with 18 points and the next guy having something like 50 points.
However I will mention that my ability to play this game against other people doesn't change the fact that Race is my favorite game right now.

[q="klkitchens"]From what I understand none of the other expansions work well for solo.[/q]
Actually the entire first arc (gathering storm, rebel vs. imperium, and brink of war) all work well solo. They all include chits for the AI for the new start worlds. The only thing is they introduce some new mechanisms (military takeovers etc.) which are optional for multiplayer and not used for solo. They are worth getting for all the new cards even if the new (optional) mechanics are not used solo.
It is important to note that the expansions are part of an "arc" so each previous one is necessary for the next one. If you have gathering storm, get RvI next, then Brink of War. The Alien Artifact expansion is part of a second story arc and is not compatible with the first three expansions.
If you get Gathering Storm then get at least RvI. The variety in home worlds is worth it, and I never used military takeovers even in multiplayer.

I didn't think of using the robot to learn, so not sure if this is possible. I think its useful to learn the main game first as the robot solo game is an adaptation of this.

[size=18][b]ORIGIN STORY[/b][/size]
Long time lurker, first time poster.
I got interested in solitaire games simply because there isn't always someone to play with. My wife isn't into many games, and there is only so much you can do in the evenings with an 11 yr old daughter (who loves games) and a squirrelly 5 yr old that always feels he needs to be included.

item.body:
[size=18][b]Preamble [/b][/size] Part 2 of my exploration of the Battletech Introductory Box Set where I dive into the basics of ranged combat! In Part 1 I explored melee combat. You can find it here: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1301981/solo-play-and-preliminary-review.
For the purposes of learning the rules, the 4 mechs I picked to run this mission represent every class of weapon in the Introductory Box.
[i][u][b]IMPORTANT NOTE:[/b][/u][/i] Throughout this report, I reference a song called "Everything Is Awesome". A link has been provided at the bottom of the post. For maximum immersion, it is highly reccomended you listen to this song on repeat as you read this play-through.
[ImageID=2382978 large inline] This mech is not included in the introductory box, but the cool map is! (Notice the cardboard arm cannon :) )
[size=18][b]The Game [/b][/size]
Fresh off his last victory, Commando strides cockily onto the field with another much larger friend, Awesome. Awesome pipes out a never ending loop of the Lego Movie theme song over his mechâs external speaker (seen mounted above his head).
[i][b]The volume is set to [size=12]11[/size].[/b][/i]
[ImageID=2382980 large inline]
And in this corner; Hermes and Catapult! Herm and Cat hate childrenâs movies. Thus Awesomeâs musical tastes disgust them to no end. âItâs time to hit the mute,â mutters Cat.
[ImageID=2382981 large inline]
[size=18][b]DEPLOYMENT [/b][/size] From above we can see Herm and Cat to the north. Cat intends to stay put, gaining a defensive bonus from the woods heâs in while launching devastating long range missile attacks against any mech that tries to cross the open ground. Herm will run interference.
[ImageID=2382979 large inline]
Awesome and Commando have wisely placed the woods between themselves and Cat. Awesome will post up in the woods to provide covering fire for Commando, who will try to flank around the east end of the board.
[u][b][size=14]TURN 1 [/size][/b][/u] Commando goes sprinting to the eastern grove of trees while Awesome slowly advances towards the southern woods.
Line of Sight can be blocked by 2 heavy woods hexes, 3 light woods, or 1 heavy and 1 light. Commando and Awesome are careful to remain out of Cat's LOS.
Herm runs to cut off Commando and Cat sits and waits. His time will come.
[ImageID=2382982 large inline]
The first attack of the game! Much like melee, to hit with a ranged attack you factor in a pilot's base gunnery skill + his movement + the targets movement + terrain modifiers: Commando finds he needs to roll an 11 for his weapons to hit Hermes. Not a likely roll. But screw it, fire all weapons!
Commando has two sets of Short Range Missiles (SRMs) and a Medium Laser (ML) and will need to make a hit roll for each weapon. SRM4... miss. SRM6... miss. ML... hit! Laser weapons have fixed damage. This particular Medium Laser causes 5. Roll to determine where it hits... Center Torso!
[ImageID=2382983 large inline]
Herm is feeling a bit chagrined at Commandoâs good luck and makes a pot shot of his own, also needing an 11. Miss. Naturally.
âEverything is Awesome!!!â booms over the field. Cat squirms with distaste. "Childish rubbish..."
[ImageID=2382984 large inline]
[size=14][u][b]TURN 2[/b][/u][/size]
Commandoâs team lost initiative, which means he has to move first. Commando advances into the woods, preparing to flank Cat. Herm, taking advantage of moving second, is able to circle around Commandoâs back.
[ImageID=2397753 large inline]
Because Hermes is directly behind him, Commando won't be able to shoot at Herm with all his weapons. Commando has to make a choice: He may torso twist left to blast Herm with his Medium Laser (mounted on his left arm) or my twist right to let off a volley from his SRM4 (the 4 means this launcher looses 4 missiles per volley). The SRM has the higher damage potential, so he chooses that option. *bing-bang-boom!* Three of the 4 missiles hit! Torso, Right Arm, and Head! Herm takes 1 pilot damage for the head-shot, though he manages to remain conscious.
[i][b]âSAY HELLO TO MY LITTLE FRIEND!â[/b][/i] Hermes cackles with evil glee as he unleashes his [COLOR=#FF3300][b][size=12][u]FLAMETHROWER[/u][/size][/b][/COLOR] at Commandoâs vulnerable backside! [i][b]âBURN IN HEEEEEEEEEELL!â[/b][/i] Herm screams, as he quickly checks his rules to find what sort of horrific fate awaits Commando.......
.....
.....
.....
[size=8]*ping*[/size]
.....
â¨2 damage and absolutely nothing else.
Turns out flamers donât do anything special. All of Hermâs actually useful weapons miss.
Naturally.
[ImageID=2397755 large inline]
Awesome has a shot at Hermes. He fires his 3 PPCs (Pow-Pow Cannons?) and one hits, nearly blowing through Hermâs left leg armor. These things cause 10 flat damage.
Cat launches a round of LRMs at Awesome for a big olâ miss.
[size=14][u][b]TURN 3[/b][/u][/size]
Herm attempts to block Commando, who sidesteps and dashes madly towards Cat. Doh.
âFollow me, Awesome! Chaaaaarge!â
Awesome makes no moves.
What a jerk.
[ImageID=2397756 large inline]
This is Cat's moment! Commando is in the open! Cat fires all heâs got!
*WHOOOOOooooooosh*
Cat misses with all heâs got!
Commando returns the favor by missing all of his shots! Oh the thrills!
Awesome, on the other hand lands 3 PPC hits against Cat, causing a massive 30 damage spread over Cat's Left, Right, and Center Torso. Because he has taken over 20 damage in a turn, Cat must struggle to keep his Mech from toppling over.........
Success!
HEAT ROUND: Those 3 PPC shots generate a ton of heat, more than Awesome is able to shed, and the buildup has inhibited his movement. He suffers -1 movement until he can cool off.
[size=14][u][b]TURN 4 - 7[/b][/u][/size]
Commando walks behind Cat, Herm runs after Commando, Cat turns right to get a better firing angle at Commando, Awesome slowly plods through the woods, rocking his tunes.
*zappy-boom-pow* various shots are exchanged.
[ImageID=2397757 large inline]
Awesome begins his charge (ponderous walk) towards Cat. He needs to close the distance fast, before Cat blows him to pieces with LRMs. But Long Range Missiles have a minimum range requirement that make them almost useless at close combat. If Awesome can just close the gap, he'll gain a significant advantage!
[ImageID=2397758 large inline]
BOOMY-BOOM! Awesomeâs greatest fears are confirmed as he takes major LRM hits! Fortunately his exterior speakers survive the barrage: âEvery thing is cool when youâre part of a team!â
Awesome answers with 2 PPCs (he holds back the third to avoid building heat so he can regain his move point). 2 Crits! Cat loses a Medium Laser and a jump jet.
Herm points his impotent flamer at Awesome. âHalt, you musical philistine!â
[ImageID=2397759 large inline]
Herm recieves 2 PPC hits to the face. Fatality!
[ImageID=2397761 large inline]
Commando has been quietly chewing away at Cat, who has lost his Center Torso armor. Cat's gyro and engine have taken hits, and most of his weapons are offline. Heâs remained standing, but itâs looking grim.
[ImageID=2397762 large inline]
Cat has realized heâs been wasting his time swatting at Commando when he should have been focusing on Awesome. That crappy music must be stopped! Cat breaks the sacred oath of âno meleeâ and desperately kicks at Awesomeâs Right Leg, simultaneously firing with his last operational Medium Laser.
[ImageID=2397763 large inline]
Now that the gloves are off, Awesome delivers a punch that neatly removes Catâs right arm!
Commando follows up with an SRM volley that ignites Catâs remaining Long Range Missile ammo! Catapultâs last moments of life are spent in bliss, as the roar of a massive internal ammo explosion finally drowns out that accursed song!
[ImageID=2397764 large inline]
âEverything is awesome when weâre living our dream.â
[ImageID=2397765 large inline]
[size=18][b]THOUGHTS[/b][/size]
The battle started with some interesting tactical situations; trying to keep in cover and going for a flanking maneuver. Unfortunately, the actual ranged combat wound up feeling a little bland. Part of this is due to the fact that I'm only using 2 mechs on each side. I can see where more mechs and more varied terrain would add some spice, and I'm looking forward to trying out a bigger, terrain heavy battle next!
The weapons provided in the base set are also very straight forward. For the most part it was point at your target and fire all weapons. Damage is mostly fixed, and it's just a question of if and where you hit. There is the choice of splitting fire, though I never found myself in a situation where I could try that out.
Missiles were the most interesting weapon from my point of view, as you never could tell how many would actually hit, and they tended to sprinkle damage all over the target instead of a single location.
I loved how ranged weapons introduced a need to manage heat! The more powerful weapons can build up heat that will quickly gimp your mech. There are a lot of interesting choices to balance between maximum firepower, maneuvrability, and maintaining low heat levels.
The box comes with two advanced mechs that are loaded with new, more complex weapons systems. My third and final exploratory scenario will include those two mechs and some more complicated terrain. But as for this battle, overall I felt a bit underwhelmed with the ranged combat.
[i][b]SPECIAL NOTE ON THE FLAMER [/b][/i] I expected the flamer would have some interesting heat mechanics to make up for its minuscule damage, but when I went to look up the rules for it (mid game) I couldn't find anything in the introductory rule book. I had to go online to find out that officially, flamers don't do anything special in mech-vs-mech combat. They're just a crappy weapon. Perhaps the crappiest of weapons? Now a lot of people suggest a house rule variant where instead of damage, flamers add heat, and I shall play that way from now on. It was just odd that the base box would include a mech with a flamer, but didn't provide any rules for it, one way or the other.
[size=18][b]SOME MORE PREMATURE THUMBS[/b][/size]
:thumbsup: A nice array of weapons to try. :thumbsup: Tons of potential for interesting tactical situations! :thumbsup: A few advanced mechs and weapons included (untested). :thumbsup: Missiles are awesome! :thumbsup: Heat management is an interesting side task.
:thumbsdown: Some fixed damage weapons felt a little dry to me. :thumbsdown: Difficult to manage a lot of mechs during solo. :thumbsdown: The Flamethrower does not have rules in the Introductory Rule Book.
[size=18][b]EVERYTHING IS AWESOME[/b][/size]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cCKONHUigVk

item.body: Still banging away at Struggle for the Galactic Empire. I failed miserably on my first outing of Scenario #1, and ended up quitting at Turn 8 on my second outing (I had really having trouble concentrating on it that day.) I plan on playing a couple more of the other scenarios and adding the optional rules in, just to see if it really makes a difference.

Today's game restored my faith in this game again. After two easy wins in my prior games, this one (still on easy level) kicked my butt. And we all know that Co-op games need to do so in order to stay challenging.
Random character draw saw me playing the Stockholder (taking a mulligan as first random draw was the Preacher, [b]again(!)[/b] :) ). I was moving along very well, had 4 slaves stacked in Northern Cities, ready to moved to Canada, 2 support tokens, enough money for the third and even still some space on the Lost Slaves Track. And then came an opposition card, forcing me to give back a support token (I had incorrectly read this as a Fundraising Token first *doh*). This crushed my plans as I would not get enough money to buy 2 support tokens again...
Some clever card-line management on my behalf could have prevented this opposition card to become activated. So, mostly stupidity on my behalf for misreading the card's text.
However, this kept the game from moving to the trade pile. :)
:thumbsdown: The solo game feels a bit too static at the moment. Would love to play it with more than one in order to experience some additional dynamics. :thumbsdown: Set up and tear down time almost equals playing time. So either play two games in a row or take some more time thinking out moves. ;) :thumbsup: Even while being a bit static, it offers an optimization challenge of making good moves through quickly crowding spaces.

item.body:
[size=24][b]ORIGIN STORY:[/b][/size]
This was the first game I posted to the list, back in June 2013. I think I just spotted the list off the front page and decided to post it. I had the game for a while, and had done one of those "I AM GOING TO PLAY THIS GAME" things, and pulled it off the shelf and sat down to attempt to play it. Again. Maybe for the third or fourth time of attempting to play it.
I know there's a game here, but for the life of me I get lost in the rulebook (like I tend to do a lot.) I relearned [thing=1608]AMBUSH![/thing] last year and played it, so I'm more familiar with what's going on in Open Fire, so maybe this year I'll pull it off the shelf again and give it a go. I know OTHER people have actually played it, so...
I don't remember a whole lot about the other games on the list, then. Even though I've been a BGG member for over a decade, I only recently started posting more and more on here. And I still tend to NOT subscribe to a whole lot of threads. (Finding yourself subscribed to something like the SGOYT lists and logging on the next morning to 50+ posts just isn't my style. Especially if I'm not involved in the conversation)
I enjoyed being subscribed to the other ones I've posted on, but have taken myself off them because I find myself thinking about wanting to buy the games, rather than play the ones I have. There are enough games out there I WANT without having OTHER ones added to the list.
I'm still a lurker.

I can see me playing this game for years. I just love it; the fact that it's becoming my Arkham Horror surrogate is really the only thing I could hold against it - and even then, I'm not sure they're so different any more. It took me over an hour to set this up, in the wee small hours, this morning. I have both expansions in the base set, and it really now feels like it's losing the "fast AH" deal. As much as I like the extra cards and encounters of [thing=164167][/thing], I just didn't want to be dealing with the extra board, this time.
So, took lawyer, George Barnaby, and handyman, Wilson Richards, up against Shub-Nicorette-patch, whilst borrowing a few details from the big box expansion (such as the prelude card - although I'm already not sure if that isn't just more needless fluff; I've played a lot of this game in the past year, and I still don't see that it's getting stale and in need of shaking up like that).
This was a weird game because, despite what felt like lousy dice rolls when it really mattered, I just dominated the board. At one point there wasn't a single gate open to trouble our boys. I know the lawyer has influence, but that seemed like a very unlikely deal. I drew a few of the softer mythos cards, and was able to tool up and get to work on the three mysteries: Blasphemy of the Black Goat, Nature of the All-Mother and Spawn of the Black Goat. Two of these simply require the death of an epic monster. Given George's insanely high influence (and thus the ease with which he can buy from the item reserve), both men went full-Rambo, and rolled up to each lair. For the record, whilst I never fuss with spells that often, the combination of Hyperborean Crystal and Arcane Tome feels close to godly.
For me, the game scales really well, and I've always felt like I had a slim chance of winning - but I've never felt so monstrously over-powered before. It was nice to be along for an easy ride... and I still love the stories this builds. Does Arkham Horror deal with narrative any better? I think so, if only because there feels like more consistency in its smaller world. That said, EH remains one of my very favourite games.
I should do a top ten some time, right?

item.body:
Played the solo/cooperative variant of this game that comes in the rule book.
All three tribes survived to the end of the game leading to a victory, although it was close. Had it been a competitive game I'm sure one of the tribes would have died out.
The Tunit went down to 1 worker on 3 occasions. Luckily that worker was the alpha so guaranteed another worker the next round with some of the cards that were in play. The Norse had some very good dice rolls and ended up with 9 valuable hunting cards in their tableau and every single worker either on permanent placements or in their hunting allocation. The Thule ended up gathering resources nearly every turn but had some bad dice rolls so tended to lose as many workers as they gained.
All three tribes stayed with Polytheism as there was no incentive to switch. All the cards ended up on the cold side and there was only 1 unrevealed card at the end of the game. With victory points not meaning anything, a lot of the cards that would normally have been taken into the hand ended up staying in play. The tokens ran out half way through the game and so I ended up having to use a score tracker to represent [-]energy[/-] iron token levels per player.
Had it of been competitive, the scores would have been: Norse = 29, Thule = 11, Tunit = 10.
:thumbsup: - For such a small game it has a lot of variety and options. :thumbsdown: - It can be difficult to see all the benefits you have with all the cards in your tableau plus any opposition daughters you are married to. :thumbsdown: - The cooperative game lacks some of the fun that the competitive version has.

item.body:
Me and [thing=22][/thing] again,
reached the third encounter, I am sure I still play a few things wrong but at least I am playing.
One thing that I must find a way to do better is the set up part of this game. I stored everything in little plastic bags but even then it takes sooo long until you can start playing. You almost have to play 2 games or you feel like it's not worth the time.
[ImageID=2398559]
Somehow I don't like the idea of the victory requirements. Maybe it's great for a multiplayer game but for a solitaire play I prefer to go out and fulfil a quest. And that's what I did. I took the Book of Quests and decided to play the first one, Dragon Slayer, with the Black Knight.
[ImageID=2398558]
Yes I have the whole Book of Quests printed, at work of course! :p
So my quest was to find the Hoard or Lair first. Then rescue the girl, kill the dragon, get rich and famous and take the girl home for.....
Anyway I was moving around the map in search for that damn Lair or Hoard but I couldn't find it. My first fight was against a big spider which I took down easily. I already started to think "Am I playing this correct?" Maybe I read too much about the fighting system and that it is so difficult and hard to get into BUT I think I played it correct. Correct me if I did not!
[ImageID=2398560] [ImageID=2398561]
Half way through the month and map I still couldn't find that damn dragon. I had to fight only a few monsters and I am not sure if that is usual? I am always wondering if I play that part correct. I mean 14 days and only a handful of fights? Monster roll and chits don't fit so no monster gets summoned, right?
I was checking rules back and forth so many times that I didn't realise I was about to enter a map tile I already was, but this time from another direction! And this time monster roll and chits fitted. More than I liked it.
[ImageID=2398562] [ImageID=2398564]
I fought the two giants, even managed to take one down, but the second one crushed me in round 2. Dead. No clue where the Hoard or Lair was. :D Guess my helmet was too dirty and I missed some paths or ways which I should have taken. If only that kidnapped girl screamed loud enough for me to hear or gave some smoke signals for me to see. Nothing.
Anyway,
:thumbsup: with the Book of Quests, this game is a lot of fun solitaire.
:thumbsdown: just writing down my victory requirements is good for learning the game but in the end not my cup of coffee.
:thumbsdown: Set up time compared to play time... it takes so long to set up that you almost have to play at least 2 games or it's not worth the time!
:thumbsup: With some imagination you can create endless adventures, high replayability! And this is what makes this game so good I think.
I start reading the magic part now. Reading rules here is a real study but it's worth it! Can't wait to play the whole game.
item.comment:
[q="Andreas Kaiser"]My first fight was against a big spider which I took down easily. I already started to think "Am I playing this correct?" Maybe I read too much about the fighting system and that it is so difficult and hard to get into BUT I think I played it correct. Correct me if I did not![/q] This sounds correct; the Black Knight shouldn't have much trouble defeating a Heavy Spider.
Most battles in Magic Realm aren't difficult to resolve, once you've gotten the hang of it... but the combat system is different enough from that of other games that beginners sometimes have difficulty understanding how it's supposed to work. And occasionally you'll have a battle that really is complicated.
[q="Andreas Kaiser"]Half way through the month and map I still couldn't find that damn dragon.[/q] That's because you're playing solitaire with a single character. If there were, say, four players in the game, each with their own character/Quest, you would see where the Hoard and Lair were very quickly.
Once you feel more confident in your understanding of the rules, try a solitaire game where you have two or three characters competing against each other. It will be a much better game (although much harder to play and much longer).
[q="Andreas Kaiser"]I had to fight only a few monsters and I am not sure if that is usual? I am always wondering if I play that part correct. I mean 14 days and only a handful of fights? Monster roll and chits don't fit so no monster gets summoned, right?[/q] Correct. Again, this is a problem inherent in using just a single character: not many monsters will show up. This is why the official solitaire rules specify the use of two Monster Rolls (10.E.1.7), although that's not a perfect solution.

item.body:
I picked this game up August 2014, between then and xmas/January I have had multiple attempts to read and follow the 'walkthrough' - not sure why, but I never managed to get through it all.
I think the main problem was not seeing the big picture of why we did certain things... why raid? why build up military? is having a high ferocity good or bad? ... but why, what difference do they make, where is this heading and why?
Anyways - I decided through January I would force myself to understand and just dive in.
Boy do I wish I had done this earlier. The game has so many moving areas of the game, the map, raids, AI tokens and then tracking MP, AP, military points etc - along with the different levels of families and passage of time. Everything subtly links everything together - the 'clicking' point of this game is to me understanding how it all links together.
Back to my first point - the walkthrough is a great idea, but to me it does not portray the 'glue' between everything.
So anyways I finally completed my first full game (scenario 2) with a minor loss just last night. I wanted to write this post, not to describe my game or tactics - but more for a flag to anyone else in my boat to persevere and see this game through.
Its a deep game, lots of rules! but very thematic and in the end I begin to 'feel' for the families. Shadows of Malice is on my table today, but I will be going back to this after !
:thumbsdown: Found it difficult to get started, lots going on. :thumbsup: :thumbsdown: Rule book is actually very good - it just doesnt explain to well how everything interacts and why. :thumbsup: Great challenge once everything is in place, not an easy game to win, but that keeps you coming back. :thumbsup: Fantastic board, very detailed and adds more to the theme. :thumbsup: Once you get going, has that just one more card feel to it.

item.body:
Hello!
Yep, I played another session, actually starting in the evening and taking it past midnight (with a few breaks in between, of course). The AI got really lucky with getting high scoring developments and worlds. I think I could have won if the AI had made a different choice for the final round (we both selected produce, but if either of us had had ship, I might have gotten a lead of 1 or 2 points) - but reality is, it beat me 47 to 42.
I also did a [thread=1312415]small flavoured session report[/thread], so please feel free to have a closer look at the details.
[b]Likes:[/b] + Lots of randomness - random tiles drawn from a bag, rolling dice to determine what you can do + Beautiful tiles - I am a sucker for illustrations, I admit + Lots of interesting decisions - use a tile as development or world, which die to return to the cup, which to leave in the citizenry, ... + Addictive - finishing a session, you really want to play again + [thread=1298979]Simple and good solo variant[/thread] - I am quite happy with it as it does not change many rules + The player screens include all rules - yep, using easy to learn symbols. Even setup is included, so once you have read it once, you only need the rules book for rare questions.
[b]Dislikes:[/b] - Plastic cups - they provide cups for rolling the dice, but since they are hard plastic, they are too noisy - Thematic mix - some worlds are planets/places while others are more like situations; this makes flavouring it somewhat difficult - Weird cash markers - okay, they are wood and that is nice and all, but I can't remember how often I toppled mine when reaching over to the AI's area (^_^;; And besides, what do they represent? - A few of the tiles are initially hard to grasp - space is limited, yes, but adding a bigger explanation in the rules could have helped with things that are not immediately obvious (but make sense once you know) - Not enough cuteness
Yours, Deathworks

I backed Harbour and just got it yesterday. Trying out the official 1-player mode. You have a dummy player that follows some simple rules.

item.body:
OK, settle down. I have the rule book, not the game, on my table, as I volunteered to help proofread the near-final materials.
For those who aren't aware of this game, [thing=68820][/thing] is a game on the Battle of the Bulge, and it is three games in one: two player, Allied solo and German solo. Probably the most important second thing you need to know is that is designed by John Butterfield, he of D-Day at Omaha Beach/Tarawa, RAF and Ambush fame. John Foley is developing it, and you may recognize his name from his development work on [thing=21050][/thing] series and [thing=39217][/thing]. Compass Games is producing it, meaning you can expect top-notch graphics and physical components.
I have to say after reading the two-player and German solo rules and charts that I am more excited than ever to see this on my table. It could be a breakthrough in solitaire game design. I have never seen someone attempt something so ambitious in terms of defining AI behavior. It's a card driven system, but uses the traditional hexes found in most wargames. Each of the three games uses its own map, and has its own set of special rules. And the amount of work that has already gone into the game was evident from the very few edits I made to the rules and charts.
But it is hard for me to make a judgment based only on reading the rulebooks. The proof will come with the play, and be warned, this is not a light game. It is several steps ahead of the D-Day game in terms of complexity. I put it up there near Fields of Fire in terms of the amount of rules you will need to absorb, especially as each version of the game will require a new set of rules to remember. The player aid cards do a good job of summarizing the key steps, and I imagine the first few times I play my nose will be stuck firmly in those cards. I've suggested to the developer that they put together some good tutorial videos, as this may help to absorption process.
And yes, this game has all the things that go into a Bulge game, such as fuel dumps, blown bridges, traffic congestion, Monty "tidying" his lines, Allied air power, the Von der Heydte unit, etc.
Anyways, you might want to put this game on your radar, and consider pre-ordering when it is $105, versus the $145 list price. Yes, this is high, but keep in mind you will be getting three games in the package. The Compass site lists a May 2015 release date.

[size=24][b]ORIGIN STORY![/b][/size]
I was bitten by a radioactive grognard...
Well, not really.
So, this isn't actually the first game I posted here, but that honor goes to [thing=41612][/thing], and seeing how Lhowser owns my copy, I won't get a chance to play it again.
So I'll post the game that I was going to initially post, but decided against.
I found the list on one of those first few days of the month bonanzas where it's on the "hot" list on the geek's frontpage. I had just finished a game of Field of Fire, but decided against posting it because I had just posted it in another geek list, and I thought that'd be tacky. I was new to using the geek then. This was back in June 2013. As I looked over the first few games I posted, I realize I've sold most of them, which is sort of funny. My gaming tastes have changed quite a bit, but a few of the games I've held onto have stayed as really solid solo games: Gears of War, Hornet Leader, Fields of Fire.
I think I'm going to try to play a lot of Fields of Fire this month. It has near infinity replayability due to different maps each game (though the layout is the same, the terrain will change), and the vast differences in action results or enemy placement. The rulebook is a bit... crappy... but the game is really complex, and doesn't build on any wargames out there (except maybe for some similarities to Up Front, or Frontline: D-Day), so it's hard to take skills from other games to apply them. But there's a lot of game in here. I've played the first mission like 6 times and it never felt the same. It's time to complete a WW2 campaign and then maybe switch over to Vietnam, as I haven't even TOUCHED that one.

I've only ever used the second edition rulebook and it's much better. I still recommend playing it with the rules handy in PDF format so you can search for answers you're looking for quickly.
The game tells the best story of any wargame I've seen. It's basically a war movie in cardboard form. Small squads doing heroic things, or being surprised by blundering into a field covered in land mines (lost my first game on the second turn because I moved a whole squad into an area I hadn't scouted and they did just that).
I also love how the game is more about issuing orders than following specific tactics. Sometimes you troops won't get your orders right, or you can't get a runner to them in time, and the phone lines have been cut. Or your leaders are too busy ducking to try to get anything accomplished.
If any board game played like Combat Mission, it sure is this one, though with fewer vehicles (which the rules for those are a bit wonky).
I've got Vol. 1 and 2 on preorder. I hope to see them before the end of the year. *fingers crossed*

[q="Sapper_SB"]I've got Vol. 1 and 2 on preorder. I hope to see them before the end of the year. *fingers crossed*[/q]
I've been waiting for volume 2 forever! I p500ed it right after I saw it announced. Really excited about the changes in the system, and I think it'll be good.
Its supposedly coming with V3.0 of the rules too, which are supposed to clear up some of the issues still lingering (though I often just make a judgement call, or randomly determine things and go with it).

This is one of the most successful games I've played - solitaire or otherwise - in terms of putting you into the mindset of what the game is simulating. In this case, it's company command. I like the fact that you need to concern yourself with things such as evacuating the wounded.
I played this with the v.1 rules out of the box, and though I had to flip through the rulebook a lot and make some judgment calls, I had no major problems. I think gamers have different levels of tolerance for resolving ambiguous situations.
My advice to new FoF gamers has been to bull your way through a mission, recognizing you will make mistakes, you will struggle with the rules and your men will suffer, and then re-start the mission for real. This is not a game you can completely absorb just by reading the rule book over and over. You have to wade in and get dirty.
I think [thing=68820][/thing] will be similar in this respect.

I have D-Day at Tarawa to get to yet and have CoH solitaire and Enemy Action: Ardennes coming, yet I have to try this one out too. I'm actually OK that this is still a far way off. I'm not sure if I'll be enamored with the story it tells or find it too fiddly, but I'm very curious to find out.
Whether I start with the first European theater one or the new PTO one remains to be seen.

item.objectname: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.body:
My purchase of this game is a direct result of reading all of the plays on SGOYT - gee thanks guys/gals :p
Picked this up from MM about two weeks ago and got it to the table last night. It was after midnight so it was technically 2/1. I played through the first Alien movie. Here is a brief report of the play.
Like most deck builders, your deck starts off slow due to the quality of your starting cards, but having your role card in there is a nice bump as that starts off as your most powerful card. Even though I had read through the rulebook once last week, it took me a bit to get the flow of game play down. Once I did though, which didn't take long, the game flows very quickly. There were situations I encountered early on (like revealing an egg that doesn't move) that I remembered reading in the rules and was 99% sure how to handle it, but was neurotic about finding the actual treatment in the rules to ensure that I was playing correctly.
It was taking a while for me to complete the first objective, which had me slightly worried, but then both parts of the S.O.S. message came up right next to each other when I scanned and the first objective was complete. I got through the early game with only one enemy making it to the combat zone although I did take some strikes from the rough landing event.
As my deck grew, those starting cards with their 1 Attack/Scan and 1 Recruit became annoying so Ripley's Quarantine cards came in handy there to weed out some of them. It took a while for the ventilation lock card to show up, but once I did, I was able to clear the ventilation shaft location and seal it off. On to the third objective.
I did have an alien make it to the combat zone and hang out there for a while (I forget the name, but it's the one that ends up costing 7 Attack if it makes it to the combat zone). I could never seem to get 7 Attack in my hand. I had six Attack a few times, but not seven. Luckily, I drew like two misses and another smaller wound. I finally killed that and was also able to wipe out two Facehuggers that resulted from eggs being revealed in the complex when an Event was revealed.
The airlock controls card showed up fairly early in the third hive deck cards so I had that ready and waiting. The Perfect Organism final enemy was the next to last card in the Hive deck. When it showed up, I was in pretty decent shape, having only three wounds. I had drawn the third Hazard earlier, which is the Self-Destruct. It was in the Airlock and I had the eight Recruit points in my hand to deactivate it, but Ripley's character card was in the HQ and I knew that I would probably need that to generate the 10 Attack and take out the final enemy. With only three wounds, I let the self-destruct go into the Combat Zone and took the three wounds. It was risky, but I hoped not to draw a double strike or anything that would hurt me too much. I ended up drawing five more points in wounds, which put me at eight total, but as the Gunner has 11 Health, I was okay. About two rounds after recruiting Ripley, I had to reshuffle and the Perfect Organism was closing in on me quickly. I got lucky and drew Ripley either one hand or two after shuffling it in and had the three Recruit points necessary to lure the Alien into the Airlock. Ripley's five Attack along with the three, two and one I had for a total of 11 were enough to take out the final enemy and win the game!
I really wanted to play more, but it was very late and I knew if I started another game, I'd be watching the sunrise.
:thumbsup: Theme: this game is dripping with it like a salivating xenomorph :D I'm a huge fan of the movies (I consider Aliens one of the best sci-fi movies ever made) and love the artwork, the flavor text, the names of the cards, and seeing all of the characters from the movies. Upper Deck did a great job of capturing the atmosphere of the movies.
:thumbsup: Good deck building mechanism. The class and crew abilities give you opportunities for combos that escalate as your deck grows. It's also important to have cards that allow you to "kill" some of your characters to get those weaker cards out of your deck as the game progresses.
:thumbsup: It's fun. I had a blast playing through the movie and really felt like I was playing out the story.
Both of my thumbs down are minor things. Overall, I loved this game and am so glad that you all compelled me to buy it ;)
:thumbsdown: Set up/clean up time. Getting all of those cards sorted and reorganized is kind of a pain, but that will get quicker now that I'm more familiar with all of the different cards/decks. This card list:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/107161/1-page-card-list
put together by [user=gwarjuice][/user] is invaluable here. This game would be brutal to figure out the sorting without that file. If you buy this game, make sure to print it out and keep it handy. It makes life much easier.
:thumbsdown: I agree with much of what I have read that the scenario isn't all that difficult, but this is easily fixed by using variants others have posted. This isn't a big deal as I still felt a lot of tension while playing.
Overall, if you're a fan of the Alien saga and deck builders, you should take a look at this one. It's great fun!

[ImageID=1971679medium]
And here is the AFTER...oooohhh, pretty:

Thanks again, Chris. [b]They're awesome![/b]
[hr] [size=12][b][COLOR=#9900FF]Space Amoeba Solo Scenario[/COLOR][/b][/size]
Difficulty = Hard [b]Result = Defeat, 11 Econs[/b]
For whatever reason, I don't see anyone really talk about the Space Amoeba scenario for this game, so I thought I'd give it a try. It's quite fun!
I played on Hard difficulty, not because I thought I could actually win, but to help speed up the game overall. There are three unknown Space Amoebas out in deep space. You must discover them, then research them, and finally attack them before they consume everything...literally. They will swallow anything in its path.
Each hex containing an Amoeba will spread one further hex if it is not contained (with a Mine) or destroyed in combat. Each Amoeba has its own set of properties. In this play, Amoeba 1 had a strength of A7-2-2 and would allow a bonus attack to my ships if I used three different types. Amoeba 2 was a straight up D6-2-2. And Amoeba 3 was also an A7-2-2 but it had a weakness against Raiders.
[ImageID=2398777medium]
I felt my chances were pretty good for a while. But once those Amoebas begin to multiply, it doesn't take long before they reach the outer Colonies and you begin to lose CP. Less CP means less ships.
My main downfall was not focusing on the weaknesses of the Amoeba. I never got around to developing Cloaking tech, so I had no Raiders. And I really only built Cruisers for attacking.
I held off the Amoebas and had quite a few back-and-forth pushes of success. But, eventually, they were knocking on the door of my homeworld, Chulak. I made one last stand actually pushing Amoeba 2 back, but I only had two Colonies remaining. It was the end of the 11th Econ, and I would lose both of them in the next round, so I called it a defeat there.
[ImageID=2398778medium]
I could have fought them off for two more Econs, I believe, but without any CP to buy more ships, it would have been fruitless.
Overall...and to no surprise to me...another fun solo session of this awesome game. It's been almost a year since I last got it to the table. Hopefully, it won't be as long for the next one.

You build Science Vessels (use the SW counters) and then send them into the Amoebas to study them. Via die rolls, you have to gain 10 research points before you are allowed to attack them.

But they multiply exponentially if you don't contain them, so one Econ, they are hanging around the outer reaches of the map, and two Econs later, they're encroaching into the center of your home space.

[ImageID=2396319 medium] Ameoba 3 was the weakest one with 1 hitpoint, so Sheldon and the Base there managed to hold that off for several turns. Ameoba 2 was the one you have to blow up a ship inside to kill. Dangerous one. Ameoba 1 was stronger than Ameoba 3, with 2 hull points and an extra attack if it rolled 2 under the hit number. I managed to get Ameoba 1 to spread into the hexes occupied by Ameoba 2, so the 2 couldn't threaten Altair.

The rule that you can chose which Ameoba spreads if two or more different Ameobas can spread there was what saved me. I used that rule to spread 1 as a barrier against 2. Had that spreading been randomized, I might have fallen to Ameoba 2.

item.body:
[size=24][b]ORIGIN STORY[/b][/size]
A few coincidences going around with this one.
I got into solitaire gaming...... well, I got into boardgaming because in Jan 2012, RAB over at RockPaperShotgun said Mage Knight was his top game of 2011 and it can be played solo and, while it might be sad to play a boardgame by yourself, MK is just as fun as with 2,3, or 4. As this obliterated all my excuses of "But you need friends to play boardgames with", I knew that I must find this game but it is OOP, so I decide to find other games to tide me over.
I dabbled a tiny bit in solitaire gaming over the next year while going through the highs and lows of the honeymoon phase of the hobby, finding and losing gaming groups and driving my new wife to hate boardgaming because of my overwhelming enthusiasm and blindly pushing her to always try new games. In Feb 2013, the ball drops and I realize I have noone to play with.
At the time, (first coincidence!) [thing=101785][/thing] caught my attention. [url=http://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic1538781_lg.jpg]It looked gorgeous[/url], it was solitaire, and it had some good reviews so I bought it. What it taught me was that, while the game was not for me, I enjoyed the experience of taking on a challenge by myself and realized I might be able to do something about this.
Mage Knight hadn't worked out for me so I ignored that but I started seeking greatest solitaire games of all time. One that came up was [thing=29603][/thing]. People were saying the AI was like playing a real opponent. As I loved the D-Day theme, it was a no-brainer...... but it was OOP. DG did have a P500 so I put myself on it then and there. The game arrived in May or June, I went through the arduous process of punching out those counters, bought plexiglass, read everything in the rules, printed out the flipbooks, and attempted Easy Fox twice over the next couple months.
My first GL item, I believe (July 2013, pretty early!) [listitem=2711318][/listitem]
I decided to put the game aside while I master two DVG games, TAL and FC:Napoleon. Both are awesome. While I have gotten a few more plays out of both, it's nowhere near the amount I wanted. However, I did master the rules to both of them to the point I find both very straightforward, whereas at the time I had a lot to learn.
DDaOB has sat on my shelf all this time. I know it's great but I wasn't in the [i]mood[/i] for it. Recently, I've been getting more into a WW2 mood. Two months ago, klkitchens generously offered to clip the counters for my copy of this and the Reverend's copy of [thing=67600][/thing]. On Friday night, I finished the awesome book Killing Patton by Bill O'Reilly/Martin Dugard and wanted to play it so badly. Unfortunately, my counters are in the mail being shipped back to me. Fortunately, I need to reread the rulebook anyhow so I've started doing that and am loving it. Reading the historical booklet that comes with the game while having the game map laid out in front of you and seeing the actual history play out in my mind's eye that I will soon be able to interact with has all my systems twitching with anticipation!
So the second coincidence is I started reading the rulebook on Saturday for this game which also happens to be the first game I ever posted on a SGOYT geeklist!
Except...... the reason I thought that this was my first item was because I kept googling my name with this geeklist and seeing what came up. Sept 2013 did, Aug 2013 I apparently just added some comments, July 2013 yes, June 2013 - no. I figured that was it but then thought, why not check May? So I did.
[listitem=2632442][/listitem]
Yup, I posted [thing=42673][/thing] as my first ever item. This community came together at exactly the right time for me, as I was searching for solitaire games starting in Feb/March of that year and prior to the geeklist, the wargamers really had the most comprehensive info on it (general Recommendations forum helped somewhat too. I didn't know about the 1P Guild nor did I even know that guilds existed on here). Had the list started earlier, when I still had hopes of finding real boardgaming enthusiast friends, I likely would have ignored them popping up on the front page. I don't consider myself a regular in the community until about September/October of 2013 when I started posting regularly. I didn't join the 1P guild until early 2014 because the GL alone was great!
Another big shout-out to the ever popular [user=reverendunclebastard][/user] for being an amazingly generous and giving man with his games, time, and support.

item.body:
With Spring Training now less than 3 weeks away (February 18th, pitchers and catchers report), I thought I'd get a head start and run a few games from my home brew fictional league.
:thumbsup: HMB does give you a great feel of a baseball game without the over-reliance on statistics that other baseball board games can have. Umpires can and will blow calls. Your AAA second baseman filling in can tear the cover off the ball for a few games then crash back to reality (remember Bo Hart of the Cardinals in 2003?). Do you bring out your all-star closer in a tight game against your rival even though he was lit up his last few outings?
:thumbsup: Easy to understand mechanics with most results being of the "If the pitcher is A then do this, else if the batter is B then do that otherwise do this 3rd thing." variety.
:thumbsdown: Some people have complained about the player cards being a bit on the small size and they are about 2/3 the size of a typical playing card, but the words and symbols on the cards are still rather easy to read.
If your a fan of sports games or even thinking about finding one you really should check out some of Keith Avallone other sports games on soccer, American (& Canadian) football, hockey, lacrosse, stock car racing and even roller derby and Pro wrestling.

The Sentinels of the Multiverse Monthly Challenge train keeps on rolling!
Here were this week's rules:
Week 3: Cut off on head, two more shall rise and take its place!
Villain: Omnitron X
Environment: Insula Primalis
Heroes:
Everyone MUST use Tachyon. The random hero is: 1d10 = 9
VISONARY
rounds+ wounds+ # of devices with HP that come into play for ANY reason from Omnitron's deck or discard pile. So this would count any device he pulls from his discard pile, played by him, or played for any other way. It only counts devices with HP so it ignores any of his component cards.
....and my results...
I made Tempest my hero of choice this week, and it worked out very well.
[b]Time:[/b] 12 turns
[b]Wounds on Tempest:[/b] 10
[b]Wounds on Tachyon:[/b] 13
[b]Wounds on Visionary:[/b] 14
[b]Devices put into play:[/b] 10
[b]Total:[/b] 59
One of my best scores yet, and with some of the combinations available with this team, it's not hard to see why! It also helped that Visionary got a [i]Twist the Ether[/i] out on Omnitron almost right away. [i]Cleansing Downpour[/i] was a huge help (as always), but the MVP had to be [i]Reclaim From the Deep[/i] which allowed Tachyon to pull off four [i]Lightspeed Barrages[/i] in a row, and kept arming Visionary with [i]Precognition[/i]! This is certainly a team I would use again!

item.body:
As this game does not come with solo rules (though I did not check for unofficial ones) and as I had to get down the rules, I played a three sided game over two of the three eras.
What an unusual take on Civ-building. The topological aspect of which tile to patch where adds a neat twist. Now you not only bid for a tile whose spaces will benefit you but also need to consider if you can patch it into your landscape. Water spaces, which cannot be patched over, and a grid limitation (5x5, 6x6, 7x7 in the three eras) had me moan more than once.
As it was a learning game, I did not concentrate on the victory points one can get per vote on achievement tiles after each era. Usually each player has three of those and you would surely have your strategy influenced by this.
I found my action space lacking a bit. The number of actions you can perform each turn is determined by your politics rating. Two players stayed at 2-3 politics for the majority of the game. This really limits what you could do each turn, as there are not so many 1 point actions to chose.
Hope I can play it multiplayer some time as I really want to explore the game further.
--------------------------------------------
Update 7/2/15:
Played it again three sided today and made it through all three eras (only took me the whole afternoon, interrupted for 1.5 hours when family turned up).
Interesting aspects: - even when I had more politics points for more actions, I sometimes chose to save them all for votes as those could turn 1:1 into victory points. This was the case when I did not have better rates for victory points. - the patching is awesome and painful. Especially in era 2 did I feel pain in the patching, era 3 did not feel as harsh - the player with highest military did win in th end. But not due to wars or too extensive skirmishes. He had Tesla as a hero, granting 5 Victory points for every building built through an action. He tried to focus on this, resulting app 20 of the final 119 VP. - all players did follow different strategies. One managed to hoard money for a whopping 24 VP at games end for a final 110 VP - the third player was unable to build a good engine/combo and only managed 91 VP in the end.
I REALLY want to play it multiplayer now!! :D
item.comment:
I'd heard of this one before but didn't know anything about it. It looks pretty neat, and that system of overlapping (patching) the tiles is really cool.
Too bad there aren't any solo rules, but even so this seems worth a look.

[q="Woelf"]I'd heard of this one before but didn't know anything about it. It looks pretty neat, and that system of overlapping (patching) the tiles is really cool.
Too bad there aren't any solo rules, but even so this seems worth a look.[/q]
It is a different take on Civ-building - the auction and patching drive the game a little more than the political actions you have each round, imo. Thus it feels quite different to my favorite CIV-Game [thing=25613][/thing] or others, where you drive your Civilization ahead through your actions. I needed a slightly different way of thinking and not let myself get sidetracked through nice civ-stuff. You want to earn victory points. And if your best chance is in earning them trough an and of era scoring where currently only you get to score, then you want to hoard votes instead of taking any political actions.
Though usually you would get a better ratio of Political Points to Victory Points than plain 1:1. My players yesterday had the following options through actions and/or heroes. - an aggression against a 2nd player: 3 PP : 4 VP (+2 for you and -2 for him) or 3:8 (if your military is far superior, which it was) - building stuff: 1 PP + 2 Resources (potentially another PP for a conversion) : 5 VP --> this was a great combo of a 1st era hero and a 3rd era hero. Nothing you could really plan for. - reclaiming land: 2 PP + 1 Resource : 3 VP (through a world wonder)
Will most likely not solo it again multihanded as it just takes too long (for me). But am really curious to play it against two or three opponents - hopefully in April this year.

item.body:
Hello!
Seeing all those plays of this game here in the lists reminded me that it has been far too long since I last played this. So, I finally put it on the table.
Of course, I went for bacterial - and got a really lousy start. A1 was the E molecule as was one of the molecules on the B-circle. Okay, so I figured starting with E was a good idea. Next thing I know, the outer E molecule got replaced (^_^;;
Adding to this, early on (first or second turn, I think), an H molecule got placed on the C-circle. I still got lucky with the containment rolls, so I had the time to get those proteins - only to have the H molecule replaced on the turn where I could have finished the antidote. Not sure what to do (it had been a while), I finished the H antidote (big mistake).
During the mid game, I was able to get some good funds by creating effective antidotes. And after the rather annoying start, the mutation rate went down. I was early epidemic when only one molecule was left. Marvin was available for purchase, but I didn't want to sacrifice for that.
Thus, I continued and 3 or 4 turns later, I was still in early epidemic, I was able to destroy the last molecule.
[b]Likes[/b] + Fast and good fun + Lots of story in it + Lots of randomness in it
[b]Dislikes[/b] - The puzzle game board is a bit loose/tends to fall apart during play - Some of the artwork is not that good (although the picture on the box is the one I like the least)
Yours, Deathworks

Not the origin story, but a playing again of my origin story game.
So I picked up the first BattleQuest dungeon, which uses one character, Baroness Ancella's Crypt. I used Karin & Jaeger, and went to battle with a Healing Stone (trinket, ante to gain 1 life, cycles with discards), Steel Armor (40hp instead of 20), and Limit Breaker (allows you to use your finisher attack) with Red Moon Rage.
I smashed through the first two rooms (zombies and imps) but missed clearing the third room (dark wisps) in time so I had to take the harder route through the game.
A room with Dual Werewolves nearly ran out my timer (I limit each level to 15 beats or else I get way too discouraged and am likely in over my head, so I restart it if I go past 15 beats) and ran me down to 12 life out of 40. Ouch.
The putrid room, with two zombies and an ooze, is much harder to deal with than the easy path's ooze room, since the zombies keep moving and taking hits meant for the ooze.
I died with 5 damage on the ooze.
I'm getting the hang of playing Karin & Jaeger, but it still takes me a couple of turns to position Jaegar such that Karin can start thumping the heck out of opponents. The werewolves are always hard, however, especially when there are two of them. They move around far too much. But once you whittle them down to one werewolf, you need to keep it stunned before it regenerates and gets +6 power against you.
The ooze is just annoying with zombies. Always try to take the easier path, folks. Unless you're into the challenge, of course, that dual werewolves and oozes + zombies make. I tend to find getting down to the Baroness to be more important, because she is something of a challenge.
I used customized standees so it was all more thematic. I think I'll need to add numbers to the standees and create a battle mat so that damage can be more easily tracked for multiple monsters.
[imageid=2399157 medium]
Well, damage and power-ups in the case of the werewolves.
I still really like this game as much as I did before, but the dungeons have a wearing effect on me. I like quick, short battles when I play this game, thus playing against the python AI feels more pleasing than the gradual attrition of the dungeon, even though each level resets the beats etc (though not your life).
I need to clear the ottoman and get Viticulture on it, and get Agricola onto the dining table... and once the upper bedroom has had its contents junked away, I'll set up another table up there (along with my game shelves) and have a third game out for solo play, probably Fields of Arle, my last big game purchase for... quite some time.
[b]Edit:[/b] Just realized that if I arrange things right, I can have a table in the other spare bedroom for games. Need to get some big plastic tubs so stuff can be stored in the closet instead of on the floor.

[size=12][b][COLOR=#009900]Score = 17 (0), Good[/COLOR][/b][/size]
Nice! This is only my third play of this fine, Euro specimen of harvesting and selling veggies, and I scored my first "Good" level at 17 (0).
I planted Pumpkins to start as two Regulars were in the offering needing them. However, Turnips (although, they look like Radishes to me) were the bread winners this session with three Regulars and a couple of Casual customers needing them over the long haul.
Speaking of which, Casual customers were scarce this time around. I didn't see any until after the reshuffle, and even then only four made an appearance. I delivered to three of them, letting the first of the bunch pass me by as I didn't have what he wanted.
[ImageID=2399302medium]
I feel my "big" move this game was going from 10 to 13 on the score track after a particularly productive turn. On the final round of play, I saw I was one dollar short of making 17, but with a lone Pumpkin sitting in the cart, I sold it back to my Market for $1 giving me just enough to get the magic mark for my first time.
Maybe Pumpkins were the right way to go after all. ;)

Arle is a big giant sandbox with less pressure and way more open choices; it is fun to try different strategies and see what the outcome is.
I didn't have any Euros in my collection, so I started with Loyang. However, that quickly led me to pick up Arle, and now I am eyeing Glass Road. Be careful, Loyang is a gateway Euro (or at least a gateway to Uwe)![/q]
Yeah, I know once I pick one up, it's just a matter of time before another one of his games will make it's way into my collection. At this point it's just a matter of which one I go for first:D

item.body:
[size=24][b]ORIGIN STORY[/b][/size]
This was my first posting on [listitem=2727261]SGOYT[/listitem] way back in July 2013. I actually got this for my birthday (July 2). It wasn't my first solo play as I'd been getting in to more solo play over the past few months. I actually joined BGG on the last day of 2012 looking to download Todd Sanders' [thing=86003][/thing] and learn more about my new [thing=124708][/thing]. I forget how I discovered SGOYT but I joined the 1 Player Guild shortly after and the rest, as they say, is history! :meeple:
Anyhow, as part of Stig's [listitem=3710910]challenge[/listitem] I played this today and scored a 57. I didn't get all 7 cities built until after round 6 and got the architecture development and a bunch of other cheap ones and just the pyramid and the wall monuments.
It's still a fun short filler. I enjoy the yahtzee mechanic because I get to have some level of control over the outcomes. I'm not as much of a filler player anymore though since I have got into games like Loyang. When I bought Loyang I bought [thing=150926][/thing]. It cost more than Loyang which was used though in excellent condition and has a box that is twice the size of RTtA and also was about twice the cost, for not much more in the box (though I bought RTtA on Amazon the cost differential is still huge) and the gameplay does have some changes, but it really feels like just about the same game to me. I know it's not quite, but there's not enough different in it to get me excited. Especially if it's just a big, expensive filler.
item.comment: Thanks for the comments re: The Iron Age. I've been thinking about picking it up, but keep holding off because it doesn't look that different than Bronze Age. Glad to know my fears are confirmed, and thanks for saving me some $$.

I should clarify that others do think it's different enough and offers more. It seemed like variations on a theme to me, and while that can be new and cool and fresh it didn't click with me. Though, I should play it some more.

item.body:
I will continue this month with my [b][geeklist=183720]Eldritch Horror Solo Challenge[/geeklist][/b]. I won't be posting here on those sessions. You can subscribe to the geeklist if you want to follow along.
Yesterday I received my copy of [b][thing=163602][/thing][/b]. After some thorough research and the first (video) reviews appearing, I was pulled off the fence to get it.
I played the Tutorial and didn't get very far: At the end of Round Three two Continents were in Panic and I lost the game. It's too early to tell what I really think, especially because I'm still internalizing the rules. They're not difficult, just some wording is a bit odd here and there. I don't mind that the rules are in the app, which is brilliant in its design and presentation.
The solo game is excellent. You have a bit more time, more than I expected, to step through the Timed Phase. Playing some Rounds during the Tutorial also taught me how I can better organize the components. I can get rid of the Reserve cards (except the Squad Leader's). I left the Role Summary cards out anyway.
What I will do next time is group all the components necessary for the Timed Phase and keep them closeby, and leave the Resolution Phase cards seperate. When playing solo, the individual roles really don't matter, it's having everything at hand when you need it.
Other than the app, [b][thing=163602]XCOM[/thing][/b] is a typically tight FFG design with stunning components and artwork. The gameplay strategy has yet to fully show itself, as I become more comfortable with the rules, the cards and abilities, and so on. This will only take a session or two more, I suspect, as I delve more and more into how to approach what the game throws at me. I can see the glimmer of greatness, and will report on further sessions as I play them.

item.body:
[ImageID=2399387 medium] Zombicide is a game I bought, played once or twice then traded away. After watching a few playthroughs and having binged on The Walking a Dead show and comics, I wanted to revisit the Zombie boardgame genre.
I preordered[thing=150376][/thing] as I think it captures the interpersonal conflicts among the Survivors. However, there seems to be a log jam somewhere as copies haven't made their way to my favorite local online store. I owned and played [thing=29368][/thing] and it captured the cheesy quality if the 70s and 80s flicks but it only really shines when you've got a Zombie master vs the survivors. Not a fully satisfying solitaire experience.
I found myself returning to [thing=113924][/thing]. I found a used copy of the original set and soon after got [thing=161866][/thing]. I also acquired [thing=137987][/thing] but that still remains unplayed.
:thumbsup: Fun! If you're looking for a game that let's you vent your frustrations on a horde of undead, Zombicide is your game. There's also a puzzle element as you have a limited set if actions. Use them wisely. :thumbsup: Each base set is self-contained. You get a great gaming experience with just the base set (no real need for expansions). I recommend getting Rue Morgue. (I ve played Season 1 and 3 but haven't played Season 2). Rue Morgue has more survivors (twelve vs Season 1's six)a better rulebook and a few more extra rules (crawlers, helicopter, team cards, triggers, camp and hospital tiles) to give the game some extra chrome. :thumbsup: Excellent miniatures. Good quality plastic and nice sculpts. I've seen some great painters work their magic on these minis. You don't really need to paint the figures if you don't want to. I just don't have the time and talent for painting. :thumbsup: Plenty of missions :thumbsup: Missions are challenging. :thumbsdown: Some missions are horribly imbalanced. But then again Zombie Apocalypses are hardly fair. Plenty of other missions to enjoy though. :thumbsup: Expansions Galore! :thumbsdown: Expansions Galore! Completionists will have to spend a lot to keep up. [ImageID=2399385 medium]
item.comment:
[q]Some missions are horribly imbalanced. But then again Zombie Apocalypses are hardly fair.[/q]

I have S2 Prison Outbreak, plus the map tiles from S1 and some extra zombies, dog companions and special guest boxes of heroes. This game is a real blast. Trying to resist the urge to run out and get Rue Morgue when it arrives soon.

item.objectname: Island Of D 2: The Shadow of Dawn
item.body: Finally got all my cards made and sat down to play this. It was fun. However, I don't know if I'll be getting it out very often. Mechanistically it's quite interesting and that's actually partly why I made it, as an educational experience. I like how he does it all with multi-function cards and you get the sense of exploration. However, the purpose of the game is to get some items and beat the bad guy. Which is fine, but as I look at the boss battle, it's nearly impossible given the game mechanics unless you have played an otherwise perfect game and gotten all the other special items. So, that puts me off. Still, it was worth the time and effort to experience it. It may come out periodically, but not too often I think.
item.comment: For me, [thing=34639][/thing] is the very best of the games using this system. The art has a bit more weight behind it than Adventure of D, and there's a bit more to do than in Island. You can certainly see how things evolve, as you work through them. Excellent travel companions, too.

Plus you can actually have minor wins and an actual score in Dungeon of D. Survive a couple of levels, feel that your resources have run out? Duck out through the mystic portal the next time you find it, and chalk up your score and do better next time.
Island of D 2 is like a little solo filler; Dungeon of D is what has the meat.
