item.body:
[b][i]2of4 D6 Games.[/b][/i]The layout didn't seem too bad, with an advance HQ on the starting row, 4 steps away. So early rounds occupied the helpful Sea tile, advanced the HQ to the half way point, and occupied both a field and forest ready to attack.
By this time the Lord of Cubes had deployed 5 armies.
The next couple of rounds were attacks reducing the Cubes armies by 2, but the (single) HQ was also down to Strength 2 and the sea dice was down to Strength 3, so used the Sea to re-roll the HQ... (several times) only to get 2 - 1 - 1.
I needed the Lord of Cubes to deploy a new army, so the field could feed all the other Dice and buy time for another attack... however the Lord of Cubes instead rolled for an already occupied tile and so removed the last point from the HQ.

[b][i]3of4 D6 Games.[/b][/i] Just the original Quest. The Fighter only lost 2 HP in the first 3 floors. The treasure chest contained an Ancient Staff for the Wizard, which helped him take out the Giant in 2 rounds using a fire ball and level 6 chain lightning. However the Giant did manage to deal 4 damage.
Whilst fighting the Skeletons, the Cleric attempted - and failed - to heal the party. With the Cleric limiting the dice the party only managed to kill 2 skeletons, whilst the skeletons were hitting hard and wiped out the party in 2 rounds.

[b][i]4of4 D6 Games.[/b][/i] Easy Level game, with the minimum recommend 4 Zombies to hunt. An odd game tonight, each round I took the maximum hunting party (2x Zombies), and only lost an infection check once.
Also, by rolling above average number of Heroes and not pushing my luck, managed to quickly reduce the Zombies to 1. However the last Zombie just wouldn't die and kept biting a hunter.
This started a rinse-&-repeat cycle.
Eventually a hunter got lucky and killed the last Zombie. (Final score 27).
Update 4 Feb: An erratic week, minimal gaming time so only playing fillers. Hopefuilly the weekend will change that, anyway;
5 more games - and just for giggles started with [b]10[/b] Zombies. [i][b]Game 1 & 2 - Scores 17 & 16.[/b][/i] Infections were rare. Hunting parties were Hero heavy capturing and killing 6-7 Zombies during each game. [i][b]Games 3 & 4 - Scores 10 & 12.[/b][/i] Infections were common, rolling 1 Hero was considered a good hunt - and the Zombies were starting to bite back. [i][b]Game 5 - Score 11.[/b][/i] Hunters could only catch infections & Zombies were biting HARD. Game only lasted 3 rounds! At this point dice were dropping [i]Zebedee[/i] hints, so took their advice.
:thumbsup: Simple PnP filler. :thumbsdown: As with all dice games, luck-central.

Have really been getting my money's worth out of this one, this weekend. After the walkover of the previous report, I decided to try my hand against new villain, Ithaqua, bringing Daisy Walker and Finn Edwards to the snowball fight.
Note to self: invest in some chuffing Focus tokens!
I must've played my way through every hypothermia condition, this game, whist staggering between bad debts, leg injuries caused by the non-payment of such, wounds getting infected and then poisoning me... and a dose of good old-fashioned paranoia too (which resulted in Daisy violently attacking her allies and driving them away; librarians, it seems, don't play well with others). Saw some horrific stacks of monsters, as every mythos offered a gate burst - and an accursed omen symbol. For the first time, the doom track was chased down to zero... I ran out of Mythos cards and so had a single chance to win, with Finn attacking with everything he had.
I guess frostbite interferes with the smooth rolling of the dice.
A loss then, but one of the most nail-biting games I've yet played. If, like me, you were thinking you didn't need this if you owned Arkham Horror, you might very well want to look more closely. This game is a bit of a masterpiece.
[imageid=2399478medium] Anyone got the number of that dynamite salesman...?

[size=18][b]Origin Story[/b][/size] Circa 2008ish. I was still married with 4 children and living in Alaska at this time. I used to play games with the kids on the weekends, Heroscape was a much played game. The wife was never really into board games. She would play once in a while. She got tired of me and found someone else. I deployed to Iraq for a one year vacation. I come back from Iraq and the kids have "decided" that they want nothing to o with me. Here starts my solitaire odyssey. I have games and no one to play with. I then start to look for games on the geek with made for solitaire, there aren't that many. I think my first two purchases are Pandemic and Roads & Boats.
Now the Army says its time to go to Missouri. So I do what any good soldier does, pack my crap and go. There really was no game scene in Missouri so solitaire was my only way to play. Over the next three years my collection slowly grows. Then the army says time to go to Kentucky, so I pack my crap and go to Kentucky. It is during this time that I discover [user=shacky22][/user] and his solitaire tracking geeklist. Looks like a good idea so I copy it and make my own (I don't keep up with it anymore).
Then the SGoyT and the 1 Player guild pop onto the radar. I joined the 1 player guild in November 2012. I believe I am member #43. My first post to the SGoyT was in June 2013 and it was Duel of Ages. I still own it and it is on my table as I type.
The SGoyT has cost me a lot of $$. But it is worth it. This is a great community and really the only thing I check out on the Geek.
Here is my current game in progress: [ImageID=2399451medium]
:thumbsup: I love the mash up of themes. :thumbsup: Unique stories develop every game. No two games will ever be the same :thumbsdown: Not a solitaire game due to lots of hidden info and bluffing. :thumbsdown: No solitaire variant

I love Duel of Ages as well. There's actually a solo puzzle version here:
[thread=1108140][/thread]
For DoA what I like to do is take an index card for each character and write down their goals, then try to achieve those goals with only what they know (noted as well on the card in shorthand). This keeps the world view of each character close enough that opposing-handed solo games are exciting still.
The goals may change as the game changes, so pencil is handy. :D Afterwards, I have story fragments from each character's point of view, which I can later stitch together into a session report, such as this: [thread=1009612][/thread]
Hm. I may do this again some time after I get a couple tables set up on the second floor for solo games.

item.objectname: Shadows Upon Lassadar: Siege at Kurth
item.body:
Recommending this as a great PnP prompted me to break it out for another play. Very quick to set up and play, and a lot of fun. Very easy PnP to make, just 18 cards (will need a bunch of cubes and some d6 too).
The goal of the game is to last three turns of four rounds without too many locations being overrun. I played on easy, so I lose the game if 5 locations have 8 or more invading units on them at the end of any round.
[imageid=2399591 medium]
One card is combat tables, one card is for tracking Manna, Spirit and Turn Number. Four of the cards make the board (two locations per card). The remaining 12 cards are drawn 3 at a time to determine various things for each turn.
[imageid=2399592 medium]
The black shield numbers are added together and this is the number of units added to each of the locations listed at the top of the first two cards. If there is a "location or location" choice at the top of the card, the units are added to the location with the fewest units. The blue circle numbers are added together and this total is added to your current manna. The red circle numbers are combined and the total is added to the defending units defense value on the combat chart. Each turn you can use one spell (printed on the top, coloured stripe) by spending manna, and one special action (printed on the white stripe near the bottom) by spending spirit.
Each turn you draw/execute three cards then move 1-3 spaces clockwise around the board, then roll dice to attack the invading units on the square you land on. Results are found on a combat chart. If you win, some invading units are removed, if you lose, you lose spirit.

item.body:
Tried this again, trying to not re-do my mistakes from the last time I played it (my first game).
My biggest mistake last time is that I tried to sacrifice lives to get rid of bad fighting cards. I did that too well took aging cards too fast, so I didn't last through yellow. I did better this time -- I made it to the second red fight and drew five cards and all of them were zeroes. :gulp: I didn't have enough lives left.
I like this game a lot and I'm starting to form a strategy:
Green is to get rid of the weak cards. This is tricky, because if get rid of too many you will age too quickly.
Yellow is to gather up as many fighting cards as you can
If you did Yellow correctly, you won't have too much cards to fight on Red. Then you have a chance against the :arrrh:
It's easy to talk about the strategy, but a completely different think to put it in play. :whistle:
[b]EDIT[/b]
All this talk made me want to play again. ;)
I did better this time -- I ran with the idea of adding "+1 life" and "+2 life" to the bottom of the deck. ;) I went to Red with 16 life left and came away from Red without a lot of losses.
I beat the first pirate ship, not without trouble, but using combos helped a lot (I had a lot of +2 cards on that). But the last pirate ship was "Fight against all remaining hazard cards" and I just couldn't get 55 points out of the 20 or so cards I was allowed. :(

item.body:
Played Core Worlds, base game only, using the SoloPlay rules, in preparation for the tutorial.
I managed to beat the easy-level AI at long last by two points, which is actually game victory. If I had beaten it by another point, it would have been major victory.
The SoloPlay version of Core Worlds is definitely thinky. The spatial movement makes for an interesting puzzle, and the fact that it's seeded from card draws adds enough randomness for me. The rest is trying to outsmart the AI, and sometimes catch rides on it. I had to pull out every stop and pull no punches to get that almost-major victory.
And of course if I had been playing on normal mode the AI would have nearly blown me away.
It's a most excellent solo variant.
[b]UPDATE Feb 4[/b]
I blew away the AI this game, with Galactic Orders, 32 points to 14. Even if the AI was on hard mode, it would have scored at most 11 more points, or 25. It was a combination (as always) of luck and hard play, particularly since I manipulated things such that the AI would never take high-scoring worlds (defined as 5+ VP straight up) if there was anything I could do about it. Once I had a hand full of nice units and a board full of high VP planets about to expire, so I just shopped for units so the board would clear.
Entirely worth it.
I really do like the addition of Galactic Orders, although I feel that events are poorly integrated into the SoloPlay variant somehow. Somehow.
item.comment: Is the SoloPlay variant similar to the multiplayer? Because apparently I need another space game.

[q="davekuhns"]Is the SoloPlay variant similar to the multiplayer? Because apparently I need another space game.[/q] Yes and no. I mean I haven't actually played this against anyone else, but it's one of those multiplayer solitaire style of games. Yes, you can invade a World or buy a Unit that someone else wanted, but you are mostly focusing on your own fleet and you own goals.
So, with that in mind, yes it's similar. You need to build up your fleet to accomplish the goals you want just like in the multiplayer version.
The difference is the spacial aspect of the "universe" instead of just a basic "market" in the standard game. It costs you Energy (one of the currencies of the game) to move. In the standard game, there is no movement. That's a major difference.
Then, depending on your action, the AI will have a set reaction. So, basically, you can program your turn at the beginning of each one based upon what you are going to do and how the AI will react. And that's where your success or failure will come.
If you can manipulate the AI into a less than optimal play [b]and[/b] accomplish your goal at the same time...Bingo!
As Ava said, it's very thinky if you want to play it that way. You can certainly just fly by the seat of your pants each turn and see how it plays out, but your level of success will certainly suffer.
Wow! Nice one one, Ava, 32 to 14. That's what I call a trouncing. :surprise:

[q="mo7189"]Wow! Nice one one, Ava, 32 to 14. That's what I call a trouncing. :surprise:[/q]
AI menaced me the whole way though. I had to sacrifice at least two good hands of units to keep it from scoring overly much. It made me sad not to be able to play the Great Brain because I've never used that card before, but better safe than really, really sorry.

item.objectname: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.body:
After a few months on the shelf, I'm breaking out one of my favorite deck builders. Legendary plays quick and has a lot of re-playibility due to the different combinations of bad guys and schemes. I enjoy finding how the different heroes interact with each other and the fantastic artwork that makes me feel this I'm in a truly epic battle.
I purchased this to play with my son and friend (who is a comic book junky.) They felt it was repetitive, solitaire-ish, and dragged at times, with no real fear of losing. I too felt this early on, but think the expansions have solved this problem.
When playing solo, there are some compromises. You only get three heroes and sometimes HQ bogs down since cards don't cycle as often with more players. Additionally, there are some combinations of mastermind/schemes that are either to easy or impossibly hard to beat playing solo. As I play more, I'm starting to recognize these combinations and can adjust appropriately. As a side note, I always play the 1 player advance rules and use a randomizer to pick the decks.
:thumbsup: Fantastic artwork and theme. Schemes make me feel like I'm part of an epic story. :thumbsup: Lots of re-playibility and plays fast solo.
:thumbsdown: There are scheme/mastermind combinations that are either too easy or too difficult to beat solo. :thumbsdown: There are times when the game stalls. This most often happens when you can readily handle the villain deck, but just can't seem to get enough attack to take down the mastermind.

item.body: I'll be continuing my Year of Fridays project - a game of Friday every Friday all year. I was 1-4 in January. I'm tracking my progress on this list: [geeklist=184408][/geeklist]

[size=18][b]Origin Story[/b][/size]
My solo gaming life started with my dad's 1960's version of Stra-o-matic baseball when I was 10. I played league schedules and completed something like fifteen solo seasons of 52 games before Dungeons and Dragons became the social game of choice.
Twenty years pass and I stumble into a podcast called the Dice Tower and during one of the podcasts he mentions BGG and I go running to the computer to look for it. I start looking for solo games but the choices are limited until I find the PnP section where I discover D-day Dice. A year ago or so I found this list and it's been a whirlwind of solo game discovery, great people sharing their experiences and some great laughs.
Therefore, it is fitting that my orgin story be posted along with a new "baseball" acquisition [thing=151022][/thing]. This landed on my doorstep this weekend and I was excited to get it to the table right away. This by no means a baseball game but more an abstraction of the mechanics of scoring in baseball. I found the rule book was okay but because my mind wanted to see strat-o-matic baseball so I watched some short clips on how to play the game. I was up and running with confidence in less than 30 minutes.
The gameplay is fast and the mini-games are short. In between the mini-games you get to deck build by drafting new players to enhance your team. The automated AI which is made of superior players and is random but still challenging. I found that each mini-game was full of decisions and surprises. [imageid=2399813]
I was able to beat the AI 4-2 in a best of seven series but each game was close and I see that the strength of the AI is based on which 15 random cards are picked...but it was still a challenge and I was lucky this time. Each mini-game takes about as long as a Dungeon Roll delve and the set up is pretty minimal with a medium size footprint. This will be my go to relaxing game during baseball season after a long crazy day at work or to play with my kids. My nine year old picked it up fairly fast so I'd say it's an easy learn with plenty of medium stress level choices. Home Run!
:thumbsup: It's Baseball... Fast baseball...WHAT!??? :thumbsdown: rule book could of had a little better sample game with just a few more examples of play. :thumbsdown:i finally resolve to slow down on my acquisitions and now the kickstarters start rolling in. The next thing I know I turned around and bought Imperial Assault...so I guess shelf space is my last barrier to full on game hoarding but who cares right? Gaming life right now is the best!

ORIGIN STORY
After playing Mage Knight and enjoying it very much, I started looking for more solo games. BGG design always confuses me but I managed to find the geeklist "The definitive list of solo games", from there I found my way to SGOYT. That was 5-6 months ago and I have been following SGOYT ever since.
However, this is my first entry. I got Ottoman Sunset a few months ago. It was my first state of siege game. I really like the concept. It is simple and elegant.
My playthrough this time started quite nicely with German U-boats protecting the straits, thus blocking the British assault on the straits. I usually lose to that. So, I was comfortable and hoping that I would get an easy victory. Unfortunately, constant advances by the enemy on all fronts and a few defeats in battles drove my national will below -3 which cost me the game.
A few days ago I ordered bunch of VPG games, including the Hapsburg Eclipse. Apparently, you can combine both games. I am excited!
:thumbsup: Very easy to set-up, takes very little space and plays quickly.
:thumbsup: Good story-telling if you are interested in the theme. It is even possible to arrange the cards in numerical order which allows you to play the events of this period in chronological order.
:thumbsdown: Everything ultimately comes down to die rolls. Some might not like that.
item.comment: Love that Ottoman Sunset! So easy to play, only a few decisions, but overall very tactical.

item.body:
Once again using the SoloPlay rules. I would have scored better had I stopped earlier and left more than 0 unused track, I think, but I might not have been able to.
6-8 points is an easy game victory (I scored 8 points), 9-11 points (which I feel was achievable) would have been a normal game victory.
I did play on hard mode (because I always forget some of the special leniency rules for the first destination), so there's that. Maybe I can just mentally add a point for that, and have a game victory; on the other hand, I used the "Flat Lands" layout, so that probably balances out.
[b]EDIT:[/b] I achieved normal game victory! I forgot to add 2 points for 3 complex routes, so 10 points. I am happy now.
Ah, a pretty map, though an inefficient network in the end:
[imageid=2399881 medium]
I finished far more destinations than usual. I wish I could have made it to 28 destinations, but I only made it to 22, and 6 more would have been more or less impossible with the amount of track I had left.
I think I can improve, and the variant is teaching me about efficient networks, certainly. There are places I could have zigged when I instead zagged.
All in all, a very fun variant once you understand set-up. I need to prepare a player aid and probably a tutorial video as well, at some point in time.

item.body:
It's my birthday in a couple of days so I picked up this game as a present to myself! I was torn between this and Omaha. I settled on this title for two reasons: firstly, I played a couple of games of [thing=105023]Fleet Commander Nimitz[/thing] in January so was in a Pacific theatre mood; secondly, this appealed slightly more as it represents the entire assault whereas Omaha is obviously just one beach in a larger battle.
Finished my first game yesterday but now know that I got a couple of rules wrong, particularly regarding Japanese activation. For the first couple of turns I wasn't activating units with depth markers when there was only a single symbol on the card, and I was activating tanks based on the colour of the position they were on and not the colour on the tank. And I got myself a little confused with Position Groups.
So I'm launching straight into another game - hopefully this time with everything straight in my head. I considering the first game as a training exercise!
I was very, very impressed with the system. It plays quite quickly once you get to grips with it, and it creates some really exciting and tense game play. The first couple of turns before any HQs are landed are massively entertaining as you agonise over your meager 3 actions. Thank goodness for Major Ryan!
I can see me coming back to this a lot. It's certainly piqued my curiosity about the upcoming [thing=67601]D-Day at Peleliu[/thing].

item.body:
[u][b]Session 1: SoloPlay - Game Victory (+1)[/b][/u]
[b]Me (Priam): 45[/b] Units/Tactics/Worlds: 13 Core Worlds: 15 Prestige: 6 Faction Tokens: 11
[b]AI: 44[/b] Energy: 11 Units/Tactics/Worlds: 16 Core Worlds: 7 Prestige: 3 Faction Tokens: 7
This was my first experience with the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/97578/soloplay-coreworlds-v1pdf]SoloPlay variant[/url] by BGG user GamesRuleforOne, andâ¦wow. That was just about all he could say: wow.
I had heard good reports from the SGoYT geek list, but I was still skeptical, thinking that it would end up being too fiddly and non-intuitive. I was quite pleasantly surprised to find that the mechanics are not that onerous and the design of the variant is actually quite thematic.
This SoloPlay variant also solves a lurking issue with Core Worlds that there is a single, dominant strategy: spend the first couple of rounds deploying the base units into the war zone, then leave them there for the entire game in order to streamline the deck down to just a single hand which recycles over and over. This has the advantage of getting Energy Surge cards into one's hand every round, while also setting them up to get +2 energy instead of just +1 because opponents will likely have conquered an additional world or two, thus increasing their base energy production. And with the addition of the Galactic Orders, cycling through units/tactics with order icons leads to many more tokens on the various order tiles and thus, more flexibility and more scoring. Opinions vary on whether or not this strategy is actually dominant over possible alternatives, but it is very effective regardless.
The SoloPlay variant addresses the issue neatly by adding the maintenance cost of 1 energy for every set of three units over the initial three in a war zone. Thus, 1-3 units in a war zone is maintenance free, but units 4-6 cost 1 energy per turn, while having 7-9 units would cost 2 energy per round. Thus, it can be ruinous to maintain a large war zone over several rounds, rendering the strategy of deploying all the basic units and just leaving them unused for the entire game untenable. This is particularly true in this variant in which energy is used for movement as well as drafting, deploying and conquering. But even without this additional use for energy, I think the maintenance idea is a good one. It is not so great as to be game-changing, but it does create some balance. In multiplayer, imposing a cost, even a minor one like this, would force players to use their war zone units more often instead of making it a glorified dumping ground for undesirable cards. And it is even thematic: maintaining a large military force in a state of immediate readiness should be expensive in any context. Real militaries don't stay constantly at high alert 24/7 just waiting to be sent into action at a moment's notice.
I know that the spectre of war zone maintenance kept me on my toes in this solo session. Energy was in such short supply for the first part of the game that I could not have afforded much extra. That said, once the AI gets its own energy production going, then maintaining a large war zone becomes a bit easier since the Energy Surge cards are doubled in effectiveness. But this is perhaps as it should be: your empire has grown, after all, and you should by the mid-game have a decent energy economy running.
As far as this specific session went, I was not sure what I was doing for the first few rounds. It took me awhile to figure out how the AI moved and how much it cost me to move, etc. I rapidly figured out that I needed to plan a few moves ahead, taking the various AI reactions into account. I liked how the variant lets you "ride along" with the AI marker, saving energy. It adds a nice element to planning; I was always thinking about how I could manipulate the AI into going where I wanted so I could move without spending energy and still get the cards I wanted. This didn't always work out though, and I even found myself having to "borrow" energy from the center at times.
I finally developed a bit of plan. I had drafted two units with the Mystic Brotherhood icon, so I had a few tokens on that order tile when the Divine Energy tactics card turned up. I immediately recognized that this represented a huge advantage for me if I could draft it into my deck. I had to do some tricky maneuvering around the AI and spent nearly all my energy moving my token into position to draft it. Once I had it, however, I was able to use it repeatedly for big energy boosts. It's almost absurd that playing the card not only gives +1 energy for every token on the Brotherhood tile, but that it also adds another [i]which counts as one for the additional energy[/i]! Since my deck was relatively streamlined at this point, I built up a large supply of tokens on the Mystic Brotherhood, several of which I was able to spend to draw additional cards. This meant quicker deck cycling and seeing Divine Energy more often -- a powerful positive feedback loop which I rode to success in the latter rounds.
It was a good thing I did, however; I obviously needed every single energy point I could muster to eke out the one-point victory. I also saved energy by spending most of the game riding along with the AI token.
I did help out the AI's score a bit in ways I hope to avoid in future sessions. I finished two rounds with actions and energy left, which earned the AI energy points. I also did not take advantage of the mechanism whereby using a token on an order tile allows removal of an AI token. I therefore probably let the AI have 6 or 7 points I could have prevented with smarter play.
I look forward to playing this variant again. It has revitalized the game for me. I had despaired of ever getting it to the table again multiplayer. The lengthy play time means it is really only good for 2-3 players and while I found that folks were favorably inclined toward the game, they tended to gravitate toward others when offered the opportunity to play. While the forthcoming iPad app will hopefully provide asynchronous play with online opponents, this excellent SoloPlay variant will keep my physical copy of the game hitting the table on a regular basis.
[b][u]Session 2: SoloPlay - Complete Victory (+6)[/u][/b]
[b]Me (Menelaus): 40[/b] Worlds: 7 Units (Worldship): 9 Tactics: 0 Core Worlds (Ra, Indra): 16 Factions: 8
[b]AI: 34[/b] Energy: 8 Worlds: 12 Units: 1 Tactics: 0 Core Worlds (Zeus, Buono): 11 Factions: 2
This session featured lower scores than my first, but a more comfortable margin of victory. I was better about keeping the AI from grabbing cards with energy tokens.
I tried deploying a lot of grunts/snubs at first and leaving them out to clear the deck; I wanted to see if the maintenance requirement would hurt. And indeed it did. This early in the game, every unit of energy is precious and losing one to maintain a 4-5 unit war zone limited options to a surprising extent. Part of the problem was that Energy Surges are only half as effective if the AI is not generating more energy than you. Since they don't start with a home world, it takes them several invasions to catch up and pass the player and make the Energy Surges effective. Thus, keeping a big war zone full of starting units does not work nearly as well in this SoloPlay variant as it does in multiplayer.
I wasn't able to hitch a ride with the AI nearly as often in this session as I was in my previous. This left me forced to spend more energy to move where I needed to go, although I avoided taking any loans this time. That said, I had to get creative in two rounds to make sure I zeroed out energy or actions to keep the AI from getting a "free" action.
I didn't generate nearly as many faction order tokens as I had in my previous sessions. The cards I picked up were not as useful or easy to deploy. And I found myself having to spend a few over the course of the game to keep turns from stalling out for various reasons. But the AI didn't get as many either, so this evened out.
I got ahead of the AI decisively in faction tokens in sector 5. The event was Warlords, which makes every player remove two faction tokens from faction tiles. I let it fire on turn 9, removing two of mine and two of the AIs. But I was able to arrange it so that the AI did not acquire a card with a faction symbol for the final two rounds while I deployed several units and used a couple of tactics cards which earned me order tokens. On round 10, I paid two energy to negate the event. The net effect was that I gained some points on faction order tokens relative to the AI.
Still, my victory was entirely dependent on the Worldship which I was able to leave deployed at the end of the game. This 9 points was decisive; without it, I'd have been defeated by three points. I was able to draft and deploy this expensive unit thanks to two tactics cards, one of which gave me discount of 3 energy when drafting, and one which gave a discount of 4 when deploying.
This session played out differently than my first, primarily because the cards on offer were different. There is a huge amount of replayability given that you only see, at most, 12 cards from each sector deck. You have to think tactically and go with what you're given to work with in terms of unit mix and faction icons.
I'm looking forward to future plays and have made Core Worlds the last game on my "10x5" solo challenge.
item.comment:
Nice one, Marc! Way to squeak out the win on your first attempt. Now that you have the AI reactions down, I'm sure you'll have greater success. I'm happy to see this one popping up more and more with the SoloPlay variant.
And I too hope the app has async play as I'd love to get in a game with a few of my solo gamer friends. I didn't back the KS but will definitely look to purchase it soon after its release.

Indeed, the SoloPlay variant is more thematic than the regular game in my opinion. The addition of a spatial element gives a fun sense of maneuvering a fleet around the galaxy looking for opportunities to strike. It definitely makes the game a bit more thinky, but in a good way as far as I'm concerned.
I don't play this game and don't have a dog in the fight, but out of curiosity to the design, would this maintenance cost mechanism work in the regular game as well and address that issue?

[q="enzo622"]I don't play this game and don't have a dog in the fight, but out of curiosity to the design, would this maintenance cost mechanism work in the regular game as well and address that issue?[/q]
I hope so, because that dominant strategy doesn't sound like much fun.
Because of the energy maintenance cost of a large army of non-robots and non-heroes, I tended to value robots and heroes over infantry, vehicles, starfighters, etc. Capital ships and star cruisers are still important, of course, but they are worth it.
I also learned to be far more selective of planets I wanted to take over (and not just because of the AI) so I would only deploy what I needed. Plus the fact that the AI invades a planet whenever you deploy units (to prepare for invading a planet on your own) means that choppy deployment (deployment that isn't done as part of one turn) screws you over severely.

item.body:
[b][size=18]My Super Solo Sunday[/size][/b]
My wife and I were sick on Super Sunday, which sucks because I live within walking distance of the Cardinalâs stadium, and we didnât get to go over there and take in all the free concerts and super bowl pre-game to-doings. But we werenât so down and out as to not make it a Super Sunday of board gaming. Wellâ¦ I wasnât so down and out anyway. Just after I set up [thing=142084]Kings of Israel[/thing] for a two player game, my wife bowed out and went back to bed. Although it may have something to do with me not having read the rules beforehand, and she didnât have the time or the patients to deal with my fumbling through yet another rule book. Needless to say, Feb 1st became a Super Solo Sunday for me.
[b]Kings of Israel[/b] After a quick reading of the rules followed up with a Rahdo Runs Through, I was ready to take on the struggles, plights, and various Kings of Israel. This being the first time I played the game, the usually first time mistakes happened. The mistakes I made were not with rules, but with shuffling. This is one game where an ill shuffled deck is death.
The sin and punishment deck had all âBrimstone and Fireâ in the top 7 cards (two were one after the other). That in itself caused insurmountable odds to overcome, but the other poorly shuffled deck was the Resources deck. All wood cards were together at the bottom which meant I could not build any altars. I lost many turns doing nothing but turning over resource cards with both prophets.
Half-way through I decided to switch to the easy version (gain a blessing card after sacrificing at the altar) which did little to help since there was only one altar on the board. Both my prophets were huddled together around the altar at Samaria searching desperately for wood and gaining blessings that only prolonged the inevitable.
In the end we were overcome with three destroyed cities (Jericho ironically being the first to go) and everyone worshiping Baal (who apparently is the god of âwoodâ). In a secular way, I can chalk this one up to not setting up the game properly. But the theological side of me wonders how this relates to the spiritual. Surely God helps those in need (Isaiah 25:4), but perhaps Ben Franklin was right in that God helps those that help themselves. Or, at the very least, God helps those that bother to give their decks a good shuffling (Luke 14:28).
Breakdown: :thumbsup:[size=9]Quick and easy setup.[/size] :thumbsup:[size=9]Excellent for fans of Pandemic.[/size] :thumbsdown:[size=9]For such a large deck, âBlessingsâ are hardly ever used (unless I missed something).[/size] :thumbsdown:[size=9]Needed rule clarifications occasionally.[/size] :thumbsup:[size=9]Designer is very active in the forums and answers all questions clearly! [/size]
[b]Imperial Settlers[/b] Next up was [thing=154203]Imperial Settlers[/thing]. I got this one primarily for solo play, but chose it in case the wife woke up and felt like joining me. She did not. The game was met with equaling disaster as with Kings of Israel due to my own buffoonery. This time, I choose the wrong deck to play. I started with the Barbarians but accidentally used the Egyptian deck. The sad thing is that I did not notice the error until I was cleaning up after the game. Maybe I was sicker than I was letting on. As far as anyone reading this is concerned, I will go with that as the only plausible excu- erâ¦ explanation. The whole time I was struggling to get things built. In the end, because of a lucky pull of attack cards, I wound up tying with the AI. Alas, in this game a tie is still a loss.
Breakdown: :thumbsup::thumbsdown:Lots of bits (fun to have bits but affects setup and breakdown). :thumbsup:Lots to do on your turn. Success is based on how well you optimize what all you can do. :thumbsdown:Table real-estate shrinks dramatically the better you do (if you donât have much space, then try not to do so well). :thumbsup:Rulebook explained everything.
[b]Well, at least someone other than me lost today[/b] I decided to cut my losses and turn to the television where a surprisingly good game was breaking out (albeit with two teams I care nothing about). The game, dubbed by friends as the Jerks versus the Cheats, ended with the Cheats winning (a lesson that every solo gamer ponders the spiritual ramifications of). However, what may appear to have been divine intervention on the part of the Patriots, was obviously none other than Pete Carroll playing with all his running play cards at the bottom of his deck.
Breakdown: :thumbsdown:Patriots won :thumbsup:Seahawks lost

item.body:
[b]Origin Story? Well, let me tell ya...[/b]
I discovered wargaming in high school, and fueled by lots of history reading (not to mention reruns of "Combat", "12 O'Clock High", and especially "Baa Baa Black Sheep")I became as passionate a gamer as my budget would allow. My brother and I played or I'd play solo: Games like "Panzer Blitz", "Tobruk", "Richtofen's War", "Luftwaffe", "Rise and Fall of the Third Reich", and "Air Force" became our passions.
But then, as the story goes, Real Life Arrived.
University, dating, marriage, work, family. Games were just part of regular family life, so as the kids came we'd cycle through Hi Ho Cherry-O, Go Fish, The Match Game, Candyland, The Game of Life, Boggle, and so on. There were a few times my daughter and I played AH's History of the World, but no one else had the patience for games that were challenges rather than pastimes.
But then the kids were off to college and my wife went back for more classes as well. And one fateful day in February 2010, on a whim searching for "wargames", I came across Winterfest Wargamers...and found that their annual week long monster game fest started TOMORROW exactly TWO MILES from my house. So I showed up, and the rest is, as they say, history.
I found a great group of guys from all over the region, but I also found box after box of the most incredible games. Unbelievable variety and subject matter and...OMG.
For the first three years after that I tried to play some of the classic solitaire board wargames but nothing really caught on with me. Since this summer I've gotten deeper and deeper into the hobby, and when I re-discovered BGG this fall it seems like everything's clicked. And I've gone big time into solitaire gaming, mostly with games not specifically designed to be solitaire.
While I joined the Solitaire Guild earlier, I've only dug into the SGOYT in the last few weeks. And here I am...with another game play to talk about!
_______________
Historically the Battle of Trebia (or Trebbia, I've seen it both ways) occurred in the Second Punic War, when two Legions of Romans let by an overconfident Consul Sepronius forded a winter river and attacked some guy named Hannibal. Little did the Sempronius know that this Hannibal guy had concealed a force (led by Mago) in a ravine to the Roman rear, and kept it hidden until just the right time for its maximum impact. The resulting victory was a stunning Carthaginian success and further established Hannibal's reputation as one of the greatest generals of all time.
[ImageID=2398130medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]The real Battle of Trebia River looked like this. Very few Romans made it home at all.[/i][/COLOR]
In Command and Colors this attacking force enters the board from behind the Roman army with the use of a Leadership card, and deciding when and how to have this force strike makes the scenario one of the most interesting in the base game. The force is strong enough to mop up weakened Romans, but if they enter too early and are faced with heavy resistance Mago's Carthaginians will be wiped out themselves. On the other hand, wait too late and Mago could arrive on a battle field already lost.
So the starting position looks fairly good for the Legions, though closer analysis would give the advantage to Hannibal's forces even without Mago. Hannibal wants to wear down enough of the Roman medium and heavy infantry so that Mago can roll through several partially destroyed units with his two units of Warriors and one of Medium Cavalry. Without such Roman attrition this force is not enough to even safely fight their way through to friendly lines, much less win the battle for the Carthaginians.
[ImageID=2397299medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Starting positions. I like to think that the situation looked dark for the Romans (so I don't have to face the fact that the picture is underexposed)[/i][/COLOR]
In my game the Carthaginians started with three Leadership cards so they would have the ability to choose how and when they wanted to bring Mago across. They decided to work carefully, and as the Romans advanced the Carthaginians focused on ranged fire to whittle down some key units. They did manage to almost eliminate the Medium unit the Roman leader was attached to, but they couldn't finish the deal so when the medium unit advanced it was able to both give morale boost and participate in close combat if it desired.
[ImageID=2398454medium]
When the Romans played a "Double Time" card they were able to close with the Carthaginian line unexpectedly fast and the resulting position allowed the Legions to destroy the first two units of the game. Two to zip, playing to seven flags.
[ImageID=2397984medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Unexpected Double Time close combat pins the annoying projectile units without possibility of evasion or retreat. [/i][/COLOR]
Now Hannibal responds, targeting the weakened medium unit and hoping for a good roll against the Romansâ only leader. Carthage shifts and advances, hitting the medium units while bringing up the heavies and incidentally getting Hannibal into the center section (knowing thereâs a Center card to come). The results are good: the stronger medium unit is weakened and driven back, while Semproniusâ unit is destroyed, forcing him back onto one of the only Roman heavies he has.
For the next several turns each side repositions or trades light jabs. Hannibal pushes forward his right wingâs elephants and light cavalry, but neither has the juice to slam into the full strength Roman line and the Romans know it. Sempronius actives a mass of light infantry to whittle down the mediums facing him, and gets a couple blocks to make it worthwhile.
Knowing he has to weaken the primary Roman units in order for Mago to spring the ambush, Hannibal risks slamming his weakened units against Semproniusâ solidified and reorganized center-right. Focusing on the light infantry that fills out much of the Roman line, Hannibal pounds unit after unit until Semproniusâ heavies stand almost alone.
[ImageID=2398484medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Going for broke, Hannibal drives his weakened line against the Legions. He has to thin their ranks in order for the ambush to be sprung.[/i][/COLOR]
In the multi-turn slugfest that followed there were assaults and counterassaults that whittled down strengths on both sides. If it werenât for Semproniusâ âRallyâ card play the Romans might have been finished right there, but as it stood each army was tenaciously hanging on without any sign of breaking.
[ImageID=2398668medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]The âRallyâ card breathed new life into Semproniusâ line and recharged his resistance. [/i][/COLOR]
So still the Roman right wing was still too strong for the ambush to be sprung. After a Roman warrior unit attacked a Carthaginian light infantry (which evaded successfully), the Carthaginian mounted troops sprung forward. Their medium cavalry hammered the warriors, taking acceptable losses in return. While the victory banners would be sweet, the real goal was to bleed the Romans down so the ambush could have maximum impact.
But then the Romans rudely counterattacked with their own medium cavalry, destroying their damaged Carthaginian counterpart and sending the second of Hannibalâs medium horse recoiling back. The Romans had four victory banners, comfortably ahead of the Carthaginians, but Hannibal knows what he has waiting and feels things are in control.
And now in turn the Carthage sends its mounted troops forward, war elephants stampeding toward the Roman horse and Hannibalâs own medium cavalry blocking the Roman retreat. This attack had the potential to utterly destroy both Semproniusâ cavalry and his warriors on that flank.
[ImageID=2398698medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]After charge and countercharge, the Carthaginian war elephants rumble into the fray. (War elephants are cool.) [/i][/COLOR]
But Mars favored his followers, and the Carthaginians could do nothing but finish the crippled Roman warrior unit. And then another unexpected blow descends on Hannibal, for Sempronius decides that he must use his heavy infantry before he loses it. Even though itâs down to a single block, the remaining legionaries surge forwards and destroy their opposing unit. Then with momentum clearly in their favor they advance to attack and destroy yet another of Hannibalâs infantry.
[ImageID=2398731medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Even badly damaged Heavy Infantry packs a terrifying punch, as Sempronius shows here. The Romans are now only ONE banner from total victory [/i][/COLOR]
This gave the Romans their 6th victory banner and suddenly things were nerve racking indeed: While they waited for the perfect time to unleash the ambush the Carthaginians had allowed Sempronius to come within one victory of winning outright!! Had Hannibal waited too long?
[ImageID=2398747medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Had Hannibal waited too long? Just before the ambush was sprung the battle seemed to belong to the Romans, who had just split the Carthaginian line in two[/i][/COLOR]
With no other choice â and with the ground almost perfectly prepared for it â Mugo burst from his hiding place and struck heavily at the Romans from behind, scattering and slaying wherever he went. Seeing near victory evaporating, Sempronius clung to his only hope â being only one banner from victory â and attacked any unit he could reach, but it wasnât enough.
[ImageID=2398764medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]â¦.ITâS A TRAP!!....The Roman momentum suddenly vanishes as Mago drives forward from his hiding place.[/i][/COLOR]
Then the war elephants on the Carthaginian left hammered forward, crushing several units; a hail of arrows dented an infantry unit on the right; and Semproniusâ overextended heavy infantry in the center was crushed by the only unused heavy Hannibal had remaining.
[ImageID=2398766medium] [COLOR=#999999][i]Final positions and banner tallies. This game told an amazing, thrilling story![/i][/COLOR]
Hannibal had come from far, far behind and utterly destroyed his opponent. Although for a while it looked like he waited too long, the trap was sprung at the perfect time to maximize its impact and as one hoped it totally unhinged the Roman force.
An utterly exciting scenario!

Terrain does not play a big role in most of the scenarios. Most ancient battles were usually fought on open plains where the armies had enough room to maneuver. Of course rivers and bodies of water were used to the victors advantage, i.e. pinning your adversary by using the water feature to block retreat.

I've not played Napoleonic, but compared to Memoir '44 CC-Ancients has TONS more depth, terrain or no. There's not much difference in the mechanics [b] BUT [/b] the unit types and implementation requires way more tactical nuance and sophistication.
More than anything else I simply LOVE the way CC-Ancients rewards historical tactics, without resorting to chrome type rulesets. It's just built in to the system.
If you try to use light troops to anchor the line, you're in trouble. Way better to have them as skirmishers and missile troops, softening up at the outset. The morale rules mean players who keep units in line have an advantage over those who split them up. Cavalry is awesome if used properly but will rebound and maybe fall apart if thrown against intact full strength medium to heavy infantry. Sequencing of what unit attacks which enemy in what order can be the difference between victory and defeat.
And having cards control the action doesn't feel restrictive the way it does in Combat Commander, while still being able to reflect command and control differences between armies.

Naploeonics, I believe, has a bit more unit variety, plus the addition of squares and such.
Though I believe the leaders are a bit less powerful.

I don't have a good Origin Story that I can remember. I've been playing games solo since I could open the game closet. My interests evolve as I age, but that's about it.
[b]Playing Right Now[/b]
:thumbsup: [thing=121921]Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island[/thing]: Yep, Still obsessed. Pulled it out every month for a few games. Played 5 of 6 scenarios thus far. Played Scenario 8 four times before finally defeating it (or should I say: successfully starting a family on the island and surviving).
:thumbsup: At the same time, I've been reading the rules to the expansion, [thing=144722]Voyage of the Beagle[/thing]. It looks awesome! Now I've played scenario 1, and just started scenario 2, which builds off the previous game. This campaign adventure is a great design. Absolutly loving it. This is giving [thing=15987]Arkham Horror[/thing], my current solo favorite, a huge challenge...
[b]Hope to Play This Month[/b] [thing=156336]Onirim[/thing]: Snapped this up in January when Cool Stuff got a few copies. Played twice in January, and reading rules for expansions now. Taking a trip to visit family and this is coming with me. Expect several plays. Enjoyed first plays, but didn't love it.
[thing=124708]Mice and Mystics:[/thing] Only played the first two scenarios, and ready to play more.
[thing=119506]Freedom: The Underground Railroad[/thing]: Love the theme and difficulty. Played solo and multiplayer a few times.
[thing=146791]Shadows of Brimstone[/thing]: Picked this up in January too, and played a few times. Ready for more. I like this, but don't yet love it. The character building and theme are great. However, they give you tons of tokens, yet in order to track your gold and XP, you have to use RPG style pen and paper, which defeat the purpose of most of the tokens. Big turn off and disappointment. Why couldn't they have built a tracking system into the game? If I wanted pen and paper, I'd go back to RPGs or games without lots of bits.

I had my first game with the Automa, using the [b]Mamas and Papas[/b] setup from Tuscany, on 29th January. I didn't record it on the January list because it was a learning game, and in the end I played it slightly wrong (I fulfilled a wine order that needed a white wine and a sparkling wine, but I mistakenly used two ordinary wines).
Today I reset the game and played my first proper games. I didn't win (the Automa is a challenging opponent!), but I scored 16 points in game 1, and 15 points in game 2.
[b]Edit #1 03/02/2015[/b]: Game 3 - 17 points. Game 4 - 18 points. Game 5 - 20 points.
[b]Edit #2 04/02/2015[/b]: Game 6 - 20 points. Well, I think I played it all correctly for the first time, so I think I'm now ready to begin the Tuscany Automa campaign in earnest, and hopefully get a win and start unlocking the other expansions!
This is likely to become one of my favourite games.
:thumbsup: It is a beautiful, thematic game with wonderful components.
:thumbsup: It is a relatively straightforward light/medium worker placement game. It is so thematic it is a joy to play (and lose!)
:thumbsup: The Automa and the variety of cards suggest that there is an awful lot of replayability in the game. And then there are the rest of the Tuscany expansions.
:thumbsdown: The Automa is a tough opponent. I'm still only using the 'easy' version. The 'normal' and the 'hard' versions (also termed 'aggressive'!) are scaring me at the moment :surprise:
[size=18][u][b]Origin Story[/b][/u][/size]
I can't honestly remember how I first came across the SGOYT lists. It undoubtedly stemmed from my compulsive trawling of BGG for solo gaming content. As solitaire games are the most common games to be found on my table/floor/hotel desk etc., it was natural for me to peruse and contribute.
I've always played games solo, right from when I was very young, often playing each side in my multi-player games. The number of games now that are solely for one player is staggering. I have a fair few now myself (yes, many as a result of SGOYT and the 1-Player Guild). I look forward to continuing to seek and try new solitaire games, and learn about some of them from here.

item.body:
Played three games of this as part of the GOLO February SGOYT challenge that can be found here if you're interested:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1312881/golo-challenge-royal-county-down-golf-club
The Royal County Down Golf Club is the course for February. It's an out 35, in 36, par 71 course. My scores for the three games were 74, 70 and 78.
In the first game, I was dead on-par for the first four holes and then bogeyed the next two to put me at two-over. I then shot two birdies to put me back even, but ended the front nine with a double-bogey on a par 4 and shot a two-over 37 going out. I started off the back nine with a bogey and a birdie followed by four straight even holes. I was hoping to make up some ground on the final three holes, but was only able to manage bogey, even, even for a 1-over 37 coming in and a 3-over 74 for the round.
I started off great in the second game with an eagle on a par 5 and a birdie on a par 4 before shooting three straight even holes. I lost my focus on hole 6 and shot a triple-bogey. I managed to even, birdie, even to finish the front nine at a 1-under 34. I called bottoms on my first roll on the back nine and that generated a hole-in-one on a par 3 with two even-par holes and a birdie following that. I was two-under for the back nine going into hole 17, but with my mulligan used up, shot a double-bogey and par to finish even for the final nine holes. Since I was one-under on the first nine, that kept me at a one-under 70 for the round; my best effort of the day.
In the third game, I shot dead even on every hole of the front nine, save for a birdie on hole #2 so that once again left me at a one-under 34 as in the second game. I didn't fare so well on the back nine however. I was two-over going into hole 17, but then shot a quadruple and a double bogey on the last two holes that put me at 8-over for the back nine and 7-over for the round.

Finished the night with Ghost Stories. This game is always tense and always reminds me of why it's my top rated game on the geek.
Played with the Guardpost in place of the dude who lets you get two Tao tokens. Had a few close calls, but made it all the way to Wu Feng. 5 black. Had 2 black Tao tokens, all Taoists stacked on Wu Feng with 1 Qi left, and a full board. Sacrificed my Red Taoist at the Sorcerer to give Blue one last chance at a double attack on Wu Feng. Two reds and a black. Roll again. Green, blue, yellow.... Oh well, till next time
Learned a couple lessons though. First, going Yin-Yang into Sorcerer too many times will cripple you if you don't manage the deck tempo. Also trying to blind roll 2 Tao dice will almost never work and is a really poor move.
I need to get better at placing my 1-2 ghosts. I never am sure how to setup my corners properly and always mess up my positioning both of taoists and ghosts
:thumbsup: Always tense and fun :thumbsdown: Rulebook didn't really translate well :thumbsdown: Card quality could be better

After clipping counters for the D-Day Twins, I decided I was in enough of a groove to finish clipping mine for this 23 year old classic from John Butterfield and Eric Lee Smith.
This one box contains 5 different battles from the War of Northern Aggression: Bull Run, Shiloh, Bentonville, Gettysburg and the one pictured below, Pea Ridge
[imageid=2400996medium]
Easy to digest rules, frustrations of the close up combat requirements (hard to get a LOS for artillery, for example), and interesting chit pull mechanic make this one pretty fun and easy to play solo.
My pea brain just got through the first two turns of Pea Ridge and despite early Southern sweep, the Union is gonna kick butt soon. The confederates only get what they started with and the bad guys get reinforcements all throughout the battle. Just took two of the Union objectives, but was immediately driven off of one due to poorly executed attack on the Rebel's part...
------------------------------------
Selfishly wrote my final AAR as a blog post which you can find here: [b][blogpost=38645][/blogpost][/b]

It adheres to realism (reasonably), with terrain playing a big part. The map was created using satellite imagery (combined with other methods, naturally)!

item.body:
So I came home from work expecting to see the copy of Gears of War I ordered when I heard it was going OOP. Well, it was there, just not in the "new" condition they said it was. Far from it. No shrink wrap, worn box, tons of pieces missing. Reboxed, filled out return with Amazon. There goes this evening's gaming.... :( Maybe I'll be able to trade for GoW or something in the future.
So, back to the original plan: Flash Point was going to be my "game of the week" that I left set up on the dining room table while my wife is on a business trip. I played the hazmat tech, the CAFS firefighter, and the imaging tech but I lost as usual (stop fallng down, buildings!) but it was good to get reacquainted with the rules. It's a good co-op but not my favorite one but a keeper nonetheless.
+ I really like the theme since it's so different + I also think it makes for a very intense gaming experience
- It's quite fiddly and sometimes I find myself struggling to remember all the upkeep. A game like Pandemc feels more organic to me while here I keep forgetting things like hot spots or refreshing POIs. Oh well, I'll get better with practice.
UPDATE: I'm going to also be chronicling my solo gaming adventures here: [geeklist=186770][/geeklist]

After the recent release of my second Dominion SoloPlay variant (the pyramid challenge, the file link is the same as the original variant) I have returned to finishing up the Five Tribes solo variant. All that is left is more playtesting and a visual aid to better describe a key mechanic.
I am struggling to perform well as I always seem to get my timing off. I have only had one master level victory but in my last five I have only reached major success. I have calculated that it is possible to hit 300 but the best I have achieved is 241.
Additionally, I have extensively playtested my Dice Masters SoloPlay variant and it is holding up very well. The last setup I tried 5+ times and I could not get the right combo of actions and heroes to finish the job. I got him down to 3 health before succumbing to defeat. This is a fairly straight forward variant and is being tested with AvX and Uncanny X Men. Not sure if future sets will support the design but it seems versatile enough.

item.body:
First play of this game this month on level 2. I made it to the red phase but lost on the first card.
Green Phase went quite badly and I had 2 life left at the end of it. Moved in to the yellow phase and at one point had 0 life left. I managed to regain 3 life and survived to the end of the phase. The first cards of the red phase had the same values so made no difference which one I picked. The first card I turned over for the fight was the Stop aging card. That cost me more life than I had remaining and ended the game. Had I of been able to spend my remaining life and drawn the full number of cards I still would not have won the fight.
Score: 31 for fighting cards, -5 for aging card, 0 for pirates, 0 for remaining life, -42 for hazard cards. Total = -16
:thumbsdown: - I lost the fight :(
[b][i]Edit 19/2 - Second Game[/i][/b] This game was played on level 2 difficulty. I defeated the pirates and still had some food left to celebrate.
The cards were much nicer to me today. When I wanted to get rid of cards, I always seemed to be the correct distance behind the goal to get rid of the cards without having spare discarded food. The only bad draw (if you can call it that) I had involved going for a goal of 4 and drawing a -2 aging card followed by a Stop aging card. This caused me to lose 6 food but I did discard both aging cards in one go.
In the red phase I managed to gain food and ended up facing the pirates with 8 food remaining. The pirates proved a little challenging as I had to spend 6 food but both were beaten.
Score: 41 for fighting cards, -5 for aging card, 30 for pirates, 10 for remaining life, -21 for hazard cards. Total = 56
:thumbsup: - The four different difficulty levels mean that the game remains a challenge even after mastering one difficulty. :thumbsdown: - The game takes too long for me to have 2 plays on my lunch break.

Newer cooperative game built on the same theme as Pandemic but executed with dice instead of cards. Each role has their own unique set of dice while infection dice are rolled to see where the infections are occuring.
Played with 4 characters - Generalist, Scientist, Contingency Planner and Containment Specialist. Lost due to outbreaks.
Really like this so far, quickly has become my go-to solo game when I have 30-40 minutes.

[size=16][b]Not-so-Secret Origin Story[/b][/size]
When I was a teenager I joined my class for an outing at the local science center. They were demonstrating their ability to control radioactive rays in the lab. It was fascinating but then things got a little fuzzy, I vaguely recall being bit by a spider.... wait, no that's not it.
Back in Feb/Mar 2013 I bought a copy of Thunderbolt Apache Leader, this was my first Solo only game though I had some others that accommodated one player (like Space Empires 4X and Arkham Horror). I had been checking out some DVG titles because I was interested in a war game that I could play against an AI rather than playing both sides and I had fun with the solo option in SE4X. I really enjoyed TAL and so I started looking into other solo game options. I won a copy of Friday in May that year from G4GG and started looking at games with an eye toward 1-player compatibility. Later that year my wife and I were excited to find we were expecting so I accelerated my search for more solo options, figuring my game group nights would become more limited. This led to winning a copies of Ogre Pocket and The Wreck of the B.S.M Pandora again from G4GG plus pre-ordering Robinson Crusoe and putting Marvel Legendary on my radar.
In April 2014 our son was born and my parents gave me a copy of Silverton for my birthday. I believe that month I also joined the 1-Player Guild which led me to finding this geeklist. My first post was for a handful of Silverton plays and I still enjoy playing it.
I keep coming back because it's a great community of players and where else can you get this kind of social interaction for a relatively lonely gaming niche? :D
:redtrain::greentrain::bluetrain::yellowtrain::blacktrain::purpletrain::whitetrain:
So on to my Marvel play... I received the GotG expansion for Christmas and hadn't checked it out yet so I decided to try a game with Thanos, Starlord, Rocket and Groot with the Unite the Shards Scheme. The shards add an interesting element to the game. I failed to win because Thanos picked up more than 10 shards, I wasn't paying attention to what he had and I thought I could get one more turn in to attack him directly before another event caused him to gain more - I should have known better.
It was good, I like what the shards add and the new characters & schemes to explore. I also decided that I'm going to try to play strictly by the "Golden" solo rules for my next few plays to see how that is versus the regular advanced solo rules. I checked them out before when I just had the base game but I picked up Dark City and started using those rules shortly thereafter so I don't recall how I liked them. However, seeing a few people saying recently that's all they use makes me want to check them out again.

item.body:
Kyle invited us to recall our [b] [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/186592/item/3710900#item3710900]origin game[/url][/b] entrance in SGOYT list and Stig proposed to play it again as a [b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/186592/item/3710910#item3710910]challenge[/b][/url] and to compare the feelings between today and the origin.
Even if I knew the SoS games by VPG (and have a lot of them in my game collection) I entered DotZ univers very late because I'm NOT a Zombies fan AT ALL! [i]and I'd rather play a game when I've got, at least a slight, interest for the theme. [/i]
I recall pretty clearly my first contact with DotZ. It was a disaster (after something like 10 cards, the Zombies were in Town) and spectacular: I found it cinematographic! How could I found a Zombie Game cinematographic without having watched a single Zombies' movie ?
That's the fabulous sweet spot of DotZ: [b]this game knows how to tell a story! [/b]
Your playing units are Heroes and villagers.
The first ones have very different abilities and offer a large number of options to choose from each time (of course, you just can't do even the tenth of what you wished.... Where would be the pleasure if you hadn't meaningful choices to make on your turn?). The seconds are really a pain: they will stick into their respective villages, totally carefree, until the Zombies knock at their doors. Then, they will either defend their lands to death (which will come soon - some are pretty weak) or flee as refugees to find protection in Town and infect town's population.
It's a survival game with many combats. The combats against Zombies are resolved with die rolls (integrating various strengths and defensive/offensive factors: there is a tactical impact there). I do protest loudly sometimes when the dice are against me. Something I rarely do, except while playing Ambush!
[i][b]Today, I played another game of DoTZ. [/b][/i]
Quiet beginning. After some turns, no more Zeds on the suburbs track and the mountain track. Johnson was having a great time foraging for supplies while Agee was busy on her microscope researching for the Super-Weapon in the Laboratory. Mayor Hernandez was taking care of the city business while Carter was on the road again.
It was almost too peaceful to be true. At some point, I was fearing the lack of pressure....
And then, in few turns, it became frantic: a disaster occurred into the lab. My heroes were not specially good at gun-firing: they wasted so many ammo missing their targets. Bubbas' band entered Farmingdale countryside through the highway track; Carter was hoping to fight back with his gambling gamers' luck, but couldn't make it. Johnson missed his target (a big fat 8 strength Zeds) and the last fleeing refugees on the Forest track were eaten. Infection level increased: outbreak occurred.
After that, I lost control: Johnson with a useless gun - no more ammo - had to fight a hand-to-hand Combat and died. Zombies were everywhere, coming out of the tunnel. One could hear the mysterious Dr Marteuse laughing.
I ended up losing again with Zombies in Town before the National Guard could rescue me.
[b]How did it feel compare to the first game I played last year? Just as much fun as ever![/b] :D
[i]Edit: numerous spelling, and I'm sure I still missed some...[/i]
item.comment: Great post, Koinsky! Thanks so much. Hermann

Sounds like your experience with DotZ was exactly the same as mine: I had quite a few other SoS titles and ignored this because of the theme and the seemingly endless stream of zombie themed games that were being produced. I finally decided to try DotZ because of many favourable reviews and I'm so glad I did: I was blown away by the narrative potential of the game. It's since then easily become my favourite SoS because the stories each game tell are so enthralling and varied, and because the game is so much fun to play.
I made a comment a while ago on a DotZ session report that I no longer think in terms of winning or losing this game, instead I just enjoy how each story develops. It's quite rare for a game to achieve that.
I recommend picking up the Director's Cut if you haven't already done so. It adds a couple of new heroes, some new super Zeds, but most importantly a stack of additional cards with other stories to tell. :)

item.body:
I've been really lax about posting in the past few weeks, partially because we're seeing the effects of global cooling in MA - over 60" of snow in 9 days had me digging out, again, and again.
I received my copy of BIOS Megafauna the other night and after a long day of shoveling I needed to relax and try to get my latest game to the table. I watched Ricky's play of this to get an idea on how to play before diving into the rules, and that made this game very accessible.
So far, I'm into the second of the 4 ages of gameplay and my species are thriving well. I've mutated one of the dinosaurs to an amphibian that is nocturnal and is armored/aggressive. That's helping me to enter quite a few areas. I encountered a disaster early on which increased the temperature of the world, but didn't have any issue surviving - it did limit the AI significantly, so we'll see how that plays out. After the first age, I scored 3 points from the tarpit, and the AI took 2 points.
I'm really enjoying the theme of this gameplay and watching the world develop and trying to adapt to the everchanging environment. It's still early for me to rate this in my collection, but I've got the same enamored feeling that I had with Navajo Wars when I first played that game, so I have a feeling that this will be one that sees repeated plays.
UPDATE: I finished my first game which almost ended in an Ice age, but I realized that erosion can't happen when the environment is at 200, so I lucked out as I would have scored 9 to 4 which would have been 1 shy of a win - but I was fortunate and ended the game 13 to 7.
Now to reset and try again :D
item.comment: Do you have the latest rules? They're much better than what's in the box.

Yes - I'm playing with the living rules - regardless though it's a typical Eklund style rulebook, which to me is somewhat difficult to get through. I also had some issue with Pax Porfiriana when I started playing it, but then it made sense once I played the game a few times. In general I've accepted that I'll make mistakes playing his games when I'm learning them, but around the 4-5th play I expect to have 95%+ of the rules learned.
That's what keeps me away from some wargames - that and the mountain of chits to manage. I do play a few, but the amount in my collection is pretty limited (maybe attempting to play A Dark Valley was not a good idea as one of my first few wargames) ;)

[q="eastwoodk"]That's what keeps me away from some wargames - that and the mountain of chits to manage. I do play a few, but the amount in my collection is pretty limited (maybe attempting to play A Dark Valley was not a good idea as one of my first few wargames) ;)[/q]
A Dark Valley is not too bad. The activation chits really break up the action into manageable chunks.
Winning as the Germans in the Barbarossa scenario is really difficult.

My first issue with ADV was the size of the map - was larger than my table would allow. Then I didn't have plexi for the map, so stacking near the creases was a pain. The setup took me an hour to figure out. I got through a few turns, boxed it up and traded it away. I'm sure somewhere in the future I may attempt again as I liked the look of the map, and the action chits were a good idea; but managing that many stacks was too unwieldy for me. I actually sold Antiquity for the same reason (even though I loved the game) - too many chits.
My wargames are currently limited to Red Winter, Nuklear Winter '68, some DVG games (TAL, HL:CAO, Field Commander and a few others). Fields of Fire is on my wishlist, but I'm trying to be good about that this year.
I also tried block wargames with Sekigahara, but soloing that game was not something that worked for me.
When VPG releases the new edition of [thing=62972][/thing], you should definitely check it out. Small footprint, Eastern Front and....solitaire!

item.objectname: Shadows of Brimstone: City of the Ancients
item.body:
I got my pieces assembled, and while I have the desire to get them all painted, I have a stronger desire to start playing this game. [b] Campaign 1 - Prologue [/b] [i]US Marshal, Peter Gosler, enjoys his beer at the local saloon. The beer and girls, as nice a distraction as they can be, are not his primary attraction. While there, two Navajo men he has had his eye on for some time are conversing in a darker, corner table of the establishment.
Then he sees it, an exchange. Evidence enough for Pete to take the next step. The two Navajo men, stand and part ways. Marshal Gosler tails his primary mark, a Navajo, removed from the tribe, and removed from town, a local outcast who answers to the name John Redfeather.
Redfeather leads Pete to a run down shack, presumably his dwelling, and enters through a rusty corrugated metal door. Light begins to flicker through a window as Redfeather lights the lamps within. Pete, creeps to the window and peeks in, to see John Redfeather, staring blankly into a chunk of black crystal, which seems to be casting an eerie purple aura on John's face.
John, with preternatural senses, turns to see the Marshal peering through the window, transfixed by the soft, eerie, crystal shard. Not knowing the voyeur is a Marshal, raises his rifle at the man, demanding him off his land.
Pete, slowly raises his badge into view. The motion had it's desired outcome. If not preventing, at least delaying a violent outcome to this encounter.
Forgetting his job, drawn to the stone...Pete can only mutter, "What is that dark stone?"
"It is not yours. Forget you saw it, and get off my land." John demands, putting the crystal into a bag.
Regaining his senses, Pete sees the piles of coin and cash on the table.
"Look, it's not what you think. I found a vein of the crystal in a nearby mine, and have found some men willing to buy it. There is nothing illegal going on."
"Take me to this vein, show me, and I will leave you alone." [/i]
[b]Session 1 - Exploration - Threat Low[/b]
[i]The two men enter the mine. Redfeather moves ahead, eager to prove his story to Gosler. He turns a corner, momentarily out of sight from Goslerâ¦when Pete turns the corner, a great crab like creature lurks in the cornerâ¦feeding on something on the ground. Redfeather fires his rifle masterfully, getting off three shots in seconds, two of which connect center mass and the third blasting off a claw. The creature drops before it can make a move towards the pair.
âWhat the hell?â Peter barely had time to comprehend what he saw. âCome, stay togetherâ Redfeather beckons.
As they wind their way deeper into the mine, Peter is overwhelmed by a horrible stench, and begins to wretch so violently, his vomit is blood streaked.
âUp hereâ John leads, unphased.
A glowing aura around the bend is bouncing its light off the cavern wall. Turning the corner, Peter canât believe his eyes. A swirling pool of light, suspended near the wall of the room.
âWhat is that?â He asks.
âThe door to the evil spirit world, it has opened, and remains so. The black crystals in this mine draw evil here.â
âCome, the deposit is this wayâ
The men enter a final cavernous room, with a huge piles of bones, animal, human, unhuman strewn about, and a vein of the black crystal visible on a far wall.
A strange clicking sound, alerts the two men. A half dozen or so of huge crustaceous spiders, with huge gaping mouths on their abdomens, skitter with great speed at the men. They have no time to react, and both are overwhelmed.
[imageid=2401913 medium]
Two of the spiders manage to knock Pete to one knee as they rear up, kicking with their forelegs and gnash with their strangely placed mouths. Two more swarm on John. Both men take large gashes from the claws on the spiders kicking forelegs. Redfeather lets a series of bullets fly, dropping two of the spiders. Likewise, Pete unleashes his shotgun and also drops 2. The spiders donât seem to know what is good for them and the remaining 2 clamber over the corpses of their bretheren, but both meet the same fate. The men approach the deposit.
Redfeather runs his hand across it.
Suddenly John pulls his hand back, as if it was hot, or caused painâ¦..
[/i]

item.objectname: Thud Ridge: A Solitaire Game of the Air War over North Vietnam
item.body:
Solo...of course!:thumbsup:
Vietnam air war featuring USAF F-105 and F-4 missions over North Vietnam. Air to ground missions and air to air when those pesky Migs rise to the occasion.
Fun with good detail but not complex. During my first mission I experienced a "dud Thud" and lost a pilot...but made up for it when one of my escorting F-4s downed a Mig-17.
Print and Play -- some don't like these but I do since they are cheaper and I can buy more games with my bucks. Very good quality for print and play.
Earned the "Swamp Hamster Seal of Approval" since my dad served as an RF-4 crew chief in 1965-1966...and an RF-101 crew chief during the Cuban Missile Crisis -- thus my icon in his honor.
Good game.:thumbsup:

item.body:
I played two more games of Infection. This game is such a treat and I enjoy it so much. It's becoming quick and it's so easy to pull off the shelf and bust through a game.
One of the things I've started to enjoy is the different ways the virus spreads from game to game. My first game, the virus spread rather slowly, so it was fairly easy to keep everything under control. It was a good victory and I never felt like I was losing. In the second game the virus mutated at an alarming rate. I had molecules on the C-Ring starting on the very first turn and I was never able to clear it out. The randomness of the card draws makes for almost a different scenario every time I play. In the first game I had a slow-building, smart virus that was taking its time to work its way through the world's population. In the second game, I fought against a raging, hate-filled disease who cared only about spreading itself to its next victim. The second game felt like I was bracing myself against a door folding off the inevitable horde trying to break through.
I also tried the lab equipment rental variant. That was really fun. It forced me to care for my lab equipment rather than hope I was successful but didn't worry if I wasnt.
I think I'm going to start using the paper map because the middle puzzle piece has begun to stick up. It's a bummer because I like the puzzle piece map, but the paper map seems really nice quality.
