item.objectname: Escape: The Curse of the Temple â Big Box
item.body:
I had never tried this game before the Kickstarter for the Big Box started, but I grabbed an early bird slot on account of my absolute LOVE for [b][thing=38453][/thing][/b] and this being another real-time co-op game, albeit less thinky. The game arrived over my birthday weekend a few days ago, and I finally made the time to play it today.
I played four times in total (that's one of the perks of a real-time game; they're usually pretty short): two plays using the basic tiles, and two plays using Curses & Treasures and 10 gems in the depot. For the first couple of plays, I was pretty underwhelmed, although I understand that I was pretty much playing the game on "family mode." The latter two were much more challenging and enjoyable--the first time I played with Curses and 10 gems, I escaped at the same moment the temple collapsed. I'm counting it as a win, although it really was down to the wire (it depends on when you consider an action completed--I rolled the keys needed before the soundtrack ended, but I didn't actually pick up and reroll the dice used to escape until [i]after[/i] the sound effect for the collapse).
I am very much looking forward to trying out the other expansions and Queenies and then working through the [b][filepage=93450]26 Challenges[/filepage][/b] in order. The Mayan Calender Queenie also looks like it will change up the game in a significant way.
:thumbsup: Quick to play thanks to the real-time nature.
:thumbsup: Those curses make discovering new chambers something to dread--in my first two plays, I figured out that it was always a good idea to discover a bunch of chambers before the first gong and then go through and activate gems. Playing with the curses module made me quickly abandon that strategy.
:thumbsup: Lots of variety with the Big Box and Kickstarter promos. Most of it is solo friendly (pretty much everything except Linked Chambers, one of the promo quests, and some curses/treasures).
:thumbsdown: You can tell it's better with a group.
:thumbsdown: I kept getting the curse where I had to put one hand on my forehead.
:thumbsdown: I am clumsy and keep accidentally flipping dice when picking up a different group to reroll.
:thumbsdown: Not nearly as good as Space Alert.

I have very different feelings about the Le Havre solo game out of the box as opposed to Agricola out of the box. I'm not sure why but will need to work out why
Also, Le Havre really is easier to play with little containers.
[imageid=2402257 medium]
Le Havre and Ora et Labora are somewhat related in that they both use double-sided goods tiles, a fiddly thing that I'm glad didn't pop up again in the Harvest Heptalogy. Other than that, I am amused watching some of the trends that started in Agricola either continue, get mutated, or be removed entirely.
But Le Havre has always been a difficult game for me to figure out. I don't feel particularly attached to the theme (in fact, I feel entirely apathetic for it). And for whatever reason, I definitely feel more pressure to feed my people than I did in Agricola, which isn't a great feeling for me because Agricola is already stressful enough that way.
I finished filming and editing the first video for "The Good, the Bad, and the Solo"; it'll go up on Thursday. In the meanwhile, need to get in one more play of Core Worlds with Galactic Orders (SoloPlay variant) and then start the instructional video.
The lateral arm arrived along with the tripod of doom, and the test overhead videos are very successful. The lighting needs to be improved, so I sent away for some better bulbs.
I now have an empty room upstairs that I should start filling with shelves filled with games at some point.
item.comment:
Another one of those games that keeps staring at me sadly from the game shelf. This sums up our relationship.

item.body:
[b][thread=1312771][/thread][/b]
I just had a play of this. Don't have the brainpower to write a story yet, but here's my setup:
Ship: Supply Bot Base: Brain World My Authority: 16 Beast's Authority: -20
That leaves me with a score of 36.
After rapidly trimming my deck, I tried to build a Blob fleet defended by some Trade Federation outposts. Note that I was playing with some cards from the Crisis expansions, which may have made things a bit easier.

Final game of the... really early morning over here.
[imageid=2402456 medium]
Pathetic score of 224. The score jump from Agricola's double-digits to Le Havre's and later on Ora et Labora's triple-digits is a bit of scoring whiplash. I think I played a little bit wrong, since I only did settlement after pushing the little teal house, so that score is not a true score, which makes me very sad.
I didn't get around to earning any of the 30pt VP tiles, but I did manage to build all but 1 of my settlements thanks to use of the neutral player's castle.
Ora et Labora's official solo variant feels rough around the edges. Of all the Harvest Heptalogy, Ora et Labora feels as though it has the most exceptions to the multiplayer game. I mean, even the two-player game has exceptions to the 4- and 3-player game, and then the solo game builds further exceptions on top of the two-player game.
The double-sided goods tiles leads to more interesting dynamics when upgrading goods (the upgrades are particularly interesting in Ora et Labora), and Ora et Labora starts the "everything is laid out before you" stage in the Harvest Heptalogy, except Ora does it in stages, whereas later games like Caverna and Fields of Arle just bombard you with everything from the get-go.
I think Fields of Arle does this sort of thing better than previous games in the series; Fields feels like the most refined of the series.
But hey, I should really save all this analysis for upcoming videos.
item.comment: I really like the theme of this and have really enjoyed Loyang. I've not gotten in to Agricola much yet and I think Glass Road is kind of fun. I also know this is hard to find. Should I consider it?

There is... probably a reason why every other Rosenberg game is still in print and Ora et Labora is not. I think... I think, and I say this despite loving Rosenberg's games in general... I think it's forgettable.
The little wheels mechanic in Glass Road and the wheel mechanic in Le Havre: The Inland Port both come from Ora et Labora, but Ora's implementation was... rougher around the edges.
Imagine if you will this: every resource has a marker on the wheel, like in Glass Road, all on one side of the wheel. But in Glass Road, you have a tight hold on resources. In Ora, you often end up with excess resources (like 7-10 of over half the things); kind of like if the 3 wood space in Agricola was on steroids and applied for every resource. So in solo, there is rarely a feeling that you can't do enough with what you have, which is why the [i]normal[/i] goal is 400 points (the "astonishing" goal is never even mentioned).
In fact, Rosenberg had to remove two of the resource markers to give challenge to the solo game: ore and grapes. It kind of irks me in a way, but I have to agree with the design decision. Ora suffers the most in the Harvest series in solo, because the lack of competition is that much more obvious and detrimental to the tension.
Still, obviously Ora is not a walk in the park; you have to be able to handle the various paths to victory and not get confused or inefficient. The buildings are fun, you can definitely get some interesting engines up and going, and if you choose different paths each time, fun can be had for quite some time. And it's a very relaxed kind of game. I mean, you're monks making alcohol. Tension would be kind of wrong from a theme perspective.
To consider also: the 3-4 player game plays very different from the 2-player game which plays very different from the solo game. Of all the games in the Harvest series, the difference is the most palpable. Rosenberg really had to hack things up to make solo workâand I do appreciate this, since Rosenberg seems to always try to fit solo into his games, which is rare enough in eurogame/amerithrash design.
I like this theme far better than Le Havre's, but I would rather play Le Havre, and I don't like Le Havre.
I would say... unless you find Ora for trade and are giving away what you feel is a mediocre game for it... I would not try very hard to get it. Others will feel differently of course, but that's just my take on the matter.

item.objectname: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.body:
My first post on SGoYT for my first two plays of LOTR:LCG. Using the preset decks against the first scenario.
Game 1 Tactics and Lore Took forever! Much longer than I expected at around 2.5 hours. Bearing in mind I was learning it still seemed to drag. I couldn't get past the first quest. Only one hero died and I managed an eventual win. Not sure about the exact score as I forgot to keep track of the number of rounds. My guess is somewhere near 200.
Game 2 Leadership and spirit Much quicker! The first draw from the encounter deck didn't hinder my questing, so I went for it as quick as I could, completing the game within 4 rounds. Score: 123. The only thing I noticed with this combo is there didn't seem a way to restore health but I didn't get through many cards.
Early impressions are this is a very smooth game. Having only bought the core set last week I'm already considering expansions. That's before I've even started deck building which will probably absorb as much time as playing!
item.comment: Welcome! It took me a while to get to love this one, but now I definitely do. Can't wait to hear about your quests through the expansions! :sauron:
Welcome! Always glad to see another LotR LCG player!
Welcome!

item.body:
...because I am nothing if not determined.
Game eight, a successful abort (yep, that built in lose condition that affords you one karma point to the survivors). I only need three such similar losses before my ork and troll can buy their first upgrade. At which point I get to have a conniption about defacing the player cards with stickers. (Still one of the dumbest design decisions of recent times; I'm probably just going to be writing on a photocopy... Thank you, OCD.)
I had some decent teamwork going on, this time, and I was more confident than usual. I'm beginning to enjoy this more, now I've accepted there's a bizarre imbalance in the gameplay. I was interested to see rahdo is filming a mock-up of the designer's play through - presumably to show the game is possible to us mere mortals. I find this all rather odd, I have to admit. It feels like damage control - or brand loyalty on Richard's part... I wonder if he feels he has to defend his game of the year shout? Bit strange, I mean it's not like a typical kickstarter shill, is it?
Anyway... Made it into the third act, bought a first aid kit, healed up a point each for both characters... and would have played the health kit to heal the ork to three points, when I drew a crossfire which automatically gives everyone a wound. Ork is staggered again, before the bloody round begins. Lose your hand, draw one card on your turn. Wonderful. Sure, the crossfire card had a name and some flavour text - but let's just call it the "automatic lose card". Couldn't make a single point of damage on the ork's obstacles, which then hit him for five points of damage. He goes critical, but the troll survived the abort round.
All, of course, utterly random and unavoidable. Although "random" implies the luck will swing my way, some times. It hasnt yet, in eight games.

I'm with you about writing on the cards - I stuck the stickers to chipboard and cut them out, so I just place the on the cards when I want to use them for an advanced scenario - and actually sometimes randomly draw them from a bag with a total "points" to spend. I don't think that's the issue we're discussing at all.
For me, I think he's made some odd judgement calls of late - but opinions, and all that. I love his earlier videos, when it's just a man indulging in a hobby he loves (I'm so grateful for his Death Angel video, for example). But once he started panhandling on kickstarter to get fans to support his hobby, I think there was a sea-change in his videos.
Pretty much any kickstarter final thought that begins with his ubiquitous, "Wow!" is typically such fawning tripe that it just smacks of not biting the hand that feeds him. His ideas about telling designers how to improve their games also smacks of someone who's buying into the whole cult of himself.
I just find it a little jarring, these days. I mean, watch one of those stooges on the home shopping channel talking about some nonsense they have to sell, for twenty minutes, then play a final thoughts for a kickstarter deal he's worked. They're nearly indistinguishable. He's become kickstarter's snake oil salesman, for me, at least.

I had no idea that Rahdo was cutting deals with kickstarter projects and then posting final thoughts as though... as though they weren't made with a conflict of interest. There's a reason the Dice Tower previews, while they lasted, and the Board Game Brawl previews now, specifically say "This is a preview, we aren't giving a review."
Granted any reviewer will get free review copies, but somehow that feels less under-the-table. Probably because at least with a free review copy, that game is published and available for public consumption, whereas with a Kickstarter everything is still... fluffy and might not even make it wherever it wants to go.
Kickstarter is a space where reviewers need to be very careful about opinions. Very, very, very careful. Be honestly blunt, or don't bother with an opinion.

To be fair to Rahdo, he has always been upfront that if he dislikes a game, he will get in touch with the publisher to check if they are okay with him posting a negative video. He has publicly stated this and there is even a thread about it somewhere here on BGG. Given this, I don't find it surprising at all that all (or at least, the overwhelming majority) of his videos are positive. Particularly for a Kickstarter game, I don't see any of the publishers agreeing to let him publish a negative video and negatively impact the KS just as it launches.
The other way I view it is to look at the kinds of games that he gushes about. The games he likes are generally in the Euro style (versus AT style) and his preference seems to be for strong mechanics which encourage lots of tough decisions. By way of example, while I have never played Shadows of Brimstone, what I have read about it would tell me that Rahdo would probably dislike the game (the only possible saving grace for him might be the level up campaign mechanics which he seems to love). Granted, this isn't a given as he has liked some AT games in the past but its very clear that he generally prefers Euro style games. And sure enough, most of the KS games he gushes about are Euro style.
As to him giving his thoughts on what to change to improve the game. His background is that of video game development. Is it any surprise he has lots of opinions on how games (albeit tabletop games in this case) should be developed?
I hear what you are saying (at least, I think I do). I just don't see any of your points as being extraordinary or surprising given his background and likes/dislikes.

For every positive KS game I cover, there's at least 10 other projects that I said "no" to because I knew I wouldn't enjoy them and therefore didn't want to take the time to learn, play and film them.
[q]His ideas about telling designers how to improve their games also smacks of someone who's buying into the whole cult of himself. [/q] Believe me, that's not the case at all. It's why I repeatedly say in my videos that people should completely ignore my opinion and draw their own conclusions based on the gameplay vids I do. Nothing makes me happier than the fact that only 50% of the folks who watch Rahdo Runs Through ever bother with final thoughts vids. I'd be ecstatic if that percentage got down to 0% :)
[q]I just find it a little jarring, these days. I mean, watch one of those stooges on the home shopping channel talking about some nonsense they have to sell, for twenty minutes, then play a final thoughts for a kickstarter deal he's worked. They're nearly indistinguishable. He's become kickstarter's snake oil salesman, for me, at least. [/q] Sorry you feel that way, but again, I'm only sharing my genuine enthusiasm for games that I enjoy, and unlike QVC folks, I'm not getting paid by the maker of the product to say what I say.
[q="BilboAtBagEnd"]I had no idea that Rahdo was cutting deals with kickstarter projects and then posting final thoughts as though... as though they weren't made with a conflict of interest.[/q] That's because I don't cut any deals. I receive nothing for the videos I do. More often than not, I don't even get a final copy of the game (just making do with the prototypes I receive). I do those videos totally for free (and for the record, I'm just about the only video reviewer out there who doesn't get paid for KS videos, and have taken heat from other reviewers in the past for making things tougher for them when they do ask for payments while I do it gratis).
As an aside, I also don't turn on ads for my videos either, which is probably $5000/year I don't receive in ad revenues, because I think youtube ads suck . AFAIK, I'm the only video reviewer who takes this stance as well :)
[q="repairmanjack"]Just for sake of clarity, the phrase "cutting deals" wasn't intended to imply that I thought he was getting cash and so forth. (Although I don't know either way.)[/q] All is revealed here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1023680/full-disclosure
[q]I read "won't admit he got it wrong" not as him refusing to admit he doesn't like it - not at all - but that when he enthuses about how brilliantly it all works and the intricate balance, etc., that he's wrong about that.[/q] Well, IMO, I think I'm right. The fact that the designers can win 90% of the time when they play proves (unless one thinks they're lying) that the game is more about skill than random luck. Random luck killing you means you made moves earlier in the game that led you to be unprepared for those events. In the strategy video I posted, in the final wave, one of the worst crossfire cards in the game got drawn, and they shrugged it off as no big deal, because they were prepared because of earlier strategic moves he made :)
[q]Ten games in, I can't beat the tutorial. Many others have screamed it isn't effectively play-tested, long before that threshold. Of course, none of us may be right... but his illustrative videos of "this is how the designer is playing it - and winning" smacks of bullshit (on the designer's part) because they can stack the deck any way they like.[/q] The designer made clear that he did *not* stack the deck at all... in fact, he actually increased the difficulty by drawing a bunch of different starting obstacles and picking the toughest combination that came up.
[q]I'm curious why he feels the need to add to the "spin" on this one.[/q] How do you mean?

[q="rahdo"]As an aside, I also don't turn on ads for my videos either, which is probably $5000/year I don't receive in ad revenues, because I think youtube ads suck . AFAIK, I'm the only video reviewer who takes this stance as well [/q] You know, I gotta give you huge props for that. It crossed my mind recently that I expected you to be doing that. As someone who recently started doing videos, it also crossed my mind what would I do if one day I got big enough with 1,000s of subscribers - would I monetize my Youtube stuff? Gotta be tempting, especially as I had no idea it could be $5,000, but I also think those ads suck. But that won't happen most likely as I'm focusing on solitaire games and not doing the cult of the new stuff you need to do to get hugely popular.
And while I'm here, when I was starting out last fall, I emailed you and Joel E. with some newb video question about what camera you use. Joel got back and was extremely helpful whereas you didn't reply. You seem pretty down to earth and like the type who's not protective of turf, so I chalked it up to not checking your geekmail, but FYI a short reply to help out a newb would've been cool. Or maybe you stated somewhere you don't reply to questions like that and I missed it.

[b][COLOR=#009900]Result: 39 VP, Standoff[/COLOR][/b] [c] 0 = Non-Medal Heroes 2 = Medal Heroes 21 = Hit Markers 0 = Burning Buildings 6 = iButho Casualties 10 = Relief Column Card[/c]
The last time I sat down to play this game, I lost three times in 20 minutes. It was over so fast, I only counted them as one play in my log. Tonight, I got through the deck for the first time. Woot! And I missed a Minor Victory by 1 VP. So close! Instead, I end with a Standoff (a draw, basically).
[ImageID=2403358medium]
Of course, I'm wondering what I did wrong this time to have actually made it through the deck. And then I wonder...do I even want to figure out what it might be?! I had fun, and that's what I was looking for when I picked up this game.
Zulus can be randomly punishing, so you need to know that going in, or you'll just end up as a ball of frustration, lying in the corner, shaking. Between the chit draw and the dice for resolution, it can get ugly. I mean, [b]twice[/b], I rolled [i]five[/i] dice for combat and only had [i]one[/i] success. Grrrr.
Overall, I do like the game and actually getting to play the whole thing was really nice. Typical Gold Banner components from VPG with thick tokens and standees. The cards don't have much in the way of artwork, but the historical text is really interesting and improves the experience, IMO.
[ImageID=2403359medium]
The game is about management...of your cards and the four tracks the iButhos follow. You need to decide when to use a normal Volley or when to sacrifice one of your Heroes to stay alive. Using the special actions of the Heroes as much as you can before their time comes is key.
And, of course, a semi-favorable chit draw at the start of your turn doesn't hurt either. That was a major difference between tonight's play and the last one. Here, I had a nice mix of movement chits in the early game. Whereas the last time, I had the same track moving multiple spaces every turn.
It's a good game. You just have to be ready for a potentially random game experience. But when it comes together for you, it makes a great time at the game table.

Got this in the mail yesterday and had a go against the "Training Dummy". I won 35 to 27.
Interesting game, not sure it will hold my interest as a solitaire game, but for the price if I get a few plays out of it, I'll be happy.

I brought this back to the table as I felt like running up a tech tree tonight. I was able to score 64 points - 2 shy of the highest winning condition. In general I think the scaling of the final scores needs to be adjusted slightly - my first play was at the highest winning condition; so between the few times I've played it I've always finished 1st or 2nd in rankings. I'm wondering if it's even possible to score a novice of 20 - perhaps I'll try to see the minimum points I can score to get through the game next time ;)

I played a solo game of this 2-handed without the solo variant that's posted on the geek, as I received this in trade and didn't have the additional "spare" blank tokens that would have come with the game - I'm sure I'll come up with another substitute for that in the future.
In general the game played really well -and at one point it looked like I had a big gap / runaway with one of the players, but in the end the score differential was only 1 point - and that's something that I understood the game to be - a very tight, non-random experience.
Overall I was quite satisfied with my first play of the game and will try to fit in a few more over the coming months (if only all the shoveling wasn't taking up my game time!).

item.body:
I'll go into more detail below on different aspects that I want to talk about. This was a session on Easy with the scenario Misdirection. The base was destroyed at the end of Round 3, which was way too early again.
I'm fine with the rules now, but the strategy is eluding me, especially with regards to keeping up the Soldier reserves (and consequently Funding).
[u]The short of it[/u] :thumbsup: Awesome game, even if you get it just for solitaire play, with plenty of replayability. :thumbsdown: Strategy is eluding me. :thumbsdown: Intimidated by the prospect of painting the Soldiers.
[u]The long of it[/u] [b]Thoughts on Painting[/b] I suppose it was unavoidable that at some point I would try my hand at painting mini's again. In my long gaming history, I have started up and subsequently abandoned a handful of painting projects. The last one was some three or four years ago, when I bought Blood Bowl and a whole bunch of paints, brushes and accessories for painting up that game.
Though I sold off Blood Bowl, I held on to those supplies. I must say that the Citadel paints are of such high quality, that they are still as good as they were the day I bought them. They are a mix of the old and new line, and contain the right colours to start off easy with the Interceptors.
[center][ImageID=2403812medium][/center] I used a white primer, Chainmail base coat, Nuln Oil wash, and Longbeard Grey drybrush. I'm satisfied with the result, though I was (re)learning as I went along. The Interceptors don't "pop" as much as I would like them to, but they certainly have a lot more definition compared to when they were unpainted.
So now on to the possibly even easier UFO's, which I will paint red. And then I'll have to see what I do with the Soldiers. There is a lot of detail on them, and even if I go the easier route and keep most of the body in the same color, painting face and hair details terrifies me. We'll see.
[b]Thoughts on Tablespace[/b] I game a lot in the living room, using an 80x60cm board and sometimes an additional side table. I can get most games played that way. [thing=163602]XCOM[/thing] is no exception, though I learned a lot running through the Tutorial about how to best organize the game.
[center][ImageID=2403811medium][/center] Even when playing the Tutorial, I already left the Role Summary cards in the box. And after finishing it, I realized there is no point in using even the larger Reserve cards. The individual Roles become meaningless when playing solitaire. And it freed me up to organize the components in such a way that I can get to what I need, when I need it. That's crucial for running through the Timed phase as efficiently as possible.
In that regard, the limited tablespace helps me organize the components. I use the gameboard for quite a few of them, like Satellites and Scientists on the Base space, UFO's above the Recruitment box, Credit tokens in the Recruitment box, and Interceptors next to the scenario box. Enemy and Crisis decks are also on the gameboard.
Then next to the gameboard, closest to me, are all the things that are needed during the Timed Phase. I do use the Squad Leader Reserve cards, because they contain the matching Task symbols for the four different Soldier types. Other than that, besides two draw decks (Tech and Missions), I just lay out the Asset and Tech cards for the Timed Phase at my edge of the playing area. Resolution phase cards go up top, and I even stack them after using them, so that they don't distract me. This setup is working fine for me now, though I may make a tweak or two.
[b]Thoughts on Gameplay[/b] This is easy: I love this game. It's beating me up, but I love the challenge. There is inherent replayability right there for me, as I learn how to get better at this game. There is a strong resource management aspect to this game. Funds convert to units of different types, and managing the flow of those funds and units, is something that I need to learn. Besides getting to grips with the resource management aspect, there is a lot of replayability in the base game itself: 4 difficulty levels (excluding the Tutorial) and 5 scenario's to choose from.
On top of the resource management is the typical FFG stuff: mounting tension on different fronts, randomness from card draws and die rolls (though for especially the latter there are many Tech cards that help you manage the results), and great components. It isn't much different from many of their other games, in that it throws anything it can at you, the player, to make you lose your balance, slip up, and fall.
[b]Thoughts on the App[/b] Where FFG would normally use decks of cards to lace a game with unpredictability, they created an app. It does basically two things: Create tension by having the player perform various actions on a clock, thereby increasing chances for mistakes. Those mistakes won't be fatal, and I don't know yet how they actually effect the game, but they do have an effect. So far I suspect on diminishing Funds and a growing number of Crises (which can be utterly brutal).
The second thing the app does, is supporting said unpredictability with an obfuscated layer of adaptability. At the end of a Round, you have to input certain aspects of the game state, and the app takes that information, no doubt with a dollop of randomness, to determine what comes out during the Timed Phase in the following Round. I don't care how exactly that works. All I know is that it works, and it's a whole lot of fun. And there is no way that this could be done with physical components, without adding huge amounts of overhead in both components, cost and gametime.
On Easy mode the Timed Phase gave me plenty of time. Only once did I run out, but as I understand it there are no additional consequences when running out of time. In Normal mode the game won't be so lenient on me, but I will only attempt it when I have won at least once on Easy mode. The Timed Phase is stressful, but I can handle it, because the game as a whole is so much fun to play.
Lastly, the App is very well designed. I have run it on my Android smartphone, and everything was legible and clear. It's even better on a tablet (an iPad in the playing area picture). I have had no problems with looking up rules in the app, and I think it would be completely illogical to have a full printed rulebook when they can easily update the rules and FAQ in the app. The Tutorial is brilliant, and besides looking up a few details then, I haven't been back into the rules during this whole session.
[b]Thoughts on the App - A Short Rant Against Haters[/b] I have to get this off my chest. If people don't like the idea of having to use a digital component with their analogue boardgaming, fine. It's their right to stay away from games that have a digital component, whether it be this one or another. It's clear to me that in this case XCOM is a boardgame first and foremost. I have explained what the app does, and it does it well. It supports a boardgame in ways that physical components practically speaking couldn't. FFG has also made clear that XCOM is a boardgame, which is why it has cards, plastic and cardboard in abundance.
If some people stay away from this game and other games like it, regardless of what the app does and how this [i]board[/i]game works and plays, fine. But, then stay away from it! Don't come onto the forums complaining about how this isn't a boardgame, and this is the end of boardgaming with physical components and whatnot. The most obnoxious offenders are those that rate the game a 1 just because XCOM has a digital component. That is moronic. Those ratings should be removed, and the perpetrators banned (I'd settle for temporary bans).
[b]Closing Thoughts[/b] As I said, so far I love this game. I have no history with the videogame, and having knowledge of it may actually be a handicap. Because see, here is what the genius, conceptually, of XCOM The Board Game is: FFG has taken a turn-based tactical videogame, and turned into a real-time grand strategic boardgame. With a digital component. That takes guts. And design savvy (which FFG has in abundance). And normally I don't even like alien-themed games!
Though I might play XCOM once or twice with others, this game is perfect for only solitaire play. Go out and get it. And post on the [b][geeklist=166714]SGOYT made me buy this geeklist[/geeklist][/b]. ;)
item.comment:
Sorry, but it's the fact that the digital component is REQUIRED that blurs the lines too much.
Assistance apps are great, but required fusion of the two is not. They should have just moved the board stuff into the app and let you play it all there.
I'm sure for those that don't mind looking at their screen and having noises and timers and whatnot disrupting their board game, then fine. But really, don't tell people what they can and cannot say and for what reasons. if I were to troll into the X-COM BGG forums and repeatedly criticize it, that would be wrong. But when it's brought out for discussion in a community, then the whole community should have a right to discuss it. [-] If YOU hate discussion, then YOU should not post it here in the SGOYT lists. (see how it feels)[/-]

P.S. I was enjoying your review until the tirade.
P.P.S As an example, the FFG Star Wars Dice app is a great example of blending the technologies. It's a convenient way to store, roll, and tabulate sets of dice. Not required, but beneficial.

Thank you for your clarifications.
I have not rated X-COM at all, however, I do feel it is a completely valid position to do so. If you don't like a game for whatever reason, even enough not to even buy or play the game, then the rating is a way to express that.
The campaign should not be to ban people who rate games a 1 for reasons you disagree with, it should be to augment the ratings system to include a "Have you played this game" and "Have you owned this game" or even better change the rating to two parts: "Rate your interest in playing this game." and "After playing rate the game."
I'd love to go and rate Mage Knight and others with a "1" for their fantasy/magic theme, because that is a fair rating of how I feel about those games. But I don't, just to be a good sport.

I suppose I can't expect everyone to be a good sport, like you, but I am glad you are. :) I wholeheartedly agree with you that the ratings system lacks in that regard, in say an "anticipation" rating. That would help tremendously, and avoid gut reaction dislike of a game clouding the actual rating. As you say, there is little other way to express such dislike.
It's funny that you mention the Dice App. I actively avoid using such apps, because I love the physicality of rolling dice, regardless of their encumbrance. This may sound paradoxical, given my staunch support of XCOM and its app, but it does for me stress the point of XCOM being a boardgame first and foremost, in my opinion. I would have no interest in it if the whole game was in a digital form, and I very rarely play any boardgames digitally.
For me one of the biggest draws of a boardgame is precisely that physicality, the feel of different types of components, flipping cards, rolling dice, moving bits and pieces around. What XCOM does is enhance tension and unpredictability, which I personally find very important aspects in boardgames, in a manner that would otherwise have been almost impossible to achieve. It doesn't detract at all from the fun that playing a boardgame gives me.

Agreed completely on boardgames in general. I only came back a couple of years ago and for real about 15 months ago. Didn't know they'd stuck around except for the box store variety. I was an all the time PC gamer. Since getting back to the physical aspect, I've uninstalled most of my Steam apps and am rarely tempted to buy the "new great game" on the PC. And when tempted, rarer still do I even buy it.
That said, I do love the tactile feeling of boardgames. It's relaxing. I love the therapeutic nature of painting minis too. I work with a computer all day, so when my hobby was that too, I felt a little disconnected. Now I feel "in touch" with things again.
However, that's what I don't like about the app being required. Just when I get more analog, the digital is an unwelcome invader, that to use the X-COM analogy, has to be hunted down and exterminated. Were it something I could invite onto my table as an add-on or convenience, that would be awesome, because I could still play the game without it.
There is no way the app fits into my gaming time/world, even if I wanted it to. I play quietly and concentrate on the board and the physical components. I can keep the game experience contained to MY hands and MY imagination. I don't have to project it to my wife and son or anyone else in the house.
Like I said elsewhere, Space Alert's CD eliminates that game for me too.
The better solution for FFG would have been to make the app optional, even if the physical version were inferior to the app usage. It would at least allow more people to play the game instead of putting up an "our way or the highway" wall.
Their choice to force this on gamers using an highly anticipated property was wise and stupid at the same time.
Wise in that the desire to play X-COM might be enough to get some people over the hurdle. Stupid in that do many would be interested in X-COM, but not the app requirement that that complaints of people being unable to play the game would be louder.

item.body:
This is my third play of this game since I got it at X-Mas.
The sadistic mage and the overly heroic warrior set on the quest to reach Doomrock and slay the evil within...
The first encounter was against the Exploding Tomatoes. Only the mage survived the encounter. But that is enough and the warrior was quickly back on his feet.
The heroes continued to venture forth and in the second encounter they faced the The Wraiths of Doom. The heroes managed to kill the boss and all the whisps vanished. Moving on the the final encounter....
The heroes reached Doomrock, and the final encounter was revealed. The Dragon and it's allies, the Exploding Tomatoes (again!). The heroes were confident for the battle. Throughout their journey both of them leveled up twice and obtained some pretty nasty items... The mage wore a Leather Armor of Doom and a Demoniac Charm of Impending Doom. On his right hand he had the Wand of Doom (so many Doom's in this game :)) and on his left he had the Forceward of Exploding Heads. The warrior was also fully equipped. He wore the Inappropriate Armor of Backflips, the Ring of Strange Possibilities and held the Demonic Axe of Random Deaths.
The battle started. The heroes were hit pretty badly, but the Dragon was slain at the beginning of the second round. However, the Exploding Tomatoes were too many, and eventually overrun the brave heroes...
This was a great adventure, although I lost. The game is awesome! The combat phase is very strategic and a lot of fun. And in the adventuring phase you really feel the pressure because you have a limited time and you must reach Doomrock for the final encounter.
So, here are my likes and dislikes:
:thumbsup: Combat is very strategic, rewarding and fun! :thumbsup: I really love the sense of humor of the cards. In many occasions the flavor text just makes me laugh. :thumbsdown: The game is hard (not a negative for me, but can be for some people). :thumbsdown: A game can take up to 3 hours if you are able to reach the final encounter (again, not really a negative aspect, but some people may be turned downed by this).

item.body:
(Played using 2nd edition of Nuts! rules. Not the best rules, and would prefer to use updated rules, but I use what I've got.)
What a unbelievable disaster!
I started on the south side of the map, (US1 starting zone), sneaking through the Bocage, hoping to crawl through the high grass in the center of the table to get close to the telephone building after dispatching PEF 1 (hopefully silently). The PEF turned out to be a 4-man squad milling about in their own Bocage, each looking in a different direction. Then, what luck, two more American paratroopers wander on board directly behind them! Of course, it ruined my chance at stealth as the two Germans pointed that way opened fire, taking one OOF and stunning the other.
Using the surprise, we crawled to the other side of the Bocage and found ourselves in a nicely dug ditch which saved us from incoming fire. We took shots at the other two and realized just how low in ammo we were (so...many....1s....). One was stunned, the other dove into the tall grass and fell prone, hiding from us. We watched helplessly as the other two finished off the remaining surprise reinforcement paratrooper, as we finished off their own downed man.
With a brief instant of time, we dashed forward and dove into the tall grass ourselves, nary inches in front of our enemy. Luckily we seemed to startle him as the nose of his gun fired into the dirt and we made quick work of him. At this point, we noticed the six men pour out of the telephone building, taking position in the ditches around it, taking as many sightlines as possible. Exchanging glances with my compatriots, we started deciding that maybe this wasn't such a good idea when 7(!) men poured out of a nearby building and began marching up the street to flank the roadway and protect all the lines. We began cautiously retreating, hoping to draw no attention.
When the large caliber machine gun team began setting up at the end of the road, I think I heard someone mutter "Brilliant idea, genius" as we left by the way we came. With only one grenade to our name, we knew we wouldn't be able to deal with 18 men in defensive positions.
This is NOT an easy campaign.
:thumbsup: Plays like a RPG, so much story comes out of any THW. :thumbsdown: Vague rulesystem has you filling in a lot of blanks yourself (I'm sure Final Version fixes this) :thumbsdown: This campaign is, and should be, very very difficult.

Hello All
First-time entry on the list. My [b]Origin Story[/b] is fairly straightforward: as a long-time solo gamer I've always enjoyed scoping out BGG for more solitaire goodies. :ninja: Imagine my delight (nay, joy!) a couple months back when I found this Geeklist and its merry band of inhabitants. I believe I was searching some Solitaire game category but honestly don't recall the particulars. Suffice to say, I really like the tone of this gang and feel right at home.
On to Legion of Honor. Got wind of this one through one of the monthly entries...maybe December Solitaire Games on Your Table. I immediately fell in love with the concept, and couldn't wait to put my paws on a copy. It was order-at-first-sight, no hesitation, pull the trigger and then stalk the the USPS/UPS delivery person every day.
When it arrived I set aside the evening (Wife: "Want to watch a movie tonight?" Me: "NO! Go away!") and cracked it open. Ooooh, ahhhhh, cool components! Look at all these intriguing charts! There's even Rachelle counters!
Dove into the rulebook and soon felt overwhelmed. The garrison and campaign decks, what with Roman numerals and all that, gave me pause. Huh? I did some stutter steps trying to get the flow of the game, but soon it became fairly intuitive and things began to roll pretty smoothly. Last night I wrapped up my initial, full play-through...a tale of two friends and rival grognards (Christophe and Garade) who lived to see the sad end. Garade (always the lucky bastard!) prospered early, married well, but was shipped off to Spain - he still made comte and was ultimately the commanding general chased into southern France by the Iron Duke. My namesake grog was gravely wounded early in his career, captured and exchanged twice, but went to Russia and rose through the ranks quickly, making Brigadier.
:thumbsup: Once you get the hang of it the game flows well and drips immersion. The narrative quality is fantastic - I even think I may write an in-character journal of sorts the next time I play.
:thumbsdown: The rules are not laid out the best, and there are some head-scratchers in the system, at least from a beginner's perspective. For example, I'm not sure who would ever choose the potential for disgrace over glory in a battle, but maybe that nuance will pop for me next time.
:thumbsdown: I don't care for the way duels are handled, which is via cards drawn from a special Duel deck. Lunge, parry, riposte. Yawn. I'm afraid I dreaded having to fight duels, given the process, and that's a no-no for a solitaire experience.
Overall, though, the game is/was a blast and I'll definitely be back in Revolutionary France again soon.

So I set up Caverna late last night, intending to play it the next morning (this morning). But I looked at the boards and thought "well, I'll just add the first round of resources." So I did.
And then I looked at the board and thought, "It's so easy to play with two workers at the moment. I'll just take the first turn."
And then I looked at the board and thought, "Hey, maybe just one more round."
And then it was 2am...
I finished with a sad 47 points because I still don't understand the huge number of rooms available, and I tend to want to both adventure and farm, so life is tough for my dwarves.
[imageid=2404008 medium]
I really should pick a strategy and stick to it, but there's so much to discover. I forgot how much because I've before played Caverna with a variant where you reveal tiles gradually and not all of them, but the full experience is a much better game for me.
Takes so long to set up and tear down though. I fear that a fair bit as I look at it this morning.

I mentioned this game to [user=reverendunclebastard][/user] in a comment and it got me thinking about it again. I'm working from home, because the furnace guy is coming over (it was cold in the house this morning, let me tell ya). I had time to give this game another go over lunch.
Here is my game, when I ended: [ImageID=2404068]
You have 60 days to find the parts to a old device before the bad guys do. Each movement within the city costs you an hour to move. You have three attributes: health, strength, and knowledge. You run out of one of them, you lose. There are some spots in the city where you can increase them but, as you can guess -- you have to give up some precious time. When you get to a spot that gives you a part, you may have to sacrifice a few of those attributes to them. There are some objects (key, map, and lens) that can help you in your quest, but they will also cost you.
The big kicker is: the city is confusing and constantly changing. Just because you went in one direction doesn't mean you can go back the way you came. Often the landmarks will change places. And, of course, as you move, the bad guys will attack you.
This particular session had me see the map early in the game, which has never happened whenever I've played this before. I spent too much time trying to get it and kept failing (getting it lets you move 3 known spaces in a hour instead of just 1). I had to hurry to get the rest of the parts, and one (#6, for those who have played the game) also took a long time to get. I ended up fending off quite a few attacks but the city kept changing. I ended up running out of time with only one part remaining to get. But, honestly, it wasn't that close.
:thumbsup: Quick play with quite a bit of depth. :thumbsup: It's fun to watch the city form as you move around. :thumbsup: Sometimes your best laid plans are thwarted easily. :thumbsdown: Once the city is formed, though, gathering the parts you need gets to be pretty generic. :thumbsdown: Some may find keeping track of the stats, including time, to be a bit fiddly. I find them keeping me engaged in the game but I could see that argument happening. :thumbsdown: There is obviously more luck than strategy in this game. For me, that's what I want for a lunch time activity.
I had more :thumbsdown: than :thumbsup: above, but I still recommend this game. If it seems intriguing to you, build it up.

item.objectname: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.body:
Got this for Christmas but, per the advice here, I was waiting until I got a copy of [thing=137762]Dark City[/thing] before giving it a whirl - and also my anal-retentive sleeving (and subsequent compressing) of the cards. Finally got everything in and took the time to sleeve it over the course of a couple nights last week, so I took a whirl at my first game the other night while Denine was getting ready for bed. I used the recommended setup for a first game, adjusted for the solo setup: Iron Man, Hawkeye, and Spidey versus The Red Skull, Hydra, and some Sentinels (?) trying to Unleash the Power of the Cosmic Cube. Things bopped along nicely; after a few hands I decided it would be a good idea to recruit Maria Hill, to in turn recruit some heavier-hitting heroes; a few more hands and it occurred to me that I ought to focus on taking The Red Skull down a few pegs, before I burned through the villain deck and allowed him to succeed. I forgot to draw villain cards on a couple of turns, but I think I rectified them all quickly. Typical first game stuff. In the end, I managed to handily defeat The Red Skull and all but one remaining villain (with a final hand that chained out to 22 attack points!) with two plot twists to spare. I had a lot of fun playing and look forward to mixing things up now that the initial learning game is out of the way, particular getting some time with my favorite characters (Midnight Sons and X-Men, baby!).
Sorry, but I'm blowing out the 1:2 rating for my first outing with this one. :thumbsup:Absolutely love the theme! I am a long time Marvel fanboy, about two-thirds of my life at this point, so almost all these characters are near and dear to my heart. I know most of them really well, how they act and interact with each other, so the narrative in my head can be pretty involved. :thumbsup:If I plan things out well the game allows me to pull off card chains that really feel like the heroes are just laying a serious beat down on the villains. :thumbsup:I have a harder time finding themes Ren and I both like, and although she'll play pretty much anything just for the sake of playing, she's more engaged when she can get into the theme. She's into the Marvel movies and reads some of the all-ages comics occasionally, so she has a foothold in that world. When she saw that I'd set the game up she was interested in playing, although it was already setup for solo and she didn't have time before bed anyway, but she said she definitely wants to play it. She'll really go nuts if I buy Guardians of the Galaxy expansion, she's nuts about that movie. :thumbsup:The iconography on the cards makes them easier to understand. Related to the above, Ren has mild dyslexia, so I've been reluctant to play things like Thunderstone Advance with her because the card abilities can get a little involved. I feel a lot more confident about her ability to play Legendary without having to ask me what her cards do all the time. :thumbsup:Dark F-ing City! The base set has all the gold standard characters that have to be in a Marvel game - a few I'd like to have, most I could take or leave, and a couple I downright don't care about (I'm looking at you, [-]Marcus Johnson[/-] Nick Fury). But Holy Cow, I love the line-up in Dark City! Nightcrawler, Colossus, and Ghost Rider are three of my favorite heroes, and I'm primarily an X-fan, so Apocalypse, Sinister, and Stryfe are at the top of my list for villains after Magneto. Now if only they make an Exiles expansion.... :thumbsdown:What the heck is up with the divided insert? [size=12][u][b]Origin Story[/b][/u][/size] I don't remember when exactly I was introduced to the SGOYT list, but I think it was only a month or two before [listitem=3314808]my first post[/listitem], which was a game of [thing=113924][/thing] last July. Now clue how I came across the list, but it was probably because some game I was looking into was mentioned. At first I felt a little out-of-place here, because I'm not into military games and it seemed like the pages were dominated by those. But I quickly figured out that there were a plenty of other dungeon-crawling, deck-building, zombie-slaying junkies around too and now this list feels like my second home (the first being the Kickstarter lists).
The only game I can think of that the list has caused me to buy that I had no intention of buying beforehand is [thing=43570][/thing], so it hasn't necessarily cost me that much. That said, it has nudge me toward buying games I was on the fence about - [thing=37046][/thing], [thing=100901][/thing], and [thing=137762][/thing] come to mind - so there is that. And it has put a lot of stuff in my wishlist that may be acquired at a later date when both space (need to move!) and finances (no overtime right now) allow.

I broke out Tomb last night because I've been considering trading it away, but thought I'd give it another go. This time I used my own solo rules.
1) Take out 20 characters and stack them (shuffled randomly). 2) Take out 4 more characters and start with 2 of them; place the other 2 back in the box. 3) Take out 2xD20s. Set one at "16", and the other will be used after each turn. 4) Take the first 2 characters from the stack and place them in the Inn. They are available to recruit. 5) Take your turn normally. After your turn take 1xD20 and roll it. If you roll under the number that was set, then the counter drops by 1 (e.g. I rolled a "7" and the counter is set at 16; drop the counter to 15). If you roll it and it's over, discard the 2 visiting characters in the inn out of the game, and draw 2 new ones.
Game ends: 1) If you run out of characters in the inn, you cannot get anymore help. If all the characters are gone, you only have 1 last turn to clear all tombs (by turn I mean that your counter is reset to 16, and when you roll over the number that is set, you lose). If you cannot complete, you lose the game. If you clear the tomb before this happens, you win the game.
2) Alternate conditions (highest score): same as #1 above, but each tomb card left is counted against your VPs collected (negative based on the amount left). Score is based on the rules in the book.
I ended last night in defeat, and decided to count my VP - only had 36VP left. I found this change to be quite interesting as I had to temper how far to go into the tomb and the time needed to get back to the inn if I needed a new character (which may or may not be there when I got back). Definitely going to play this again!

I really enjoy this with Cryptmaster as a solo experience. Like you i have my own ruleset. I play it similar to Elder Sign where you disregard movement entirely and choose a Crypt to raid each turn. I play that you have to find 8 treasures to win before running out of characters. After clearing a Crypt you roll a dice to see if a treasure card is found. Which dice your roll (Green, Blue, or Red) is based on the size of the Crypt you cleared.
Anyway - i vote no on trading it as it will be very expensive to get if you want it back.

I also used to play this without the movement, but then it felt as if I was just drawing cards - and that I think was the reason it was up for trade. Now that I added the movement requirement into the game it makes me think about how far to travel into the tomb and pushes me for "just one more" tomb to clear before heading back as I'm already next to it.
Glad to see you're also having fun with the game :D

item.body:
I'm having a blast with this one working on a solitaire variant that is amusingly tough yet reasonably beatable and reliably consistent. I think we're close as I had a 58-52 victory over the MegaClinic today and am excited to apply some tweaks gleaned from today's test. I say "we" because I'm collaborating with:
[username=steve carey]
As you might expect, Steve is abrasive, hard to work with, and doesn't have any good ideas, but I'm allowing him on the project anyway. Ahem. Which is "guy speak" for Steve is the Nicest Guy Ever and certainly knows his stuff when it comes to making solitaire games. It's a pleasure and an honor to be exchanging ideas with him on this.
I haven't been doing any other solitaire gaming as a result of being consumed by this project and don't really have session reports to post, but I'm having fun so I'm not pushing myself. Suffice to say, the base system works pretty well and now it's a matter of making the game consistent or reasonably so.
[b][size=18]ORIGIN STORIES (2)[/size][/b] I have two actually.
[b]What brought you here? Was it from a subscription, or did you find it on the front page or on a specific game page? [/b] I wish I could recall, actually. I must've tripped over the GL from a game subscription of mine maybe? In any case, I found the post to [b][listitem=3108017] my first item from [u]a year ago March[/u] [/listitem] [/b]when I had tried kittenhoarder's variant for [thing=83330][/thing]. That was my first origin story.
Apparently, I wasn't ready to come into the fold at the time because I pretty much did a drive-by and [u]didn't return again until the fall[/u] when things crystallized and I decided to both [b][listitem=3583608]get into solitaire gaming more seriously[/listitem] [/b]and start [geeklist=183035][b]my own video series[/b][/geeklist] aimed specifically at solitaire games (and user-created variants in particular as they interest me). This is the origin story that's stuck.
[b]What was the first game you posted? Do you still own it and/or play it?[/b] I'll go with my 2nd attempt that actually stuck -- it was a user variant for [thing=131287][/thing], and I haven't played it since but definitely like the variant.
[b]Was there anything else notable about your first visit?[/b] People were really welcoming, like I'd walked into some really friendly clubhouse somewhere. And creative. I was blown away at the variety of creative reports, a lot of them with photos. I knew there something here I needed to explore.
[b]Anything else you'd like to share about your first visit?[/b] I'm just glad I didn't do another drive-by.
[b]What keeps bringing you back?[/b] The community here is extremely friendly and creative. I'm inspired to play games and continue to make my reports more creative (haven't gotten there yet, but I'm inspired to).
I was also discovering a lot of new games I either hadn't considered for solo play or wasn't even aware of. I came back to the hobby and found BGG in 2008 so I already went through that "new to the hobby" phase but I feel like I'm re-experiencing the new hobby smell to to some extent.
The only problem is...
[b]How much money have these lists cost you?[/b] ... it's hard to see people having fun and think, "I could have that fun too!" and not run off and get stuff or otherwise plan a list of too many games to purchase/play. I posted a thread in the 1PG about sorting out my thoughts on all the games I want to acquire and all the ones I want to play. I tend to get a little paralyzed when I feel there's a huge "to do" list hanging over my head. Yeah, I know this is supposed to be fun, but even having a huge "to have fun list" can be a bit paralyzing, at least to me.
So, I'm trying to let others have their fun and enjoy the fun via their reports and not necessarily think I should try it too. [thing=150997][/thing] is a great example. I seem to be perfectly fine reading reports and enjoying the stories that are being told with no significant urge to get, glue, and glamorize the damn things. Keep holding back the darkness, y'all.
[b]If you haven't been back since your first visit, how are you even reading this?[/b] I was that guy but no more. :D
[u][b]Edit 1:[/b][/u] A successful couple of playtests today. I also reread Morten's great series of blogposts on solitaire "automa" design and think I'm at the point where I need to back off and let others try lest I burn out. I'm very happy with where it is.
Today I was behind but came vaulting back for a big lead. Until the last turn. That damn last turn. The MegaClinic came roaring back and ended up beating me due to final scoring. I think I could hear my jaw hit the floor. It was great as I want a challenging design.

item.body:
So this actually happened last night, but since it was such a good bedtime story I told myself, I promptly fell asleep on the floor after finishing.
I ambled down to the edge of the Shire to seek some adventure, bold Took that I am, and came upon a [b]stony ford[/b]. I managed to get across without getting too wet, when I came upon a [b]traveling dwarf[/b]. I asked him what his name was and he replied, "there are those who call me Tim."
So Tim and I set out over the edge of the Shire to see what we could see. There was a dark wood up ahead of us that was very cob-webby and we thought there might be a [b]spider colony[/b] there, so we avoided it. We found some [b]forgotten path[/b] and trudged along that for many miles.
We must have been getting into some of the old Numenorean realms since we began to see [b]old castles[/b] on distant hilltops. As we rounded a bend we saw some ruins right ahead of us and wondered what could be in there. We didn't have to wait long to find out because a band of [b]highway robbers[/b] came out from behind some rocks and assailed us! They must have robbed us and taken us to be prisoner in the old castle because we woke up in what seemed like a [b]tomb[/b].
Tim and I were just starting to prepare our escape plan when out of the center sarcophagus a [b]foul thing[/b] emerged. It reeked of death and horror. We seemed to be blinded by a darkness that flowed from it. We reeled and stumbled backwards trying to get away from this new terror.
The darkness was suddenly shattered by daylight as the [b]brigands[/b], returning to their lair, opened an outer door. With a shriek the thing leapt on them. Seizing this opportunity, Tim and I ran for it.
I was very grateful to have Tim at this moment though I didn't realize it at the time. Keeping his dwarven head and sense he managed to snatch back the [b]dwarven gold[/b] that had been stolen from him by the robbers. This proved to be a very smart move on Tim's part.
As we wandered in this wild land we came upon no civilized folk. All that live out there are [b]wild folk[/b]. But even wild folk appreciate gold, and so we were able to "convince" them to lead us back to more civilized places. As we came near the Shire again we noticed a [b]dark cave[/b] under an old weathered hill that seemed to look pretty [listitem=3667730]familiar[/listitem], though I couldn't quite place it.
Since we hadn't yet had our fill of adventure, we ventured in. I don't think I would have done it if I hadn't had a dwarf at my side. We hobbits are good underground, but not dwarf-good. We had made some torches, and thankfully they lasted, but we wound our way under the Shire until we came up in the cellar of the Green Dragon here! :tankard:

item.body:
I finally, finally, finally got Cuba Libre to the table today.
First of all, I would like to give a huge thank you to my very generous
[user=secret soloist][/user] who gave me this game last year.
I'm truly embarrassed that it took me so long to play it.
I only had time to play through the tutorial, but that's okay. I really love playing through GMT's tutorials. It's a great way to learn the game and it's a lot of fun to see a handful of turns play out. It's also really nice to spend a few hours just soaking everything in.
My plan is to play a couple games playing all four sides before I try playing solo against the AI. I think it will give me a better handle on the game.
I'm curious to hear how other people have played this. Do you play all four sides and just see what happens? Or do you pick one side that you would like to win, play the other factions as best as you can, and then hope your faction is victorious?
I'm curious because I haven't quite got the hang of playing multiple sides just yet.
[b]Edit - 2/11/15[/b]
I played my first full game today, playing all four sides. It went really well. I did spend a lot of time with the rules, but that was mostly because I wanted to understand the operations rather than needing to look up a bunch of rules.
This game is great! It's really exciting to see how the different factions move their way around the country trying to control and influence everything.
[center][ImageID=2411618medium][/center]
Here is the board at game's end. The Directorio won during the second propaganda round. They took Havana City which propelled them to victory. The 6 population points make Havana a huge deal in the game. The other three factions really messed up by letting the DR have it.
The Syndicate had 9 open casinos but couldn't scrape together the resources to win. The Government was looking really well after the first Propaganda Round but dug themselves into a deep hole by buying so many civic actions. Oops, live and learn. 26July never could get off the ground, but I think it was a slow build. However, the DR's domination of Havana stopped any chances 26July might have had.
I know that understanding of Cuba Libre will get better with time, but I found it really difficult to look at the long game. Long-term strategy was hard to grasp so I played the game rather tactically. I also wonder how much of that was because I was trying to hold onto to four separate strategies at once. I'm going to play again, but this time, I think I'll play against the AIs.

item.objectname: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.body:
Made the switch from playing RftG two handed to the Robot AI (easy difficulty).
It's start world was Epsilon Eridani (#1) while mine was Damaged Alien Factory (#7).
I lost 49-58. The Robot placed it's 12th card on the same turn we ran out of VP chips.
I got the Galactic Renaissance 6 Dev card down and had the Research Labs and Galactic Trendsetters world.
The scoring broke down as follows:
[u]VP Chits[/u] Me: 17 Robot: 26
[u]Tableau VP's[/u] Me: 21 + 11 (Gal Ren 6 Dev) = 32 Robot: 26 + 6 (6 dev chit) = 32
[u]Final Totals[/u] Me: 49 Robot: 58
I really liked this. It seemed much easier to me just to play my own hand while the Robot played its game. It is relentless though. It's credit and econ spiked pretty early and put me behind in the VP chit game early.
[b]EDIT 2/6[/b] Game #2 vs AI
Me: Separatist Colony AI: New Sparta
[u]VP Chits[/u] Me: 8 AI: 7
[u]World VP's[/u] Me: 19 AI: 9
[u]Dev VP's[/u] Me: 7 AI: 10
[u]Total VP's[/u] Me: 34, Victory! AI: 26
[u]Final AI[/u] Credits: 4 Econ: 2
The AI was hurt by bad draws, a couple of turns it exhausted it's draw pile.
I was able to get Space Marines and Drop Ships out pretty early and that really boosted my Military to 6 and allowed me to Settle some decent VP worlds without burning through cards. My final three worlds settled were Rebel Colony(4 VP), Lost Alien Warship(3 VP) and Alien Robotic Factory(5 VP). While the Factory was not a military world I was able to exhaust my hand in the final turn to lay it down and seal the win.
[b]EDIT 2/10[/b] Been playing a few more games. I have found that the Robot playing with Old Earth (world #0) is very difficult. It gets 'x2' as it's Robot action (after an initial '$' one) and it just rakes in the VP chits at a very fast rate. I've lost to it 35-10 and 48-16. Can't really see a way to stay with it. Maybe Military but you need the right cards for that to work.
item.comment: The robot is an elegant way to streamline solo play while keeping the game really challenging. I find it important to limit your production phases to prevent the robot from building up too much econ.

How did you end up with so many VP chits out? The game is limited to 24 in solo plus any extra earned after the last chit was claimed.
I thought about playing without the limit but I never tried it.

[q="Wayne LaBanca"]How did you end up with so many VP chits out? The game is limited to 24 in solo plus any extra earned after the last chit was claimed.
I thought about playing without the limit but I never tried it.[/q] The last round started with 2 VP chits left (started with 24 available) and the robot with 11 cards out. I knew this was the last round so I picked 'x2' as one of my actions (Produce had been played the round before).
Of course the Robot rolled a '*' and so also got the 'x2' bonus. The Robot's economy was a 5 so he got 10 VP's. By this time the Robot had already played his 12th card so the game was ending. The rules state to break out the 10 VP chits for the final Consume round so that each side can collect all the VP's they are due. I believe I also got 10 VP's in that final 'x2' action.

[q="reverendunclebastard"]The robot is an elegant way to streamline solo play while keeping the game really challenging. I find it important to limit your production phases to prevent the robot from building up too much econ.[/q] Yeah, the Robot's econ grew way to quickly for me to keep up. If only the Robot wouldn't roll '*' when I selected Produce (seemed like that always happened).

[q="reverendunclebastard"]The robot is an elegant way to streamline solo play while keeping the game really challenging. I find it important to limit your production phases to prevent the robot from building up too much econ.[/q]
:arrowN::arrowN::arrowN: Sound advice. In the games I have played I have also found that avoiding produce and consume actions is a key to success. Military strategy seems to work well against the AI 1)if you get the cards to pull it off 2)the AI's start world isn't New Sparta.

I greatly cut back on selecting Consume/Produce actions in this game and was able to win.
I've noticed that the 12 card tableau limit means that you need to picky in what you set down. Just because you can play a Dev or a World doesn't mean you should. Early in the game you will need to place some lower value cards to get your economy going but after that you need to be picky about what you lay down so that you aren't stuck with a tableau filled with low density VP cards.
