item.body:
Hi everyone! It has been MONTHS since I've posted to SGOYT. I honestly don't have much of an excuse other than "life happens".. haha... one day I felt like I was starting to get really involved with this community and the next thing I know its been months since I've posted on BGG.
Anyway, got my copy of Tiny Epic Defenders in the mail today and decided to check it out before going to bed. This is a great little game! Definitely seems like its going to be a good short solo game for nights like this one where I want to play a quick game before bed and don't have the energy for anything with more complicated setup and game length. I played it on easy difficulty with only one dire enemy and lost! I thought for sure I had it totally beat too up until the last couple of rounds. I was doing a good job of keeping the threat levels of all the regions down but totally didn't plan well for how quickly they go up when all those enemies start getting shuffled into the turn deck. But hey, losing on easy means I have plenty of games ahead of me to get better at it :)
[size=18]ORIGIN STORY[/size]
So, I've been sitting here thinking about how the heck I stumbled across SGOYT in the first place and its driving me crazy that I can't remember exactly how it happened. My story is that around the 2nd half of 2013 I started really getting back into board games. I was a huge gamer when I was younger (mostly RPGs back then) but just drifted away from regular gaming after college. Now I've got kids and as they started getting older and I was looking for fun stuff to do with them I started checking out board games again. Next thing I know I had bought several games and even backed a few on Kickstarter (now up to over 50 KS projects and over 150 games in the collection total).
At some point I ended up on BGG looking for rules clarifications for some game I was playing with the kids and stumbled across something having to do with solo play of a board game. I can't remember what game it was but I remember a light bulb going off in my head (more like fireworks in hindsight) when I realized "woah, it never even occurred to me to play board games solo". I played the occasional video game but just never occurred to me to play solo board games.
By early 2014 I had found SGOYT and made my first posts. I've never been one to participate much in online communities so those of you that are regulars may not even remember me as I drifted away again in mid to late 2014 but am hoping to get back involved again this year as I'm really hoping to get more games to the table.
Ok enough rambling for now... hopefully I'll be posting more plays this month.
item.comment:
Great to have you back.
I wish my copy would turn up. It shipped a week ago so hopefully not too long now.

item.objectname: BB1: Kalgor Bloodhammer and the Ghouls Through the Breach
item.body:
So I downloaded this and two other solo RPG's over the weekend. Mostly paragraph driven dice rollers. Less role-play and more roll-play adventures.
Played this one three times, and it doesn't really get better the more you play. A fun one-shot for four dollars...

[b]Feb 5[/b]
Played three straight games of Viticulture with Mommas & Papas, Properties, and of course Automa.
Automa is tough, but mostly I was my own worst enemy, losing twice due to my usual downfall in games, pursuing too many strategies because they all sound cool. Trying to overachieve in games tends not to work out if it's the type of overachievement that loses focus early game.
I tried to get the cottage strategy working (draw lots of visitors in the hopes of getting bonus actions, cards, and points) without getting the cottage from my papa, which is not a strategy to pursue when time is so short. It did work for me once when I got the cottage from papa, but not so much otherwise.
The third game succeeded because I focused my strategy at long last, and did it based on the cards from momma and the [i]small cellar[/i] from papa. This all told me: make looooots of wine tokens as soon as possible. I also concentrated on creating a couple new workers while getting vines planted early on.
But I don't know what strategy you start off with when you get, say, the windmill as an inherited structure. Do you just trade it for money so you can get a trellis and irrigation early on?
Can you win games without investing in the large cellar?
You definitely need irrigation or the trellis or, preferably, both. But I might try a new strategy (depending on what I draw)...
Properties was interesting, but I seem unable to use it properly. I probably need to be more aggressive about it. The game I won I didn't sell any properties at all because I simply didn't have time and Automa kept blocking the sell grapes space when I had better uses for my grande worker.
Next on the docket is... Patronage. I don't think I'll try to win every game in order to advance to the next, if only because I won't have enough time to do so before the review next week (which will require the script to finish at latest on Tuesday, and filming to finish at latest on Wednesday).
Meanwhile I finished the first cut of the script for the Core Worlds tutorial, which I've broken up into three videos (basic concepts, for people who've never played Core Worlds; the base game with SoloPlay rules; and the addition of Galactic Orders).
Busy, busy, busy. The week after will be more relaxed.
[b]Feb 6 - Properties and Patronage[/b]
Adding the Patronage expansion made it easier to beat Automa, what with 3 points granted by filling a wine order of a 5 wine and an extra 2 points for accomplishing the activated Patronage card's goal by end game (in this case, 6+ structures). I scored 24 points. I was more aggressive with agriculture, since I got the Windmill from my papa. I did sell a property in order to pay for some structures, so I finally used that expansion correctly.
Advanced Visitors is the next expansion to add to the mix, and I'm excited to have visitors that are useful at multiple points in the game, rather than just one. Thank goodness! I'm going to use the Advanced Variant and remove some of the original visitors. Poor original visitors.
[b]Feb 6 - Advanced Visitors[/b]
I removed the original visitors that had no advanced version, and thus had mostly advanced visitors throughout the game. Wow, they made a difference. Now there's even more paths to explore, not all of them victorious.
I made 19 points. It would have been 21 if only I had not miscalculated in mid-game. I could have had a blushing wine for my Patronage to pay off, but noooo.
I'm tempted to try again with another bonus token. But the first Tier 2 expansion, which is basically more visitors, sounds intriguing and not too difficult. After that it's the expanded board, which looks like it'll make games last longer, which I'm not sure I will like... one of the things I love about Viticulture is that it's a good weight of Euro in a short amount of time.
[b]Feb 6 - New Visitors[/b]
Added in the new visitors except for the Swindler, and removed the Queen from the winter visitor deck as well, since they are both purely interactive cards and carry zero solo benefit.
I won again at 24 points.
Now... onto the expanded board, side 1. I'm curious to see what that does to the game.
And then tomorrow it's mostly filming and then spending Sunday editing.
[b]Feb 6 - Extended Board[/b]
Wow. This board adds so much. Now I can get bonuses on some of the spaces without paying bonus tokensâunless Automa gets there first, of course.
Also, ow. I ended up 14 points behind Automa, at 21 points. Not shabby on the normal board, but pretty bad on this new one. Of course, it didn't help that papa left me quite a bit of money but only a yoke. I'm not sure what strategy you can frame around the yoke.
I could have turned in the yoke for 1 lira, but given that I had to spend at least one extra action on a structure, it didn't seem the best possibility in the world.
I was often behind the eight ball, and it was worse since I didn't create more than one extra worker. There are so many spaces and four seasons to spread workers around. o_o Plus there's now an area control element on a map.
I'm definitely going to throw in one more play before moving onto the structures expansion.
One thing I dislike about the expansion is that it walks further and further away from the theme in some areas.
[b]Feb 7 - Still Extended Board[/b]
I would like to make an announcement.
I have scored 43 points against the "easy" Automa (which scored 31 points).
I am flabbergasted at myself. I didn't know I had the winemaking spirit in me. I was aggressive with the area control game, or influence, especially since placing in an area yields rewards as well. I also kept making workers whenever possible until I had the full six, which gave me sooo many possibilities. I'd say you pretty much can't win the game unless you do that... just as you can't win the game without
1. Trellis 2. Irrigation 3. Small cellar 4. Large cellar
I made a bunch of sparkling wine (well, two) and sold them off for four VP each. I saved my grand worker to either create new workers or to fill wine orders. I used all my bonus tokens to either place extra stars or to get +1 VP on the fill orders, plus once the one time I was allowed to trade twice and pay 6 coins (5 from my residuals from the previous year) to get two more victory points.
Plus I made the most of all my visitors, including trading two away for more wine order cards.
I'm not sure I really had a strategy apart from "make wine, lots of wine, lots and lots and lots of wine." Such a strategy demands early planting so that wine tokens can be made. Blushes were easier than whites or reds because I often combined red and white grapes on single fields.
I also had harmonious numbers on my fields (2 red, 3 white, 3 red, 3+1=4 white) and was harvesting grapes and making wine like gangbusters.
It helped that the AI did not press me as hard on the final two years in fall and winter.
Then I hit the Patronage tipping point, delivering a 5 wine to activate it. I already had 5 vine cards planted to also satisfy its condition, netting a total of 5 VP alone.
I hit hard as possible and basically brought my weak El Grande game to the influence map.
Oh, what fun I had. What fun. I'm prepared to move to Special Workers, after which follows Structures. Thence to Aboriculture (apples and tomatoes!) and Formaggio (cheese! but cheese can apparently go rotten. Somehow).
Hopefully I'll have everything wrapped up in time for a Wednesday filming of the Viticulture/Tuscany review, else I'll have to delay it until Friday or Saturday.
Today I spent most of my time filming the basic concepts tutorial and the base game tutorial for Core Worlds SoloPlay.
[b]Feb 9 - Special Workers[/b]
So February 8th was spent finishing filming, then editing video, and then finally posting [thread=1317145][/thread]. There's still some work left over (the audio-only release) but for now I am gaming. Today I also ran some errands.
And today I also played more Viticulture! This time adding on the Tier 2 expansion "Special Workers". The two workers for the game paired together really well: the Messenger, who travels into the future to reserve a spot; and the Traveler, who travels into the past to take a spot regardless of the action spaces available by player count. So the Traveler can, if I'm reading this properly, take an otherwise unassailable 3-player space.
With all this time traveling power at hand, I still was pressed very hard to beat Automa. Even though I managed to do so by 4 points (scoring 33 points), I had to make over 10 points in the final round of the game. In the influence game I decided to just block the AI from scoring majorities as much as possible.
It says something about Automa that even with time travel I couldn't relax my game at all. Usually I look like I'm losing horribly until round 7, haha.
Highly enjoyable. Looking forwards to Structures tomorrow. I think the review will be delayed until Saturday, because Tuscany is just so freaking DEEP.
[b]Feb 10 - Structures[/b]
Well... I didn't build any, even though I drew a few.
My mama left me $2 and only two cards. My papa left me a victory point that I did not take, instead taking the $3, along with $3 more. This was not an auspicious start.
The special workers were the professor (you may retrieve a regular worker from the current season and use it again this year) and the traveler (travels back in time). I only had five workers in allâthe professor, the traveler, two regular workers, and the grande worker.
If I hadn't been distracted by needing to build structures that weren't inherited from my papa, I probably would have built one of the new structures. Although I had to discard more cards that were purely opponent-based.
I won by 1 point, 31 to 30. It was an incredibly close game and had I miscalculated by actually building one of the new structures, I would have lost by at least four points.
Hm.
Tomorrow I get to juggle all this plus making tomato sauce and olive oil in the Aboriculture expansion. Maybe I can build useful structures then.
Such a lot to explore.
[b]Feb 11 - Still Structures[/b]
I could have won it, if the wine order draws hadn't been so bad, and if the AI hadn't taken the "sell one wine token" spot AND the "harvest one field" spots. Ah well. Lost 26 to 31.
I did build the Label Factory, which is why I didn't lose as badly as I could have. I should have chosen to go there first instead of to the normal wine fill spot because you get 2VP every time you set foot there. Also I wish I'd taken the time to make another worker, but I didn't, thus missing out on the Mafioso.
Hrm hrm hrm hrm. Also I didn't perform as well with my beginning VPs as I could have. The "normal" Automa would have crushed me in year 3 or even earlier.
Time to break out Aboriculture I guess, even though I'm quite sure I'll lose.
[b]Feb 11 - Aboriculture![/b]
Lost by 4 points! 27 to 31. I got distracted by all the aboriculture (tree-growing) and keeping morale up because by gods I got crushed under the heel when I was working often enough to not want to do the same to little wooden meeples. It doesn't make sense, I know, but right now the idea of working people to unhappiness, depression, illness, or suicide is touchy to me, even when it's about hypothetical people.
Anyways, so I really tried to get apple trees. Apples never give you victory points except indirectly by being one of the gifts you can give to your workers at the end of the year to boost morale. Also, apples have this advantage over tomatoes and olives in that they go directly from harvest to the warehouse, whereas you need to spend extra turns and workers turning tomatoes into sauce and olives into olive oil. Sure, they're worth points, but meanwhile your workers are unhappy.
I was happy with two apple trees, but really, it would have been better to just make a gazillion wine tokens and have one apple tree. You could then
1. Spend one year discarding wine tokens and one apple to boost up to the "+1 vp" morale bar. 2. Next year, when your morale goes down one bar for using the grande worker, increase morale again to the "+1 vp" bar by discarding a single apple token. 3. Keep earning VPs for making workers happy.
This strategy requires an early vine and wine boost, which I didn't get because my papa left me a tasting table. It was difficult to make use of, but did net 3 VPs which I guess is something.
As for structures, I built the dock (residual income: 1 wine card) but there was so much going on! I definitely did not do my patronage card, which would have won me the game.
Lessons learned, I suppose. Thinking about trying this expansion again (this is everything from tiers 1 and 2 plus Aboriculture).
[b]Feb 11 - Aboriculture Again![/b]
This time I beat up easy Automa, 37 to 31. I didn't bother with morale, which makes me sad, but as I didn't get an apple tree (but tomato and then olive trees) I knew that the destined strategy was wine, wine, wine.
I made use of every part of the expansions involved:
- Mamas & Papas for set up - Property, sold the $5 property - Patronage, made the patronage though not the secret goal - Advanced visitors, played - New visitors, played - Extended board, de facto - Structures, built the label factory and veranda (reinforcing the wine wine wine strategy) - Special workers, used both (the Traveler and the Farmer, the time traveler and the bonus taker, respectively) - Aboriculture, cultivating tomato and olive trees, then using refined olive oil to boost wine orders - Automa, of course
I tended to not use my bonus tokens as a result of having the Farmer, allowing me to use them to create more scoring opportunities.
I worry a bit that it's not skill but luck that's letting me beat the easy Automa.... or maybe just a combo of both.
[b]Feb 12 - Formaggio![/b]
Ha ha, I stumbled around trying to figure out how best to use cheese, which mixed up my wine wine wine strategy. I managed to make 27 points versus Automa's 32, which isn't too shabby (is it?) when you don't know what to do with a main strategy vein in the new game world.
I'm thinking that cheese allows you to make points faster, if you can get your wine game going sooner, which doesn't always work that well with other opponents who block you. I never used the Politico, I think I could have used some bonus spaces repeated. And I constantly felt one worker short, which made sense with the extra actions needed for milking the cows and creating cheese.
I tried desperately to draw visitors. It didn't help that papa left me just a yoke, and I gave up on it and decided to just take the $2. I feel like the odds were just against me this game, but I also feel that if I had a better grasp of cheese it wouldn't have made a difference.
Which is sometimes both the best and the worst feeling a game with any player count can give you, but I think it's especially poignant in solo games.
Automa is excellent from start to finish, and believe it or not, I [b]still[/b] have depths to plumb.
I'm wondering if I should do an enormous playthrough of everything (I like Aboriculture the best thus far, although I feel that I could grow to like Formaggio just as much, though I feel it's the most advanced of the expansions).
Viticulture is great. Viticulture with Tuscany is exquisite.

item.body:
I decided to break this one out of the dust for the challenge. Since it's been awhile, I need to reacquaint myself. Had the place to myself this morning (afternoon will be hectic) so I treated myself to a session of this as a reward for surviving this week. In the morning, I tend to feel most optimistic and have the most energy so it's a great time to do it (it's also a great time to tend to my responsibilities, but priorities amirite).
Well, it's definitely been awhile. I ended up with a Fab-o score of, dum da da dum(!), 14. Wait, it gets better! I had two loans(!) so 12. This was my first game where I bought the improved shed to hold 4 veggies.
I realize now that one thing I was doing was trying to sell and not plant. This meant I had to keep buying. Despite my best efforts, I had to recompensate many angry customers repeatedly.
I really enjoyed this session because I saw where I could improve, that's always time well spent. One thing I'll point out that's obvious to many of us, When it's clear you're going to lose (and lose badly), instead of wrapping up the game then and there it is sometimes worth it to keep going because you will see the end result of your planning and possibly learn something. The early game chaos will feel that much less chaotic next time.
Have it setup already for another go around when I get some time to do so.
I don't want to give any negatives because of my mood recently so I'll just give one positive
:thumbsup: It's great to play a game that plays in less than an hour but you actually build an engine and feel a real evolution and progression. I love building engines (the gifts that keep on giving!) and Uwe's magic is certainly present here.
If anyone is wondering, despite the planting being similar to how it is done in Agricola, the main economic decisions here of spending money to make more money (as opposed to what most euros call "economic") really make this game feel different to the rest of his games. The market is static but you're constantly struggling to increase your income and that, to me, is much more satisfying than trying to attain VPs. Although there are VPs in this game, they are ONLY earned by spending money so your focus is just on making money. The game is very mathy in that sense and it's awesome!

item.objectname: Don't Tread On Me: The American Revolution Solitaire Board Game
item.body:
Just got this one on the table last night to take it for a test drive. It's (self-admittedly) not a simulation but an abstracted look at the challenges and strategies related to the war for American independence.
The player is the British (which includes Regulars, Loyalist, Hessian, Indian, and naval units), while the system takes care of the American rebels (which includes Continentals, Committees of Security, smugglers/privateers, and French allies). Militia is handled abstractly on a battle-by-battle basis, which is one of the cooler tidbits in this rather unique system.
At first blush the map was a negative, but there is a clever functionality to how things mesh: sea zones off of regions (dubbed "states" in-game), four sections (dubbed "counties" in-game) per state, each with a terrain designation, which in turn meshes with unit ratings.
My first few turns have been dramatic swings of momentum. My British Regulars (dubbed "Lobsters" in-game, and how can you not like that?!?) annihilated a sizable American presence in New England, only to have the tables turned due to a major American campaign shortly thereafter which almost swept the board clean of my red crustaceans. THAT, in turn, was followed by a decimating dose of smallpox and enlistments running out (take that one-two punch, you rascally colonists!). When I left the board last night, units were few and far between, and the Americans were peacefully drinking Sam Adams while I pondered a career in IPA shipping.
:shake:
More to follow...

item.objectname: The Hunters: German U-Boats at War, 1939-43
item.body:
My wife was on a business trip all this week, so I was left to my own devices after the kids went to sleep. Solitaire games ahoy!
I picked this one up last weekend after watching Das Boot for the first time, and have played a couple games. My first playthrough, with Kommandant Fredirich Keller, was mediocre: he survived the war, and ended up with 170,000 tons of ships sunk, but I played it entirely too safe. That total took 17 patrols, and there were numerous opportunities missed because I wasn't aggressive enough.
My current playthrough is shaping up to be much more exciting. I sank a capital ship on my second patrol, and I'm getting smarter at picking out targets.

I've been working on a variant of this, a version based on the worlds of Patrick Rothfuss' Kingkiller Chronicles, called Tales of the Four Corners. The hard thing about adapting a game like this is that you'd typically examine the game to see what to tweak and how to fit everything in, but the very last thing I want to do is look too closely through the encounter book! So, I've been doing the next best thing, and playing solo games while choosing reactions I typically wouldn't, to see what happens. Court the beggar, taunt the djinn, drink from the black river! It's true, I am encountering things I've never seen before, and sometimes it works out well, but in general, I've found my first instincts are pretty sound. You don't need to eat the yellow snow to know that it probably tastes bad...

item.objectname: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.body: Along with SotM, I've been playing some Legendary lately (I'm on a big card games/superhero kick, apparently). I've been enjoying everything for it, although I'm not particularly excited for Fear Itself. What I have been enjoying is playing around with my first custom expansion, [filepage=110960]Starjammers![/filepage] Between this, Fantastic Four and Guardians of the Galaxy, there's a lot of neat content for the cosmic side of Marvel.

I had a few minutes with nothing to do this afternoon so I pulled out Onirim. I really do enjoy this game. It's so quick and fun, yet I feel like I have tough decisions to make.
I played with Book of Steps Lost and Found and I really played badly. I kept discarding cards hoping to get the colors I needed. What I should have been doing was use the discarded cards to swap for the doors I could find instead of hoping for the cards to open the doors I couldn't find. By the end, there was simply nothing left for me. I guess I'll be stuck in that labrynth for awhile.
When I first played the game, I thought that the base game was okay, and the expansions really brought it to life. Now, I still feel that is true and I enjoy the expansions, but sometimes I just want to enjoy the elegant simplicity of the base game.
:thumbsup: I really love this second edition. It's superbly put together and the packaging just fits the game so well. It's always a treat to open up that box. :thumbsdown: The cards of the second edition are such lower quality than the first edition. I'm surprised by the decision by Z-Man. I can't believe they didn't keep the card quality the same. :thumbsdown: It makes me wish I kept the first edition so I could use those cards when I wasn't playing with the new expansion.
On a side note: Justin, this game is awesome. It's worth the trouble you've had with the misprinted copy. :)
[b]Edit:[/b] Here's another thumbs up... :thumbsup: This is an easy game to play when I'm not wearing my contacts.

item.objectname: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.body:
I had been awhile since I last pulled this off the shelf, which is part of the reason I added it to my [geeklist=183042]10x10 challenge[/geeklist]. I decided to play the Emergence scenario again as a rules refresher. I went with Marcus and Augustus.
Even though it is just the introductory scenario, I did find myself scrambling to complete the mission. I was able to close the last emergence hole without too much worry, but the mob of Locusts that appeared afterwards presented a bit of a challenge. Augustus ended-up bleeding out after I left him open to a Boomer after a failed mortar attack. Luckily, Marcus had just enough life and luck left to finish off the last group of Locusts.
I had forgotten how much fun and tense this game can be. I'm looking forward to moving on to the China Shop scenario, which I have never been able to complete.
[b]2/18 Update[/b]
This update is well over a week late as I just haven't had the time to update this thing. Anyway... I was able to take a few more cracks at the China Shop scenario and am happy to report that I finally got a victory.
The first few plays were pretty much par for the course. I would get about halfway through only to get ambushed by a gang of locusts and die. I finally decided to change my strategy up a bit. Instead of trying to defeat all the Locusts in my path, I would be more selective and make getting to cover my main priority.
The benefits of this approach were immediately noticeable as I noticed that keeping 1 or 2 drones and/or wretches around actually reduced the amount that would spawn through the AI cards. The overall threat level became easier to manage and I was able to spend a few turns just hanging out, filling up some life and/or luring Locusts to their doom. There was still a fair amount of running and gunning, but that mostly came during the last part of the scenario.
[imageid=2419890] [i][b]Who's the big man now?!?![/b][/i]
In the end, I was able to lure the berserker to the courtyard and defeat him with a nice Teamwork/Pummel combo. Victory!

[b][i]Game 1[/i][/b] (without shadow card): [color=red][b]Defeat[/b][/color] turn #6 (No ally to defend against the Hill Troll) [b][i]Game 2[/i][/b] (without shadow card): [color=green][b]Victory[/b][/color] turn #18 ; 170+46-15=201 Pts (well, this deck is quite slow. Cause, first I didn't remember the Beorn's trick when I build my first deck, and I think it will be awesome here. Well, this is just the Sneaked Beorn here as I think that Stand and Fight is not part of the base deck but a support card in case.

[b]Score: 0 (Death in the Pit)[/b]
[b]Character:[/b] Scholar
After reading [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/183994/item/3644248#item3644248]the session report in last month's SGoYT list[/url] by [user=repairmanjack][/user] and doing a bit of research, I found myself intrigued and ordered a set of cards for this nifty PnP dungeon crawler. It was a great solitaire experience; the design is clever and intuitive and plays smoothly while offering some agonizing decisions.
I drew the Scholar to start off, and proceeded to bumble my way around the dungeon. After the first level, I had the mechanics and game flow down pretty well. It's great how the cards drive everything and have multiple uses. I found them very easy to use and read no matter what their purpose.
It rapidly became clear to me that it is primarily a hand-management game. Cards in the hand represent hit points -- when you have none left, you are dead and lose the game. Thus, having to discard a card to do almost everything in the game creates a delicious tension. Even something as mundane as moving to another room becomes fraught as you not only choose which type of card to discard to execute the action, but also which sort of wandering monster you must potentially face.
I managed to get through the first five levels well enough, although there were some close calls in there. At one point I got to a Mystic Portal with just a single card left in my hand -- I would not have been able to move again had the Portal not been there to let me descend and gain a fruit for resting.
I wasn't quite sure what try for in terms of character development, so I settled for collecting cash and upping my basic stats as often as I could. I hit the Peculiar Store on the first three levels, and kept thinking it would turn up in the future, but I never saw it again. While I picked up (and used) several mundane items and potions, I got nothing I would consider terribly powerful.
But I made it to level 8 and had about as good a setup as possible. I had all three abilities maxed out, but I descended from level 6-7 with only one card left. The first room was the Hidden Door with 0 danger but ((A)) check1 for a monster to fight, with a 2-5 chance at getting a monster. A monster would have killed me, but I drew a 1 to get an item! It was just a rope, but I was relieved simply to survive. Then, since it was danger 0 and I had the fruit from descending, I immediately rested to get back up to 9 cards. Then I used a move card to move (keeping hand size at 9) and found the Mystic Portal! I decided it would be best to hit level 8 with 9 cards and a fruit, so I descended then and there without exploring level 7 further. The first card of level 8 was the Mystic Portal. I used a move card to start exploring and found the Pit of Darkness; this meant I was hitting the final tests/combat with a full hand of 9 cards.
And not just any 9 cards: I had two 5-INT, two 5-AGL and two 5-STR. With my abilities upgraded to the maximum +4 each, this was about as good as it was going to get. I easily passed the first two tests to enter the treasure pit for the combat with the Ice Dragon. I had two 5-STR cards and a +4 STR score. I did not have any arrows or strength items, however, so I would need to draw a 4 or a 5 power for the second effort in order to beat the dragon's 13 STR. I drew a 3 the first time, falling one short. Then the second time a drew a 3. I then threw down a 5 move card I had drawn, but drew a 2 for second effort. At this point, I chose to run away, which I managed to do by discarding all but one card. Then I used my one fruit to rest at the top of the pit and fill up to 9 cards for another try.
Alas, I drew nothing higher than a 4, and then only two of these. Reentering the Pit, I failed the first two INT tests to open the door, but got it open finally. I then managed to pass the AGL test to get into the treasure pit, but I was left with a hand of nothing higher than 3's -- insufficient to beat the Ice Dragon since his STR is 13. Death ensued when I couldn't muster enough to run away. Not that running would have made a difference: I was out of fruit, so would have been limited to teleporting out of the dungeon and merely surviving.
In hindsight, I should have moved to the portal after my first attempt on the pit failed and simply left the dungeon, at least gaining a Survival result; however ignominious that might be, it would have at least gotten me a small positive score. I can see how holding onto some items/potions which increase combat strength is beneficial for this final battle. In future sessions, I will be much more chary of using such things without dire need.
I am highly impressed with this design. It packs a deep, immersive and tense experience into a small package with the ingeniously implemented multiple use cards. It will be hitting my table again soon.

Getting back to my [geeklist=183197]2015 Challenge[/geeklist] focused on bicycle racing games with this one.
1. [2/6] This was my first play of this game, and, as usual, I missed a critical rule until about halfway through. It didn't necessarily affect the outcome of the race, but does make a big difference in terms the overall feel of the game. Nonetheless, I'm looking forward to another couple of plays to get a better grasp of where it falls on my list of cycling games. I may also have to take a shot at one of the other language versions of the rules to make sure the English one is correct, or that I'm interpreting it correctly.
2. [2/7] This is a quick playing game, even when playing all 12 riders solo. I was more confident about the rules this second time through and appreciated the flow of the riders, which seems to reflect what one would expect on the road given the course I chose and the energy I used for each rider. Next time out, I'll make a longer course since that should complicate the decisions on energy use through the race. These first two plays have demonstrated some of the tactical nuances of the system, now I have to see if I can implement them more effectively.
3. [2/7] With a longer course this time out, the elegance of the game mechanics became more apparent. Proper use of energy, both stretching it out over a whole race and choosing the moment to exert the crucial effort, are critical factors here. Some of the tactical subtleties are also revealing themselves.
The game designers suggest expanding the rules to include specialist riders and other factors. With an excellent base to work with, I think this game is an excellent candidate for development that way. It's also one of my favorite things to do with these games...:whistle:
It's been very interesting to see how the different games try to accomplish their goal of providing the flavor of a bicycle race on a cardboard map. This whole process is also demonstrating to me the value of a 10 x 10 type of challenge. Perhaps next year I'll delve deeper into the games I find most interesting. My fear is that I'll end up with 20 games that need more investigation, and there's no way I can get in that many in one year. :(

[2/1] I hadn't played this for a couple of years and it showed! :blush: My local volunteer firefighters will be very happy that I just call Bingo for them and don't get near any fires! Firefighters were knocked down continuously, most of the household died, and then the whole thing fell down, taking out the rest of the family. Quite a debacle, but it left me anxious to go back for another try. I'm hoping to finally get one of the expansions on the table.
Oh, I forgot to mention, I did save the dog!:shake:

I can't believe I haven't seen anyone post about this game on here yet.
I wasn't a fan of Ghost Stories even though I liked the art, and so I traded that away a while ago. The same designer put out Samurai Spirit, and I personally like the theme better as I studied martial arts for years, and am a big fan of samurai flicks.
I played my first 2 games of it tonight and each game takes about 30 minutes or so. The game seems quite easy on the surface - you're playing cards and making decisions on 1 of 3 actions each turn, but you never really know what's in the deck - that is until your first round is complete.
See that's where the beauty lies in the game - you have an idea based on probabilities of what could be coming, but don't know for sure. It's like a ninja is waiting beyond the gate, and you know it; but from which clan - the wannabes "1's" or the skilled "4's". But wait, perhaps you can know, that is if you use the samurai that has the power to see the card and decide to discard to the bottom of the deck. Stand and fight, but don't get overwhelmed, otherwise your village starts to burn - and that's no good for anybody.
When you stand and fight you also have to decide if you're going to slot the card on your right or left side - left side is defensive, and if all 3 slots are not filled at the end of a round, you face a penalty. Slot it on the right and the numbers start to accrue towards your maximum - and if you land on your max you get an extra power to use, if you go over, you barricades start to burn. When you fight someone you also get assessed a penalty based on the card for the next draw, so that makes the choice a little harder (or perhaps you have a samurai that nullifies the even card penalties).
Once the first round is completed, you add in some additional enemies "5's" for the second round and "6's" for the third round. If you can defeat them you win.
All I can say is WOW! Any way you slice this, it's one hell of a game, and as good as Friday is, this will be my go to filler game for a long time.
:thumbsup: Game play and artwork is excellent :thumbsup: Box and insert fits perfectly and there's no wasted space :thumbsdown: not enough people seem to be playing it on SGoYT

item.body: Played Journey Along the Anduin two handed using two sphere decks. I took a mulligan on one hand, but went three rounds before I was wiped out. I kept pulling creatures who combined w/the Hill Troll just did me in. I feel if you just use the base set cards, not getting the snare out right away just spells doom.

My last post got a little long, so I decided to add a short one here after my play tonight.
Did a best of 7 against a pretty stacked AI team that only had a few defensive cards. He seemed to play them right at the best time.
I lost the first 3 games and was in danger of losing the series, but some clear buys, and a dash of luck let me win my next 4 in a row!
I gave myself 5 buy rounds, so I suppose this was "easy", but my opponent could hammer out the runs...
Ive now played this three times, and I think the design is pretty cool. It doesn't exactly feel like I'm managing a baseball team, but at the same time, the decisions sort of mirror what managers do, and I feel quite a bit of tension when I flip that last card from the AI, or my save attempt.
Heck, the whole series came down to the past save attempt by the AI, which didn't do enough to keep me from winning by one!
The more I play this, the more I think it'll easily replace Star Realms for a quick solo Deckbuilding(ish) game. This isn't really a traditional deck builder. I'm still not sure if it's the theme that appeals to me so much, but I think the game play is pretty clever, and the mechanics are simple, but allow for some tactical and strategic flexibility and response.
item.comment: More love for this game. I got to play a series with my brother while traveling this week and I was a bit surprised to find that I actually enjoyed soloing it a bit more. I think learning how to counter the AI deck over the course of the series is a fun mental exercise.

I am also enjoying this solo much more than I anticipated. Enough so that I went ahead and bought the expansion players so that once I think I've totally figured it out I'll be able to retool the AI deck so it's pwning again. I originally bought it to play with my dad but I'm pleasantly surprised at the solo challenge.
Even though it's only a six card hand per game there's crazy tension, heartache when your batters get zeroed or fist pumps when you empty the bases. Your run cushion is never large enough so every card you have to adjust your strategy for the most effect.....it's a thinker.

item.body:
This was my pickup after returning my flawed copy of Onirim. I recently caught wind that this was the 200th anniversary of the battle and given my enjoyment of learning history and lack of knowledge about Napoleon's battles, I thought this would be a fun, inexpensive addition.
First thing noticed: Whoa, those are some small counters. I knew the game was a light production and the box felt as such, but only 74 small counters was surprising. Not a bad thing by any stretch. The overall production is simple, but attractive.
Second thing I notice: That player aid looks kind of detailed. Wait... that's the whole rulebook?! Again, I knew this was a relatively light game, but I figured there'd be a bit more to it.
Third thing noticed: I wish there were a bit more history in the rulebook, but I suppose I can get that anywhere. Onward...
So I set it up and have played through 2 pretty quick turns. The game moves fast as it's just move/attack, move/attack alternating between French and Allied forces. So far, the Allies have successfully managed to contain Napoleon with reinforcements due out next turn. Already seems to be reflecting history, but you never know what Napoleon might have up his sleeve.
Or... you do.
[imageid=2405897]
[b]Update:[/b] I had to abort my first play due to getting the retreat rules wrong. I was giving both sides a major advantage by letting them retreat into enemy zones of control. I thought something didn't feel right.
So play 2 got underway and things felt much different. This game seems pretty stilted to the Allies, which I suppose makes sense. However, it doesn't feel impossible for the French to overcome the odds and push through. Victory is determined by who inflicts 40 strength point losses first, but Napoleon has to also get 7 units through the other end of the map. The Allies were victorious at turn 5. The map ended up looking like so:
[imageid=2407005 medium]
:thumbsup: Very easy to pick up and get going, but there is some thought involved in the way you maneuver your troops and utilize cover.
:thumbsdown::thumbsup: It is just a move and attack game. Simpler than chess when you get down to it.
I'm hard pressed to think of other knocks against it. Overall, I'm pretty happy. It's as advertised: a simple, fast-playing recreation of one of history's most famous battles. The tactics may not get more intricate than advance/hold/flank, but the tension of the "will they or won't they break through?" is there.

item.body:
Instead of sleeping in as fitting for a Saturday, my biorythm decided to stay on weekday mode, waking me at 5:40. Quiet time in the house and the chance for some reading (Am way too slow to get the THE MALAZAN BOOK OF THE FALLEN series read while my memory lasts to remember characters and events from earlier books :cool:, currently reading book 4), rules checking (finding out that I did play movement incorrect in PATHISTORY), brewing tea (a good 1st flush Darjeeling) and trying out the newest addition to my game collection.
Compared to ONIRIM, this feels like a walk in the park - not in terms of winning the game but in the hurt and pain along the way. There is a nice flow in this game once I remembered that icons need to be observed when playing a card. I like the discard and swatch mechanism - basically giving you the chance to bring out some cards here and there and then swap some to gain equilibrium in two cities at once.
I found it very easy to clear 10 cities in my two games and was then struggling to clear the final two (beimg one card short for the final city in my first game and having a complete mess in my second game). This tells me that I should aim to have maybe three cities left on the table for better swapping options. So, two losses to start with.
What I observed: when I draw a chaos card, I almost always discarded cards at an unbalanced city. Only once did I place it and I never chose the option of drawing and discarding four cards as this feels too expensive.
item.comment: Im into book six (The Bonehunters) of the Malazan series and i have to say that it wont get any less confusing :p. Perhaps i will have to read everything from scratch some day? :what: The way the world evolves is just fantastic!

[q]What I observed: when I draw a chaos card, I almost always discarded cards at an unbalanced city. Only once did I place it and I never chose the option of drawing and discarding four cards as this feels too expensive.[/q] It seems that you're playing this rule wrong. You can discard all cards only from an unclaimed BALANCED city upon drawing a Chaos card.

[q="abersen"]Im into book six (The Bonehunters) of the Malazan series and i have to say that it wont get any less confusing :p. Perhaps i will have to read everything from scratch some day? :what: The way the world evolves is just fantastic![/q]
I have a strange relationship with that book series.
I despised the first book when I read it, but I reread it and liked it more. The second one was decent, but I felt it dragged way too much. The third was kind of cool, but the grimdark stuff got a bit annoying.
So I stopped reading. But now that I think about it, it does some really cool stuff. I feel I should keep reading, and that I liked it. But it also annoys me.

The first book got me completely hooked - even though quite some story strands were opened quite suddenly. Only in the third book have some been shed with more light, helping me to grasp some background. What I really struggle with, in the speed I am reading the books, have been some quick changes in the narrative, some half dozen strands and ten times as many characters to follow. This is not made easier with the more demanding English vocabulary.
In some parts I also thought the second book dragged a bit long. In retrospect it was an awesome story of the struggle of the chain of dogs. Felt like a constant tower defense game on the move (which would be a cool idea to turn into a game).
These books share the basic atmosphere of A Game of Thrones: a deep world, deep characters who all have their good and dark sides. And who are all in danger of dying on the next page... :sauron: Really looking forward to the remaining 6 books (which are all published already - take that, G.R.R Martin! :) )

[q="juanma99"][q]What I observed: when I draw a chaos card, I almost always discarded cards at an unbalanced city. Only once did I place it and I never chose the option of drawing and discarding four cards as this feels too expensive.[/q] It seems that you're playing this rule wrong. You can discard all cards only from an unclaimed BALANCED city upon drawing a Chaos card.[/q]
Oh, did I read that rule incorrectly? Would make the game tougher, for sure. :D
Thanks for the help!

[q="HRune"]The first book got me completely hooked - even though quite some story strands were opened quite suddenly. Only in the third book have some been shed with more light, helping me to grasp some background. What I really struggle with, in the speed I am reading the books, have been some quick changes in the narrative, some half dozen strands and ten times as many characters to follow. This is not made easier with the more demanding English vocabulary.
In some parts I also thought the second book dragged a bit long. In retrospect it was an awesome story of the struggle of the chain of dogs. Felt like a constant tower defense game on the move (which would be a cool idea to turn into a game).
These books share the basic atmosphere of A Game of Thrones: a deep world, deep characters who all have their good and dark sides. And who are all in danger of dying on the next page... :sauron: Really looking forward to the remaining 6 books (which are all published already - take that, G.R.R Martin! :) )[/q]
I like the depth of the world. There's a lot going on, and I like how the story is gradually revealed. Thus is something the I also think is really well done in Sanderson's Stormlight Archive.
What I don't like is that it's obviously written based off their Rpg campaign. Anomander Rake is a dumb character. He's a grimdark emo elf with a giant sword that captures souls in it. Oh, and he can turn into a dragon (when it's convenient to the plot), though he doesn't frequently. The concept is cool, but it just obvious he's an NPC from their stories.
The Chain of Dogs was OK, but it just went on for about 200 too many pages. They get attacked, and they run. Then the flee some more. And the situation is bad. And it's so bad. And things are awful. It's just a bit too heavy handed.
I think the problem is that Erickson isn't a great writer. He creates cool stories and a great world, and a few cool characters (and some genuinely stupid ones..... Don't get me started on Kruppe), but his actual ability to craft that together into a well paced story is lacking.
As much as I complain, it's still better than a lot of the other drivel out there. I read Cephrael's Hand, and it was trash. Just so bad. It, seriously, used the word "verily" in the narration. The a few pages later, used the phrase "who is the broad?".

Sounds like a great (albeit early) Saturday morning.
I've had this game on my shelf for a couple of years now. Got it at the same time as Onirim and I play that one all the time. I think I've been too lazy to sit down and read the rules to figure out how to play Urbion. Thanks for the reminder, this one is now moving up on my list.

item.body:
Based mainly on seeing it on SGOYT, this game rocketed to the top of my wishlist over the last year, and I was lucky enough to receive a very nice trade with another 1-Player Guild member shortly after Christmas. Tonight, I finally got it onto the table. I decided to ramp up the complexity by adding in the expansions one at a time, so my first game used only base game components.
I randomly received the Druid, Seer, Prince, and Scholar characters. I was honestly not too thrilled with this lineup, since they didn't promise to be that great at combat, but I stuck with them anyway. For the first few rounds, the Seer and Scholar moved up into the mountains and searched (uncovering two keys very quickly), while the Druid defeated a Blight in the Village. Later one, the heroes all gravitated toward the Castle to try to beef up their skills. The Prince came VERY close to death at one point, only surviving by rolling a 6 on his event-initiated combat. Once the Scholar found the Ancient Sword and Find Weakness, he moved to the Ruins, clearing them out, while the Seer brought him the last key. Combining the three keys, the Scholar grabbed a Holy Relic while the other heroes grouped at the Ruins to serve as his backup. The Prince Inspired him, and then the Scholar's Event draw (Ritual) brought the Necromancer right to his feet. Rolling three dice, he got two 6s, which easily killed the Necromancer with the bonuses from Holy Relic and Ancient Sword. Since the Ruins was clear of Blights, that won me the game with the Darkness track at 20.
This game definitely lived up to my expectations. I love the style of the visuals and the overall mood, and a lot of the mechanics (Map cards, the way Powers work) are really clever. I do feel like some of the heroes I had in my party were difficult/unintuitive to use, especially the Seer, who had a lot of great powers but never seemed to shine.

item.body:
(vs. Automa)
[b]Defeat[/b] Me: 20 Automa: 20
In my third solo session of Viticulture, I did much better than in the previous two. However, I still came up short of victory, tying Automa at 20. I did not play with the moving Automa VPs or aggressive option, preferring to win one before moving on.
What I did differently in this session was focus on a single plan based primarily around what I got from the Mama and Papa at the start of the game. In this case, it was a spring visitor and two wine orders from the Mama, and $2 and a Tasting Room/$5 from the Papa. I chose the Tasting room figuring that it would be worth 6-7 VP over the course of the game, assuming I could get into the tour space almost every turn.
What I didn't have at the start was a vine card, so I had to draw one of those with my first wake-up action. It required a Trellis, but fortunately, the initial spring visitor was an Architect. I used him to build a Cottage for just $1 then paid $2 to build a Trellis, having given a tour with my first action. This used all three of my workers, however.
I never managed to get a fourth worker, which I'm pretty sure was the difference between victory and defeat in this session. I believe that I built too many structures -- I should have forgone the Cottage and used that money for a fourth worker instead. The extra visitor cards I drew using the Cottage did help my cause, but I think a fourth worker for most of the game would have helped more. As it was, I had to forgo giving a tour twice in the game, including the final turn, because I needed that worker elsewhere.
I was fortunate for most of the game in the Automa worker placements. In the first half of the game, they were rarely in my way or even nonexistent, but in the latter turns, they did cause some trouble, limiting my options. Automa did not limit my options as much as my lack of a fourth worker did.
I kept my focus on fulfilling the wine orders I had, one of which required a large cellar. Getting the money for this and then building it took too many actions; again, I think I would have been better served by forgoing the Cottage and saving my money for other stuff. Just one additional big wine order would have gotten me as many points as I gained from the Cottage, for instance. I didn't fulfill any until the last two turns, however. I simply didn't have the workers to do more.
On turn 6, I fulfilled a big order for 6 VP. The on the final turn, sitting on 15 VP, I did a second order for 3 VP and used a winter visitor (The Judge?) to give up a medium wine for 2 VP. This got me to 20 and a tie with Automa.
In my next session, I am going to spend some time at the start thinking about what I got from the Mama and Papa and how I can parlay that head start into points. It's becoming clear to me that it is best to go in the direction their "legacy" pushes you toward. They provide a head start of some sort, but the challenge for someone new to the game like myself is to figure out what path you've been started on and how best to follow it efficiently.
I am quite impressed with this design, and I was not at all certain I would be. I took the plunge on the purchase only after exhaustive due diligence through myriad reviews and videos, but the devil is always in my personal perception of the gameplay details. I find the game very clean; the mechanics are simple, and the options not overwhelming, but there are many meaningful choices to make, each with long-term implications. The game rewards thoughtful planning ahead; scoring usually happens in bursts in the latter part of the game after various elements come to fruition. The trick is getting the components of a scoring move to come together at the right time while having the necessary workers and open action slots available to make it happen. That this all fits intuitively with the theme of winemaking (a time-intensive, long-term process) is a huge strength of the design.
The "legacy" style expansions in Tuscany are another great element, providing something to shoot for in solo play; win a particular set up often enough, and you are ready to change the game with a new expansion tier, giving you a different set of parameters to mull over and master. The full package of base game and expansion is certainly a big expense, but so far anyway, it seems to offer more than sufficient bang for the bucks.
item.comment: I'm still trying to figure out a solid strategy for this one too. I started a Tuscany campaign, but so far I haven't been able to get past the first stage. My highest score was 19. It is such a great game though and I hope to get it to the table this week after a bit of a hiatus.

It took me four tries to beat the 20-point Automa score for 1 expansion (Mamas & Papas).
The solitaire targets are tough. I'm learning the importance of optimizing efficiency. All those leftover wine and grape tokens at the end of the game represent wasted efforts.
In my first few multi-player games I put off getting wine order cards because there is so much else that needs to be accomplished. Perhaps wine order cards are needed earlier than I thought to allow for targeting of my efforts and optimizing efficiency.

Yeah, efficiency is the key to beating the AI. The "easy" AI also gets easier to beat the more expansions are added.
Here are some tips from my ... apparently 13 plays of Viticulture thus far, heading into Tier 3 of the campaign.
1. Draw vine cards ASAP so you know the order of building the two vine-related structures, the trellis and irrigation. You will typically need both in the end, but figuring out which to build first so you can plant as early as possible (and thus harvest as early as possible) is vital.
2. Draw wine order cards ASAP as well. If you luck out you might get ones that only require a medium cellar, which means you can optimize filling wine orders sooner. Otherwise you'll know that you need to find a way to get the large cellar in.
3. Visitor cards are also vital for gaining the odd VPs here and there and being able to execute actions that you're blocked from by the AI (for instance, I highly cherish winter visitors that allow me to fill a wine order. It means that I can possibly fill two wine orders in one year. I also really like the ones that allow me to do one thing and draw another visitor card or draw another wine order card.
4. Make sure you're playing all the rules correctly. Remember: - when harvesting, do not remove your vines. they stay on the fields. - do not reset your residual income to zero at the end of the year. - age both your grapes and your wines. - on the regular board, always pick up a visitor card when passing to the second half of the year.
5. When playing on the regular board (as opposed to the extended board) your bonus tokens should aim towards harvesting more than one field typically.
6. The earlier you begin to produce grapes, the better your chances of filling wine orders that require very "old" reds and whites. Also you'll have more grapes, which will allow you to create blushes and especially sparkling wines.
7. If playing with Mamas and Papas (which you should be, because otherwise Automa punches you and takes your lunch lira) try to build strategies around what your papa and mama give you.
- Papa gives you a trellis or irrigation. Get a head start on planting vines.
- Papa gives you a medium cellar. You are fortunate, and look out for visitor cards in winter that will allow you to upgrade your cellar for cheaper than 6 lira
- Papa gives you a cottage. This is great because you draw an extra visitor every year. This will widen your opportunities for practically everything.
- Papa gives you a windmill. Try to plant often to get VPs (1 max per year). It seems small, but it gives you VPs to burn to pay for uncertified teachers or oneologists. You can always go to negative VPs of course but the windmill gives you a cushion.
- Mama gives you wine order cards. If they are good ones (4 - 6 VPs, lean towards 6 VPs) then build your strategy around getting them delivered early since those are card draw actions you no longer have to take.
- Mama gives you visitor cards. Similar to the cottage situation, except you get the boost earlier and it doesn't last as long.
- Mama gives you vine cards. Get a head start on planting them.
That's what I can think of, off the top of my head at the moment.
[b]ETA:[/b] Get a harmonious mix of vines in the fields. If you can do it:
1 field with high sum of either red or white grapes. These will get you higher quality wines faster for the "big and old" wine orders (like 6 red, 8 white, etc).
2 fields with a mix of red and white grapes. These will allow you to create blushes, sparklers, and fill 3-wine orders faster.

item.body:
I am fascinated by WWII and I got Memoir 44 as a way to experience some of the history, even if it is in a slightly abstracted way. However, I haven't really found anyone to play it with me. When I first got the game, in 2011, I tried it out on a few people but nobody really enjoyed it. I've kept the game, though, hoping that my son might play it with me when he's older. It's funny to me, because I am pretty quick to get rid of games that don't get played. Yet, I've held on to Memoir.
Seeing it show up on SGOYT inspired me to play it solo. I wasn't sure the best way to go about it though. I'd read that there are a few solo methods, but [b][user=Ad79]Stig[/user][/b], who's played this a bunch, told me I should just play both sides. So I did.
I've played the first three scenarios so far, Pegasus Bridge, Sainte MÃ¨re-Ãglise, and Sword Beach. This has been a good start. The game is very fun solo and it's very interesting trying to play both sides at once. I do feel like I have a bias toward the Allies, so I'm afraid I'm not playing the Axis side as best as I can. The Allies have won every time, and I'm afraid I (the Axis) let them. I'm sure that I will get the hang of it though.
It's also really great how the different scenarios actually feel different. From first glance, it seems that the Memoir system is capable of some great and varied stuff. I should probably say Command and Colors system because that seems to spawn so many different games (and it's the first, I think).
[b]Edit:[/b] Battle Cry was the first, not C&C. Thanks Ava!
item.comment: Battle Cry was the first in the C&C series. They taught me a lot about historical battles, especially Ancients. I had never heard of Cannae before.
When I solo this I also have a bias, but mine is different. I am biased towards whatever side historically lost the battle. I love an underdog.

Very easy to play solo. Just draw 3 cards, use 1 and discard. Put the other 2 into a reuse stack. Shuffle the reuse stack to form new draw pile until they are all gone, then shuffle all cards (now discarded) to form draw pile.
Then there is no advance knowledge of what the other "side" has.

[q="klkitchens"]Very easy to play solo. Just draw 3 cards, use 1 and discard. Put the other 2 into a reuse stack. Shuffle the reuse stack to form new draw pile until they are all gone, then shuffle all cards (now discarded) to form draw pile.
Then there is no advance knowledge of what the other "side" has.[/q]
Thanks Kevin, that sounds like a good way to do it. I had been thinking to just draw one card, but that could end up with some very poor play by the other side. But with three cards, I can pick the best for the situation without having advanced knowledge, like you said.
Could you explain the reuse pile some more? I'm not quite grasping it.

[q="Malaiser"][q="klkitchens"]Very easy to play solo. Just draw 3 cards, use 1 and discard. Put the other 2 into a reuse stack. Shuffle the reuse stack to form new draw pile until they are all gone, then shuffle all cards (now discarded) to form draw pile.
Then there is no advance knowledge of what the other "side" has.[/q]
Thanks Kevin, that sounds like a good way to do it. I had been thinking to just draw one card, but that could end up with some very poor play by the other side. But with three cards, I can pick the best for the situation without having advanced knowledge, like you said.
Could you explain the reuse pile some more? I'm not quite grasping it. [/q]
Sure... you have three piles.
DRAW DISCARD (used cards) REUSE (unused, but drawn cards)
You draw 3 from the draw pile and the one that gets played goes into the discard. The other two were never actually "used" and should have a chance to be used before the discards come back into play. So I put them in a different pile. When the draw pile is gone, you'll have discards and reuse piles left. You cycle through the reuse cards again to insure the balance of card distribution isn't messed up. Only when the draw and reuse stacks are depleted (meaning they are ALL in the discard pile) do you reshuffle the discards.
This works great here, but was imperative in [thing=128204][/thing] where each side can only use their cards once (once through the draw pile)

item.body:
[b]We have a tie![/b]
Prior to playing CC:E, I only had one other game rated at â9â on my list, and that was [thing=1608]Ambush[/thing]. After implementing [filepage=108109]Domostie's Solo Variant[/filepage] on CC:E, I now have two. Although ambush probably edges CC:E out a bit, since it was designed purely for solo play, CC:E has enough flavor, theme, and solo surprises to be right behind it. In the long run, it might have more, since there is more replayability.
[b]Scenario:[/b] Startup intro scenario (designed to introduce the game mechanics) Germans: AI defenders Russians: Me (attackers)
[b]Time: 0[/b] -Russians off to a good start with the infantry gun crew breaking Sgt Ganz and his rifle squad with a long range attack down the tree-lined road. Sgt Ganz is routed for a one-hex retreat out of Objective #3, but his rifle squad rallies. -The Russian Guards Rifle squads make their way through the forest to the treeline opposite emplaced German squad in house (Objective #5). German LMG takes opportunity fire and breaks one Russian squad. -Time!
[imageid=2406464]
[b]Time: 1[/b] -Russians dig in along the treeline, but a squad is broken by that pesky LMG in OBJ #5. -SGT Ganz rallies, and one of two Russian squads rally. -German LMG squad dig a foxhole in the treeline, but still take a hit from the Russian Infantry Gun. Germans play a âlight woundâ to avoid breaking (but take a 1 VP hit). -SGT Kaminsky orders a 3 hex firing group against the German LMG in OBJ #3, resulting in suppressing the German squad, but the Germans return fire, suppressing the northern most Russian Guards Rifle squad. -SGT K makes the same group order, but the Germans play another âlight woundsâ to avoid the break! -SGT K orders a rush of OBJ #3 across the road, but they are hit with opportunity fire and receive a mass Russian suppression event! -SGT K rallies his squad and the infantry gun tries to cover them, but suffers an event and the gun breaks, followed by a german sniper completely taking out the gun! Not good for the Russians. -SGT K tries one more group fire on the German LMG. Hits, but the germans keep getting âlight woundsâ to avoid breaking. -Time!
[b]Time:2[/b] -The Russian weapons crew (sans weopan since infantry gun gone) try to make it across the road. They are entangled in wire and face opportunity fire, and â¦ Time!
[b]Time:3[/b] -Russian weapons crew entangles from the wire, but right into a minefield. Fortunately no damage taken. -SGT Ganz orders his Germans into melee, completely destroying a Russian squad. SGT K takes advantage of the Germans vacating OBJ #3, moving in but a squad breaks on the road from opportunity fire from that LMG in the house. -SGT K and LMG make it to OBJ #1. Russians making slow progress. -Time! Sudden Death rollâ¦game continues
[b]Time: 4[/b] -Russian sniper breaks the German LMG squad in OBJ #5, but SGT Ganz breaks another Guard Rifle squad with an attack. -German rifle team makes a rush across the open field, diving into foxholes and popping smoke along the way. Face opportunity fire, but the Russians miss from the smoke and foxhole cover. Event! -German hero appears! He breaks a Guards rifle squad and moves into OBJ #2. -Time! Sudden Death rollâ¦.game continues.
[b]Time: 5[/b] -Russian sniper breaks SGT Ganz and Russian squad sprints across field to a foxhole, but are broken by opportunity fire just prior to jumping in. -SGT Ganz rallies and German sniper breaks Russian Guards Rifle squad in OBJ #3. -Germans play âhidden unitâ and a German HMG Crew enters play. German rifle squad becomes a veteran unit, as does one Russian Guards Rifle squad. -Time! Sudden Death rollâ¦game continues.
[b]Time: 6[/b] -Russian LMG eliminated! Time! Sudden Death rollâ¦Game over
After 7 rounds, German AI wins with 32 VPs
You probably canât really follow along with this AAR, but I hope I was able to express some of the [b][size=18]chaotic fun[/size][/b] that can be had with this great game and a good solo variant.

All good points. When learning the rules, I played both sides normally against "myself" and it was enjoyable. I do that with a lot of games, but I never get the sense of "winning or losing". I generally just feel like I am being a neutral party or referee.
The variant provided a bit more feeling of playing a side. The opponents deck gets quite large with many more options to make it difficult to fight against. If they are able to use an opportunity fire, it is usually pretty devastating since they generally have a lot of + modifiers available. For that reason, I think the variant works for me.

item.body:
I played two games so far.
Game 1: A two handed two player game - Barbarians vs. Romans. I almost got all of the rules right. I messed up the Raze-your opponent's-house rule - I forgot to give the razee wood and turn the card over. I just discarded it. I also thought Deals were made by paying gold instead of food. The Barbarians got off really well. They had a lot of population and also bonuses for razing. The Romans were very slow to get a momentum going, but their last turn was fantastic. They managed to build a lot of their locations. The Barbarians got a lot of VPs throughout the game, but Romans managed a draw. 37 vs 37
Game 2: The solitaire rules playing the Barbarians. I thought I was pretty good, so I tried going against the AI. I had a really bad first turn in which I built just one location. I also made too many deals (which "wasted" my faction cards) and didn't generate a card-drawing combo. I had lots of resources, but nothing worthy to build. And I had lots of common buildings which made razing by the AI easy. I lost 3 to 7 (and had 27 VPs).
I understand the game a bit more.
:thumbsup:Simple rules, buy a deep game underneath. :thumbsup:Lots of replayability, with four very different factions and different ways to score points. :thumbsup:Challenging AI and the published campaign mode. :thimbsup:I keep thinking about it. :thumbsdown:I keep thinking about it.

item.objectname: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â The Black Riders
item.body:
I played this a few weeks ago with the box heros, going for a thematic deck since this is a saga expansion after all and I got creamed. Gave it a few more tries and then put it away after I picked up a few other APs.
Picked it back up last night and played a couple rounds with my all-star deck featuring Spirit Glorfindel, Haldir and Theodred. Got completed destroyed in just a few rounds. Thought perhaps it was just bad luck with the encounter deck so I tried again and got the same result. Frustrated, I got on the BGG LOTR LCG forums and was reminded (doh!) of the recommended deck list on the back of the rule book.
Played again this morning with the recommended deck and I did get a win. It was tense though, those black riders and hide tests really do keep you at the edge of your seat. It was great!
:thumbsup: If you love LOTR books and want to relive them LCG-style, this is the expansion for you. :thumbsup: You only need it, plus 1 copy of the core set, so doesn't require dropping a ton of money to play successfully. :thumbsdown: It's kinda hard for a newbie.
One thing I have to keep reminding myself when I play this game - or any of the LOTR LCG quests - is to read every card carefully. I find myself regularly making rules mistakes because I forgot one little detail on a quest card, or I miss a "when revealed" effect. Gotta slow down.
item.comment:
[q]One thing I have to keep reminding myself when I play this game - or any of the LOTR LCG quests - is to read every card carefully. I find myself regularly making rules mistakes because I forgot one little detail on a quest card, or I miss a "when revealed" effect. Gotta slow down.[/q]
That is true and probably a lot of problems are solved that way. In fact I found that the whole game made a lot more sense when I understood that everything should be read word after word and actions executed sentence after sentence. Then the only difficulty resides in understanding and playing "revealed" correctly.
That expansion is very tempting for me. I find the black riders an aesthetically striking view (I have a weakness for goth designs and am a bit of a horseman) and would love to find the playmat with that illustration on it.

item.body:
Another attempt at the [thread=1312771]Star Realms Challenge #3[/thread].
Started with Brain World & Supply Bot - reportedly the easiest starting combo, and this shows on the Hi Scores. Won the game :) - but with 33 pts, this is the worst score for this combo so far :whistle:
[b][i]Squads 1-10[/b][/i]; Seemed like an stream of Folorn Hopes, delivering slowly increasing stirkes, but the Beast was eating mainly Trade ships, so growing in size as well as strength.
[b][i]Squad 11[/b][/i]; (Fleet 13 - Beast 49) This wave was initially a mix of StarFleet and Blob ships. Each called for reinforcements - who in turn called forward yet more ships and/or bases, including a Machine Cult Stealth Needle (emulating a Blob Destroyer). The combined fleet mustered a a 31 strength attack and earned 4 authority.
[i]Plans were discussed about scrapping 2 bases to generate an additional 10 attack, but as the Commander couldn't remember what was in reserve, and so couldn't estimate the next attack this was deemed too risky.[/i]
[b][i]Squad 12[/b][/i]; (Fleet 15 - Beast 18) The battle now seemed winnable, battle logs were not well maintained in the excitement other than Squad 12 had 10 attack strength and could have slain the Beast had the Commander scrapped those bases during the previous attack.
[b][i]Squad 13[/b][/i]; (Fleet 7 - Beast 8) Another squadron with a majority of Blob representation, delivering an overkill strike of 34.
:thumbsup: The more this is played the more the game, partly due to range of cards and artwork, pushes Ascension: Apprentice Edition aside. :thumbsdown: If it weren't for Shaun's Challenges (with house-rules) this wouldn't hit the table as often. [i]In fact the (full) App version with live opponents could replace this otherwise.[/i]
Edit: Added link.
item.comment: I really enjoy Shaun's creative challenges and am glad that they'll still be around for me to try later on. However, every time I think of playing one, I decide to do something else instead. I think I'm just at a point in this game that I'd rather do the simple, straightforward solo mode. But Shaun's challenges are definitely :star::star::star: quality.

item.body:
This is on my 15x15 list and hadn't been played this year... decided to get it out after seeing a short tactics discussion in another entry this month.
[b]Level 2 Won; 78 pts[/b] (and a Personal Best) Fight +35, -10. Life +40. Pirates +30. Hazard -18.
I wasn't paying attention to the life pool, just that it didn't seem to run down too quickly this game. I entered the Red Phase with 10 life in hand - which I have done before, and still died in the last couple of fights before meeting the Pirates on the beach.
This game I had won most of the eating/feeding cards - and got lucky in some fights when Aging cards were setting me up for a loss, along would come a Destroy card.
This allowed Robinson to step on the beach with 7 life in hand, ready to face off against #5 @ 14 Strength (based on ageing cards used) & #6 @ 20 Strength. [i]The Aging/Destroy luck continued here, otherwise Pirates may have won.[/i]

item.body:
Back from an evening out, and found this still on the table... seemed rude not to allow it a parting shot, given the time taken to refresh the rules. Played the beginner game, basic decks, looking for two succesfsul quests. Randomly drew Evil Has a Name (put the named villain - in this basic set, the "mascot" Greenknee - into the ground) and perennial favourite The Damsel. Final quest was the somewhat tricky The Stars Are Aligned (the dungeon deck of that round bears card values of 0, 1, 2 and 3).
Played to a bloody but fairly swift win, tonight; I at first thought I was going to walk into the Stars quest, as the first three draws gave me cards valued at 0 to 2 consecutively - with another 2 card having to sit on the deck. I didn't have the equipment cards to allow me to get to creative with the dungeon, so I couldn't sustain the win conditions... Two rounds later Greenknee popped up, with his summons command and annoying stealth. A light spell let me find him in the dark corridor - and I put him into the grave within three rounds. When I finally discovered The Damsel, she was surrounded by non-aggressive terrain cards, leading to a quick breather for my final hero, who walked out of the dungeon with the maiden, Greenknee's teeth, and more dignity than I can usually muster.
Time to start a little deck-building with some of the goodies from the delve packs, I think.

item.body:
I [i]finally[/i] got my shipping confirmation for this yesterday or the day before, and it arrived today! I'll certainly be giving it a play or two today, in addition to wanting to replay Darkest Night. Kicking myself a bit that I didn't plump for the Deluxe version, but there's still plenty of variety in the retail box...
[b][size=14]Update:[/size][/b]
Hey, that was fun! :D
I played my first game on Normal difficulty (2 Dire Enemies) using the standard solo setup (2 heroes). I randomly drew the Warrior and Paladin, and used the original side of all the regions. The Dire Enemies turned out to be the Wraith and the Minotaur, while my Epic Foe was the Demon Lord. I was so scared to attack him (he reduces your health to 1 whenever you attack) that I almost lost the game. Luckily, I realized just in time that I could deal up to 3 damage to him in one turn, which was way more important than keeping my health up to defend the regions.
I really like how the importance of the different regions changes throughout the game. In the initial deck, there were no enemies attacking the Coast or Desert, so I got used to ignoring them...and then the Coast was destroyed before I knew it. I did find some of the rules/abilities a little vague, but overall, this is a great little game. Feels like much more than a microgame.
