item.body:
This is a game I've been looking forward to and it met my hopes and expectations.
I've enjoyed [thing=43710]Pocket Cricket[/thing], a fast playing game that reflects the shorter form of cricket. This new game brings features that add significantly to the tactics of play. They provide both the bowler and the batsman with new choices without straining the basic simplicity of the system.
I can see that I'm going to have to be careful with these [company=17797]Pocket Sports[/company] products. I just received their [thing=168578]baseball[/thing] and [thing=168577]boxing[/thing] products, as well, and am a bit concerned that they'll distract me from my main challenges for the year. :(
My first play through gave me a pretty good feel for the flow of the game, though I'm going to have to get it out a few more times before I'm confident about the match-ups. In any case, lots of fun for the armchair cricket fan.:D

So I had a good gaming session tonight and didn't feel like posting all of them separately, so here they are:
[b]Fleet with Arctic Bounty [/b]- played the solo variant posted on the geek instead of the one with the expansion tonight. I had a CRAZY score on this, beating the AI 152 to 51 - how's that possible with only 50 cubes you ask - well I ended up getting all Canadian licenses, which made each cube on those vessels worth 3 points each, so that was 9 per boat, and I had a large fleet of those alongside some shrimp boats which helped to keep the AI out of contention for the auction.
[b]At the Gates of Loyang [/b]- I wanted to try my hand at this tonight, and farms were running well, but I managed to upset a few regular customers which hurt my chances. I was able to pull out a 17.5, which is right around average for me.
[b]Paperback [/b]- To me this is one of the most enjoyable deckbuilders to play because every turn is a new word puzzle. In the solo variant you're working your way up the pyramid which top tier cards getting harder to acquire. I built my deck around a few cards that allowed me to score wild cards, and then added a few more that increased my draw, but I was unlucky in the last few rounds and fell short of the 17 points needed to get the win
[b]Samurai Spirit[/b] - My latest acquisition, and such a great game. I managed to pull off a win tonight on normal mode. A few more times and I think I'm going to ratchet up the difficulty to Hard.

item.body:
Like many others, I got my Kickstarter version in the mail this week and finally found some time tonight to get out the rules and give it a go.
I played two games, but the first one shouldn't count. I was making way too many rules mistakes. For the second game, I was the Cleric and Druid. I just never could seem to be in the right place at the right time. Desert fell first, then the Ocean and the Plains. I did make it to see the Epic Foe (Dragon), but only got one hit on him before the capital city fell.
:thumbsup: Huge replay value thanks to the variety of characters to choose from and enemies to encounter. Like TEK, I'm sure this game will feel fresh for a long time. :thumbsup: Challenging solo play with a lot of tough decision-making moments. :thumbsup: Great variety in both scaling and in difficulty. :thumbsdown: Not a great rulebook, took a lot of stumbling to figure out how to play the first time through. :thumbsdown: Slightly confusing location layout in how you can/cannot move to the capital city.
I definitely need a few more plays in before I have a solid opinion on this game, but so far so good. Glad I backed it, and I think it will get to the table often, both solo and 2P.
item.comment:
Anymore, with a hobby game, I try to find a play-through video before reading the rules, and then consult the rulebook. I find it helpful to see the game as a whole before diving into the rule details.
He has gotten some static on this list earlier this month, but Rahdo Runs Through is a good one (though I think Richard is a bit of a spatz). Wil Wheaton's Tabletop is pretty good too, though they aren't as numerous as Rahdo.
And, before you say it -- I can't stand the Dice Tower reviews. They don't have enough meat or details on them, imho.

I almost *always* watch a Rahdo (or Watch It Played) video before trying to play a game for the first time. Yeah, he's kinda crazy but his thinking-out-loud play style actually helps me understand the game better. However, when I went to watch his video for this game, he said that he was playing with an early prototype and many of the rules would be different in the final version. I didn't want to confuse myself, so I went straight to the rulebook.
Funny, I don't really like the Dice Tower reviews either for the exact reasons you list. Rahdo is crazy, but he's full of in-depth and interesting content.

Hello fellow backer! :cool:

item.body:
Picked this up last week and played about 4 or 5 games, making it through the first 2 maps.
This is the only solo game I've played more than three times not called [thing=96848]Mage Knight[/thing], so i must like it! My son also played solo, which is rare for him - his only other one was [thing=94362][/thing].
:thumbsup: = the very small footprint, even smaller than [thing=155708][/thing], which i just got this week. :thumbsup: = each map feels like a quest. Makes you want to complete one map before going on to the next, even though there's no connection. :thumbsdown: = setup is kind of fiddly, with all the card finding and separation. Not terrible, but enough that I keep the cards for the map I'm currently working on separate, so I can only be working on one map at a time, which is fine (see previous :thumbsup:). :?block: will the map progression be interesting enough to keep it interesting, or will it start to feel samey? At its low price point and commitment requirement, it will have been worth picking up even if it provides only 10 or so plays.
Comparing this to 2 other games really popular solo games that I didn't like:
[thing=71721]Space Hulk: Death Angel[/thing] - in DDD, you build up your troops, acquire special soldiers, acquire more tools. The opposition will wear you down eventually, but you still feel as if you are getting more powerful. In SHDA, you start at full power, and the game beats you down; it's a one way ticket to hell. I guess i like the feeling of playing DDD's game arc better, even though I like SHDA's theme more.
[thing=121921]Robinson Crusoe[/thing] - Both games are scenario-based puzzles and rely heavily on dice. DDD feels lightweight and nimble, and let's you play in 20 mins. RC has tons more setup and rules and fiddliness and time involvement, but i didn't feel that it gave more game, and possibly even fewer decisions to make. It is oozing with theme though. I've still got theme stuck to my rug, even though I sold the game months ago :p

item.body:
I don't quite get this game, but I haven't yet given it a fair shake yet either. Nonetheless, my Spidey sense is tingling with "This game isn't for you; let it go." I'm going to have to wait another month before I can get a proper play.
Let me back up first. I had played a ftf learning game with a friend who got a thank you copy for proofreading (NOT on this game as he was sure to point out; these rules suck big time). He lent it to me afterwards as he has no interest in wargames of any type. Tonight I figured I'd muck around and play a scenario or two, you know, just play both sides. I was unsure how I felt about the game after my ftf play as I was expecting something different, and I've been curious to revisit. More on that in a bit.
First off, I discovered my friend had gotten some things wrong, including giving me the wrong units to play the first scenario with, heh. No worries, I figured I'd just read the rules and figure it out. Ugh. After struggling with the rules I was incorrectly taught, the rulebook, and consulting BGG, the light went on and I was able to get started.
Well, while some wargames lend themselves to playing both sides as best you can, I don't think this is one of them. And I do realize there is a solo variant posted but I didn't want to learn the base game AND a variant at the same time. Trying to plan the sequence of orders for each side against myself was not interesting or fun for me in any way. I finally decided to randomize the orders for one side and try to play the other side intelligently. I got through the first scenario OK, as in "just OK but I didn't get a sense of the fun", and decided to try the 2nd scenario to see if things got more interesting.
They didn't, and I finally stopped the play 3/4 of the way through because I realized this is just not a good candidate for solitaire play and I may be predisposed against the game to boot. Something about the game seems discordant. On one hand, whereas I was expecting a "fun, light, WWII movie-esque game", from the first impression I'd gleaned, I found myself locked up in AP with the programming. I think the ostensible fun of the game is programming some of your units in order and hoping the sequence actually works out. For me, it was annoying and not fun when the sequence didn't pay off. I find playing [thing=24800][/thing] a lighter experience than this one.
OK, so my impression of what the game is was off, but then (and here's the discordance), the cards introduce some really, and I mean really, random elements. So the experience of the game for me is, Have a hard time envisioning the order of units I should activate, agonize over it, finally commit, and then have very little if any of it matter anyway. Repeat. And I get the whole "... until contact with the enemy" concept of making a wargame, but from a player's standpoint, it wasn't tripping the fun wire for me.
Wow, that was longer than I expected, but it feels good to work my thoughts out. I have a friend I normally play CoH with who wants to try it with me next month, so I may do that, but I packed it up and put it back tonight. Not gonna force it. Guess I'm kinda bummed because I was set to spend my evening and tomorrow playing around with it.
:thumbsup: Um, I have a free copy to try
:thumbsdown: Not a good solitaire candidate IMO
:thumbsdown: I doubt the fun the game offers is the type I like
item.comment:
Love this game for solitaire play. I've bought a ton of the extra units too as they come available and as February is becoming Wargame Month for me, I expect to get it out again.
How I've handled the solo play with the unit orders is quite simple. I made numbered chits for each unit (1-15 or so for each side, grey and white). One number goes on or next to each unit on the board.
Then for the number of orders I'm to receive, let's say 3, I put into a cup or bag the number for three units I want to move and one more (so 4 in this example). Do that for both sides. Then you draw up to the number allowed (3 in this case). So it mixes up what order they resolve in AND even you don't know which three of the four you are going to actually get to use.
As for the cards, since they are pretty much just special abilities, playing them as you see fit is just fine.
You just have to remember that when you're playing the Germans, you're German and when the Allies, you're allied. Do what works best for the turn your own.
Works like a champ.

For those trying this I should add that all units that don't get orders still get their move only activations per the regular rules.
I also did separate draw cups for each side but you could easily use one to really mix it up.

Not my favourite for solo play, but it can be done if you don't use hidden units.
Love the component quality, especially the template system and the armoured units.
Probably the best sandbox game I've ever come across because of the template system.

item.body:
Second play of this one. Again, I just used the base game components, picking most of the heroes I hadn't tried last time: Knight, Priest, Acolyte and Wizard. I'm more and more impressed how different each hero seems from the others. I'm also impressed by how the game avoids cliche. For example, the Knight's abilities, especially [-]his[/-][b]her[/b] Oaths (another unusual thing, of course, is the knight's gender), are very thematic while at the same time being unlike anything else I've seen associated with a Knight character in a game, while the Acolyte character is all-around unique (but also very thematic).
I had a lot more killing power this time. Unfortunately, none of my characters were any good at searching, and this was compounded by a lot of lousy rolls and a few poor choices. I also started the Darkness track at 5 this time (since I won the previous game, I figured I should increase the difficulty). All together, that led to a drawn-out loss. I [i]nearly[/i] turned it around at the last moment after the Priest died and was replaced by the Rogue, who is great at searching, but the same round the Rogue dug up the last key, allowing the Knight to unlock a Relic, the Darkness track spawned a fifth blight in the Monastery and we were all doomed. :(
Spent a lot of this game hiding out in the monastery. In many games, that might be un-fun, but this one does it so thematically, I ended up enjoying myself anyway. Enjoyed it more when I won, of course. :D
I'm not sure if I should mix in the expansion stuff yet or not. I'm still barely getting my bearings with the base set heroes, but I am feeling a lack of variety in the blights being spawned (near the end of the game, I had to do a lot of redraws when the Map cards called for a blight that was all out of stock). I may just mix in the new Map cards from Shifting Winds and maybe play around with some new characters, but not necessarily take on Quests yet.

item.body:
Yup, again. Can't seem to get this one off the table, this weekend. (As a sidebar, I'm rather enjoying my new philosophy of not bringing bloody work home on a Friday - and I sure can't remember a single time in all these years anyone thanked me for such.)
Simple set-up, basic decks - with a couple of promo adventurers thrown into the mix, for the first time: the Barbarian Beserker and the Ice Dwarf Explorer (figured I could make use of a couple of extra health points). I haven't used any of the new dungeon promos yet, but I rather like the new tricks they bring.
Anyway... the dungeon was up to its old tricks, this morning. I met a card that I couldn't get around (a troll, giving me terrible memories of similar issues with the Lord of the Rings LCG). The bugger is immune to regular melee damage... unfortunately, when all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail. I pulled a couple of swords out of the bag, but spent ages getting slapped around until I grabbed a magical damage dagger. (Yeah, he wasn't immune to that.) Greenknee, once again, made an early visit to the dungeon, but I seem to be getting better at handling him. Got close to the Stars are Aligned quest, but I think it's just too random, unless you have rare cards which allow for dungeon deck manipulation, and I might swap a different quest in, next time.
Sheer weight of numbers wore me down, I suffered a couple of drain effects - which toss the top card of your deck to the discard pile. Lost a useful bag of supplies which would have restocked my hand, and a fire spell, which I could have happily used five or six times. As ever, unable to find the Damsel to rescue, my poor, wounded, Gypsy Stormcatcher was left alone in the dark. Until she realised those strange sounds weren't her imagination... and she ended up blundering into a dart trap. Whilst poisoned.
Which is thorough, you have to admit.
[imageid=2407256large] An unusually good opening hand. Plenty of defence. Which you will need.
[imageid=2407257large] Greenknee and the troll (which sounds like an excellent title for a 70's cop show). A glance at the Necromancer's cards shows a stamina (health) of two and an attack power of three. His attack is augmented by a ranged three magic attack (he gets plus three power against adventurers without the "ranged" keyword, "magic" is the damage type); he is a unique character, which means he allows the completion of the Evil Has a Name quest; he adds one extra point to encounters (add the numbers in the top left of the card, usual limit is five); he is a Reaver - which means he can kill a low level monster to regenerate a life point; he summons bastards to help him, once he arrives; stealth means you can't attack him until every other villain character is dead.
I promise, this all becomes really intuitive after a few plays. The rule book glossary is great at explaining and referencing it all. (It was just the basic mechanisms that were initially woolly.)

item.body:
Played a solo game of this against 5 Civ-Bots (2 medium, 3 easy). Used two variants which I hoped would add some spice to the game:
I) Advanced rule of choosing your advisor when allowed to draw a new one, instead of drawing randomly. II) playing with the events deck
I will definately stick to I) in all future games (solo or multiplayer) as it adds more control.
The events are quite harsh at times, even though you can see them one round in advance. Makes fun in the solo game, where I will keep them. Not sure, if they do the multiplayer game any good. Rather fear the opposite.
Got my butt kicked by one of the noble Civ-Bots. We had the world under our control at game's end with him being roughly 50 points ahead of me. The mid 2nd era was crucial as he was already up to highest military due to combination of events and always drawing both advance military cards. Thus not the slightest chance for me to get in his range and I could only hope for the other bots to slightly sting to him. They did, but were wiped out eventually and my mixed tactics saw me falling short.
:thumbsup: Still a challenging solo Civ-like game which holds enough challenges for me. :thumbsdown: The character of the solo game is quite different from multiplayer, especially as the leaders (scoring you VP at end of each era and thus providing you with additional strategic direction) are not in play. :thumbsdown: the rulebook is a pain in the butt. Searching specific rules is not an easy task. In addition, there are quite some loopholes in the rules, especially when it comes to events and to Civ-Bots.

item.body:
Another solo game with my playing both hands while I waited for Darkwynd to post his solo rules for the CapAp version of the cards (that version is now posted!).
The Aliens got off to a slow albeit steady start. They were never able to massacre the marines but were able to kill off at least 1 marine per round. This meant that, relative to the movie, they were slightly behind (Apone didn't die until the marines were escaping by way of APC).
However, in the mid-game, the Alien player managed to pull off another dropship disaster which helped to thin down the marines. The murder of Ferro lead to an additional 2 rounds in the Dropship Evac stage which gave the Aliens a chance to recover and get some kills. Particularly helpful was the lack of operations cards during the same period.
Moving into the final stage on the Sulaco and things were pretty tight. The marines still had Ripley, Bishop and Newt. By now, the Alien player was starting to feel pretty good albeit the marines did have a pretty decent handsize as the marines were unable to play many operations cards during Dropship Evac.
These cards were promptly discarded to power the Sentry Gun! Woohoo!
However, the joy was shortlived as the Aliens threw down an Alien Swarm and managed to kill off poor little Newt. Advantage to the Aliens!
However (again!), a lucky draw in the second round of the Sulaco (after poor little Newt got eaten by a passing Alien) allowed the marine player to field the Powerloader. Together with the Sentry Gun and other ops cards, the marines now had 13 power on the Sulaco stage! Firepower FTW!
The last couple of rounds were brutal as, in desperation, the Alien player threw everything he had at the marines. Two security doors dropped to delay the marines final escape - pushing back the turn marker back twice in the final rounds. However, this would only delay the inevitable if they couldn't pull any Alien cards to overwhelm the marines firepower. With the lack of marine kills, the Nuke counter was also ticking perilously close to zero!
Aliens kept coming at the marines in waves. Some were devastated by careful controlled bursts by the marines. Others were blown apart with grenades. Despite this, the Aliens kept coming - knowing it was their last chance to take out the last surviving marines before their timely escape.
Ultimately, despite Bishop being torn in half, the marines were able to keep the Aliens at bay and scrape out the win. It was a close call but, in the end, the combined firepower of the Powerloader and Sentry Gun proved too much for the Aliens to deal with.
Hoo-ah!
:thumbsup: What an intense way to end the game! When the Powerloader dropped, it looked like it was all over for the Aliens. However, the two security doors kept the game going (1 more round!) and, in addition to giving the Alien a chance to get back in the game, had me starting to worry that the marines were fated to lose! :thumbsdown: Still waiting for the CapAp version of the solo variant (Its up now!) :thumbsdown: I now play the Dropship Evac stage with the Ferro side up by default. So far, I have never had a game where Ferro died after the Dropship Evac stage!

item.body:
The fourth week of the Monthly Sentinels challenge! Here were the rules:
Week 4: We're all citizens here
Villain: Citizen Dawn
Environment: Ruins of Atlantis
Heroes:
Everyone MUST use AZ. The random hero is: 1d10 = 9
Reroll: 1d10 = 4'
Wraith
rounds+wounds+1 for each HP that Citizen Dawn (and only Citizen Dawn) heals.
EG, if the healing light card is played and she would heal 10 damage but only has 5 HP to heal, you add +5 and not +10.
And here are my results:
I went with Legacy, as I know he's a great match with Wraith, and I wanted some potential for team healing. It nearly worked, but ultimately wasn't enough.
I knew this was going to be tough, but wow did I get pounded! Once Citizen Dawn flipped, a pair of Krakens kept picking off the citizens, which kept her flipped!
[b]Time:[/b] 17 turns [b]Legacy:[/b] 32 wounds and K.O.'d [b]Wraith:[/b] 26 wounds and K.O.'d [b]Absolute Zero:[/b] 29 wounds and K.O.'d [b]Healing to Citizen Dawn:[/b] 31
[b]Total:[/b] 135 and a loss!
Ugh. Dawn's card sweeper came out late in the game, which would have been great, if I could have beat her before then. Worse, Citizen Tears came out right after Dawn scrubbed everyone's ongoings, and after that, it was just a matter of waiting for the beat down to end. Still, it's losses like this that make the victories all the sweeter!

After changing job last week, alongside all the bumf that goes with finishing my last job, this afternoon has been my first solo session of the month, a lovely relaxing intro game of Loyang to ease me into the rules. It seems to travel along at a nice clip once you have the rules down and probably only took 45 minutes or so - although perhaps I ought to have spent a little longer think looking back on my ignominious score of 14. Still, it seems to be one of those games where you realise stupid things as soon as you've done them so I know a few little tricks for next game that'll hopefully bump the score up somewhat.
:thumbsup: Quick, brainburny goodness as you might expect from Uwe (I seem to remember saying almost the same thing about Glass Road actually, but this felt a lot more satisfying for some reason) :thumbsdown: Putting all the veg on those little cards is an absolute faff, especially for my sausage fingers :thumbsdown: Tempted me away from painting the bathroom which is what I was supposed to be doing this afternoon

[b]Origin Story[/b]: So everyday for about two years I drove past two FLGS, always curious, but never stopping in. One I knew was a Miniatures type store, which wasn't my thing, but last year that at the behest of my wife we stopped in at the other one. After purchasing Dominion, I had the bug, and went back up looking for something to play solo. After a whole lot of help from the staff, I picked up Pathfinder. I really dug playing solo, and after I found out some of my co-workers played games, I got pointed in the direction of BGG, and checking it out I stumbled across this forum. At that point, I joined, and never looked back. Great club to be a part of, although my wallet may disagree;)
That being said, I played this beast today, starting with scenario number 1, and boy did I get hammered. That being said I did kill a lot of undead, and had a blast doing so!

item.body:
Played "Might is Right" where the goal is to find three survivors in hiding and get off the map. Used the "Romero mode" which uses spawn cards 43 to 54 and only spawns regular walkers, no berserkers, runners or fatties. Just rewatched Dawn of the Dead, so wanted to go old school!
==================================
So a priest and a clown walk into a zombie apocalypse:
[imageid=2407761 medium]
Padre Johnson armed with a pistol and Uncle Honk with a claw hammer, they head into the first building:
[imageid=2407762 medium]
In the building they find a shotgun for Padre Johnson, another clawhammer for Uncle Honk and the first survivor, Bones:
[imageid=2407763 medium]
Scouring the building, they find a riot shield and a sword for Bones, then head out into the street:
[imageid=2407765 medium]
Inch by inch they work their way forward, Uncle Honk swinging wildly with his pair of claw hammers and Padre Johnson blasting away with his shotgun:
[imageid=2407766 medium]
As Padre Johnson stays in the intersection, keeping things clear with his shotgun, Bones and Uncle Honk work their way to the door of the next building:
[imageid=2407767 medium]
Uncle Honk pries open the door with his hammer and finds another survivor, Belle, plus a matching sword for Bones and a sword for Belle:
[imageid=2407773 medium]
Rejoining Padre Johnson in the intersection, the survivors work their way to the second last building, hoping to find the last survivor there. The noise they are making is drawing more and more walkers:
[imageid=2407776 medium]
Belle and Padre Johnson remain in the street, hoping to keep an escape route open. Uncle Honk and Bones fight their way into the heavily infested building and Bones finds a dog that has been hiding out from the zombies:
[imageid=2407779 medium]
With their two swords and two claw hammers, and some help from their new canine friend, Uncle Honk and Bones clear the building of zombies in a bloody battle. Bones' riot shield the only thing preventing him from becoming zombie chow. As the battle ends, the last missing survivor, Joshua, emerges from hiding. A quick search uncovers a hatchet he can use to fight his way out, and Bones gives him his riot shield:
[imageid=2407783 medium]
Now it is a mad dash to the exit before the ever growing horde makes escape impossible:
[imageid=2407784 medium]
Padre Johnson continues to blast away with his shotgun as the other survivors make a break for the exit:
[imageid=2407785 medium]
As Uncle Honk gets held up by a swarm of zombies, the rest of the survivors wait for him:
[imageid=2407787 medium]
Dispatching enough zombies to make a break for it, Uncle Honk makes a final run for the exit:
[imageid=2407789 medium]
With everyone alive, it is time to head back to their boarded up safe house and celebrate this rare victory!

item.body:
First play, finally! And a lot of re-reading.
[ImageID=2407744]
Set up took me quite a while but I guess this will be faster next time. It took me some time to find out what marker is what ship and which ones are not recommened for the first few plays. After I sorted out what I need for this learning game I had the map ready pretty fast.
I played the Deathmachine Solo mission. The small one.
My Scouts were racing through the galaxy and exploring as much as possible. Lucky as I was I had two planets right next to my home system. And my first question came up. Can I transport Ship Yards? You start the game with four in your HS and I was asking myself if I can transport one or two with a ship to a planet I colonized. Guess not. I only found that you can build them on planets but nothing of transporting them. I know, I know... how do you want to transport a Ship yard? :what: Hey it's Sci-Fi, right? Nothing is impossible! If I can shot my PDS in [thing=12493][/thing] into a system next to the system where the PDS is stationed, why not transport a SY? I mean how crazy is that? Shot a cannon on a planet into a system next to it's own and even score a hit! :D
Anyway...
[ImageID=2407745]
I lost 2 of my Scouts because of a Danger! marker. But I did not waste any rescourses on new ones because the first DM was about to enter the game.
I used my resources to get technologies and to build ships. I build my first Destroyer which I used to explore. The DM then entered in the same area as my DD and was a real killing machine. My DD was out in no time. I have to mention that I played the EASY mode. :p
[ImageID=2407746]
Ok, I am sure I played some things wrong and the DM was faster at my HS than I thought. My two new build Cruisers managed to score 1 hit on the DM but that beast also took them out with the first attack. The dice hate me! I rolled fantastic on the DM rolls and totally failed on my own.
First impression. :thumbsup: I like the idea that you always play with a fog of war kind of thing. Always a galaxy to explore, always new. Just what I love! :thumbsup: The more I play games with markers instead of minis, the more I prefer marker over minis. The strategic point in a multiplayer game is unbeatable if you compare minis and markers. I really like the idea of not knowing what your opponents might have under their markers, like they handle it here in [thing=84419][/thing]. Ok not of interest in a pure solo game. :thumbsup: The Tech sheet is fantastic! I wish TI3 had something like this. :thumbsup: A rulebook so short but a game that has such a depth. A great example for others! :thumbsdown: I lost my first game. :D :p No really, I couldn't find anything so far that was really bad.

Welcome to the fandom of counters over stupid plastic minis. Counters are the best. They can have info printed on them and no on cards. They don't need to be painted (just clipped), and you can fit a ton more on a small space.
They just don't look as fancy. But they sure are a better system for most games.
Not let me get back to painting minis... :whistle:
Seriously, though, I do vastly prefer counters to minis in 99% of games, and get annoyed when they try to shoehorn minis into games that don't need them.

item.body:
Solo play with 1 deck (core set only - simulate to 3 exemplars of each card - 10*3 deck). Spheres: [b]Tactics + Lore[/b] (Theodred - Dunhere - Eowyn) Scenario: [b]Journey along the Anduin[/b]
[b][i]Game 1[/i][/b] (without shadow card): [color=green][b]Victory[/b][/color] turn #12 ; 110+30+5-17=128 (Just the Hill Troll as setup, a Marsh Adder came but stayed on the staging area as Dunhere's target. The flip of the third part of the quest gave nothing bad) [b][i]Game 2[/i][/b] (without shadow card): [color=red][b]Defeat[/b][/color] turn #12 (When I lost Eowyn and 3 allies on a single The Necromancer's Reach) [b][i]Game 3[/i][/b] (with shadow card): [color=purple][b]Fail[/b][/color] ; cause I forgot the ability of Banks of the Anduin. [b][i]Game 4[/i][/b] (with shadow card): [color=green][b]Victory[/b][/color] turn #16 ; 150+35+4-10=179 (I had never seen any Sneak Attack, so I had to delay the fight against the Troll till I had enough allies) [b][i]Game 5[/i][/b] (with shadow card): [color=red][b]Defeat[/b][/color] turn #7 (Or when the encounter deck doesn't stop throwing horrible things to you)
[b]The Deck[/b] [u]Heroes:[/u] Theodred - Dunhere - Eowyn [u]Allies:[/u] Faramir - Longbeard Orc Slayer - Northern Guide - Wandering Took - Beorn [u]Attachments:[/u] Unexpected Courage [u]Events:[/u] Ever Vigilant - Sneak Attack - The Galadhrim's Greeting - A Test of Will
[b]Verdict[/b] That doesn't work as expected. But, strangely, I think I did mulligan on each game. I don't really see how I can improve it right now. A Test of Will is perhaps not that important against this quest. Power in the Earth could be more interesting in fact. Or at least it would be useful for me on game #5.

I am trying to avoid spending too much time writing for the SGoYT lists as it could be time better spent playing games. However I will occassionally add an entry for a less popular game such as this one.
There is a simple solo variant included in the rulebook, however it really does limit gameplay and doesn't provide the complexity of the full game. The designers did submit a Co-op variant, which works very well as a solo if you do not mind playing with three ships. The Goal is to survive, although I like to add the extra "super win condition" of actually destroying the end Boss. :devil: I have played this a few times before, so I did have a strategy and was aware of the "gotchas" in game play (Like things you forget or lose track of!) :)
The first bonus was having spaces for all the ships to enter play. [ImageID=2407757 medium]
I then made sure I tracked all the Bellonium both from defeating enemies and the occassional Global acquisition. (It is something I missed often last game).
The other objective is to keep ahead of the Nemesis Cube by earning Glory and preventing enemies from exiting the board. This proved to be a lot easier in this game than in previous sessions.
A lot of energy was wasted using the rotary cage to target enemies, so the first upgrade for all ships was to give omni-directional firing. This was quickly followed by Generators and Weapons. Captain Hawk (Yellow) and Captain Bomber (Grey) both took the short range level 1 flamer while Captain Warlock (Red) took a level two laser to get rid of those stronger enemies.
With good coordination and the death of many enemies, shields, upgraded generators and more powerful weapons, meant we were ready for the final Boss. [ImageID=2407756 medium]
The generators were essential to the strategy as there were only two turns to wreak damage because of the short range flamers. Unknown to me, one Boss segment was immune to Laser damage, so the final ship formation was also exceedingly lucky.
We all managed to survive but I just couldn't get enough firepower together to destroy the Boss (Although there wasn't much left!!!) Even a suicide attempt (I did have an extra life available) would not deal enough damage. As it is Captain Warlock barely survived the Broadside on the final row. [ImageID=2407755 medium] Well, Maybe better luck next time.
:thumbsup: An exciting puzzle type game where the luck is reduced to card draws. :thumbsup: Plenty of variety in enemies, upgrades and other effects. You are never bored. :thumbsdown: Lack of a true solo game. :thumbsdown: A large investment of time (Although you don't actually notice that when you are playing).

Without me having to dive into the rules, can you explain WHY? Is there some kind of timer, or did you literally not have enough resources left to buy a big enough gun, or what?

[q="ThroughTheDeckGlass"][q]but I just couldn't get enough firepower together to destroy the Boss (Although there wasn't much left!!!)[/q]
Without me having to dive into the rules, can you explain WHY? Is there some kind of timer, or did you literally not have enough resources left to buy a big enough gun, or what?[/q] There is a timer. The board consists of 5 rows of cards and after each player has had their turn, the bottom row is removed and a top row is added. The Boss consists of the last cards in the game, so when he appears you no longer add a top row to the board, so it gets smaller. The last two photos are of the last two turns of the game. The first photo shows the start of the 2nd last turn (2 rows without any damage yet) and the last photo shows the end of the last turn (1 row). Flamers are short range weapons, so I should have moved the player ships up closer to the Boss earlier. That way I would have had more turns to deal damage instead of trying to do it all in the last two turns. :soblue:

item.objectname: Warfighter: The Tactical Special Forces Card Game
item.body:
After easily and successfully [thread=1315325]completing the Jungle Campaign[/thread] earlier this month, I was keen to move into the Middle East for some much higher intensity firefights.
My first attempt at [b]Short & Sweet / Command APC[/b] was tense and down to the wire, and I lost it due to a lack of actions (and a poor decision perhaps to not hold onto a Mortar Call), as well as some bad 'Event' draws at both locations (Refugees and an IED). [listitem=3724385]My second attempt[/listitem] drew on lessons learnt (more bang! for those numerous groups of hostiles), and was ultimately successful, which is always a rush.
Enthused, I embarked on mission 2 of the Insurgents campaign last night ([b]Short Patrol / Chieftain[/b]). [geekurl=/plays/thing/149951?userid=659773]2 attempts, and 2 dismal failures[/geekurl]!!!! GAH! Those numerous value 1 Gunmen, with 2 reticules and Defense of 3 are a curse, especially when you are rolling poorly on the Penetration dice!
My second attempt was a protracted firefight, that saw large numbers of suppressed hostiles in side street, on whom I squandered my explosives, but really struggled to eliminate. Eventually my men pushed through into an open field just shy of the chieftain's house, but as they started to empty magazines on the prolific number of defenders, the hostiles' return fire rapidly pinned them down and overwhelmed them.
Sigh... Back to the drawing board. I think I may try two player-soldiers next, just to get more action cards (and more frags?)..... And I need to maximize my penetration bonuses for ranged attacks....
item.comment:
I have found I like having two player-soldiers before I add any NPS or squad-soldiers. They don't even have to be maxed out super player-soldiers either. Having two hands of cards gives me more options in how to handle the hostiles/situation.
There is something to be said for having more actions to help handle the hostiles, but I place a higher value on two hands of cards and then actions.

[q="fee_weasel"]I have found I like having two player-soldiers before I add any NPS or squad-soldiers. They don't even have to be maxed out super player-soldiers either. Having two hands of cards gives me more options in how to handle the hostiles/situation.
There is something to be said for having more actions to help handle the hostiles, but I place a higher value on two hands of cards and then actions. [/q]
Yeah, good call Waylon. I guess the Action Deck is really the implementation/manifestation of the 'Special Forces' advanced training of your team (compared with the Hostiles). If you fall back on solely actions and firing, you will eventually get overwhelmed by sheer weight of numbers. The trick is to be able to buy yourself the time to gain and leverage those action cards....
I spent a very relaxing 20 minutes last night planning my next team. Two cheap player soldiers: one with ranged 'bang' (UGL); and one with a suppressor on a HK417 (I recall?) and attachments, plus a few frags and M2, for close range bang. Suppressor should help a lot with higher defense value hostiles in adjacent locations, rather than wasting explosives on them; it also means this soldier is effective at both range 0 & 1 (unlike the much cheaper but more limiting suppressed MP7's etc). I did look longingly at the SCARS, but reloads on 3's would really hurt a 2 man team...

item.body:
[size=18][b]Six nations tournament, first round France-Scotland, Stade de France[/b][/size]
First time out with that game, I decided to play a 2x20 turn game since it seems that a turn lasts about 2 minutes.
[b]Kick off [/b]Scotland aims for an early gain on their left flank, hoping to outrun the French. It is however a mess and France gather the ball.
[b]10th minute[/b] [imageid=2408088 medium] The Scottish defence is nowhere to be seen and Fofana eases on the right wing to score an opportunistic try. Despite an easy angle, Spedding fails to convert it. France leads 5-0.
[b]14th minute[/b] Trying to keep possession for his team, Russell cannot anticipate the tackle and is badly knocked down.
[b]32nd minute[/b] [imageid=2408089 medium] Scotland keep the ball and dominate the game. They seem to play the French from one wing to the other and back. The home team is pushed back in its own 22m and the Scots try to find an opening along the touch line. Dunbar makes a silly handling mistake and the referee is quick to blow his whistle and ask for a scrum. As Russell gets back on his feet, a nice introduction by Kockott helps his team mates and France finally get the ball. In order to ease the pressure on his team and push the Scots back, he opts for a long kick and finds the touchline close to Scotland's 22m line.
[b]34th minute[/b] Ford throws the ball in for Scotland but cannot focus his aim, offering it to the expert hand of France's Chouly. Well aware that such a chance may not present itself again, he grows wings and dodges the challenges of Beatty and Bennett. Fortunately for Scotland, Dunbar is there to save the day and brings Chouly down.
[b]36th minute[/b] [imageid=2408090 medium] Le Roux gathers the ball and passes it to Huguet who scores a great try without being challenged. Spedding makes amend for his previous miss and converts the try.
[b]Half-time[/b] A lucky French team leads Scotland 12-0.
[i]next: second half, stay tuned![/i]

item.objectname: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â The Dead Marshes
item.body:
Playing on Easy Mode with Shadow cards
Oh man did I get lucky! I actually played it pretty well, I got a good hand for the Spirit/Leadership deck. I put Steward of Gondor on Aragorn and got Northern Tracker out immediately and Sylvan guide out soon after that as well as Faramir. So, I was a questing beast (oops, wrong mythology!) I intentionally chose Impassable Bog as my active location (has 12 quest tokens to be placed!) because I figured there was no way that I would get a low number of resources on Gollum's first time out of the Encounter deck. He starts out in the staging area and then you have to do escape tests-draw 2 cards and look at the escape value, but you have to have exhausted more characters to combat this and if you fail you put tokens on him, if he gets 8 he goes back in the deck until he comes out again. At the end though you must draw escape cards equal to the number of tokens on him and pass that test to win the game.
Well, he had 7 tokens on him. I "over-quested" again and blew through the remainder of the Impassable Bog and the final 3 tokens needed and had to then pass the test. Thankfully I didn't use Aragorn, Glorfindel or a Gondorian Swordsman and could muster 6. I drew 7 cards. Only 1 was from the Dead Marshes deck! The others were all Core and so didn't have "Escape" values on them and were therefore 0! That Escape value? 1!!!!!
So, I won. I nearly burned myself pretty badly with my own strategy, because then I would have had to go back to the first Quest card (of 2) and get 12 more tokens and find Gollum again, etc etc.
Whew!
I'll have to come back to this one (and several of the others), but right now I'm just playing each one until I beat it. More for the adventure than anything.

item.body:
First play of this PNP that I'd won back in December [i](along with Lord of the Rings)[/i] from [username=garyrbrooks]. [b]Thanks Gary![/b]
Hadrian and Renee were randomly chosen as the starting characters. Round 1: 25 points Round 2: 18 Points Round 3: 12 Points Total: 55 Points [i](Showy Seeker)[/i]
The first round went really smooth and I got through most of the deck before things started to really get bad. In the second and third, Specters appeared early on which made the decision on whether to proceed much more difficult and forced early retreats.
------------
Mechanically this is a simple push-your-luck game that works along very similar lines as [thing=37759][/thing]/[thing=15512][/thing], where you get more points the further you go, and where some of the bad doesn't happen until the second time you see a particular card. The encounters throw an extra wrinkle into it, but some can actually help you quite a bit. The four different player abilities add some options as well, and also add a bit of replayability and variety as you try out the different combinations [i](only two get used each game)[/i].
Thematically the push-your-luck mechanism fits really well into the concept of exploring a haunted house because it's very much a matter of seeing how far you can go and how scared you can get before you've had enough. The "loss" trigger fits even better than it does in IG/D because that always seemed to imply that your adventurer was killed [i](which didn't make as much sense with multiple rounds)[/i], while in this game it basically means you shit yourself and ran screaming out of the house. You're still alive, but you're not getting any points for bravery... unless you go back in and try again.
:thumbsup: Highly thematic fit to the push-your-luck gameplay :thumbsup: PNP made up of just over 30 cards, so it's very easy to build and transport. It would be completely playable even if you printed just one side and didn't include the card backs. :thumbsup: Plays super quick and has a tiny footprint, so it's a great option when you have only a few minutes free and little to no space available.
:thumbsdown: Very luck-driven. You do have some control over when to back out, but with good luck you can ride it out far longer than with bad luck. :thumbsdown: It's a high score chaser. You can't really "lose" unless you manage to panic all three rounds, so your measure of success depends almost entirely on how you've done in previous games. :thumbsdown: Replayability seems somewhat limited. The four characters can be mixed to provide variety, but without the high score chase there's not a lot to draw you back.

Last night I played the first reconnaissance scenario to get back into the swing of things. Tonight I'm playing the [thread=1315341][/thread] hosted by : [user=flannc][/user] This challenge is based off the [thread=936337]Draconum infestation[/thread] variant. I'm half way through so far and really enjoying this. Playing Tovak, I ended the second day at level 7. All three villiges are freed of the draconum. I'm just approaching the blue city which hosts two random draconum. I should be through that in the night phase. [IMG]https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-JBSfWedyekE/VNg_SjFz0SI/AAAAAAAAErI/HOiVzsaRAKA/w278-h371-no/IMG_20150208_230136694.jpg[/IMG] :thumbsup: I don't mind the AP with this game at all. I'll stare at my card for 10 minutes with glee as I solve the puzzle of my current turn. :thumbsup: This challenge is very fun. I've never played anything other than the introduction and conquest scenarios. This is a nice change of pace. [b]EDIT:2/10[/b]
Finished this variant tonight with a score of 206. I had some spells and AA that helped ease the threats of the Draconum. Here are the details of my city battles:
[b]Day 3[/b] Blue city â Ice and High Dragon. I cast Tremor on the Ice Dragon giving it -3 armor (down to 4). The Fire Golems finished it off before it could attack with a ranged fire attack 4. Since these are not fortified I used the Illusionist to prevent the High Dragon from attacking. I hit it with the cold swordmanship (attack 2), Utem Guardsmen hit it for 2, 3 from the Soul Harvester, and 3 from the Utem Swordsmen. 9 normal attacks. The blue city is saved and I'm rewarded with the Altem Guardians.
I decided with my last turn of the round to assault the Red City. I had a good hand and tranquility. I might as well take out a few enemies before assaulting the city again in the night phase. Revealed were: a High Dragon, Fire Dragon, Fire Mages, and Ice Golems. The red city fortifies them and gives them the brutal ability. Also, the city has a white crystal and according to the variant rules I canât use white powers here.
I used Cold Toughness (6 ice block) to block the fire mages. I used shield Mastery (2 fire block) to block the Ice Golems. Altem Guardians (8 block), Rage and 2 cards sideways were used to block the high dragon. The unblocked Fire Dragon hit me with 18 pts of brutal damage to disburseâ¦ouch! Fire Golems absorb 8, Utem Guardsmen absorb 5, Illusionists absorb 2, leaving me taking one wound with the final 3. My turn. Snowstorm + Cold Swordmanship kill the Fire Dragon. Fireball kills the Ice Golems.
[b]Night 3[/b] Only one thing left to do, conquer the Red City. Using the Sparing Power tactic I assaulted the city with 10 cards. Using black mana, I turned the Snowstorm into a Blizzard (Ice Siege 8) killing the Fire Mages. The High Dragon was blocked using Cold Toughness, Shield Mastery and Rage (12 total block). Using the remaining cards I easily generated 9 normal attack points to slay the dragon.
:thumbsup: I like the revealed map. It really allows you to plan out an strategy right from the start. :thumbsup: A bad hand is rare (personal opinion). Even when I think I have a bad hand, I always find a way to use it efficiently.

item.body:
Was challenged by a co-worker that I wouldn't play this after I got through the first battle, so of course I had to prove him wrong. Setup for this game is so easy really once you sort and bag the counters. Except for markers, the units are used in only one scenario, so like [thing=42673][/thing] you can just bag up all the ones for a given map.
This time I took on Bentonville, which only lasts 6 turns. This one starts with a lot of units already on board and the Union phases in reinforcements randomly over turns 2-5. To win, the Confederates only need to capture one of 6 objectives. If none, then the winner is determined by victory points.
[imageid=2408320medium]
About turn 3 I realized I needed to use the Union forces to keep some of the rebels engaged away from the objectives and the rest to close in on the objectives and protect them in sort of a zone defense.
For the CSA, I tried to use my cavalry unit (just one) to skirt the perimeter through the woods, but in the end didn't make it close enough due to movement restrictions.
The CSA fought well up until the last turn, closing in and managed to take one objective and contest a few more (via zone of control), however they were driven off via the two attack pulls and the Union elite moved and occupied 5 objectives and controlled the sixth.
However...
The next to the last chit pulled was D.H. Hill's Corps of the CSA. They were only two units strong to begin with and were both reduced and on opposite ends of the battlefield. But the westernmost unit, closest to the objectives had kept moving over to support and had just enough time to move into the only unoccupied spot, [b]giving the CSA a substantial victory![/b]
[imageid=2408333medium]
Had it gone to points, the Union would have eeked it out 23-21.

item.objectname: Enemy Coast Ahead: The Dambuster Raid
item.body:
Due to the lousy weather here in Toronto, my construction work site has been shut down for the week. A great opportunity to hibernate with my game collection. Set up this awesome GMT game before bed tonight so I can leap right into the campaign game in the morning.
[imageid=2408356 medium]
[b]Update 09/02: [/b]
So played the full campaign this evening. The whole thing took me about 5-6 hours (not sure exactly what time I got started). Very immersive experience. I lost badly. 14 Lancasters and countless crew lost. The effectiveness of Group 5 was seriously damaged and both Bomber Command and the Ministry of Aircraft Production were very disappointed in the results. A catastrophic loss so bad that Churchill suppressed news of the raid from the public. No Dam Busters movie in my alternate timeline.
Now I have had a full run through, I have a better idea of how to manage the pre-mission planning and training. My sloppiness around security (especially requesting too many resources) cost me dearly in the final raids. Almost every dam turned out to have added significant defenses since the last reconnaissance. The added spotlights in particular made it almost impossible to breach the dams.
I think the next time I play the full campaign I am going to split it over two nights, my brain hurts!
:thumbsup: In-depth and engaging look at a very specific event in history. :thumbsup: For a procedural game, I find there are a significant number of choices, particularly in the full campaign game. :thumbsup: Great components and a beautifully designed map, with some of the most useful player aids in any game I have played. :thumbsup::thumbsdown: Definitely a procedural game. If you don't like that style of gameplay you won't like this one, but if you do this is a fantastic example of how to do it right. :thumbsdown: My enjoyment of this game has led me to an interest in [thing=39941][/thing], another procedural game that generates an interesting looking narrative.
item.comment: I'm looking forward to "Scenario 10" myself. I agree, it's easy to get lost in story, get lost in the game, and lose. Just lose.

item.body:
I finally have played Claustrophobia thanks to
[username=reverendunclebastard]
and the idea to play it both sides like he mentioned [listitem=3694830]here[/listitem].
Claustrophobia has sitten on my shelf for a long time now and I just have never gotten it to the table to play it with my girlfried. Even though I really think that she would enjoy the game. She loves playing [thing=104162][/thing] and she loves rolling dice. Claustrophobia would be the perfect game for her, wouldn't it? I think so. But in reality we always end up playing something different so I thought to my self, I should try to play both sides and see if I would have fun.
I had a lot of fun...:thumbsup:
The fact that there are not much (or even none?) hidden informations and your actions are determined by the outcome of the dice-rolling makes playing both sides a fun way to enjoy the game. It felt a bit like watching a story unfolding. But I constantly had the "what to do next & what is the best thing to help my guys or the demons"- feeling, and thats awesome.
I have never done playing both sides in a game and that was a new and exciting experience. So much that I was very intrigued by [listitem=3725155]this mention of playing Memoir'44 both sides[/listitem]. [thing=10630][/thing] is a game I always wanted to try out but never found another player (my girlfrined would not play a game about WW2). But it seems like Memoir'44 could give me the same experience like I had with Claustrophobia. That's awesome and it's now very high on my wishlist.
So I only had one game so far (first scenario) and the humans won, but I guess I made some gameplay mistakes on the demons side. It's great to acknowledge those mistakes. Makes me want to play again and see if the humans can cash in another easy win.
:thumbsup: I can play such a great game whenever I want to
:thumbsup: It's beautiful. By the end of the game you have got an entire dungeon on your table plus great looking miniatures.
:thumbsup: As a dungeon crawler it plays fast so you can play a couple of games in quick succession
:thumbsdown: I wish there were more different bad guys

item.body:
Did one more game of this with the base game stuff only (except I mixed in the Map cards from Shifting Winds...helped a lot!). After being stomped all over in the previous game, I went back to starting the Darkness track at default instead of at 5. I also picked my four favorite characters from the previous plays: the Rogue, Wizard, Scholar, and Knight. To compensate for choosing my characters, I selected their starting powers at random.
This was definitely the dream team for me so far. The Rogue is just insanely good at searching and remaining undetected. He's no good at fighting, but he's good enough at eluding that it doesn't matter unless he needs to defeat a blight for some reason. The Wizard is the most fun to play with his frankly overpowered abilities (balanced out by his low default grace and the fact that most of his powers need to be exhausted after use). When he got the Rune of Interference, giving him a 1/6 chance of instantly destroying every new blight that spawned, that was a real game-changer for this playthrough. The Scholar was also good at searching, although squishier than the Rogue. I parked him at the Swamp and tried to find an Inspiration. Finally, I got to play with a lot more of the Knight's Oaths this time. They're very fun and make her a great asset in combat--it was a no-brainer to give her the three keys to collect the Relic and defeat the Necromancer at the end.
This game is so good, it's not even funny. I'm sorely tempted to get the Into the Abyss expansion, and I haven't even played with the other two yet! The rules tend to be straightforward, but there are a few I find myself occasionally forgetting: you lose 1 secrecy when attacking a blight, and if you fail the attack, you need to apply the blight's defense. I also sometimes forget to draw an Event card in the heat of the moment. I think I caught all of my mistakes as I was making them, though, and I'm getting comfortable enough with what the blights do that I can start putting them face-up on the board, which makes it a lot more attractive.
I also played another game of [b][thing=155708][/thing][/b] earlier. I chose two more random heroes, excluding the ones I've seen so far, and ended up with the Druid and the Oracle. I also randomized which side of the Regions I used. I don't know whether it was the new heroes, the regions, the Horde deck, the Epic Foe, or my own poor play, but I lost badly this time. I was holding onto the game okay, with just one destroyed region when the Epic Foe appeared, but he was the Giant...at the start of the round, he knocked the heroes over, meaning they couldn't defend or do anything else until they used an action to stand up. Well, I was halfway through the Turn deck before my heroes got a single action, and by that time, the Capital was well on its way to ruin. Boo!
[imageid=2408435 medium]
item.comment: Gah! The next time this goes on sale I'm picking it up.

thanks for continuing to post about Darkest Night. Almost as good as having the game! Almost...
As for TED, I'm starting to wonder if the timing of the action cards in the final round is the overarching predictor of success (along with being able to get artifacts). In our last game, playing hard mode, we seemed to be losing consistently, and lost a region early 2nd round. But when the epic came out, our move cards were in the top half of the deck, and we dispatched him quickly.

[q="SirWashington"]thanks for continuing to post about Darkest Night. Almost as good as having the game! Almost...
As for TED, I'm starting to wonder if the timing of the action cards in the final round is the overarching predictor of success (along with being able to get artifacts). In our last game, playing hard mode, we seemed to be losing consistently, and lost a region early 2nd round. But when the epic came out, our move cards were in the top half of the deck, and we dispatched him quickly.
[/q]
I think the same thing. It's not a completely luck-driven game, but a bad run of enemy cards in the later rounds can be literally impossible to react to. And artifacts are of the utmost importance--for various reasons, I only got 1 artifact in this game, and I think that definitely hurt me.
If you get 4 hero turn cards at the start of the round the Epic Foe enters play, yeah, you are probably going to win. (May not be true for all Epic Foes.)
But that luck of the draw is an integral part of the game. I think it's excused by the game's shortness and lightness.
If you wanted, you could prepare the deck after the Epic Foe appears so that each half of the deck contains 2 hero turn cards and half of the enemy cards. While that would be more fair and consistent, I don't think it would improve the game for me.
I hope you love Darkest Night when you finally get it. I'm loving the heck out of it.

[b][size=18]ORIGIN STORY[/size][/b]
Recent converts to the SGoYT lists may not even recognize me, but I've been here from the start. In the past few months I've built a house, got a promotion, and had a baby, so coming here to post has been lower priority. I still do read all your posts, though!

Although it wasn't called that when Albert got it going. Go give it a read. You'll recognize a few of the posters as being regulars around here, and it's fun to see some of the same games show up (my favorite: Hostage Negotiator is on that very first list, and I'm getting excited about getting a physical copy and adding it to lists two years older!). Scroll down to the bottom and you'll see Ryan start the next list and name it SGoyT. The rest is history.
[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/156765/item/2651593#item2651593]My first post[/url] there was Dawn of the Zeds. Coming up on two years later, I've just done another play with the expansion mixed in.

I don't post as often as I'd like because (except for a couple times recently), I tend to be very wordy ([url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/169311/item/3085395#item3085395]there[/url] [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/179645/item/3536412#item3536412]are[/url] [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/178257/item/3438655#item3438655]lots[/url] [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/176697/item/3386096#item3386096]of[/url] [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/172996/item/3252423#item3252423]examples[/url]). They've [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/172996/item/3202533#item3202533]participated in my challenges[/url], [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/169311/item/3085395?commentid=4446733#comment4446733]rooted me on[/url], [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/171003/item/3170584#item3170584]bought me stuff[/url], and even [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1011853/wip-2013-solo-pnp-harbinger-project-defeating-enem]playtested my games[/url]. [ImageID=2408651]
I decided to go on an adventure from the Book of Quests again. Last time I was hunting that dragon and couldn't find it, this time I decided to hunt down a demon. Why not?
[b]Passage into Darkness[/b]
This is a short but brutal story. It took me exactly 2 phases to discover where that demon is, not like on my dragon hunt where I was running through the whole realm and was killed by a giant. Dragon? There are no dragons in [thing=22][/thing]!
The spells I took were: - Fiery Blast - Lightning Bolt - Pentangle - Broomstick (I wanted to have Melt into Mist first but how does this damn spell work? Can someone explain it to me? Can I move with it from Hex to Hex or from Clearing to Clearing? Can I move with it at all? I don't get it.)
Broomstick was cast and I was flying around. First hex, nothing. Second hex..... Lost castle. I was unhidden, so I turned those chits around. Monster roll was 1 & 2! This time I rolled 2 dice for the monsters, I did not forget it. Now what do we have here:
[ImageID=2408653]
Well, I found my demon. Damn that was fast! But since I was unhidden and the monster roll was 1 and 2 those guys:
[ImageID=2408654]
attacked me. I did not even roll. I just died. Crying. I am not sure if I played this correct. Again, help appreciated.
Set up time was faster this time. It took me around 45 minutes I guess. But I am not sure if I can get it any faster. Even though I have everything sorted into tons of plastic bags and ready to be placed as soon as the markers are out. Play time today? Well I guess with rules re-reading... 30 minutes? :D

item.body:
[center][imageid=2408726medium][/center]
I had eyed this one for a while, then I heard that White Dog were no longer listing it so swiftly ordered it from Noble Knight games. Postage was pricey and I was hit by a customs charge - oh dear.
Then I heard a new version was to be produced with "bells and whistles" - double oh dear.
With That in mind on opening I was slightly disappointed with the production values - they're not bad but they are on the 'keeping the cost down' side of things i.e. very thin cards, stiff paper map. The counters though are great, lovely and thick and generally speaking I do like the design.
[center][imageid=2408728] Lots of suppression after a particularly heavy Artillery Barrage[/center]
But that is all so much sausage, let's get the meat and bones.
After one play - I like the game. It plays nicely, it's a different kind of wargame and the mechanisms really fit the theme. It's very much a grind down but the real action is in setting units up to be evacuated and making the most of your time to do that. You get hemmed in and attacked and pounded all the while trying to get more and more units together and on to the escape routes. All very thematic.
I finished with a score of AWFUL which I'm pleased about, you wouldn't want to do well in a game on your first go when you're not really sure what you're doing now would you?
:thumbsup: Good game :thumbsup: Very different angle for a war-type game :thumbsup: Good rulebook (but could do with an index) :thumbsup: Small footprint :thumbsup: Good player aid but could do with a couple of small additions :thumbsdown: Fiddly set up (but not terrible) :thumbsdown: Need more dice

item.body:
I know the game since it was published. It plays fast, it's puzzly, it's thematic, it's challenging. So many qualities... I like that game a lot. What I didn't notice before last month was that there is a story in it.... and it's funny.
[b][i]personal back-up story[/b][/i]
Last Christmas, my father - who will be 83 in a week and has never played a boardgame in his life - asked me to find a solo boardgame he could play. First idea that came to my mind while talking with him was Infection. However, he doesn't understand English: I had to translate the rules and the cards in French. I assumed, it would not be an easy task.
Before initiating translation, I asked for advices [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1291377/help-me-choose-solo-boardgame-lifetime][b]in the 1st Player Guild Forum[/url][/b]. I received a lot of very interesting suggestions (I'm still working on two of them) but as I "sold" Infection to my father in the first place, he was really interested in playing that particular game.
It took me more time than I expected. It is especially challenging to translate cards. Very often, it takes several words in French whereas English use one or two to express the same idea. Anyway, I did finish the translation just in time to send the game to my father for his birthday [i](it was the initial goal).[/i]
[imageid=2408761medium]
[b][i] my revelation regarding infection story [/b][/i]
When I play, I focus on the effects [i](place a molecule here or there, substract 1 or add 2 to your die roll...) [/i] and not on the ambiance text.
The translation forced me to read every single word on the cards. That's was a mistake to ignore the ambiance text. It's really worth it.
There is a true life in this Laboratory! Adam, who is the youngest team's member, is really a nice "kid". He fells asleep regularly which pisses of Amanda whereas Sylvia is more forgiving. He disguises Marvin - the RatLab - when he's got some free time and watches TV a lot! The relationship are tensed between the Lab guys and the story develops in few-well-chosen words.
On the other hand, there is also a life outside the Lab. The death section tells that story like a never-ending-scrolling informations at the bottom of the TV screen while watching the TV-news.
Just don't know how I could have missed the excellent job they did with the story in this game. It cannot be called a "story-telling" game, though, but there is a story. I will play it with new eyes now :D
:thumbsup: Fast playing, Thematic, challenging and funny! :thumbsdown: Highly improbable to save humanity playing the viral level :thumbsdown: Unlucky die rolls. There is a lot of luck involved in that game, anyway. I don't mind but some do...
[b][u][size=12]Update[/size][/b][/u]: I did save the world for the last time (I cowardly played the bacterial side and I was insanely lucky during mutations steps, though...) before sending the game to my Father. I also did my first (highly unprofessional) video playthrough to teach him the game.
[imageid=2414830medium]
Humanity's fate will be in his hands starting from Monday [i] (if French post-office permitted)[/i].
item.comment: Great gift to your dad! Hope he enjoys it!
That's amazing your father wants to try a game at his age. Don't think my father has ever played one either. Very happy for you; great story!

Thanks for sharing, Koinsky. :)
That's a lot of work to translate so many cards. I truly hope that your father enjoys the game.
As for the Infection story, I spent 3 days working on the text of the cards. I tried to envision it like a movie, but I had to keep in mind that the cards would be pulled in random order, so there could be no real linear plot. Think of it more like a movie trailer where they show you a series of quick clips that might not be in the same order as they appear in the movie. They give you a sense of the drama (and humor) of the film without dwelling on any particular scene.
It was like trying to write a novel but I could only use a Tweet amount of characters per scene. :D
So yeah, it was very gratifying to read about your appreciation of the story and its characters.

That is great, Koinsky. I'm sure your dad will live it. This sounds like a very special present.
You're right about the story! I love it. One of my favorite moments is when Sylvia places a blanket over a sleeping Adam.
You are right about the quality of the ambiance text. It really is strong in this game.
I expect to see posts from your father on this list on Tuesday. :p

Do you, really? :D
I'll translate his thoughts with pleasure (here and/or in the Guild) but I wouldn't wait for it soon. He has always soooo many things to do [retired people! :)] he'll probably take his time before giving me any feedback on the gameplay.

item.comment: It is a bit of a conundrum for me whether to post the session report here, in the game forum, or both. Not that I'm a big session writer (yet), but it's something I wonder about.

[q="enzo622"]It is a bit of a conundrum for me whether to post the session report here, in the game forum, or both. Not that I'm a big session writer (yet), but it's something I wonder about. [/q]
I figure, when you post here you're adding to the health of SGoYT and when you post on a game's page, you're adding to the health of the game. Both are good things, so why not do both? If you didn't post here, I'd never have the opportunity to see it (as I don't frequent the DDay page) and likewise, someone researching the game DDay would never see it if you didn't post to its specific page.
Personal Experience: When Shadows of Brimstone first came out I was ravenous for session reports. Some were getting posted to the board, but I've stumbled across a lot that were posted in other forums, blogs, etc. I would have loved to have those things also posted to the SoB forum for easier access.
[u][i]My [/i][/u]hesitancy about "double posting" comes from it feeling self-serving or self-aggrandizing. After all, it IS gratifying to get feedback and having double exposure gives more feedback. But I think in this case, it's not only OK, but a potentially good thing for the hobby and the game itself.

I really like it when people do what you have done here - post a link on here to your session report on the game page (a direct link might be nicer though). That way those interested can click through and others can pass on by. I know an extra click can be annoying but first world problems and all that.
Also, I think it's great when people sum up their opinions about the game here but go into more session details in their reports.
So, nice work!
But feel free to do it however you want to do it - no harm in double postings.

My third game for today! And my second time for [thing=84419][/thing].
[ImageID=2408906]
I played the Doomsday Machine solo mission again. Easy mode of course.
This time I wanted to have more ships on the board when the first DM was about to attack. The first planets to colonize were 2 hexes away from my HS.
[ImageID=2408907]
My HS was surrounded by minerals. Which was a good thing. My Scouts were exploring and exploring finding planets, minerals and everything else but Danger! markers - good. But one of my three Colony Ships got destroyed by a black hole. Damn!
[ImageID=2408908]
The Scouts were in the game almost until the end. And while writing this down I realised that my DMs were coming in too soon! :D I let them appear after turn 7, 9 and 11 and NOT in economic phase 7, 9 and 11. That makes it of course an unbeatable challenge. :D Ok second game at all. Still learning...
Anyway I had lots of fun getting destroyed by those killing machines. I almost took the first one down with the three CAs I managed to bring in. But the dice again. Today they hate me. Attack rolls on my side - bad, attack rolls for the DM - score, score, score...
[ImageID=2408909]
The DM attack is a powerful one and my last fleet was no match for them. (of course not, since I played it too hard)
[ImageID=2408910]
Those two DMs entered both in area 8 and that was a straight line to two of my colonies and my HS. The third DM entered in 2 but did not even matter. Next time I need to play this correct.
I played wrong (again) but it was good for learning how battle is done. Next time, with more time to build a good defense I think I can handle at least one of those DM with no problem. (if the dice are on my side)
[ImageID=2408911]
One big :thumbsdown: for myself for making this big mistake. :shake: One big :thumbsup: for the game, because I am already addicted! Can't wait to bring it on the table again. To read the tech sheet only makes me plan my defense and counter attack on those DMs! Next time you bastards I bring you down!

item.body: I brought this back out this month (don't worry Navajo Wars - you'll be back soon!). Two games so far, one a clear Jihadist victory (ouch!), but then the luckiest game I've ever had for the US. The Jihadist AI was stuck with Serbia and China on its first two radicalization placement rolls, and with plenty of cells available, kept recruiting there (I kept the rest of the board clear of cells and cadres besides IR Afghanistan). Relatively free of interference (and with a hand that was full of 3 point cards), I was able to Regime Change Iraq with Iraqi WMD and a couple of action phases later, get it to Good (thanks Mass Turnout!). With Gulf States also on Good Ally, I was well placed for the Oil Price Spike coming out of the Jihadist hand. Two lucky successful rolls later, and Saudi is Good Ally - 12 Good Resources victory with half the deck remaining! This was my first solo victory before the shuffle. Love this game! :D
