item.body:
[b][u]Challenge 7, Week 4[/u][/b]
[b]Villain:[/b] Citizen Dawn
[b]Environment:[/b] Ruins of Atlantis
[size=18][b]Score: 56[/b][/size] Rounds: 10 Wounds: 38 Dawn Heals: 8
[b]Hero Wounds (order of play):[/b] Visionary: 16 Absolute Zero: 8 Wraith: 14
Finally, a victory on my sixth attempt at this challenge! The win feels very satisfying, for I had just about despaired of beating it with this set of heroes. It seemed like every time I got something going, Devastating Aurora would turn up and set the heroes back. Absolute Zero in particular has a tough time with that card -- it takes him a few turns to get going even without interference, and it is just, well, devastating when his board gets wiped.
Ideally of course, the heroes can manage some villain deck control to keep the Aurora's out of the game, but I found that even with Infrared Eyepiece going, things could transpire such that a D.A. showed up despite my best efforts to keep it away. Those cards which play an extra villain card per turn can scupper the best-laid plans this way.
My other issue in previous sessions was somewhat self-inflicted: I tended to lose focus and hit citizens when I should have been concentrating on Dawn herself. After several sessions, I started to figure out which citizens were not urgent threats and to leave them on the board in favor of directing damage at Dawn. This, I'm convinced is the key to beating her: you simply have to take her down as quickly as possible and ignore all but the most dire distractions. Yes, the heroes will take damage, but it's a race they can win if they get a bit of luck and have some time to set up (i.e., avoid Devastating Auroras).
[b]Visionary[/b] contributed in several small but significant ways. I chose to use her primarily for her inherent power, which is invaluable in helping Absolute Zero get set up early in the game. And in the event, this is exactly what she did. She then got Mental Divergence out, which she used to take out some of Dawn's more annoying ongoings. She later drew a Wrest the Mind and the Cocoon, which is a great combo. She first played Wrest the Mind on a recently-arrived Mystical Defenses, making sure that she took enough damage to take her down to 10 HP so she could be the lowest HP hero (the better to suck up hits from Krakens when no citizens were available), and on her next turn went into the Telekinetic Cocoon. She pumped as much Mystical Defense damage into Citizen Dawn as she could, and then remained in the Cocoon because, yes, there were two Krakens out. Finally, Visionary used Mass Levitation a few round to cut down on damage from the environment cards. Visionary came out of her cocoon in the final round to play a Mind Spike on Dawn so she could participate in the final takedown.
[b]Absolute Zero[/b] was able to get set up about as quickly as possible thanks to Visionary helping him draw cards. He started with a Null Point Calibration Unit in hand, but to really get going, he needs Isothermic Transducer, Thermal Shockwave and Focused Aperture. With this, he can start to both do damage and heal himself each turn. His second card play was an Impale which he stuck on Dawn, and this was responsible for 9 damage over the course of the session. Once he had his equipment suite up, he started to do steady damage using Thermal Shockwave while keeping himself healthy.
[b]Wraith[/b] did what she does with her equipment, but her focus throughout was using the Infrared Goggles she began the game with. She was thus able to bury both Devastating Aurora's during the game. Before her Utility Belt appeared, she forwent stealth in order to keep checking the villain deck each turn. The goggles also helped to bury the more annoying citizens, such as Citizen Tears. Once the Utility Belt showed up, she used the goggles and a Micro-Computer aided Razor Ordnance to hit Dawn each turn. Combat Stance played a role in keeping damaging citizens and environment cards in check. She also used Grappling Hook twice on pesky ongoings; keeping Dawn's various ongoings in check is also a key to fighting her, I think.
In the final round, AZ could have finished Dawn off, but instead simply healed himself to improve the final challenge score, leaving Wraith to effect the coup de grace. Even though Dawn had just 3 HP remaining, she played Inventory Barrage to do 12 damage, just 'cause.
[b]Citizen Dawn[/b] could not get her Auroras out thanks to Wraith's goggles, and fortunately, she was also not able to get any synergistic pairs of citizens played. The Infrared Goggles also kept some of the more effective citizens out of play. Dawn did flip once, but then flipped right back. She did manage to heal 8 points of damage during the battle thanks to Illuminate the Dawn and Citizen Spring, but Wraith buried that one-shot which heals her for 10. With her citizens unable to effectively team up, Dawn lost health at a steady rate. The game would have ended a round earlier but for the last-minute arrival of Citizen Truth; the heroes had to spend another round taking him out before they could finish Dawn off in round 10.
[b]Ruins of Atlantis[/b] was more help than hindrance in this one as it turned out. All three Krakens were played, but these feasted first on a steady supply of citizens, battering themselves ineffectually against Visionary's cocoon when no citizens were available. Two Mystical Defenses also came out, but one helped the heroes as mentioned above when Visionary wrested it's, uh, "mind." Toxic Seaweed showed up twice as did Leaking Room. Fortunately, both of the latter appeared late enough in the battle so that the heroes could continue doing damage using the various powers at their disposal even if they couldn't play cards.
While this was one of the more frustrating challenges, it was a fun one to try to solve. After five defeats, I wasn't sure that I'd picked the right hero in Visionary, but she proved her worth in this battle. And the repeated plays also forced me to learn how to play Absolute Zero. He's not a hero I'd choose to play on my own very often because he takes so long to get set up. He operates with a different paradigm from most of the other heroes in the game, but I came to appreciate how powerful he can be once he gets his stuff out.

[size=18][b]Origin Story[/b][/size]
[b]What brought you here?[/b] I can't even remember how I found this place. Probably cruising the 'Geeklist' section of the 'geek front page, or else I was looking at a particular game and looked for 'active' on the geeklist section of the game page. Something like that.
[b]What was the first game you posted?[/b] See game listed for this geeklist item.
[b]Do you still own it and/or play it?[/b] Yes, and yes. Just played it today so it would match up with my secret origins' post.
[b]Was there anything else notable about your first visit?[/b] Maybe not the 1st visit [i]per se[/i], but once you start following SGoYT, you start to see the same games over and over and THAT leads to (see 2 questions down).
[b]What keeps bringing you back?[/b] Camaraderie, learning about new games I might want to acquire, posting my own plays, the contests.
...and this is a big point--> it might seem counter intuitive, but spending time HERE makes me play more games. Yah, I spend an hour or so here, but then I get all amped to play something. Web surfing something like www.si.com doesn't get me playing games more often.
[b]How much money have these lists cost you?[/b]
This is the wrong way to frame the question. The right way to frame the question is:
[b]How many time have your friends at SGoYT helped you to make an informed decision on a cool new game?[/b] Glad you asked. After seeing and reading all the hype on these games here, I have acquired [thing=71721][/thing], [thing=29603][/thing], [thing=41490][/thing], and [thing=68876][/thing].
[b]ADDITION[/b]: Looks like SGoYT has convinced me to acquire [thing=39941][/thing] as well.
Now that you've heard about my SGoYT origin, let's talk about WMTtE. I always play for military victory. Knocked out the Brits. Had Mac and Nimitz on their last spaces, but couldn't get the DRMs to get rid of them, too. When you go for knock out something else has to give, and in my case it was resources. All 3 went to 0 on the 1st card in the Late War deck.

item.objectname: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.body:
Ah, so now I see why this game pops up on this list so much -- so addictive. That is, if you like getting beaten into a pulp. It's a fun beating though, with the promise of maybe, just maybe, winning the next one.
I'm not a very experienced player having just 6 plays under my belt, and those interspersed over the past 6 years, so I had to relearn the game and then learn the AI. It was a little painful for a bit. The whole Consume action was hanging me up, but I think I got it -- unless you choose Consume: Trade yourself, you can't sell, but you can (and must actually) trade for VPs even if you didn't choose the action (assuming you have a card that allows you).
So, assuming I played correctly, the bot kicked my butt good and hard, 5 games to 0. I got as close as 48-42 but was frequently 10+ points lower. Still, this is exactly what I wanted it to be -- a training ground for me to catch up to my friends who know the game well so I can play better from now on.
And now that I have a copy of the game, it's more likely to come out on game night. I'd sort of avoided the game only by virtue of the fact that my friends and I were all in on [thing=19857][/thing] rather than try to split our plays between the two games. I know that one the way some know this one. Lately, though, I find myself interested in playing this both m-p and solo. I look forward to more practice sessions of this one.
I was surprised at how addictive it feels. [i]Just one more game![/i] But I got tired and decided to retire to the couch with all of you on my lap.
Now, don't get weird about that. :D

item.body:
[ImageID=2409584medium] [size=12][b]Thief + Prophetess[/b][/size]
[b][COLOR=#CC0000]Score: -6, Villager[/COLOR][/b] [c]+59, Monsters (11) +8, Treasures (2) +7, Firestone Shards (2) -80, Dungeon Tax[/c]
Man, this game is so fun! It's a mix of tile-laying goodness and a solitaire tableau. The joy of building your dungeon and seeing it completed is so satisfying.
And then you get hit with the Dungeon Tax. :shake:
I randomly drew the Thief and the Prophetess this time around. The Thief can move 1 or 2 spaces and can avoid Monsters without discarding. The Prophetess can look at the top four cards of the deck, choose one to play, and move the rest to the bottom.
The Ladies were fighting machines, slaying Monsters all through the dungeon. They took down the big 7 and 9 strength Monsters, a couple of Enchanted Monsters, and even a Double Monster.
[ImageID=2409585medium]
For Treasures, they went with Potions for the first half of the adventure, putting to good use the Speed, Deja Vu, and Reprise spells. Although, they should have waiting a little longer to cast the Reprise spell. It refills the dungeon with Monsters and Treasures, and the bottom of the deck was stacked with some juicy rewards they could have grabbed on the way out.
No matter, though. The construction and ensuing adventure were great fun. If you're looking for something to use that ArtsCow coupon on, give this one a gander.

What a fun little game this turned out to be!
I was skeptical after seeing only 2 pages of rules, but I enjoyed this game more than any game I've played in a long time. I was on the edge of my seat at several points during the game. Real decisions had to be made. The degree of historical background is outstanding, more than I've seen for any wargame. It's wonderfully compact and portable, and takes no time to setup and play.
My only criticism is that the element of luck is very high. Also, it's unclear if the novelty will wear off with further play.
I've alread ordered the expansion!

I played first two-handed to get an idea of the basic concepts of the game, then played the SoloPlay rules from [user=GameRulesForOne][/user].

item.comment: Such a lovely little game!

I love this game, but didn't know there were solo rules! Yay!
My husband and I play 2p and we always feel so relaxed after a game. It's really like going for a walk in the woods.

[q="de_la_poer"]Such a lovely little game![/q]
Agreed!
[q="suzyvitale"]I love this game, but didn't know there were solo rules! Yay!
My husband and I play 2p and we always feel so relaxed after a game. It's really like going for a walk in the woods. [/q]
The SoloPlay rules are lovely that way, too. Of the SoloPlay variants I've tried, it's the most relaxed.
I kept eyeing it and knew about the solo rules - how do you rate the overall gameplay?

[q="eastwoodk"]I kept eyeing it and knew about the solo rules - how do you rate the overall gameplay?[/q]
If you're looking for a peaceful game of hand management, goals management, and the occasional poison mushrooms, this is a really great game and a great SoloPlay variant. There is tension, but for some reason it's not really pressing like it is in, say, Viticulture or Core Worlds SoloPlay.
In some ways the SoloPlay variant (as it usually does) balances out some issues in the multiplayer game. For instance, spending mushrooms to buy walking sticks isn't as valuable in the multiplayer game as it is in the SoloPlay variant, where reducing the sticks unbought is important to game scoring.
And when you do play it two-player, it is a nice walk through the woods gathering mushrooms.
nice - i've owned this for over a year and haven't quite gotten my wife to jump in. So maybe i can get it to the table another way! Thanks for the pointer.

item.body:
Am I completely insane to play an 18xx game solo? Can 18xx even be enjoyed solitaire?
Yes and No.
After a hiatus from the 18xx system, I'll soon be teaching a group of players (old and new) 18NEBraska so I decided to put it on the solo table tonight in order to experience the design. Private companies were randomly dealt, and my goal was to operate each corporation as efficiently as possible.
[center][IMG]http://i92.photobucket.com/albums/l32/sacentaur/8e20e0dc-c617-43fc-bf96-eb357bc095aa_zps47287692.jpg[/IMG][size=7][i]At start, 3P setup[/i][/size][/center]
I aborted play before the permanent trains appeared as the tipping point had been reached and it was just too much for me to comfortably handle (alas, I found myself making quite a few mistakes).
But it was definitely worth the time and effort - this was a comparatively easy 18xx title to re-familiarize myself with, and I was able to explore many of the ins-and-outs of the design. One thing learned is that there is potential for a high screwage factor (strategy) here when Towns are upgraded to Cities and are then tokened by other railroads. Sweet!
18xx is not generally recommended for solitaire play, but tonight's action temporarily satiated my train craving and it also fully prepared me for the teaching sessions ahead. Mission accomplished...
I must conclude with the thought that 18xx is one of the finest gaming systems ever created - I simply love it.

My kickstarted copy of this plopped through the door today. (Well actually I had to answer the door to the postman as it was too big to fit through letterbox but the plopping description sounds better).
[imageid=2410098]
It meant that I have finally been inspired to write something this month and that I played this a few times whilst the girls were at school rather than [thing=121921][/thing], which had been my plan.
I had a couple of wins (1 on easy, 1 on normal) but I played the extra action rule wrong completely in the first game and then slightly wrong in the second game.
Played it a third time with all rules correct on normal level and lost.
[imageid=2410096]It had all been going so well.
I really enjoyed the three games of it I played and wish I could have played a few more. It has simple rules but quite a few exceptions thanks to all the powers of the heroes and villains. That means the rulebook comes across as a bit lacking but nothing major. Most of the stuff I called on the fly seemed to match up with the official FAQs when I checked them.
It's not as tiny as it could have been with the region, hero and epic foe cards being quite large for a 'tiny' game. This makes the footprint small but not tiny.
That said, the rules sink in quick, it is a challenge to win (when you play the rules right) and the quality of the components seems good. This will be coming on holiday with me and can fit in my work bag. It was more fun than [thing=158900][/thing] (another recent game I bought about defending) and I prefer the theme of this one too.
The arts quite nice in a cheesy fantasy way too and it fits in the box without loads of extra space.
Finally, I was worried that I wouldn't like it as my interest in it had fallen since backing it and the last game I crowd funded had disappointed me. My worries were unfounded.
Despite the completely different nature of the game, this now makes me very excited about having backed [thing=163967][/thing].
[b]Like:[/b] The challenge, the theme, the size, the fact that I could play it within 5 minutes and play it right within a couple of plays.
[b]Don't like:[/b] The wait between backing a game and getting it can make my interest wane. It had with this but within one play I was happy I backed it. Is it right to be disappointed with the final size of it being too big?

The mistake I made [geekurl=/geeklist/186592/item/3729440#item3729440][b]yesterday[/b][/geekurl] burnt inside of me. I had to get the game back on the board again, today!
What did I change? Most important, the DMs entered correctly. ;) Did I win? No. But first things first.
What did I learn? Even if your colony ship could get into a hex with an unexplored marker - don't do it! Happened to me yesterday, happened to me today...
[ImageID=2410219]
I took my time getting better technologies and building colony ships before I build myself a good fleet. My scouts were all over the galaxy only to end in dangerous areas. Anyway I found a lot of minerals and planets because of them. They will not be forgotten!
When the first DM entered the map I had a decent fleet to face it.
[ImageID=2410220]
The first attack of the DM was a laugh.
[ImageID=2410221]
I took the thing down but lost some ships too. To score 6 hits is not that easy if the dice hate you.
Finally I got the technology to build my first DN! YES! The second DM was on the map and this was a real killing machine! My last fleet was good (looking), at least that's what I thought. I rolled 3 hits with every attack the DM did and it destroyed my fleet without a problem.
[ImageID=2410222]
DM 2 was a killing machine!
DM 3 entered the map. My last DN was no match for DM 2 and my HS was terminated.
Damn! If the dice were on my side I would have crushed that second DM! Next time I need to research more attack and defense tech!
:thumbsup: I am already addicted to this game. :thumbsup: I love that it is not an easy game. Ok the dice hate me... :thumbsup: I am up for new things! Next time I add some new stuff.

[size=18][b]Origin Story[/b][/size]
[b]What brought you here? Was it from a subscription, or did you find it on the front page or on a specific game page?[/b] I got a GeekMail invitation from someone, so I thought I'd check it out.
[b]What was the first game you posted? Do you still own it and/or play it?[/b] Hmm ... maybe [thing=28829][/thing] or [thing=71721][/thing]. Not sure anymore. I still own both, but I haven't played either in a long while.
[b]Was there anything else notable about your first visit?[/b] I was overwhelmed by the size of the guild and of this regular GeekList. I had a reputation as a solo guy long before SGoYT came along, but I was under the impression that I was in a tiny minority. Hardly any other BGGeeks seemed much interested.
[b]Anything else you'd like to share about your first visit?[/b] I got off on the wrong foot by immediately suggesting that this list could stand to be broken down into a weekly thing so as not to grow so big and unmanageable. Didn't mean to complain or anything; I just wasn't used to the information overload (or the fun "block party" as someone else called it).
[b]What keeps bringing you back?[/b] My subscription notice. Frankly, I often skip this list, or check in only now and then, because it's too much for me to keep up with.
[b]How much money have these lists cost you?[/b] "These lists?" OMG, don't tell me there's more than one! :surprise:
Oh, maybe you mean one per month. (Whew!)
I don't think they've cost me any money; only time. Well, except that I kept seeing Mage Knight praised around here, so I put it on a wish list, and my wife bought it for me last Christmas.
Aside from that, I've been spending most of my money at GOG.com on non-tabletop games.
[b]If you haven't been back since your first visit, how are you even reading this?[/b] Hmm ... maybe I'm not. Could be I'm just imagining it. Or maybe this is still part of my first visit, and I've never really left. Or there could be some kind of multidimensional thing going on. But most likely, I have been back, so here I am.
[size=18][b]Game Rating[/b][/size] Just noticed the game-rating bit in the header. I'm new to Mage Knight, but ...
:thumbsup: A wonderfully variable, challenging puzzle of a game, with great components and a built-in solitaire version.
:thumbsdown: Deceptive, in that at first glance it appears to be an RPG/Adventure game; not very engaging imaginatively/emotionally.
:thumbsdown: A brain-buster; one of those games (like chess) where you do a whole lot of thinking before you make a move. (Of course, that's a thumbs-up for anyone who loves that sort of thing.)

Mission accomplished: three games of Mage Knight, in two nights - from refresher (with thanks to a couple of video walkthroughs; download the usual suspects) up to and including elements of [thing=130704][/thing] and [thing=144763][/thing].
The last few hours have been a bit of a blur, but the solo conquests were fantastically rewarding. I was still using the dummy player as a timer, as I've always enjoyed the simplicity of it. I'm getting to the point where not every game is a learning one, but I want to get another half-dozen plays under my belt before attempting to add in Volkare again. (I've made the mistake of over-complicating a base game, without knowing it intimately enough, before.)

item.body:
I just finished my third straight game of this. I think I can say that it doesn't make the cut. I really wanted to like this game. It's got dinosaurs, evolution, cataclysmic events. I love all three of those. Sadly, this game isn't the one for me.
Why it's getting fired: 1. Rules are not easy to digest. I read the rules, watched Rick Royal's video, played the game, read the rules, played two more times. I still find myself needing to consult the RULES! Yes, I have the living rules.
2. Herbivore and carnivore contests, herbivores can become carnivores, road runner DNA, dentition, size....it's just too much that is not implemented in an easy to understand way.
3. It seems as though the DNA I need is never in the display. Most of the early biomes require BB and I could never get BB or even a single B.
Me: "BIOS: Megafauna, I'm sorry. I wanted to like you, honestly. It's not you, it's me....good-bye"

item.body:
Inspired by Marco's recent video review of Cruel Necessity, I decided I was long overdue in getting this to the table again.
As it turned out, the last time I played this was 18th February 2014, and I had played the 1st English Civil War in my 5th Campaign. I was on -6VP after that.
I re-read Wes Erni's strategy tips, and felt ready for the fray once again, so onwards in this session with the 2nd ECW! The highlights of the 2nd ECW were the 3 battle victories. They provided me with a little comfort and zeal, but that was all. I made little progress and finished the 2nd ECW on -9VP.
The position going into the 3rd ECW was fairly dire. The Battle of Worcester was fought as a decisive battle, and this again provided me with much needed zeal. However, my dice rolls failed to inspire for much of the game.
I barely managed to survive to card No.60, the end of the 3rd ECW, finishing with -11VP. Surviving counts as a victory, but the points edges the victory into 'marginal defeat' territory. Once again, I just could not manage to obtain an achievement card! When a card appeared to be within reach, the political track moved me out of reach.
:thumbsup: I love this game :) - it's a lavish VPG States of Siege game with high production quality, beautiful map, and so many moving parts.
:thumbsdown: I hate this game..... :) I cannot seem to crack it and achieve any kind of worthwhile victory. I seem to be getting worse at it, not better! My last three campaign scores are -6VP, -9 VP, -11VP.
:thumbsup: It has the Battle of Worcester :) - I live only ten miles from the site of the Battle of Worcester!
item.comment:
I worked quite a bit with John Welch on this while it inexplicably languished in limbo at VPG for several years.
The prototype was a ton of fun, but there were some unfortunate issues (all initiated by VPG) that prevented it from being published by GMT (in the proposed Revolt & Revolution pack that had to be cancelled).
Still, the final production turned out nicely but the game would have garnished more attention (and many more accolades) if it had been released by GMT - I feel bad for the designer who put his heart & soul into the project, he truly deserved a lot more success than he actually received.
Having spent years in the trenches, few people realize that our cherished hobby puts creative talent at great risk, just like in movies, TV, books, etc. Just the way it is.

It is fair to say that John Welch has produced a marvelous game design, which provides a great insight into the history of the ECWs. It ought to have won an award, really. :D
It is a very tough nut to crack too, though I am probably not a good enough player (or my dice are not loaded in my favour!) to really get the most from the game!

item.body:
Ok - so another solo game night and here's what I played:
[b]Euphoria [/b]- LOVE this game. I stupidly backed out of the KS and had to acquire the Deluxe edition via trade, but now that I have it I'm psyched. There's a good solo play variant on BGG that keeps the general feel of the game, but I wanted to play 2-handed tonight, and in the end there was only 1 move difference between losing and winning - a very tight game.
[b]BIOS Megafauna[/b] - This was a recent acquisition after watching Ricky Royal (sidebar - every time I watch his videos I buy the game - seriously I've got 90% of the games that I've seen on his channel). This was my second play of it, and I liked it better than the first. I saw another SGOYTer post tonight about never getting the cards in the display, and that happened to me for part of the game tonight, but still managed to pull out an 11 to 9 win. I'm going to remove the advanced cards since the AI can't buy them - I'm sure that will add some additional stress to the game.
[b]Shadows over the Empire[/b] - After perusing my shelves, this was collecting dust and was on my "trade" pile, so I gave it another shot. It's not made for solo play, but since I was playing 2-handed earlier I thought it was fine. In general the gameplay consists of influencing cards, and using abilities - but there's quite a bit going on in a small display for 2 players ( I can't imagine a 4 player game). Overall, I like the artwork, and feel that it's an ok game, but when shelf space is a concern, it's probably headed out the door.

item.objectname: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â Base Set
item.body:
Harsk, Amiri, and Ezren are back at it again facing the Stone Giants attacking Sandpoint.
I continue to be impressed by the small thematic touches in this game. This scenario has you roll for an open location each turn and reveal the top card. If it's a boon (good), you put it back in the box. If it's a bane (bad), you shuffle it back into the deck. Seemed like a bunch of stone giants were raging around the city slowly destroying everything in their path. Cool.
The fight itself was a pretty simple one. Find enemies. Kill enemies. The good guys won, taking out Teraktinus in the final location they ventured to.
The only other thing I must bring up is a beef I have with one Kev Cossley (I think that's the right name) who drew the artwork for the Deathweb monster.
[imageid=2410853 medium]
Seriously Kev... I have enough spider nightmares without you putting this horrifying image of a zombie spider in my head. Of course, you would probably take that as a compliment. :shake:
item.comment: That picture makes me want to get back on track with this game! That is a awesome card.

item.body:
[b]Origin Story[/b]
I found the list just by noticing it as a regular on the active geeklists. As I started to play more solo games, I got curious and checked it out. This was the first solo game I posted to this list back in August 2014. The two games I can immediately think of that this list was instrumental in me buying were D-Day Dice (it's ok) and Navajo Wars (solid game).
I keep coming back just to see what others are playing so I can gather ideas on other things I might be interested in picking up. I also like any solo variants for any games that aren't normally considered solo games.

Played as the government again and didn't do well. Aid went to zero almost immediately as a Propaganda card hit as the 2nd card and another aid-diminishing event right after that. Still did better than in the past with the Las Villas firewall strategy, but could keep the insurgents under control. Either Directorio or Syndicate could have won, it was up to Castro on his final turn to decide (he could either close the 8th casino or place enough guerillas to rest control away from the key Directorio population area). As I was the government, I didn't really care.

It's been quite a while since I last posted to SGoyT and that's partly down to the fact that I've not been playing an awful lot of solo games, just the odd evening here and there but also just down to the fact that I've been really lazy. ;)
Anyway, decided to make a bit more of an effort so here's a few posts of games I played yesterday.
First up was Euphoria using this [filepage=108724]solo variant[/filepage], written by [user=MrTetsuo][/user]
It was my first play using the variant and I've only played a couple of learning games of Euphoria before that. Needless to say, I didn't achieve the full victory condition, I took the easier victory condidtion and used my dilema card to place my last star. I quite enjoyed the variant, it's quite a nice little sandbox to play around with Euphoria's optimisation puzzle. I might have the opportunity to break Euphoria out tonight for a multiplayer game, so it'll be interesting to see how it compares.

Viticulture was next up (staying on a theme) - there's been a ton of posts on this recently and even after just a couple of games I can really see why. It's just so smooth and easy to play, yet challenging and for me, has that right level of thinky-ness.
I managed to pull off a semi-win in this one, technically I hit the victory point total but there was one winter when I forgot to apply the automa and it was halfway through the next turn before I realised. I tried to handicap myself a bit to make up for it but really there was no telling just how much difference that made. So I'm not considering that one an official win for the campaign, just a good learning game.

item.objectname: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.body: This was the last game I had time for and was the second play of the game. My first game ended fairly violently with a Chestburster emerging after I was unable to deal with a Facehugger early in the game. Happily, the second game was much more successful and I pulled off a fairly easy victory. There's a lot I really like in this game, most of the art is great, I love the mechanism for building the Hive deck and the way it works with the objectives, I like the scanning and some of the enemies are really cool. Yet I can't help but feel it's got some massive problems when played with 1 player. There was very little tension in the game I played yesterday and the use of the Coordinate mechanic seems to be fairly integral to the game at times, losing that when playing 1 handed really took the shine off, imo. These are all things (from what I've read) that can be fixed by playing multi-handed (which I have no problem with), so I think, for me (rather than tinkering with house rules) that's the way to go in the future.

item.objectname: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.body:
For reasons that will become clear in time, I'm trying to get more plays of this game in in the near future. I tried my first play of the Alien 3 (Fury colony) scenario today.
Wow! I had remembered the other scenarios being a bit soft for 3 players, but this one really ramped up the combat difficulty. I played with the Priest, Executive and Commander avatars. My Priest died before Objective 2. As I understand it, this actually helped me a little bit by giving the other characters more opportunities to cycle their decks. Still, this one definitely puts a heavy emphasis on combat, even more so than the Aliens scenario, with a lot of really nasty enemies. The Beast, the final boss of this scenario, is particularly nasty in a way that I won't spoil for anybody. In a nice thematic moment, I finished him off with the Lead Works.
I have also been playing through the tutorial of [b][thing=102435][/thing][/b]. I believe that where I left off last night, I had just used my first Ceremony card. I really appreciate the time that went into making this tutorial--without it, I bet I would understand the rules of the game, but I would have no clue what kind of strategies to pursue.
I was surprised to get a shipping confirmation from CoolStuffInc for my order of [b][thing=163602][/thing][/b], [b][thing=34119][/thing][/b] and [b][thing=166679][/thing][/b]! Looks like I have a lot of gaming in my future. Good timing, too, because my wife just started the spring semester and will be busy studying more often than not, leaving me more solo gaming time.
In a non-gaming related but happy life event, I had a job interview today that I think went pretty well. Hopefully something comes of it.
Finally, I'm playing a game this week that, while I'm playing it solo, I'm not at liberty to describe the game in any way, even the theme or publisher. I will say that I think it will please some members of this guild. If things go as I expect, you probably won't hear much from me for the rest of the week.

French has nothing to envy to English in terms of written complexity. Note that language is not my specialty, although I've studied Latin, Greek, German in middle and high school (ages ago)
Because it went very far away from its Latin's roots (much more than other Latin languages, I guess), we've got so many words with similar pronunciation and different orthography-meanings. Some of them are very common and used in every day life. For instance : "cinq, saint, sain, sein, seing, ceint" = "five, holy, healthy, breast, "signature", "to put something around the head..."
Then, we've got the accents on letters, coming from Greek, which have a common grammatical rule and sooooo many exceptions to the rule. Furthermore, we've got numerous letters (mostly consonants) which are written and not pronounced. But, we haven't got many diphthongs.
German is incredibly difficult with the declinations (like in Latin and Greek) when the word changes depending on its location-role in the sentence. You have to master grammar when speaking-writing German. Not a surprise to me to notice that German people are fluent in foreign languages and don't do many mistakes while writing. They learned how a sentence is built.
English grammar seems much more accessible, IMO. I didn't, actually, learn English at school, never read a grammar book but I guess I'm fluent while speaking and understandable while writing even if I'm not at ease when I write. I don't master all the subtilties but I find this language very... Inventive, let's say poetic and the English thesaurus is a beauty.

But we do have huge thesaurus as well!
[q="philmcd"]many words having multiple meanings and many parts of words spelled the same way but pronounced differently.[/q]Oh yes, that's a problem! Tell me about "concrete" :)[/q]
I love the subtleties of English as a native language, I just wouldn't want to learn it as a foreign language :D[/q]
English is a very simple language apart from the worst match of spelling to speaking in the world.
Edit - [u]Sorry[/u], I'm late to this party, my browser must have skipped a page when I was reading the thread!:blush:
[/q]
Come on, English is many things (because it derives from many diverse sources), but simple it isn't. It is a very complex language, made doubly obtuse by the various oddball pronunciations of seemingly similar words.
However, it's complexity has the upside of making it a very expressive language, capable of describing minutaei in a rainbow of textures and colours, each slightly different from the next.
[/q]
My comment is a bit tongue in cheek to express my frustration at how English not only has inane spelling variations, but even the vowel sounds have been corrupted so the letters don't match the phonetic symbols. However, there is a bit of truth in what I say - just 700 words represent 68% of written and verbal English material. [/q]
That will be the influence of the tabloid press and texting. When you've got 100,000+ words to choose from, why compromise?
Personally I like to use words as a palette.[/q]
Well the stats predate texting and the rise of the tabloid press, and I am talking about everyday usage, for instance, of the 21 words in your sentence "That will be..." 16 of those are from the 700. Of your next sentence only 'palette' and 'personally' are not from the 700, although 'personally' is derived from personal, which is. Both % both close to 70%.
[/q]
The stats pre-date the 1970's ?? Maybe they are superfluous, out-moded or ambiguous :)
But in any case, the complexity of the English langage is a funtion of it's grammar, spelling and contextual pronunciation, not the quantity of vocabulary.
I know quite a large number of French and German words, but my French grammar is poor and my German is non-existent.
[/q]
Having had to conjugate verbs in French, German and Portuguese I still think English is simpler. In Chinese, apparently, how you intone a word changes its meaning, without the native ear for it, it is very difficult to get the right intonation. In Arabic, the difference in pronunciation is so subtle, when my friend Farah, told people her name they laughed, because her slight difference in pronunciation changed its meaning to 'rat'.
I find English is simple in some ways compared to these languages, and very forgiving. It's amazing how metropolitan English speakers can understand English spoken in a wide range of accents and variants from countries where it is a national second language with very different but accepted ways of using it.
I know I said this tongue in cheek, but as I said there is a bit of truth in it.
As for the stats, they aren't out-moded, as I just used them on a contemporary use of English - yours. Neither are they ambiguous, you can take a sample of modern literature and count the words that are in the list of the common words. Superfluous? I suppose it depends on what you are trying to use them for. Originally they were used as a way of teaching Pitmans Shorthand.
I am not saying English is not a beautiful language with a rich vocabulary. I am sure it is popular world-wide for that reason, but its spoken accessibility is also probably part of the reason. It's just a shame about the spelling/pronunciation mismatch :angry:
[/q]
Are we building the Tower of Babel out of quote boxes?

No, but maybe a Babel Fish would come in handy. :D
That won't make sense to anyone who doesn't know The Hitchiker's guide to the galaxy :shake:

Very interesting chat. Reading through the comments reminded me of the time I was chatting to a mate about the true story film "Let Him Have It". Basically Derek Bentley was hanged for saying "Let him have it Chris" to his mate when a policeman had asked them for the gun they were holding when caught during a burglary.
The informal meaning of "shoot him, Chris" instead of the literal meaning of "give him the gun, Chris" would seem to be an ambiguity that could not exist in probably most other languages (particularly German which we were talking about at the time).

Getting back to the language discussion...
Did you know that Spanish is the most intelligible language? It was determined by otorhinolaringologists of several countries. They made a pool of bisylabic common words, and recorded them, then made the volunteers for the study hear them, one by one, beginning with very low sound volume, and slowly increasing it. The Spanish volunteers heard the correct word at much lower sound volumes than in other countries.

[center][imageid=2411042medium][/center]
This arrived yesterday, what a small box.
Tried out the solo variant, it's a fun distraction but only gives the slightest whiff of the multi-player game. I'd certainly play it again even though it is only a beat your own score thing. I only scored 11! I think high 20's and 30's are more usual but I banjaxed myself by discarding too many soldiers and only using one Entertainment (purple) Guild card (as I had excluded the expansion/promo cards in my play) when these two Missio cards needed to be completed. Doh!
A quick game, bit deeper than a filler.
:thumbsup: Fun, quick :thumbsup: Nice looking :thumbsup: Small, v portable :thumbsup: I think will be an excellent multiplayer gateway game :thumbsdown: Will need more plays for informed negatives
item.comment:
I've played this solo about a dozen times. My best score is having only 2 Missio cards left (with a score of around 36 I think), and I now get 30+ points usually every time - but still not completed ALL Missio cards, the elusive elixir!
It's a nice quick filler solo game, but if I DO ever complete them all, I'm not sure I'd want/need to play it solo again.
Would be nice if someone came up with an AI variant where you have to play against that player instead of just beating your high-score...

Cool - It's always great seeing this one pop up on these lists! You're welcome, too!
I can say with 100% certainty that this is the best gameboard ever created. It doesn't have any of the fancy artwork that you see on most boards, but what is there is a marvel of functionality. 99% of what's on the board means something and is relevant to playing the game somehow. Then you add the fact that every site shown on it represents some actual object that's buzzing around our solar system. I've owned the game for about three years now and still love looking at that thing.
Look closely and you can find a few Easter Eggs too. For example, in the upper left corner there's a space marked "Heliopause", and right next to it is [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voyager_1]a tiny silver object[/url]. I can't recall if it's on the Colonization board or not, but on the Poster Map version at least there's also a peculiar object in orbit of Europa.
Even if you never get into most of the extra Colonization stuff (Bernals, Colonists, GW/TW Thrusters, Futures, etc.) and just stick to the Basic or Expanded game, having that extra half to the board really opens things up. You get a ton of new sites to develop, and gain new access routes to the tried-and-true sites already on the original board - especially if you add the slingshot rule to the basic game [i](there's no reason to ever leave out even with first-time players)[/i].
The A&C rules are much better for learning the learning the game from scratch than the original set that came in the box, although I actually prefer the original. To me it's laid out much more logically, and it's far better as a reference document when you need to look up specific rules.

I tend to order any Sierra Madre game right when it comes out, as they tend to have really small print runs with really long gaps between reprints. Though it's criminal what some people charge for copies of this game.
Mmmm, two fried eggs, over easy, please, with 3 strips of bacon, and...WAIT, THAT'S A GAME BOARD?!? :surprise:
OOOO, looks like the Vassal mod has the Colonization expansion with it. I'm terrible learning games through Vassal, though this might be worth it (though if anyone's looking to teach...)

I have the large poster map for HF (got it as a gift from a GeekBud) and absolutely love it.
HF has quite an intimidation factor attached to it, so I will be rather curious to see what the 3rd edition has to offer.
As it stands, HF has one of the best support groups of any title here on BGG (and that includes Kyle, whose passion for the game is contagious and he has personally enhanced my enjoyment of the game).

That is wild. As much as I would love to learn a complex and highly rewarding simulation, I'll look forward to the inevitable card game version of this, since that seems to be the trend that [company=101][/company] is following.

What annoys me with this game is that it's a pretty middle-weight game at heart. In fact, the core is much simpler than many Euro games that are popular. The art design and rule text, however, seem to go out of their way to make the game feel ten times more complicated than it really is.
I tried to learn this game and Dungeon Lords at the same time and it was interesting to compare them. In a many ways, Dungeon Lords is more complicated but has a very well-done art design that gives the players what is needed to understand and flow with the game. The card design still makes me dizzy in High Frontier.
There is another 20% of the factor that there exists too many rule exceptions and overwrought systems in High Frontier, especially with the Colonization modules, such that it becomes hard to keep the rules in my head. The A&C ruleset of the Advanced game, however, is pretty solid and, again, if it had nicer designed components designed by someone who realized this was a 'game' and not 'real life,' would be much better.

item.body: Month 2 playing this. Participating in the challenge. Having fun learning it.

Started the [b]Jovian Wars Prelude[/b] campaign last night with the 51st. I gave the [b]Deadly Strike[/b] talent to my shotgunner.
[b]Mission 1 - S002[/b] Mission 1 turned out to be Surface 002, the search and rescue of four scientists from Jovian III. Intel indicated [b]Mercenary Forces[/b] on the surface. But our biggest fear were the native Sand Worms. I selected the Shotgunner, C/C unit, Fire Team Alpha, Fire Team Bravo, and the Explorer specialist. We'd also be using the Pilium ATV to cover the vast distances on the surface. I used a full 110 squad points and all 8 allowed resources but chose not to use any Strategic Options in hopes of generating an extra VP if successful.
Things got off to a slow start. We had a hard time making good time on the planet's surface. In retrospect, when many nodes require a skill check that only one unit can accomplish (such as Pilot by the Pilium ATV), it is a good idea to invest in a lot of intelligence resources. I made a dash for the two locations where scientists were located near or in Cave Complex C. Unfortunately I only found two instead of all four. So I had to back track in a hurry toward Cave Complex B. However, I ran out of time 1-2 turns short of reaching then next scientist's location. Next time, bring more [b]intel[/b]!
During the course of this mission my squad eliminated three Sand Worms and a small patrol of Mercenary Forces (2 soldiers and 1 sergeant).
Result: [b]Failure[/b] VP Earned: [b]-1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: -1 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 2 - S004[/b] Mission 2 found us assigned to destroy an enemy base on an asteroid called New Phobos. The base had recently been taken from us. The brass decided that it was best if no one owned it. To do so we needed to infiltrate an automated Drone defense force and find access through one of two possibly blocked entrances. Our target was the Engine room fuel supply, which when crippled, would explode and cause a huge crater in the asteroid. Intel showed the base was protected by a force of [b]Mutants[/b]. The Squad Leader took Zero G Team Alpha, Zero G Team Bravo, our Sniper, Fire Team Alpha, an Engineer, and a Technician.
The mission ran smooth. After disabling a Drone and entering the base as hoped through Entrance A we ran into a small Mutant patrol in the computer room. Fire combat was brisk and went in our favor. We took some wounds but put down the enemy without suffering any incapacitated troops. Our next and last encounter with the Mutants was after we had breached the Security Door guarding access to the Engine Room. We were able to ambush a small section of Mutants. Two were killed and one wounded before we suffered any return fire. Once the last was neutralized we gained access easily into the Engine Room. Fortunately no hostiles were defending the room. Shortly after that New Phobos had a new crater and a new orbit. Any mutants that survived the blast were doomed to enjoy a lonely and cold death as life support systems failed and zero degrees Kelvin approached.
Result: [b]Success[/b] VP Earned: [b]+6 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +5 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 3 - H003[/b] Our 3rd Mission put us in a damn Hive system where an enemy base was thought to be located. These places are always ugly; I don't think any of us secretly thought we would make it out alive and knock out our objective. We needed to locate the enemy HQ and perforate the honchos inside with holes. The assault team was composed of the Squad Leader, Fire Team Alpha, the Heavy Weapons Team, our Sniper, Assault Team Alpha, and a Demolitionist. The Cybers, a robotic force with some great defensive systems, was holding the unfriendly turf.
There's not much to say about this. Not much good, anyway, At least we all made it out. We made a bee line for the location we suspected might contain the HQ. Unfortunately that was empty. Along the way we eliminated a group of Drones and got sprayed by some nasty Toxic goo. We had to back track to get to the next target location. Unfortunately we were hit by a couple of Cyber patrols. One of them got the jump on us. Assualt Team Alpha went down and nearly everyone else came out of the fight with a few more holes and burns than they had going in. Clinging to life and carrying Assault Team Alpha on our backs. We were able to make our insertion point and make a timely withdrawal. Mission failed but squad preserved. Assault Team Alpha made it, too. They're down for a bit in sick bay but will be back with us soon. In the meantime, we're still waiting to hear whether we'll be reattempting the assault or writing this one off. We just lost the element of surprise.
Result: [b]Abort[/b] VP Earned: [b]+1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +6 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 3 - H003 Reattempt[/b] Command decided we had to go back in and make another attempt on that enemy HQ in the Hive. This time we didn't make it as far as the first time. We knew they would be expecting us (Nullified the scenario specific special rule describing the enemy being unaware and made all draws on the Enemy Presence Table at +2, both house rules to add flavor). We were greeted at the entrance by 4 Drones. Took us some time to knock them out and we took some hits. The Medic patched up most of the holes before we advanced to the next node. There we found 3 Drones and 2 Guardians waiting for us. Fortunately we were able to execute a Withdrawal under cover of smoke and egress the installation. The Armor used by all Cyber units is particularly challenging. We need to figure out a way around it. So many of our hits do nothing.
Result: [b]Abort[/b] VP Earned: [b]-1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +5 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 4 - H002[/b] A report of abducted civilians flung us back into another Hive, this time against Mutant forces. Intel said the civilians were going to be used for biological weapons testing. Our goal was to extract them alive. The Hive was large. All intel showed the civilians' location to be on the far side of our entry point. We pushed our way in and found a likely spot for the civilians to be penned up on a dead end. Unfortunately it was vacant. At least halfway into our allotted time, we could play it safe and head for the entry point to abort or head for one of two remaining spots likely to hold the civilians. We headed for the easiest spot to navigate to. With only minutes to spare we made entry into the holding facility and took down the captors while taking quite a few hits ourselves. Unfortunately the civilians had already been hit. Looks like we were only a few hours too late to save them. Before making our escape we fired their remains and brought the ceiling down on them. Hopefully denying the enemy any use of their experiments.
Result: [b]Success[/b] VP Earned: [b]+4 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +9 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 5 - S007[/b] Brass had determined the location of a hideout on Xargon IV used by those wacko but insanely deadly suicide cultists who followed The Dark God. They'd been wreaking havoc on several civilian worlds and space stations in the area and the brass wanted on the ground confirmation that they and their hideout had been sterilized. So we went in. But we didn't make it very far. We were hit hard in both of the first two sectors we passed into. Our Pilium ATV was annihilated by a couple suicide Cultists; we were lucky enough to make an emergency exit at the last minute. Not so the gunner and driver. After mopping the remaining few Cultists up we got hit hard in the next zone. By hit hard I mean that my entire squad was down once the last Cultist had blown himself up. They still showed signs of life. I called a Rapid Intervention Team to recover them while I headed back to our extraction point. Fire Team Bravo will need a couple weeks in Rehab before they can get back in it. The Sniper and Shotgunner got lucky and made out pretty well. Fire Team Alpha and the Medic...well, we'll miss them.
Result: [b]Abort[/b] VP Earned: [b]+1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +10 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 6 - S008[/b] We lost a communication relay hidden within an asteroid belt to an enemy attack. Time to go reestablish commo! We inserted with our Zero G Teams and the Shotgunner. We were assisted by a Technician who we needed to help us navigate the technical aspects of this operation. The enemy must have known we were coming because they hit us unexpectedly hard. We were attacked by Flesh Eaters in 7 of the 9 zones we maneuvered through. We made good time but they kept hitting us. As wounds started to mount and supplies began to run low a feeling of desperation set it. At the first power station our technician could only power up one of the two power couplings. We were hoping he'd be able to get both couplings powered up at the nearby station, otherwise it would necessitate another journey to the furthest power station. The way we were getting hit it looked like we'd all be sucking vacuum if that was necessary. Fortunately we got lucky and eliminated the forces holding the second station and our technician got both of the couplings powered up. It took tenacity to blast through 23 Flesh Eaters to find success, but this victory they couldn't take away from us!
Result: [b]Success[/b] VP Earned: [b]+8 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +18 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 7 - S005[/b] A craft on some kind of black ops mission when down. We were tasked with recovering the radio and a cache of supplies that were believed to have survived the crash. We went in light against the Mutant forces reported to be on the surface. This was a bad idea. Immediately after setting foot on the ground we were hit by a strong Mutant patrol. We took stiff casualties and several of our troops were incapacitated. We evacuated with nothing to show for our efforts. Fortunately everyone made it out alive. We took one straight to the jaw.
Result: [b]Abort[/b] VP Earned: [b]+1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +19 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 7 - S005 Reattempt[/b] Apparently what went down on that ship was important so they told us to get back at it. We were still pretty light going in the second time. Probably a bad decision but resources were getting scarce and were needed for multiple efforts. This time we made it just shy of our first objective. We had made it through three hairy engagements prior to running into this fourth group, comprised of only one Mutant who happened to be accompanied by an Abomination. Already low on resources we fought this one by the skin of our teeth. When it was over both the enemies were dead but the squad had lost nearly all of its combat effectiveness. We evacuated once again from this damned planet. Despair had set in. We weren't doing so hot and the big picture didn't look good.
Result: [b]Abort[/b] VP Earned: [b]-1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +18 VP[/b]
[b]Mission 8 - H006[/b] We were getting ready to pull back. The war was not going well and the brass was hoping some consolidation and reorganization would help. Just before we can ship out to somewhere relatively safer they catch wind of another enemy HQ far beneath the surface of some crap-hole planet. The Followers of the Dark God were holding it. Guess who gets to go in? It was a suicide mission - we told that to each other anyway. No one outside our company was interested in hearing about it. We were right. After making our initial entry we were immediately hit by an Acolyte and four Cultists in a Pitch Black sector. We entered Melee combat abruptly. We all had decent cover and tried to lay adequate fire to keep them from maneuvering. No luck. Or rather, no light. Three of them sprinted forward in the pitch black, dancing nearly unseen between our fire. They detonated suicide vests. None of us remember anything after that. Our Rapid Intervention Team was waiting just the other side of the entry point and came hot. They managed to pull us out of there just before more explosions brought the ceiling down. Somehow we all survived. At least until the next suicide run they put us on.
Result: [b]Failure[/b] VP Earned: [b]-1 VP[/b] [b]Running Score: +17 VP[/b]
[b]Campaign Results: DEFEAT[/b]
[geekurl=/plays/thing/66781?userid=121622]Ryan's Plays of Space Infantry[/geekurl] - More details about this campaign. [listitem=3663209]Ryan's 2015 Solitaire Gaming Challenge - Space Infantry[/listitem]
item.comment: Awesome. I need to get in to this again. I have the expansion now too!

I'm getting my butt kicked. Fortunately I haven't lost any troops yet, but that failure on Mission 1 is smarting still. Had it not been so long since my last play I would have done a couple things differently and attempted to abort the mission instead of desperately trying to succeed on a Hail Mary.
My initial impressions of the best way to play everything about this game seem to be pretty far off. From assigning talents to determining what traits specific units improve with accumulated XP to mission planning; success is proving to be a formidable challenge.
It is fun try to figure out a way to defeat the randomly determined enemies I'm facing on very different mission maps. Fun until I realize that I planned poorly! Hive missions are tough. Ugh.

The outcome of this campaign isn't looking like something to be proud of currently.
The missions leave me both enjoying them and feeling frustrated. The game is difficult. I also haven't figured out how best to approach the missions so as to minimize my odds at failure. My early impression regarding the proper implementation of my assets was faulty and I don't know if I can recover. It makes it a bit harder to go on when I don't think I can make it work. I've got some ideas but will have to wait for a new campaign to see if they work.
The other problem I have is that some of the enemies are so difficult that I don't see how it's possible to succeed against them. I've already eliminated three enemy groups from play because I don't want to play against them knowing it will be for naught.

[q="Ryanmobile"] The other problem I have is that some of the enemies are so difficult that I don't see how it's possible to succeed against them. I've already eliminated three enemy groups from play because I don't want to play against them knowing it will be for naught.[/q]
I read a comment by the designer about facing one of the harder enemies, that they are designed for a specific strategy-using smoke bombs or something to cause them to become a melee opponent I think it was-in order to make them easier to beat. I guess part of the game is divining those little tricks. Not having played but once or twice I am not really expert enough to say if that is so or not.

I think I read the same thing Dave.
What I'm struggling with right now is that my ineptitude (based solely on being inexperienced with this game, I hope) has put me in a bad place late into the campaign. As the Alert level rises the game does indeed get tougher. Having more failures than successes at this point has stunted the growth (via XP points) of my squad and made them less likely to handle even the gentler combinations of mission and enemy.
Toss in a real monster like the Dark Roots or the new enemies in the expansion (Beast Masters and Cthonians) and some missions look all but hopeless.
I've got a better feel for how to proceed next time. I hope the game doesn't beat the spirit out of me because I'd really like to play the same campaign again with a different approach.
I think there's far more strategy to this game than meets the eye.

Let's be brutal : we knew it would end like this for a some time....
Even if I don't have the game and surely missed some meaningful details, I had a lot of pleasure to read your analysis. Thank you so much Ryan for this campaign by episodes. Loved to follow it!

Glad you enjoyed it Koinsky. Hearing comments like that make all the typing feel more worthwhile and rewarding.
The campaign was a strange mix of fun and occasional accomplishment with frustration. This game is hard. I've played 17 missions total now and feel as if I have only a small piece of the comprehension necessary to play well. Frustration aside, I am looking forward to playing another campaign soon to capitalize on my experience so far.
Segueing to another thought now... It has been nice to focus on just one game. Usually I play a bit then like a butterfly alight to a new branch to see what's there, continuously flitting about for only short duration stops wherever I land. I hope to transition back and forth between Space Infantry and Silent War for a bit to gain a deeper understanding for each.
Focusing on two for the time being is much more attractive than playing ten different games once each. Part of my new angle of attack for solo gaming in 2015: [geeklist=185155][/geeklist]

A good read Ryan, thanks for writing that up. I really enjoy about 90% of this game, and would love to get it back to the table. I started a campaign and was writing up missions here, but only got through 3 or so (all losses I think) before I "flitted" off to something else.
The game has some really great mechanics (some of which I may even "adopt" for something of my own), but every time I think about playing it I remember all the chit pulling and decide not to.

I decided that I really like the chit pulling over die rolling. I used the die rolling variant and decided it took too long/was too clunky compared to drawing chits.
The biggest impediment I feel toward playing is the impending sense of doom from a mission that seems nigh impossible. I don't like going to the work of setting up and playing a game when I know there's not much I can do to win.
Hopefully, I'll be able to minimize that occurrence in the future with more skillful play.
I'm glad the game is 90% working out for you, Jack. If I remember correctly an early perspective of mine may have had a bit to do with that...

item.body:
As mentioned [listitem=3710246]way back at the beginning of this list[/listitem], this was my Origin game. Technically I didn't even play it solo that time, but it was one of my goals for the month and it did get played, just with other, non-robot opponents. ---------------------------------
[b]Solo Play Brazil map 2 Robots:[/b]
[bgcolor=purple][color=white][b]Purple Robot[/b] 1) Early Choice For All [/color][/bgcolor] [color=red][size=7][i](The rules say to leave this piece out with two or more Robots, but I didn't notice that until after starting and it still seemed to work okay as-is.)[/i][/size][/color] [bgcolor=purple][color=white]2) Highest Number; Max Bid=Min+Cities 3) All 4) 1:1, 2:2, 3:3 5) Always Last[/color][/bgcolor]
[bgcolor=green][color=white][b]Green Robot[/b] 1) Player's Choice 2) First For Minimum 3) Normal 4) Only Supplied 5) All Cities Cost 10[/color][/bgcolor]
I hadn't played this in ages, so it was long overdue for another trip to the table.
[floatright][imageid=2410814][/floatright]Coal was a very scarce resource on this map, so right away I tried to push both of the robots into buying the inefficient coal plants so they'd be competing directly with each other for a dwindling supply. Meanwhile, I went for the inexpensive oil and managed to grab both of the early wind plants. Purple was effectively shut down early, but Green's slow and steady approach proved a bit tougher to crack. It pulled ahead briefly in number of cities and cash on hand, but with it invested heavily in coal and BioGas [i](thematic replacement for garbage on this board)[/i] it was only a matter of time before it came crashing back down when the supplies dried up.
Two turns later the coal and biogas were gone and both Robots were floundering; Purple kept spending money on resources it didn't really need so it couldn't afford to expand, which took away just enough that it prevented Green from running (and building) to full capacity. At the same time I used my wind-assisted nuclear plant to expand rapidly and push the game into Step 2, with the endgame within easy reach. Two turns later I was able to build up to 17 cities and could power 15 for the win; Green had 11 cities but had no power at all; Purple had 8 cities with surplus power.
Resource deprivation proved to be the winning play with this set of robots. A human would have gone away from coal and biogas long before they dried up, but these robots aren't programmed to feel pain.
----------------------------------
[thing=2651][/thing] :thumbsup: One of the best "Pure Euro" and Economic games ever created. Period. :thumbsup: Loads of expansion maps and promo items to add tons of variety and replayability.
:thumbsup::thumbsdown: Virtually no luck involved.
:thumbsdown: No solo option in the box, and little in the way of variants aside from doing it multiplayer solo. :thumbsdown: Tends to get "mathy", so beware of AP! :thumbsdown: The theme is kind of boring (but at least it's unique!)
----------------- [thing=108667][/thing] :thumbsup: Solo Option!!! :thumbsup: Puts up a pretty decent challenge if you use at least two or three Robots
:thumbsup::thumbsdown: The Robots cheat. [i](Each gets a special ability that gives it an advantage, like extra starting money, discounted buildings, rebates on their bids, etc.)[/i]
:thumbsdown: Not actually designed for solo, so there's a little bit of weirdness with some of the abilities. Some minor modifications are required. :thumbsdown: Sometimes the Robots make really dumb "decisions" that can be exploited.
item.comment: Nice write up Kyle, I picked up the Robots a long time ago with an eye on solo play but never got around to it. I did put it on my goals list and this has tempted me to break it out sooner than later... Power Grid is definitely one game in my collection that doesn't get out nearly enough.
Gonna use the SoloPlay rules, but thought I'd use the bots to help learn the game.

[q="klkitchens"]Gonna use the SoloPlay rules, but thought I'd use the bots to help learn the game.[/q]How well do those play compared to the standard game?
I haven't looked into the SoloPlay rules for PG, but from what I've seen of those variants for [i]other[/i] games so much gets added or changed that it ends up feeling like you're playing a completely different game. That's fine when the only other alternative is not playing the game it at all, but it's pretty far away from my preference.
The Robots work really well for solo, despite their issues, because you're still playing plain old Power Grid. All they're really doing is simulating opponents in the most direct way possible, but the rules to the game itself are exactly the same as normal.

I like the SoloPlay rules quite a bit actually. The idea is that the AI helps to block where you can expand, and the utilization of resources is also quite good. The rules are easy to implement, and IMO doesn't deviate too much from fundamental gameplay.
I just picked up the robots. This game has sat unplayed on my shelf for a year now. I'll be learning both the robots and soloplay rules.

item.body:
[b]February, 11th[/b]
[i]First play of this one as soon as it arrived at my doorstep.[/i]
I randomly dealt one(!) hero, an epic foe and the outer regions. Else I played the easy variant, in order to get the rules down. After my play I realized that I was supposed to use two heroes ...
My hero was the Paladin and the epic foe was the Demon Lord. The Paladin did pretty well, but she was lucky that the single dire enemy showed up only in the last turn before the epic foe hit the stage. So I guess this game was the "super easy" variant. When the Demon Lord arrived all the outer regions were in pretty good shape and the Capital City hadn't received any damage so far. So the Paladin could concentrate on taking out her epic foe, letting everything else go up in flames.
Here's a photograph of the game state at the end of the game: [imageid=2411199]
:thumbsup: small "pick your fights"-game :thumbsdown: The rulebook is not very well structured (at least for my mind). :thumbsdown: Though the flame tokens are nice, they are bit small for my clumsy fingers.
Edit: Does anybody know why the picture shows right side up on my computer but upside down on BGG?
[i]Second play the same day:[/i] This time Cleric and Sorcerer defended against The Ancient. Still the easy variant, but the dire enemy showed up early in the game this time. However, the heroes managed to keep the outer regions in good shape until the epic foe arrived. Concentrating all forces on The Ancient won me the game, again.
[imageid=2418558]

Haha, I thought that was a sly reference to my Tiny Epic Defenders image a couple of pages back!

item.body:
Set this up a few days ago and took a turn here and there. Had a pretty easy go of it, mostly. My primary target (which was the Dwarf Warrior) only managed to take 3 wounds, one of which was intentional so he could counterattack and take out Greenknee (the bastard).
I got really lucky with the Damsel quest/event, as the encounter there was pretty easy and I was able to rescue her without incident.
I really enjoyed my time with this, and the game flowed very well this time. There weren't a ton of special cases, but after playing this a few times (second recorded play after my first few aborted attempts), I think I've got a somewhat decent handle on the rules.
Quick question for those who have played:
Normally, no matter how much I lose by during the defense stage, I only put one wound on the primary target (unless it's a poison attack, or some other special type), right? Even if I choose to not defend at all?
[b]Edit[/b]
Sometimes the shuffle gods giveth, and sometimes they taketh away.
Setup a second game using the standard 80 card decks. Semirandomized both the dungeon deck and the crawler deck (mostly even amounts of each type of card, made sure there were at least 30 creatures, then grabbed another 15 cards from the starter deck) using the mines expansion. Crawler deck consists of roughly equal numbers of each type of card, with a few favorites tossed in.

item.body:
Picked up this pretty little two-player game today to play with my girlfriend. Quick to play, easy to teach but quite a bit of strategic depth and replayability. Couldn't wait for her to get home so I came up with a quick and dirty "beat your score" solo variant that seems to work quite well.
[imageid=2411763 medium]
[imageid=2411765 medium]
Game is a 3x3 grid of tiles, each tile with a set number of cattle on it and one randomized token. Cattle are 4 different colours and they are distributed randomly on the board. Players are represented by a two-sided token, each player represented on one side of it. Each turn the current player takes all of the cattle of one single colour off their tile, then moves the player token a number of orthogonal spaces equal to the number of cattle taken and flips the player token to the other players side. You cannot move the player token to a space with no cattle. Then the next player goes. If you take the last cattle off a square, you also take the token (which can have varying effects, good and bad). Game ends if a player is forced to take the sheriff tile (they lose), one player gets all 9 cattle of one colour (they win), or there is no legal move left. If there is no legal move left, the players take score, high score wins.
Here is an example of me with no legal move left (just picked up one cattle):
[imageid=2411769 medium]
The 3x3 grid is arranged randomly each time, there are 18 tokens but only 9 are used in each game, and the cattle colours are distributed randomly too. Seems like a ton of replayability for such a small game.
Scoring is interesting, you get $100 x (remaining cattle) for each cattle of any given colour you have (i.e. if you have 3 black in your collection and 4 black remain on the board you score 3 x (4 x $100) or $1200. Plus you add any gold tokens collected.
Here is my solo variant (posted [thread=1318929]here[/thread] for easy linkage):
[size=18][b]Longhorn solo variant [/b][/size] 1 - Set up the board as per regular instructions.
2 - Play as one character only.
3 - All tokens have the standard effect except [i]Extra Turn[/i] and [i]Ambush[/i] tokens will have no impact on play. If you clear a space with an [i]Extra Turn[/i] or [i]Ambush[/i] token, simply remove it from play.
4 - Gathering all 9 of one colour cattle will [b]not[/b] win the game.
5 - Take each turn as a single player. Stockpile all cattle and tokens acquired in one pool.
6 - If arrested by Sheriff, game is lost.
7 - Once you can no longer make a legal move, tally your score as per normal instructions.
8 - Try and beat your high score.
My scores so far:
[b]Game 1[/b] - 6000 [b]Game 2[/b] - 8300 [b]Game 3[/b] - 5100 [b]Game 4[/b] - 8100
In the solo variant you are attempting to get 4 or 5 of each colour cattle for maximum score, while avoiding the sheriff (who will only show up 50% of the time) and trying to create an endgame position before you are forced to take too many cattle.
:thumbsup: Gorgeous components :thumbsup: Cheap (I picked it up for $15) :thumbsup: Quick to set-up and play but lots of thinking involved :thumbsup: Cowboys! :thumbsdown: Not designed for solo play out of the box. Not sure how much longevity my solo variant will have (but optimistic). :thumbsdown: I imagine it will be more interesting to play 2P (but haven't tried it that way yet).
[b]Update Feb. 14: [/b] Finally played this two player with my girlfriend and it has remarkable strategic depth for such a tiny footprint/ruleset. Will be trying it out again with my solo variant a few times before I can recommend it as a solo only game, but definitely worth it at the price as a quick but deep 2-player filler game.

It is a fun game to play. I didn't fell like I need to completely abstract the Empire. I think there was one option that I ended up rolling a die to decide.

item.comment:
Hmm...there are definitely ways to improve the game if you decided to play again. It is pretty easy to win, depending on the ancient one you're fighting, which is the first problem. I play that you must combat the ancient one AFTER collecting the Elder Signs needed to win, but you only need to damage it equal to the number of doom tokens on the track at that time. If it awakens, tough cookies--that's an instant loss.
The game also becomes harder/more interesting when playing with more investigators with different abilities to call on, adding some strategy to which adventures to assign each character to. If an investigator dies while playing solo, you should remove that character from the game instead of drawing a new one, and if all investigators die, you lose. (This is how the app handles it.)
The game really opens up as you become more familiar with it and you start to more deeply consider the rewards/penalties of the adventures. It's still just "okay" for me, but I like it enough that I've got the newest expansion on its way.
