item.body:
The quickest game of this I have ever played.
I played with 2 characters - Dispatcher and Researcher. I only had 4 epidemic cards in the deck. The game lasted 10 turns (5 rounds) and about 15 minutes.
The initial cities drawn were either in the middle of nowhere or, in the case of the triple marker cities, directly next to each other. At this point I knew the game was going to be tough as it would take a few turns just to get to the cities.
The starting player cards were very good (5 yellows between the players and an event card). In retrospect it was probably a bad set of cards as the Researcher spend their first turn offloading their yellow cards to the Dispatcher rather than trying to get to the infected cities. The mistake was exacerbated by drawing an epidemic card on the first turn. The infected city was next to the other ones that also had 3 markers and one of those cities was drawn for the intensify action. This led to a double outbreak and only 4 remaining black markers.
The next few rounds were just firefighting but another outbreak did occur with a different colour city. There were then 2 consecutive turns with outbreaks before drawing a second epidemic card. I thought it was game over at that point but the cards were having too much fun toying with me so they gave me some nice cities for that draw. Finally, on turn 10, I drew Jakarta which already had 3 markers. This spread the infection to Sidney which also had 3 markers and caused the last outbreak leading to me losing.
Had Jakarta not had 3 markers I would have run out of black markers on the next city draw.
[ImageID=2412909 large] [ImageID=2412915 large]
[i][b]Edit 13/2 - Second Play[/b][/i] This time I chose Operations Expert and Scientist for my characters. The game lasted twice as long (30 minutes) but still used just 4 Epidemic cards. I won the game with 3 turns left before the player deck ran out but could have ended it 2 turns earlier had I not have eradicated the blue disease.
This time the initial infected cities were much better positioned and no 2 critical cities (i.e. already had 3 markers) were next to each other. The scientist managed to cure blue early on but the infected cities were spread out. The Operations Expert cleared out the black markers and drew enough black city cards to cure and eradicate on his next turn. The red markers were left to spread and led to 4 outbreaks while the yellow cities had a further 2 outbreaks. The yellow disease was the last one to be cured but the red was the closest to costing me the game (only 4 markers left).
[i][b]Edit 14/2 - Third Play[/b][/i] I decided to play with 2 characters I hadn't used together before - Medic and Quarantine Specialist. The game seemed easy as both of these characters are very strong if used correctly but I only won the game on the very last turn. There were only 2 outbreaks and they both came from drawing the Infect card a second time for the Intensify stage.
I managed to cure each disease in the order they are printed on the board (not that there are any bonus points for this).
:thumbsup: - Each game is slightly different and a challenge. :thumbsdown: - Sometimes the draw of the city cards can make even a game with the easiest settings really difficult. :thumbsdown: - I lost :cry:

item.body:
I'm trying to use Vassal to play some "slower and longer" games. I usually don't have the stomach to play any boardgames for any length of time while sitting at a computer, but doing 1 turn at a time is certainly feasible and fun, (I've been playing in a 6 player game of Arkham Horror for months now) and it turns out this is the perfect game to be played on Vassel.
The board isn't huge, so you don't find yourself scrolling all around trying to see everything. Most of the "noise" of the other cards on the table are in other windows that you can close so usually you're just looking at your hand and the board (and occasionally your player mat to see your army and your mana stones). And staring at the screen blankly for 10 minutes is frustrating in other games, but is kind of expected in this one!
So I'm in day 3 of the solo conquest, and I'm doing rather poorly. I'm Tovak at level 4. I've got my army of 2 with a nice skill of being able to heal one or untap one (which I sadly already had to use). I only just now found the first (Red) city, but I'm staring at it through the middle of two Draconians. I wouldn't be too worried, but I just spent my big battle cards clearing a spawning ground for a sweet artifact (Forget what it's called...something like the golden mana orb). Looks like I'll have to wait until the last night to do much, but I'm hedged in by mountains, so I'm not sure to do with what's left of the day. A tough spot to be in...especially when I took down a Keep on my second turn of the game!
[b]Edit 2-16-15[/b] Well, I ended up doubling back and exploring another tile and revealing the Blue city. I also revealed some dragons I could take, so BAM, down they went and up a level I go. Got a nice skill to get a badass unit, so I picked up some fire golems at my keep and headed back to the red city. I took down more dragons but that used my last cards and the night was over. With my ability to untap a unit and the deck I had, if I had another morning I probably would have been able to take both cities, but I'm still new at this game (only 5 or so plays), so I'll take it.
Final score: 60.
:thumbsup: Epically big and engaging. :thumbsdown: Epically frustrating when you find yourself in a pinch :thumbsdown: You read the word "epic" far too often in reviews.

And I made the fatal mistake of starting with ADP. Just sold it recently because it was waaay too much and too subtle for me. I'm not put off of COIN completely, but the reason I got ADP was because I liked the theme, and I'm not as interested in the others (though FitL is starting to look better).
Funny enough, I did play one 3 player game of it, and the AA ended up winning on the third Prop card. The other two wanted to kill me for bringing a game that was smarter than the three of us combined.

[q="CthulhuKid"][q="often"]I don't like the sudden death rules in ADP's solo game. [/q]
And I made the fatal mistake of starting with ADP. Just sold it recently because it was waaay too much and too subtle for me. I'm not put off of COIN completely, but the reason I got ADP was because I liked the theme, and I'm not as interested in the others (though FitL is starting to look better).
Funny enough, I did play one 3 player game of it, and the AA ended up winning on the third Prop card. The other two wanted to kill me for bringing a game that was smarter than the three of us combined.
Live and learn. The reviews said don't start with ADP, start with AA or CL. My advice: Listen to them.[/q]
It really is true. Like you say, there's a lot of subtly to playing the game. Too many people jump out to a big lead and get bashed, then mistakenly call the game a "bash the leader" game. There's so much counterplay and subtly to your actions. You need to make temporary alliances with other players knowing they're going to turn on you when it's to their advantage.
You have to also advance you cause while not appearing to be a threat, so you can turn and take a turn or two to get ahead to the point that no one can do anything about it in time. Sometimes you even set someone else if as a threat so you can take advantage of the lack of focus on you.
The COIN games are brilliant. ADP is my favorite. I love the interactions between the four factions. It's not quite as forced as FitL (though that's not a bad thing), and offers greater strategic depth than Cuba Libre and Andean Abyss.
The reason people suggest starting with Cuba Libre is because it's a smaller map, with smaller pieces. There's still a lot of options and choices. And decisions. But the decision tree is smaller as the map is very small and the time between the prop rounds is also shorter. It's a knife fight in a phone booth.
Also. Vassal....

I don't know of one competitive multiplayer that isn't a "hop on the top." In the COIN series, the penalties for not stopping a runaway are more dire. Likewise, the penalties for over prosecution of the leader are higher. One absolutely can not afford to blow one faction out of the game until the last campaign. Subtle shifts in the balance between factions mean a lot because the asymmetrical capabilities of the factions are required keep a lid on each other.
The first time that I played all the COIN series face to face was in a tournament. The experience with ADP was probably the least fulfilling of the group. I think that was probably because I played the Government and was on my second COIN game of the day. Of them all, ADP, which was the final, had the quality of trying to scratch your opponents with a knife when they were not looking while convincing them not take the knife away. AA and CL had more of a "lets you and him fight while I steal all your stuff" feel. I found it easier in AA and CL to push the other factions into a box with each other like I'd done with the bots in solitaire.

I feel the same way you do about ADP... Well, I agree with your assessment, but that's what draws me to it over the others!
I think the government is the least interesting faction to play, though.

[q="often"] Also. Vassal.... [/q]
Well, there is this fine GeekList [geeklist=187244]HERE[/geeklist] where you could get players for these games.
Just sayin'.
Heck, I'd even play ADP again even though I sold my set. I still have a pretty good grasp of most of the rules.

[q="often"]I feel the same way you do about ADP... Well, I agree with your assessment, but that's what draws me to it over the others!
I think the government is the least interesting faction to play, though. [/q]Didn't really have a choice for the final. I think it was between the Taliban and the Government. I had always lost with the Taliban with the bots on the long campaign game, so I chose the Government. I figured I could stick really close to the Coalition and at least pull out a second by dominating the other two factions. At some point, I was planning stab him in the back before he could surge out for the win or make it such that he couldn't get out. But, the last prop card flipped early before he could escape, and I won. Sometimes, it's better to be lucky than good.
But I do understand why you might think that Government is the least interesting faction. It's the only one where your ability to act is controlled by an another with dissimilar goals. You're not as independent as any of the other factions. The Coalition can drag you around, spend all your money, and limit your own freedom to act severely. I don't think the Coalition is as severely impacted by the lack of money. They still have the freedom to move and protect their gains while you can't do anything but play events, so you have to cooperate to some extent to stay competitive.
At least in Fire in the Lake, the amount the US can spend of the shared budget is limited. They can't completely spend the ARVN out of action.

Well. After finally learning how to play this [article=18296604]correctly[/article] (Two packs come from the draw pile! :whistle: ). I decided I'd break it out for my first "real" play. I was kind of nervous as to how I would do! I had grown confident in my veggie trading skills only to be shown that they were built on lies! Thankfully, it was only really one lie and now that that was fixed it did alter and slow my play (as one might guess).
So, I scored a 17.6. Which I am very proud of. Glad to see that most of the veggie trading skills were worth learning as they proved very useful in this "new" game.
I will say one thing about the "old" strategy (I like to call it my "variant"), I do like the advance planning that is required. If I'm taking two packs from the offer, I can really manipulate the offer and make more lengthy decisions and I find that to be fun. It's why I got absurdly high scores too, but it does offer an enjoyable in-game experience.

Still playing my way through the games I acquired with holiday cash and gift cards.
This time I've broken out SotM for a whirl.
Took Wraith, Ra and Legacy up against Baron Blade in Megalopolis.
I was able to take down the Baron but only Legacy was left and he only had 3 HP's left.
The final kill was actually made by the environmental card with the train/subway on the loose. The Baron had 5 HP and a Blade Battalion at full strength (5 HP) were the two targets with the highest HP during the environmental turn and therefore got run over and taken out. I actually thought it was sort of funny.
I thought Wraith and Ha were pretty decent damage dealers but I'm not sure I "grok" Legacy yet. He seems to be more of a supporting character that occasionally does damage. I don't remember him having any powers that do damage, just one shots.
Anyway I liked the game, especially how the environment is involved in it. I was lucky and by mid game had two 'Police Backup' cards in play so they kept plinking the Baron with 2 damage each turn.
[b]EDIT 2/17[/b] Finally playing my second game. Have Haka, Tempest and Bunker taking on Omnitron at the Mars Base.
This match is taking forever to finish. Bunker got down to 1 HP but the Meteor Storm came out and I took a few rounds under it's protection to use Tempest's Healing Power and Bunker's Maintenance Shed to heal.
The heroes have some decent stuff out but the environment keeps getting in the way (Meteor Storm, Red Dust, Self Destruct, etc), mores than in my first game.
I am liking the game and handling all the modifiers doesn't bother me like it bothers others so I guess I am lucky there.
I did get the app but it doesn't seem to immerse me into the game as much as using the physical cards.
Now I'm starting to look at the various expansions. Goodbye $$$

[size=24][b]ORIGIN STORY[/b][/size]
[b]What brought you here? Was it from a subscription, or did you find it on the front page or on a specific game page?[/b]
After getting back in to gaming at the end of 2013 and knowing it would be almost exclusively solo I spent ages looking at solo game posts here on BGG and other places. Watched some videos, etc. I came to this list a few times through google searches but I didn't really 'get it' back then and passed it over. Too many games being played. I just wanted a few recommendations of games to get.
After a few months of playing I came back here (I think I read about it somewhere else on the site) and read the posts properly. I then understood this was about sharing your experiences playing solo and I had been bursting to talk about mine but my wife, kids, family and friends weren't interested in how I had stormed a city or fought some genestealers.
I started writing some stuff and posting it. Some people seemed interested (at least it seemed that way) so I wrote some more and then got more and more involved. Now I can't go a day without checking in to this small corner of BGG. [b] What was the first game you posted? Do you still own it and/or play it?[/b]
It was Legends of Andor, way back in those ancient days of February 2014. I don't own it anymore. I have had a high turnover of games in my first year and half of solo gaming (lack of space has been a key driver for this) and this didn't click with me.
[b]Was there anything else notable about your first visit?[/b]
Not particularly. Within the first few days though of posting someone kindly helped pay for my first avatar. Basically, sums up the place. People do stuff for each other that is generous and surprising.
[b]Anything else you'd like to share about your first visit?[/b]
I had a really hard time finding the toilets, which could have been embarrassing.
[b]What keeps bringing you back?[/b]
It's the only place I really interact on the web and that's because of the people. Their interest in my gaming, my interest in theirs and the friendly nature of the place. You're all brilliant! [b] How much money have these lists cost you?[/b]
More than I expected but less than a second mortgage. Hopefully, I've calmed down a bit now. [b] If you haven't been back since your first visit, how are you even reading this?[/b]
My wallet wishes I wasn't.

item.body:
This game finally arrived from the big boat and I've played it solo 10 times so far (it is part of my 10X10 challenge).
(all at normal difficulty) Warrior + Cleric vs Demon Lord, Win Cleric + Bard vs Colossus, Win Ranger + Sorcerer vs Giant, Loss Druid + Warrior vs Kraken, Win Oracle + Sorcerer vs Dragon, Loss Commander + Cleric vs Dragon, Loss Warrior + Barbarian vs Giant, Loss Warrior + Bard vs Kraken, Win Commander + Cleric vs Colossus, Loss Ranger + Sorcerer vs Demon Lord, Loss
I like filler games. And co-op games. And solo-playable games. Every game has been on a razor's edge - the wins are barely, from-the-cusp-of-failure wins and the losses were soooo close. With my "likes" and with the very close sessions, I "should" enjoy this game more than I really do. I've pondered this and think it is the random player activation mechanic. Yes, it adds tension. But it also makes it difficult to co-op or plan ahead. Every one of the those games that were won, it was because the player activation cards came out early in the last round. Every game I lost was because the activation cards came out late. So, on the surface this should be an exciting session, but instead it feels a bit disappointing; it all comes down to how the cards are randomized on the last turn. I really "want" to like this game, but so far it has been lackluster.
:thumbsup: Quick setup and play, different character abilities and boss monsters mix up the challenge
:thumbsdown: Some decisions are obvious, randomized player turns feel lackluster, diminishes co-op elements
item.comment:
[q="barteus"]it all comes down to how the cards are randomized on the last turn.[/q] so far this has been my conclusion as well. On the other hand, it does take some thought to keep the game under control until then, and over the course of a game, some rounds will see activations in your favor and some against, so managing that could be considered part of the game.
I thought this would be a pandemic or defenders of the realm killer, but seems it will fall short.

But isn't this how almost every solo game plays? Once you implement the most effective strategy and play the odds, it usually comes down to cards you draw or dice rolls.
Maybe in a shorter, lighter game the element of luck with the cards is just more obvious?
I can see how this may spoil the game, if it's so obviously dependant on the card draw that it seems like simply tossing a coin for a win or lose.
I was thinking of getting this, after Kickstarting [thing=163967][/thing] and reading a few positive reviews; not so sure now.

[q="nickbolton"]But isn't this how almost every solo game plays? [/q]
True. And with a game of Pandemic, for example, if that one city card comes up, it can spell doom. If the wrong tile gets flooded in Forbidden Island, you can lose. Etc. When that happens with Pandemic or FI (or others), I feel like it was a great, close game. But, for me, it seems unsatisfying with TED.
I've been pondering the difference and I think it is the mechanic of the epic foe coming out at the end. You can't win the game until that tiggering event and once that happens, you have to neglect (to some degree) the defend/succor parts of the game, so it all comes to a head at once. You can't win (and seldom) lose before that, so I think the turn order at the very end seems more.. pronounced.. than in other games.

[q="Moe45673"][q="reverendunclebastard"]
As for music, I have a pretty extensive collection of early jazz, jugband music and tinpan alley/vaudeville stuff on vinyl that seems to work really well. Or I will break out some 12-tone stuff like Pierre Boulez which fits the non-euclidian creepy vibe of Lovecraft pretty well.[/q]
Rev, is this music considered "atonal"?[/q]
It is indeed atonal (atonal = not centered around a particular key). 12-tone music is composed around sequences of 12 tones instead of traditional keys. The pieces are centered around a phrase (or "tone row") that contains all 12 chromatic notes (but from any octave). Composition involves combinations of the tone row including inversion (reversing the direction of the intervals between notes), using the retrograde (reversing the phrase), transposition and layering/sequencing of versions of the original "tone row".
That reminds me of Prokoviev's Sarcasms.

I fumbled about with the tutorial, which embarrassingly took 2 sessions, because I made sure that I could get every rule correct and understand every move, and I didn't have the stamina to do it in one session.
Finally I get the game to a point where I think I'm ready to play...
[imageid=2414328 medium]
I manage to get through the deck, managing what I hope is a mistake free game (rules-wise) and draw the final historical event...which just so happened to be the last card.
I truly had no idea if I was doing well at the beginning of the game, but I began to sense that I was getting my butt kicked towards the end... Not knowing was a bit weird.
I followed the instructions for the final victory check, and realized that I finished in a Major Defeat.
Ouch.
However, I am glad it wasn't a victory. It would have felt like a shot on the game if I won without really knowing what I was doing. Unfortunately though, I'm not sure I learned too much in terms of strategy... but this game intrigues me enough that I can see it staying on the table for a few more plays...

item.body:
[b]UGH![/b]
Was on the final mission of the second scenario, when the villain decided to hide herself the second card from the bottom on the last location, so the Blessings Deck ended before my team could get to her.
:yuk: That a bad shuffle can make the whole night's quest pointless, always bums me out, for a game which I generally really enjoy.
Maybe, when this happens I'll remove one location on the next go through. I hate repeating quests just because the villains randomly land on the bottom.

As I predicted, the mystery game is eating up most of my gaming time. I pushed late into the night and had my first play of this very unusual game.
I tried the solo variant listed in the rulebook with Captain Brix Berkwix. I didn't use any particular setup--I modified the 2-player setup for 2 rows by adding 12-8-12-8 cards. I think for the "real" solo game, I'd want to use fewer cards to increase the challenge (tougher enemies and boss come sooner), but this was good as a learning game. To have the same number of rows as a multiplayer game, I'd need to do 8-6-8-6. I ended with 1 Energy left and had: Engine 1, Rotary Cage 2, Generator 2, Laser 1, and Shield 1. 17 Glory.
It's too early to call this one. On the one hand, I spent a large portion of the game trying to remember if I'd used my move yet this turn, looking up the different space thingies in the reference guide, and small things like that. That's not what I think of when I think of a scrolling space shooter! On the other hand, I got a lot more comfortable with the game toward the end, and I still have lots of different ways to try the game, including the unofficial cooperative variant, official solo scenarios, the smaller random deck I mentioned above, and oh yeah, multiplayer.

First SGoYT post...been lurking, thought I would throw something on the board!
[b]ORIGIN STORY[/b]
[b]What brought you here?[/b] I was responding to a prospective solo-gamer recommendation thread about games that I have enjoyed, and someone "hotlinked" this list. I followed, added to my "want list" and have since taken out a 2nd mortgage on my home and sold my youngest kid to fund my habit.
[b]What was the first game you posted?[/b] YES
[b]Do you still own it?[/b] Yes, I will never let this one go, as hard as it can be to find.
[b]Was there anything else notable about your first visit?[/b] I am setting up a solo run of [thing=121921][/thing] while typing this...well, not WHILE typing this, as I am not that coordinated.
[b]How much money have these lists cost you?[/b] My wallet has shed a tear in anticipation...looking at a couple of new acquisitions in the very near future.
[i][b]Now...about [thing=1608][/thing][/b][/i]
I am 43. If you can rewind the clock to the late elementary/early middle school days, hearken back to English class where we used to get the "Weekly Book Reader Club" order forms. If you graduated prior to 1990, I am sure you recall that getting these was the pinnacle of your day when it happened.
[imageid=2414887]
I would instantly scan the books to find one of those "Choose your own way" books...you know, you would read the first few pages, then get to the bottom where you had to choose: "If you would like to grab the controls of the smoking plane and attempt to fly it, turn to page 148, If you would rather jump from the plane with the makeshift parachute, turn to page 86." Inevitably, I would die a few times, but eventually find the right route through the narrative maze to "solve the book".
25 years later...
So I am playing excellent solo games like [thing=123955][/thing], [thing=62227][/thing], and [thing=121921][/thing]...but want something with a little more "narrative"...something that tells a story. Someone on a random "Hey, I would really like a great solo war game" mentioned [thing=1608][/thing] as one of the pinnacle solo games, way ahead of its' time in 1983. Why didn't I buy this as a budding gamer in the 80's? Because a friend and I decided to buy [thing=243][/thing], which was an adventure in its' own right.
So, I searched out this little gem, paid a fairly decent premium for it to ensure that all of the chits were accounted for, the maps were in perfect shape, etc. And once I learned the rules and began playing...fell in love. Mix the heavy narrative of a "Choose your own Way" story, with individual soldiers with varied skills that could potentially survive and level-up (feeds the RPG'er in my blood), SMART AI which react according to your movement, excellent fog of war mechanics, etc., excellent squad-based WWII combat, and I was hooked. So highly recommended if you can score yourself a copy.
:thumbsup::thumbsup: Immersion!!! In spades! :thumbsup: Fairly easy to read rules, which are implemented in layers over scenarios :thumbsup: A great user-community ready to answer questions in minutes! :thumbsdown: Somewhat hard to find, cost a fair amount to ensure completeness :thumbsdown: There's no reprint! :thumbsdown: Expansions are supposed to be fantastic, but are kind of hard to find, and may be cost-prohibitive to some people on a budget.

item.body:
Hello!
Okay, I finished the first test run for a randomized AI for this game. There are still some gaps and the AI is rather weak - which shouldn't be surprising, given that I am not really an experienced player of Dominant species. In the end, playing the arachnids, I won with 161 VP. The reptiles scores 124 VP while the mammals only reached 101 VP.
The basic idea for the AI seems to be fine, but the tables need some tuning and probably also a few more conditions. Each AI player needs 7 markers or cubes to show which sub table it has selected and which line it executes within the table. At the beginning of play, randomly select tables for the AIs.
As such, AP placement uses the following rules: If Domination and Initiative slots are vacant, roll 1d6: 1 - Initiative, 2-6 - Domination. If Domination slots are vacant, place an AP on Domination If all Domination slots are taken and that particular AI player has not picked a strategy for this round yet (which happens on its first turn where all Domination slots for that round are taken), roll 1d6 for a strategy. Move the cube on the strategy table next to the first line of the strategy. If the current line of the strategy makes sense (e.g. Protect Endangered Species only makes sense if there are potentially endangered species), execute it, otherwise go to the next line. Executing strategy lines usually results in consulting the tables below it, which also may change from round to round - a table that has not been used in a given round by a given AI player gets rolled on with a die that is larger than the number of tables available (so 1d6 would work for all tables except for Protect Endangered Species, for which I used 1d10 in the test run). Once a table is picked for a round, it is used like the strategy table, skipping things that would not work (like protecting an endangered species using abundance if there are no elements your animals can use available for abundance).
To mark which tables have been used, I put the cubes I use for markers on the tables in the top row of the selected table (where there are three squares). As stated above, during play, a die larger than the number of sub tables is used - if the result is higher than the highest number, the AI sticks to the sub table it used the last round. Sub tables are only rolled for when needed (that is, when a table is used for the first time in a given round).
When picking options, AIs will select the ones benefitting themselves directly the most. If that is not applicable, they will pick those that have the biggest impact on the board, and if there is no significant difference, those that will harm the human player the most.
For Dominance cards, one additional golden rule is that the AIs pick AP cards first; if several are available, they pick the one that they would otherwise not benefit from.
Well, that is the basic idea. Here is also the cheat sheet with the tables I used.
[ImageID=2415029]
I probably won't get around to experiment with Dominant Species for a while, so there won't be any progress in the near future from me. But maybe it can inspire people or give ideas for AI development.
Yours, Deathworks

item.body:
Libya 1984. Cut off.
Again I played with random squadron selection and drew two A10s, the F16 and all three A1s. Thanks to the additional 4 SO points I also felt that I could stretch to two scouts so I had a pretty strong looking squadron. I also randomised pilot experience (while still observing the one-up-one-down rule) and felt that I had a pretty good mix of skills.
The campaign played out like a bit of a dream. I was destroying every single battalion that I attacked and even splashed out on three SO points to call in a B52 to take down the always threatening enemy infantry formation. My aircraft did accumulate some damage along the way so I was flying some pretty beat up birds by the end. The campaign also took its toll on my pilots as their stress limits got pushed to the max.
The one downer came on day 3 when Gator (flying his Cobra) got killed by a pop-up helicopter. It was pretty galling because I had been taking a rather unnecessary risk at the time and I had not lost a pilot in any of my previous campaigns. I chose not to replace him or his aircraft because the Cut Off situation imposes a higher cost to do that and I figured I could cope without a third a Cobra. Had one of the Hogs gone down that would have been a rather different matter.
Going into the final day I only had one enemy battalion left (!) but it was a big nasty Command battalion bristling with every conceivable defence. With no other targets it was a pretty easy decision to throw my whole squadron against it but even then I had an uneasy feeling about it. Had I been feeling a bit more prudent I would probably have abandoned the mission but I figured that it is, after all, just a game. And I wanted to see what would happen.
As it was I chose to arm my aircraft with as many cluster bombs as I could manage. I had some good strike bonuses and with so many enemy to attack it seemed a certainty that there would be plenty of hexes with multiple targets. While this proved to be the case, I really didn't take enough stand off weapons to neutralise the AA threat early enough. Although I managed to steer clear of the worst of it my opening turns were really hairy but I managed to limit myself to light hits for the most part. This kept me flying but my pilots' stress levels were starting to reach their limits. Ultimately I just about managed to wrestle control of the situation and I bugged out as soon as I'd done enough to destroy the battalion. It had been a bruising final encounter but it was good to come through it without any further losses.
And so my campaign ended with every single battalion destroyed and with my final score comfortably in the 'great' bracket.
On reflection I do think the 4 SO bonus for random squadron selection is way too generous. I had thought the same after my last game and now I am sure of it. I think in future I am going to deny myself those bonus points because I will welcome the additional challenge, I think.
I've had TAL on the table for a month now so it is time to give something else a bit of attention. Still, it's been a fun few weeks and I will look forward to the next time it hits the table.

item.body:
Having played the official extra layouts for a 10x10 entry, I am now working thru the fan-made layouts.
[b][i]Atoll of Apprehension[/b][/i] - Navigator & Diver. Lost; Unclaimed Treasure Sank
...Flood Level was 4. Up till now things were going well, the Fire & Water treasures had been secured, but 1 Earth temple had sank. The Navigator held the tokens for the Earth treasure and was adjacent to the remaining Earth temple.
The Diver took his turn - nothing special. During the Flood phase, he drew the last 2 flood cards, the Earth temple plus one - reshuffled for the other 2... and re-drew the Earth temple again. [i]Unfortunately the Diver's ability only allows him to swim over sunken tile to get to land - he can't swim down to sunken temples.[/i]
[b][i]Bermuda Triangle[/b][/i] - Engineer & Pilot. Won. Fools Landing and 3 of the temples were in the SW corner. Both Fire Temples were the last 2 tile in the SE corner, with the Copper Gate (Engineers start point not far away). The Fire treasure was collected early.
The Pilot worked hard to shore up the key locations in the SW corner. However with an early Water Rise card, the SW Earth temple sank - the remaining being the Northern most tile.
The Pilot headed North, via the Engineers location to collect the Earth tokens he was holding. The Engineer headed to the SW corner to use his double-shore ability. It took more turns than felt comfortable to recover the other treasures - by which time most of the island was either sinking or had sunk; the flood pile was low and Fools Landing card hadn't come out yet.
In the final turn the Pilot grabbed the last treasure and flew to Fools Landing with one Helo Lift in hand. Luckily the first treasure drawn was a 2nd Helo Lift, so the Engineer was helo'ed in and the take-off order given.
[b][i]Baleful Bluffs[/b][/i] - Engineer & Explorer. Lost - Fools Landing Sank. A game which didn't need to be lost. Fools Landing went under water on the 2nd turn - and the Explorer, at least - if not both, was in range to shore recover Fools Landing but didn't. The game then them a lesson with an early Waters rise and an unfortunate shuffle causing Fools Landing to sink, leaving the team stranded.
:thumbsdown: Re-playability out of the tin could be limited with only 1 layout. [i]The extra official layouts have been mentioned as being in the German Edition.[/i] :thumbsup: Lots of fan support for this; extra layouts, characters, tools (as treasure cards) and rules for missions or gaining boosts from the treasures collected.

1. [2/14] This is a great little game, somewhat similar to [thing=442]Um Reifenbreite[/thing] in its basic play, but definitely containing a number of features of its own. It also has a drafting/slipstreaming method which adds an element of luck unusual in the genre, at least as far as I've explored it. For a pocket sized game, it packs a lot of theme into it.:surprise: I'm looking forward to the next two plays in my [listitem=3613646]33 x 3 Challenge.[/listitem].
2. [2/15] My second play through the game confirmed my earlier experiences. This is a very good game contained in a deceptively small package. As I note in the comment below, it looks like one where a solitaire variant could be adapted from a similar game. That would make it an even more useful portable product. item.body:
It's not War of the Ring, but does it solo better and give a similarly epic Tolkeinesque experience?
I'll know more after I play past two turns. :whistle:
[b]Update:[/b] First impression time!
:thumbsup: Another attractive game graces my table. The map is particularly striking. I can see the units marching across the fields and holing up in the settlements. The minis, tokens, dice, etc. are all nice as well.
:thumbsup: Rules are straightforward and I only found myself checking the rulebook in the interest of getting everything right. Once you nail down the flow of a turn, it's all very simple.
:thumbsdown::thumbsup: I'm not sure how I feel about having a general "event" deck (drawn by both sides) and faction-specific "story" decks. I really like how WotR has completely separate cards for the two sides, even if some of the functionality overlaps.
:thumbsup: While the battle system initially felt slow and cumbersome, I came to realize that by adding a bit more meat to the process, it really gave each battle narrative significance. Every assault on Dale was memorable BECAUSE it wasn't just one simple roll to see which side won or lost.
So unlike WotR in which you are balancing military strategy with navigating the ring to Mount Doom, this game is all about the combat. This is not a bad thing as there are many leaders involved, each adding their own flavor to the proceedings. You also deal with things like terrain, delayed deployments, and a damage system that forces you to really weigh when and where to mount your assaults. Sometimes, it's better to let the army come to you because you know you'll have the upper hand on that terrain.
I wasn't able to finish the game because my wife has actually said she wants to try and play Twilight Struggle again tomorrow so that's getting set up before I go to bed to maximize time during my daughter's nap. It might be awhile before I return to this, but I think it was a good addition that will make for a few good solo sessions and hopefully several plays with my buddy who loves the Hobbit.
ADDENDUM: I should note that while comparisons to WotR are inevitable, this game really is its own beast.

Just making myself ignore the fact that I know what the other guy has.
I'm sure that like WotR and many other 2-player designed games, this will be much more satisfying with another brain across the table, but watching the spectacle unfold is pretty great.

item.body:
Played some more Pathfinder a couple times today, with a match of [thing=30549][/thing] in between.
Finished off the evil Medusa witch, [i]finally,[/i] after the first time the Blessings deck going empty. The next match versus the Ogre mother...
[IMG]http://cdn.memegenerator.net/instances/400x/25573344.jpg[/IMG]
...became a fight of attrition. Valeros had to fight her off 3 times, when he finally put the Mammy Graul to rest.
[IMG]http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-LfI5KQ-hxms/UchpPkUQnBI/AAAAAAAAA28/jacD6KGLNSA/s1600/MammyGraul.jpg[/IMG]
In the process, Kyra got some Elven plate armor and some better Blessings, she also took the +2 Spear from the Medusa chick.

:thumbsup: Have I mentioned how addictive this game is? Because once I start, I end up wanting to go on endless adventuring. :thumbsdown: The draw of no win/no lose, when you run out of Blessings is kind of weak.

[thing=146021][/thing] for me is almost total random, but Pathfinder controlling your hand lessens a lot of the 'pure' luck of the game.
item.comment: Ughhh, that Mammy Graul looks like Jabba the Hutt - only in ugly. :gulp:

Mammy Graul gave me a lot of trouble. That was one of the few scenarios that I "lost" several times (by running out of blessings) before I finally beat it. The whole "the first time you defeat this villain, the villain is undefeated" thing really ups the difficulty--you end up losing blessings from the blessing deck when she escapes, which can be really bad if there are a lot of open locations. And it's even worse when you aren't able to beat her on your first try, so you end up having to fight her 3 times or more.
I hate her stupid fat face. :yuk:
Quickly becoming one of my favorite posters.... always love the pics.
Thanks, Hal. :)

item.body:
Hello!
Well, I finally purchased this GMT title as well and finished my first match against the Donald. It took much longer than I would have expected, and about halfway through, it became obvious that I was seriously outclassed. In the end, Donald scored 202 prestige points, while I was glad to reach at least 126 (I was worried I would have more than 100 points less than him).
Somehow, in mid-game, the events really came pounding me - while I was mayor, all the things occurred that would result in point loss for the mayor unless ransom was paid - by myself as regularly my buildings were threatened. I probably lost 30 or so prestige points during mid-game.
I was also unlucky that the reshuffle card for the planning deck was the bottom card of the planning deck - however, I had not been paying too much attention to the cards' flavour as there were so many rules to watch out for.
Despite all those hardships, I really like this game. Personally, I think its usage of cards is much better than in [thing=62219][/thing]. I really love that the trigger events are in the middle of the card stacks, ensuring that you will not see all cards in a single session (too bad that the planning deck failed me in that respect (^_^;; ).
While I rushed past the flavour because of the mind-boggling first experience, I see that there is a lot, not only in the events, but also in the individual buildings. Too bad that there is no expansion with individualized building tokens (you know, a zoo token that really looks like a zoo).
[b]Likes:[/b] + Quite some randomness - The cards really dictate what you can do at a given time, and they also generate lots of action besides the building of the actual buildings (elections, payouts, events) + Incomplete runs - For me, it is important that a game using cards or similar flavoured randomizers does not deplete all those cards in a single session. Even if you really work hard, at least 15 metropolis cards will not be seen in any given session. + Flavour - It is hidden as the tokens do not look impressive, but it is there. + Street names - Yes, this was a positive when I looked at the game board. It is part of the flavour, but their adding it is worth extra mentioning. + Useful board design - The board layout may be a problem when playing with 3+ players, but for solitaire gamers, it is really ideal. All the cards go onto the board, so you don't need to find extra space for those card stacks. + Lots of action - When your turn ends, often the real action starts as the cards used to replace the used ones can trigger various effects. + No hidden information - Yep, there is not a single bit of hidden information (safe for the order of cards in the stacks, of course). So, playing a solitaire variant does not need to mess around with that.
[b]Undecided[/b] +- AP - There is a lot of potential of Analysis Paralysis as you have to make the best of very limited resources.
[b]Dislikes[/b] - Takes very long - Even my quick run took several hours (okay, having to check rules adds to it). - Lots of small rules - There is nothing really complex there, everything is in the open. But there are so many small pieces working together. When you build a building, you have to get enough permits with the correct zone code, pay the block value, meet the zone restriction rules, meet any special conditions on the card, gain prestige points for neighbouring buildings of the same zone type, may gain and thereby score one or more vocations, execute the card effects, and remember that you have the district atourney who doubles the prestige you get for neighbouring zones, when applicable :) :). - Quite a bit of US flavour - Not a big dislike, but something that feels rather weird from a Central European perspective. Wilderness at the edge of a city can be seen as forests or maybe woods, yes, but having an airport event to move from town to city? (^_^;; Not really a problem, but something I noticed. - Lots of recalculations - During most elections, you need to calculate the value of blocks to find the most expensive building of a given zone type. And believe me, it is quite easy to miss one of those markers during those calculations (^_^;;
Yours, Deathworks

item.objectname: Lord of the Rings: The Adventure Deck Game
item.body:
Finally got this to the table and played the heck out of it today. Still haven't won, but came very close a few times. My best was when I was down to TWO cards, but ran out of time.
:thumbsup: Love the theme. :thumbsup: It's tough. :thumbsup: Quick and easy to play. :thumbsdown: I need to figure out an easier way to track the passage of time. I kept screwing that up early on.

Latest VPG acquisition; another excellent title from the little game company that could do no wrong. I played a basic game, with events, two-handed competitive, just to get the main feel of the game down, but with an eye on the adaptations necessary for the solitaire variant.
Gorgeous components, once again, and another really engaging and unusual theme. There's a few tweaks to be had, dependant on player-count, regardless of solo mode, and I was initially concerned that the yellow player, who put on a couple of early shows, took and confidently held the VP lead - even when blue far outstripped him in how infamous his shows were becoming. The game actually seems really nicely balanced; the better player (blue) cinched it on points, right at the end - which seemed fair and right. I love the thematic event cards (you draw five, randomly, per game). If two economic depressions hit, though, the game ends immediately, and the winner is decided on points at that time. This is really rare, I would say, given the randomisation and, instead, I simply chuckled my way through starving fat ladies, desperate for food; an animal stampede; the clowns all getting alcohol poisoning through some dodgy hooch. (What can I say, I have a strange sense of humour.)
Ricky Royal does a great play-through of the dedicated solitaire game, which I'll be looking at intently next time.
Another winner, it seems.

item.body:
I am unfortunately sick so I have been poring over the SoloPlay rules for Terra Mystica. Since I'm learning the game alongside learning the SoloPlay variant I've experienced a learning curve that is [i]especially[/i] curvy.
I've played twice, the first aborted because I didn't understand the costs associated with improving the worker to shovel ratio, the second completed on easy mode to a game victory (one rank above "easy game victory").
So far as I can ascertain, the Witches faction confuses the AI. Instead of creating a cohesive large combined town, it attempted to follow me on the board as I plopped down dwellings willy nilly all over the map. Although this behavior did effectively keep me from forming another town, so I guess that's good for the AI still. I had to concentrate all my efforts on just making the one town before the AI's "terraform within two shovel types" reaction broke my fragile town structure.
I'm sad that I only built the one town, but I grabbed the one with 9 VPs. (You only get 3 possible town tiles at the beginning of the game.)
The end game scoring is a little bit different considering that the two neutral opponents gang up on you in terms of scoring, and there are multiple bonuses applied as well if you can achieve them.
More than other SoloPlay variants I've tried, this one both gives limited set up player choice that really helps shape the rest of the game. Had I not chosen the two scoring tiles that boost dwelling VPs, and chosen them to happen early on, I would have lost. I'm not as sure on the bonus tiles, as I removed the 6-dollar one before shuffling and randomly selecting the five bonus tiles to use, because I wanted to prioritize everything else.
I upgraded to a stronghold as soon as possible, but it was difficult to upgrade in general. There are so many levers to pull that I had difficulty determining exactly which ones to use every round. Terra Mystica is a very meaty game, no matter its incarnation.
One thing I did do is that, towards the end, when your opponents run out of actions, they start attacking you on the cult board (basically placing priests, but only if they can change the lead). And if they can't succeed there, you just start losing 2 VPs per reaction.
Yeah, ow. After I was nearly out of stuff to do and the -2 VPs started hitting I quit while I was ahead. I'm pretty sure that also contributed to the normalish win on easy mode with the easy faction.
I'm going to try harder factions next, but maybe after some Formaggio with Viticulture/Tuscany, or possibly something else, but now I need to rest some more so I can actually get better.

It doesn't really help with the recovery but ... Who knows? Hope you'll feel better soon.
Thank you!

item.body:
A package arrived on Thursday, and another on Saturday, bringing many fine goodies:
[imageid=2417143 medium]
I have been very busy all week with the "mystery game," but that ended today and I got to look forward to playing some other games. My wife went to bed early, and I decided what the heck, I'll give XCOM a shot.
I played the tutorial mission and performed ABYSMALLY. From the first round forward, I kept overspending and having my interceptors shot down in combat. The game ended on the third round, with a score of -45!
I did really enjoy the game, though, and look forward to exploring it more. There are two major cons to solo play. One is that the board is clearly designed for 4 players, so no matter which way you rotate it, something will end up in a less-than-ideal position. I played with the base defense/mission side facing toward me, which seemed like the most crucial area to be able to access, but that meant the world map was rotated 90 degrees.
The other con is that there is just SO much to keep track of with all the cards and tech providing special abilities (especially the ones that apply to the timed phase). I think the game would definitely reward carefully reading through these cards and trying to memorize them as much as possible.
Overall opinion, though, was positive.
item.comment: From what I have read about XCOM, it really seems like it would be a really fun game. However, it also seems like it would be a massive nightmare to play solo!

Looking through the forums after the game, I did play a couple of things incorrectly, which added to the difficulty.
1) The rules state that "For each UFO remaining in orbit, increase panic in the continent with the lowest panic by 1." This is really poorly worded, in my opinion. I played it that you selected 1 continent and moved it up by 1 for each UFO. Apparently, what they MEANT is that the first UFO moves the least panicked continent 1 single space, then the second UFO moves the least panicked continent (which may have changed) by 1 space, and so forth. BIG difference between moving 1 continent up 8 spaces and moving 3 continents 2 or 3 spaces each.
2) When you play a card that saves an Interceptor or Soldier from being killed, you can keep rolling for that task as long as the unit remains assigned to the task. I played it that a "LOSS" result killed your units and ended the task, so even if you save the unit, you can't continue rolling. Again, it could have made a difference.
3) This is not an incorrect rule, but I did forget to use my timed abilities some of the time--lots of time pressure!

item.body:
After a (much too) long hiatus from my table I set this up yesterday after I put Rallyman away. Thanks to the others posting SE4X this month I was inspired to dust this one off.
I have never played the Alien solo scenario and have that on my goals list for 2015 so I'll get to cross that off soon. I'm currently set up against 2 Alien players. I clipped all of these counters last month and they are looking pretty sharp. ;)
Now I just need to refresh myself on the rules and learn how to operate the Alien opposition.
[b]2/19[/b] This wasn't very tough to relearn at all and the AP rules weren't too hard to grok either. I set up an easy scenario for my first try so it was against 2 AP (Yellow and Green) who I had to defeat before they combined their forces and became a massive Blue empire. (Actually, they weren't friends at all, they were from totally different parts of the galaxy, never really met each other and had little in common.)
I did not keep any session notes for this game since I was concentrating on relearning the rules and learning how to work the AP players. I did have some confusion about determining if they were launching raider fleets or not and some other minor quibbles so I'll have to do a comprehensive read through of their rules again and maybe some forum skims before I go again. I'll also have to up the difficulty level - though they did take me to turn 19 before I wrapped things up.
Green got off to a strong Tech start before it started accumulating Fleet and just a dab of Defense. Yellow had grabbed a few economy boosts early to help it along in later turns and made more Defense rolls early on as well. Yellow was the first to launch a fleet at me, this happened in turn 4 and it was just a tiny 10CP fleet though it did force me to divert some resources to meet the attack. Green didn't launch a fleet until turn 8 and it was just a 10CP fleet as well (but boy did they have fancy gadgets).
I had shipyards set up on the outlying colonies so I could move more quickly to intercept incoming threats. I started by building a small force at each location but quickly realized that it was much better to combine my forces to overpower the enemy. I had built up my move tech to level 4 which I felt was good enough and was able to keep the small AP fleets from causing trouble. The AP players both failed Move tech rolls the entire game - this really helped.
About half-way through I realized that Yellow was kind of falling behind on Fleet but had built up 50CPs for defense. I decided to go after them first. After they launched a 75CP fleet in turn 12 I met them on turn 13 and then continued on to their home world. They managed to get another fleet out in turn 14 (40CP) and then revealed a massive amount of mines as their home defense - unfortunately, I had low SW tech and just two Sweepers so they chewed up a bunch of my ships. However, it wasn't enough and the rest of my fleet hung out and bombarded the crap out of their homeworld. Yellow fell on Turn 16.
While I was tied up with Yellow, Green AP launched a 90CP fleet on turn 14. I was on it though having saved some CPs in preparation to generate a fleet to meet them. With 6SY in two systems that were relatively close together and SY Tech 1 I was able to put a decent fleet on the board. I met their fleet and it was a good battle. However, I had done one thing I had not ever done before in my plays of this game - I invested in Fighter Tech (I'm not sure why I never went for it before). By the time I had pushed past their 90CP fleet my remaining units from the Yellow campaign were ready to join the forces at the Green front and Green launched a 50CP fleet (easily defeated). I bid my time for one turn so I could send in a small force to generate their home defense. I sent in 2 Mine Sweepers, a lone scout and a couple of CAs - intending them for mine fodder. Instead of mines though they ended up generating Bases. I fled that battle until my main force could come in.
I assaulted the Green homeworld with 6CVs, 16 Fighters, 2 BBs, 2 BCs and 2 CAs. My massive Carrier fleet could not be stopped. Green chipped away at me a bit but by sheer numbers I overwhelmed them (and I totally forgot my +1 fleet size bonus in that fight too).

item.objectname: Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island
item.body:
My [-]second[/-] third go at Cursed Island.... and a success! I barely got any wounds; when early on, I found the boxes to store all my food so it doesn't rot, the game went pretty smoothly after that. Just one winter die in the last five rounds meant a roof of 1 was sufficient. Also, the explorer with his shortcut managed to give me two wood a round by the 5th or 6th.
I will add that it helped that I didn't roll a single non-success on the build-dice but I only used them about 3 times, rather I attempted to use two tokens as much as possible (limiting my actions, but still :p)
I was also a bit lucky with some card draws. A Savage arrived and stole my weapon, which was already at 0 so nothing happened. I then later found him, dead (serves him right) but he had managed to nab some candles that allowed me to build more efficiently.
The explorer also has an ability where you discard 3 morale and can draw 2, discard one of those little round tokens that give you some benefit. This allowed me to get an extra building token more than once.
My last playthrough of this scenario I lost hard and couldn't understand why everyone was saying it's the easiest one. Now I might.
This game should be played often, when you know the rules it's a pure delight.
[b]*EDIT*[/b] Ran myself through the third scenario, Jenny needs Help! Well guess what? She doesn't need help anymore! Cos she's dead :(
The rope is huge in this scenario and I also had the Carpenter who builds a snare with it. You need to uncover three totems to get the rope built automatically. You can build it yourself but you'd need hills terrain. Well, I didn't get either until about turn 5 or 6, by which point there wasn't enough time to build the raft and use it to nab Jenny. I doubt there was anything I could have done differently to win this..... the shuffle of the island tiles was the culprit. Annoying session

One of the absolute gems in the VPG line, I remain hopeful that this is allowed to blossom in a deluxe boxed edition, one of these days. A really smart - seriously, the interlocking mechanisms on this are truly impressive - political game of hunting for a conspiracy and then taking it to trial.
Possibly.
You see, the impressive thing about this game is the variability of it; not just in how it plays out, but in what is actually happening behind the scenes.
You are Thomas Jefferson, keeping an eye on the worrying machinations of Aaron Burr (the so-called Hero of Weehawken). Burr may be up to something, raising an expedition that could be an invasion force, a coup, or possibly a peaceable mission to settle Ouachita Valley. There are nine conspirators in the deck; three are selected in secret at the start of the game, the rest shuffled back into the event deck. You spend action points, you flip a card, each round, and you try to bolster your political strength, prepare evidence for a trial... and then try to work out what you might be putting Burr on trial for.
The genius of the system is that it can be one of seven end goals you're trying to discover - and you might play a game where you don't even get to trial.
I didn't, this time. I had plenty of federal agents, out in the Midwest, searching for possible conspirators, and I kept blundering over James Wilkinson (who may or may not be in on it), making his way down to New Orleans - which can lead to him tipping Burr off, forcing an arrest, or instigating martial law and costing me precious action points. I never found Burr himself, this game, and I fell foul of several expedition cards (which add to the power of his forces and mitigate dice rolls when you do an expedition check). Today, Burr martialed his forces and managed to start his expedition, closing off my chance at a trial, despite the fact I'd drawn very well with evidence cards. Flipping the conspirator cards revealed that Wilkinson did indeed have a hand in it, and he and Anthony Merry, along with James Blennerhasset, were attempting to invade Spanish Florida.
Impressively, the local militia were able to thwart this hostile move, ending the game with me sitting there with egg on my face for lacking the power to bring Burr to justice and quell the rebellion. Minus ten points, then. (And I distinctly recall winning this one, last time.)
A historical puzzle, a detective story and a legal battle (depending on many variable factors); check it out.

item.objectname: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.body: I won playing 3p (Mercenary, Commander and Medic) against the 4th scenario. The medic allowed me to come back from an early Xenomorph that wreaked havoc in the combat zone starting in the 3rd turn due to a bad event draw. In the end, 4 of the 5 HQ slots had been destroyed by events and the last was Ripley's rare costing 9, which I had been there since the first turn and I never did buy. Fortunately, the Mercenary was able to able take out the Queen and Newborn as he had been the dedicate Ripley card collector and was doing 13+ at least one time each trip through his deck.

Lost again playing 3p (Dispatcher, Containment Specialist, Contigency Planner). Felt like I was keeping everything under control, had cured two diseases and then the outbreaks spiraled out of control. It's more chaotic than Pandemic which I'm finding I actually view as a feature of the game. Since you never know where the diseases are going to show up, so the keeping the spread under control part of the game is more challenging, at least so far. Of course, I've played 20 games of Pandemic and only 7 of this, so maybe I'll start to see more patterns.

In my ongoing quest to play solo variants I find on BGG for games I own, I tried the Ticket to Ride solo variant. It's ok, but a little too luck based for my tastes. My tickets we all in the West, which affording me the luxury of patience and I scored a very healthy 117, I think it would have been very different if my tickets had been in the East. Intersting that it flipped the early push is to grab the short routes you are going to need, you have the luxury to be patient and wait on the long routes.
I doubt I'll play this solo again, but it was a solid variant, I just have games I like better.

Hello!
I did another solitaire game, this time using the shorter variant suggested in the rules and using two bots - Donald was joined by his evil twin sister Dorothy. This actually sped up the game a bit and also made it easier as Donald wasn't able to hoard all politicians. Actually, I ended up controlling most politicians in the end (Donald wouldn't release the Treasurer, though, no matter what I tried).
I decided to stick to the variant rules by the letter (save for changing all complete 10 wealth for the bots to prestige immediately), although this lead to rather stupid play on one or two occasions (Donald wasted good points when playing the Nuclear Power Plant, for instance).
Getting the union boss early on was part of the key to success. And then I got all the good event cards while the nasty ones failed to impact me (I started with the Res-3 building to get the media vocation, but early on, it got auctioned to Donald who then abandoned it as he would have had to pay prestige to keep it; in the end it was removed following the local head lines). Very few value chips got into play (thanks to shorter play variant, I guess): prestige 5 got into play fairly early, but prestige 6 was delayed once because Donald and I were tied as far as prestige went, but it returned towards the end of the game and I was able to place it beneficially for me.
In the end, I won with 169 prestige, Donald only scored 107 and Dorothy had a misely 64 prestige. During the last few turns, I really swam in money and I had hoarded vocations (the bots had been rather unlucky, with few vocations available and the bots sometimes missing them in their dice rolls).
It was good fun, although the board didn't get filled too well (remember, each bot plays one card and discards another). When going for a big session report, I may end up doing it in a more classic fashion. Or maybe not have the bots discard contracts?

item.body:
Decided to go back for another try, after letting Burr get the better of me, so easily, earlier. Things actually got off to a far worse start, with few decent card draws benefiting me. The expedition was kitted out, from the get go, and I just couldn't muster the prestige points to reshuffle them into the deck.
It looked like I was going to be trounced - again - until I pulled three conspirators from the event deck, narrowing the odds for my investigation. Using the guide, you begin to puzzle out which nefarious goal Burr might be pursing, and I was hedging my bets against a couple - but making few arrests.
With the expedition almost ready to roll out, I gambled and played a strategy I've never used before. I let Burr go. There's one option to explore that suggests he is actually innocent, and it only comes up if his daughter is one of the hidden conspirators. Never seen it happen before, but I was heading for a loss... so...
Let the bugger walk free, flipped the conspiracy hand... and there was Burr's daughter. Poor old dad was only guilty of trying to settle down in the valley. I earned twenty points for rightfully dropping the charges, and one extra for my remaining prestige point.
If anyone can recommend another game with this kind of variability and just downright cleverness, I'm all ears.
(I'm also, oddly, feeling an urge to sing Hero of Canton... but it's been a long day.)

item.body:
Oh man... I'm a bit into my first game and this is most definitely living up to the hype thus far. I believe it was [-]Often[/-] [size=18][u][i][b]MOE[/b][/i][/u][/size] who mentioned perceiving the images on the blocks to be animated or moving or something to that effect. I definitely get the same impression. I see the battle happening. The card play is quick enough that it almost feels like it's happening in real time.
I'll have more thoughts upon completion. the Carthaginians are roughing up the Syracusians pretty bad so far.
[b]Update:[/b] A Carthiginian win is in the books. Syracuse pushed with it's heavies up the center map when it had an opening and for a moment, that seemed to have Carthage on its heels. However, a devastating counterattack by Mago's heavy unit broke that effort up in a hurry.
[imageid=2418320] Boom.
After that, it was all Carthage, culminating in a decisive final blow to Dionysius.
[imageid=2418321] Apparently, the second die wasn't necessary, but better safe than sorry?
So I'm sure I made a few mistakes along the way. I certainly forgot to "Battle Back" a few times. Syracuse had 3 banners in the end to Carthage's winning 5.
Recently, with big games like this, I've rarely set them back up for a second play. Tonight is a different story. I want to play another round right now, but the wiser me knows I need to get in bed. This game has left a great first impression. Enjoyed every minute. To be continued...
[b]Update 2:[/b] Second play is in the books. I call this one the Carthage Catastrophe. I thought of taking pictures, but I got so absorbed into the proceedings, I forgot. I'll take that as a good thing.
What I loved (Syracuse loved it anyway) about this game was that Mago's battalion got stuck in their corner for darn near the entire game. Carthage couldn't get a right side order card or any leader order cards to save their life (literally). So the rest of their army just had to suck it up and push ahead, getting pretty well slaughtered in the process. Finally, Mago got his stuff together and pressed forward, quickly taking out 2 heavy units within a matter of a couple turns. Imagine what might have happened had he been active the whole game.
Thumb time:
:thumbsup: Simple but necessary: The components are awesome. I have always written these block games off thinking it would just look weird on the table. Quite the opposite. Maybe it's a novelty that will wear off, but I find the aesthetic of the blocks moving around pretty striking. Like OFTEN said, I feel like I'm looking over a map plotting moves and strategies, but at the same time, I can almost hear the shouts and the pounding feet of infantry and cavalry racing across the field. Pictures don't do this game justice.
:thumbsup: The rules are well written and easy to piece together. I missed a few things here and there on the first play, but on the second, I don't think I missed anything. A rare feat for me.
:thumbsdown: Stickering is a pain in the butt, but it wasn't quite as bad as I anticipated. Only took a couple dedicated sittings.

item.body:
I'm not dead! And I played a solo game, too.
I'm still working my way through expansion 4 of last year's game, and it's still a great game. Amiri and Merisiel were not seriously challenged by the lamia clerics in this game, and I won easily.
I was planning to attack the next scenario, but I was interrupted by a visitor from Porlock then had to go play squash.

[size=24][b]HA![/b][/size]
After a ridiculous number of plays, it finally happened.
[size=18][b]I WON THE COMBINED SCENARIO.[/b][/size]
I'm not saying it was pretty, but I won.
With about 12 cards left, the Austro-Hungarian empire got invaded by the Italians, thus causing them to fall.
With that added pressure against the Balkans (Salonika front in Ottoman), I was doing ok. Why? [i]Because the Salonika front hadn't even entered yet![/i]
So I draw War Weariness and continue to plow through. The Caucus were hanging back; Gallipoli had already fled; and I had dealt with the Mesopotamians, pushing them waaaaaay back to the #5 space.
I just had to hold on... The Arab front crept closer, but I was able to push them back. Using Yildrim, I kept the Sinai front at bay.
Finally, last card: Enter Salonika.
[b]Final score:[/b] 16 (Marginal Victory), but per the combined rules I nabbed an [b]Operational Victory![/b]
The irony in all of this is I still have yet to win Hapsburg Eclipse. You're next though, Hapsburg, you're next.
item.comment: I have no idea what that is (haven't played the game), but it sounds like you accomplished something big! Congratulations!

[q="kittenhoarder"]I have no idea what that is (haven't played the game), but it sounds like you accomplished something big! Congratulations![/q]
Ottoman Sunset & Hapsburg Eclipse are two states of siege games from Victory Point Games. They deal with the incoming threat of various forces into the Ottoman & Austro-Hungarian empires around WW1. They are both small footprint, card-based, dice rolling games that seem a little tower defense. And they're both pretty tough to beat.
When Hapsburg came out, Leviloff (the designer) found a way to combine both of these solitaire games into one big one, that could be played solo or even co-op. Many of the cards drawn affect the other player and there is even a way to give the other board more actions.
In this combined scenario, ultimately you want both sides to win, BUT if one side fails, the other side can still win but with a pretty tough handicap. I, for the first time ever, actually made it to the end of the combined game and won, but the Austro-Hungarian side of the battle lost, which made the Ottoman side winning more difficult and much sweeter.
Nice job, Travis! You rock. :cool:

item.body:
Gave this one another shot, playing on easy. As expected, familiarity with some of the cards made the game a lot easier. I also really took my time, during the "Commander has access to emergency funding" step, to count the pieces already on the board and estimate how many more I'd need to place. The app gives you enough time to do this, roughly 30 seconds if I remember correctly, and this is your chance to avoid going overbudget.
I played the Infiltration mission, which throws more Crisis cards at you than usual, but I found those pretty easy to deal with--it's a "lesser of two evils" choice rather than "OMG I don't have enough money to defend all these places at once!" I balanced my budget well (this really is the key to the game) and completed the final mission on Round 5. Here's a picture of how it looked in the end:
[imageid=2418339 medium]
I ended with a score of 82 points (perfect is 100), which is not bad at all. None of my continents were in the red, and the base was on the last yellow space. I completed 2 missions over the course of the game, plus the final one.
As you can see, I tried a different board layout today, and it worked really well. Everything was in reach, and I didn't get that awkward feeling of looking at the world sideways. I did play all of the timed rounds standing up, but I do that for [thing=38453][/thing], too.
:thumbsup: The game looks really good on the table, with the minis and board gelling together well. :thumbsup: I love the real-time challenge in games like this. And unlike some reviewers, I find the game mechanics interesting even without the time crunch. :thumbsdown: It does get pretty overwhelming to remember all the cards in play and use them opportunistically. :thumbsdown: Certain roles get a lot of clock time, and others seem to get less than they should (esp. the scientist). :thumbsdown: Most real-time games are lightning fast. This one isn't--this game took 2 hours. It's like playing a regular real-time game multiple times in a row, except this one [i]forces[/i] you to keep playing until you've resolved the mission, which took 5 rounds for me.
item.comment: I agree with everything you said. I'm hoping that getting more and more familiar with the science cards help me play faster. Getting organized in a way that works for you is critical. I'm enjoying it solo, but I'd really like to try it with four.
