item.body:
The chosen were:
- The Valkyrie (Skewer, Sprout Wings, Visions of Death) - The Crusader (Wrath, Defiance, Annointed) - The Monk (Chi Burst, Clarity, Quiet) - The Scholar (Foresight, Preperation, Thoroughness)
So the plan was half good fighters, half searchers in the hopes of getting at least one relic (and thence into the hands of the Crusader).
But we got two relics early on (by which I mean, a little before halfway through the darkness track). We should have, I feel, with two searchers turning up keys, pressed for a third relic. I mean, we were even turning up keys in the castle, and with the Monk's Clarity's Chi Bonus, we could pull keys just about anywhere.
Instead we started fighting the Necromancer. Everything seemed ready. Relics in the Valkyrie's and Crusader's hands, but our searchers were not up to fights and had lost most of their secrecy. We did draw the necromancer into the mountains where there was only one blight, and hit him with everything we had. Even the Scholar took out a blight, but the Monk risked a search when he shouldn't have and died to a Dead (Dread?) Servent event card.
The Crusader wrathed a lot, but without secrecy he was vulnerable in the end, due to not being able to fuel Defiance's trade of secrecy for grace. Even with Bottled Magic we couldn't pull the win once the Scholar had luckily knocked out a shroud, and a Valkyrie attack had killed the other blight, whatever it was.
The Scholar died next. I play without replacing heroes, by the way, because I feel after a certain point in the game there's very little reason to. This is possibly "hard mode" but if so it's not much harder than normal mode. The Crusader then went to the Promised Land, with one last die roll with no blights that did nothing. The Valkyrie lasted quite a bit longer, but without people to kill blights, and 1s and 2s being rolled by the Necromancer, she succumbed. At the time there were two blights in the monastery, with two more likely delivered quite soon.
In the end, the dice weren't with us, and I was left thinking about how unfair that is. Beyond unfairness, it's also tedious as heck. [-]I've decided to go with the following house rule, which I shall call "Divine Intervention":
[q] The Necromancer is automatically defeated when:
- There are no blights in his location, and - The hero fighting the necromancer would be rolling at least (5 - (number of heroes in location)) dice, and - Said hero has a relic. [/q]
This rewards due preparation, teamwork and logistics, gives a better reason for replacing dead heroes, and reduces the inevitable excess rolling of dice. These are also basically the conditions for an average win through combat with the Necromancer during a normal game.
Because really, if you have managed all that, you deserve to win.
Arguably this will result in more wins, in which case you can pull out the Darkness deck at long last to increase difficulty. [/-]
[b]Update:[/b] See comments below from the designer!
item.comment:
[q]- The hero fighting the necromancer would be rolling at least (5 - (number of heroes in location)) dice ... These are also basically the conditions for an average win through combat with the Necromancer during a normal game. [/q] I fully encourage you to use whatever rules make the game most fun for you, but I want to point out those conditions are quite a bit easier than the "average win".
Statistically, under the normal rules, you need to roll an average of 6 dice against the Necromancer to kill him (which usually entails multiple attempts with your strongest fighter); under this rule, your weakest fighter can automatically kill him on the first try as long as the entire group is together (5 - 4 = 1 die, which is the minimum you roll regardless of all penalties).
You also may want to note that fighting bonuses are more common than searching bonuses, so a "half fighting, half searching" party is actually weak in fighting and strong in searching compared to the average--an excellent candidate to go for the ritual victory, as you suggested.

[q="Antistone"][q]- The hero fighting the necromancer would be rolling at least (5 - (number of heroes in location)) dice ... These are also basically the conditions for an average win through combat with the Necromancer during a normal game. [/q] I fully encourage you to use whatever rules make the game most fun for you, but I want to point out those conditions are quite a bit easier than the "average win".
Statistically, under the normal rules, you need to roll an average of 6 dice against the Necromancer to kill him (which usually entails multiple attempts with your strongest fighter); under this rule, your weakest fighter can automatically kill him on the first try as long as the entire group is together (5 - 4 = 1 die, which is the minimum you roll regardless of all penalties).
You also may want to note that fighting bonuses are more common than searching bonuses, so a "half fighting, half searching" party is actually weak in fighting and strong in searching compared to the average--an excellent candidate to go for the ritual victory, as you suggested.[/q]
Thanks for the insights! Also I am humbled. :blush:
I hadn't thought this through completely. Now I understand the reasons behind some of the design better. I'll play normally in the future and keep in mind the divide between combat and search.
Probably would have won, sticking with the ritual win condition. We only had two keys to go.

item.body:
I've got this all setup on my table and ready to go tonight - we'll see how this plays solo and will report back.
UPDATE: First impressions are quite good - the artwork is amazing, and has a "Flying Frogesque" type of characters / crew cards, while the encounter, peril, and resource cards have a nice artistic style. The location cards look gorgeous, and the die that I received in the box is quite unique, having a 3d texture to it.
The player boards are ok - mine are experiencing warping on the first day out the box, and the back does not have any artwork on it (plain white) so that was a little disappointing as I thought that either a plain black backing or some artwork would have added a nice touch (although admittedly you don't look at those when they're flat on the table)
I also received 2 additional encounter packs (I didn't open yet) and a cool USB drive which has the artwork from the game - I did check out that file today and that also looks like a lot of effort and love was put into the game.
Now for the gameplay... I played 2 solo games, changing my character for each play through, and I only used 1 ship (which perhaps I will try to manage 2 next time). When you play the game you're deckbuilding to help you get through location and encounter cards. The tough part is that resources are hard to come by - you can use your characters for resources, but then they exhaust and you can only make them available again by resting, or by playing a card that allows you to make them available.
There's a catch though... you need to find 2 keys which are positioned on 4 cards (2 have keys, 2 have blanks), and you don't know where they are. When you move to a new location, your peril increases. Once you hit 10, it's immediately game over! Just under 50% of the peril cards are a "3", so there's some luck involved if you're going to complete your game (although you can mitigate some of the peril by playing a set of 3 resource tokens). Each time you lose an encounter you also need to pay a penalty, which for me was to lose a crew member (randomly by rolling a D6).
My first time through I cleared 3 locations, but couldn't get the peril down, and lost before I could secure my second key. The second time I played I was able to secure both keys and get to the final destination card. On the last location you need to clear 2 encounters in the same turn, and the card also makes it a +5 difficulty. So.... lucky me my peril card stated that the first encounter doesn't count towards the number I needed to clear (which was 2), so I needed to try to clear 3 different encounters. I cleared the first 2, and had 3 cards in my hand that let me ready 1 of my crew (each card). I drew the worst possible encounter I could have which resulted in a toughness of 20 to complete.
I had to look at the rules to see how the location effects would take place, and then my modifiers, which I believe I got right and dropped it to 18. Looking at my crew I only had 16 points to use, but I had 2 money resources in reserve and a card that let me convert money into the other resource I needed for the win. By the skin of my teeth I completed the scenario.
Overall, I think the game is quite challenging, even by using 4 rest tokens instead of 3 (rules state you can use 4 to make it easier). I'm thinking that using more than 1 ship would really help even out the difficulty; so I'm going to try that again tonight!
Hopefully I can get some pictures on here, but it takes me too long to upload them :(
- that's all for now -

Decided to take a break from my fantasy 10x10 challenge, and dusted off this absolute gem. Played the Agincourt scenario to get back into the swing of the rules.
Since I've been listening to Hardcore History's treatment on the Mongols ("Wrath of the Khans"), I'm setting up a few Mongol battles next :)
:thumbsup: Awesome game -- really fast, fun, and playable. :thumbsup: Gives a real feel for how the conflict *might* have gone, but is far more gamey than simulationy. Not that I don't enjoy deeper sims, but this one is about the only tactical-level simulation I enjoy. :thumbsdown: I don't own King of Kings or Imperator (yet). A few nights ago I set aside some time to take care of the three Rallyman Challenges for the month. The first two took a little longer than expected, so I did the third a few days later...
First up was the primary challenge for the month: [imageid=2399049]
[floatright][imageid=2413374 medium][size=8]That went well.[/size][/floatright]SS1: [bgcolor=gray]V9-V6[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=cyan]J11-J14[/bgcolor] SS2: [bgcolor=cyan]J13-J12[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=gray]V5-V0[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=cyan]L12-L13[/bgcolor] SS3: [bgcolor=cyan]L14-L17/C15-C14[/bgcolor]
This set started out well and I was able to find a way to thread through the double hairpin quickly, but then all hell broke loose, when somehow all seven dice came up with hazard symbols at once. Ouch. Deep in the woods and rocks, there was no way that could end well so I had to use the SISU card. That made the rest of the run more risky, but it ended up not being a big problem. The remaining two sections both went smoothly without incident, aside from a spin crossing the line right at the very end of the third section.
Est. Total Time: [o]The Biggest Ball of Twine in Minnesota[/o]
----------------------------
I followed that up with a run through [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/18195767#18195767]Mud Challenge 5[/url], a mixed-terrain setup where everyone was forced to use Soft tires with no assistance between section.
S1: [bgcolor=gray]A24-A26[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=tan]D4-D5[/bgcolor] S2: [bgcolor=tan]D6-D1[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=gray]P16-P13[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=cyan]B14-B15[/bgcolor] S3: [bgcolor=cyan]B17-B10[/bgcolor]/[bgcolor=gray]A22-A23[/bgcolor]
I had to use my SISU card in the first stage again which never bodes well, but the second went lightning fast. The expected losses of control happened in the third near the end, but with the second-to-last one I was able to push the car just far enough down the track that I was able to get across the finish line on the final roll.
Est. Time: [o]Gravity [o]Bareilles, not Mayer[/o][/o]
----------------------------
Rallyman was still sitting on my desk from a few nights ago, so I took the opportunity finish off the third SGOYT challenge for the month: [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/18204419#18204419]Rally Challenge 5 - "Wriggle Room"[/url].
Route: [bgcolor=cyan]C18-C13/L16-L15/C14-C15/J15-J16/L14-L17[/bgcolor]
Even though it was set up to be playable with the base game only, double downshifting was allowed which turned it from a grueling slog through the snow into a grueling sprint through the snow. The double downshift was used numerous times throughout, and twice I even did a double-double where you drop from 5th to 1st in just two spaces. Not much room for error in those, but the clutch held out both times. Trouble came a little later when I had to use the SISU to avoid a bad shift, only to skid off the road on the very next move.
Snow runs usually feel slow, but this one actually seemed pretty quick despite that loss of control. Fortunately the rest of the course was mostly only short throws, and they went off without incident.
Est. Time: [o]1000 Times[/o]

item.body:
Four mismatched adventurers set out in a strange land...
[imageid=2418657 medium][size=8][i]Overview, ready to begin. This entire Dungeon was built using MagnaTiles. (http://magnatiles.com/)[/i][/size]
Minos - The Warrior/Mage* Sky Heron - The Thief Jadreen - The Archer Oracle Matteo - The Healer *[i][size=6]Originally a Minotaur Mage misprinted with Norfur Thott's dial, slightly modified and repurposed as a Hero.[/size][/i]
-------------------------------------------- [b]Rules Mods:[/b] -Coop-style team rules (characters can act in any order) -WMTs don't move, but convert when a Hero enters their area. -WMTs convert by rolling a d10(%) for total value and a d4 for the number of monsters (value takes priority over number if a match can't be made) -If the last active Mage Spawn is defeated, the nearest WMT automatically converts -All Mage Spawn values are rounded to the nearest 5. -Mage Spawn get a number of activations equal to the number of active Heroes -[bgcolor=red][color=white]Quickness[/color][/bgcolor] - Double movement but cannot attack or use artifacts, OR may attack and/or use artifacts multiple times per turn as movement points allow -Called-Shot & Friendly-Fire modifiers (from Mechwarrior) - Can shoot into or out of base contact, but target gets +1 Defense. -Various other minor adjustments made on the fly as needed. --------------------------------------------
[imageid=2418658 medium][size=8][i]Whip It. Whip It Good.[/i][/size]
[imageid=2418659 medium][size=8][i]Skeleton Attack![/i][/size]

------------------------------
Our kids were given a set of [url=http://magnatiles.com/]MagnaTiles[/url] for Christmas this year, and they've been playing with them almost every single day since. It's a really awesome building toy that is made up of flat plates with magnets on the edges so they stick together and can be used to build some really impressive structures. A couple weeks ago while helping them build something, I realized that the gridlines created by the square tiles looked remarkably close to the size of a Mage Knight "Clix" dial, and a quick check showed that they were a perfect match. That got the wheels turning, and last night I had enough time try it out by building a dungeon layout. The biggest limitation ended up being the table itself, but aside from that they worked awesome, and made a fantastic alternative to the ridiculously-expensive 3D Tile sets that were once available for the game (not that MagnaTiles are exactly cheap, but you can do so very much more with them).
Mage Knight Dungeons tends to go a couple months between plays, but this will make a great new option for future plays.
:thumbsup: Incredibly versatile dungeon-crawler :thumbsup: Tons of good pre-painted miniatures
:thumbsdown: Out of print collectible miniatures game :thumbsdown: Long setup and takedown times :thumbsdown: Will fill up your table, no matter how much space you give it.

item.body:
Hello!
Well, I went down to town today since I had seen a game on the shelves of my game shop the other day and after checking BGG found that there were several attempts at providing it with a solitaire variant. So, I intended to make it mine.
But I usually check both game stores while I am at it, to see if there is something new.
And in the other store, there was Dungeon Roll on the shelf. Okay, it had been there already quite a while ago, but that had been the German version and thus definitely something I would not buy. So, nothing of interest.
As I idly looked over it, I noticed that the Pegasus mark was missing. Odd. I turned it around. English text on the bottom. Still no Pegasus mark. Could it be? I asked the shop owner, and he also figured it was the English version.
... Insta-buy. ...
Well, getting the components all ready was rather quick, but some of the rules sounded rather ambiguous. I had to consult BGG a bit to be sure I got everything right.
So, I sent the Enchantress to venture forth into the dark depths of the dungeon. Right on the first level, her party encountered nothing - except for some rotten shelves that made a lot of noise that was probably heard far below. But after reaching the second level, foes like goblins and oozes attacked the party.
I was a bit worried after concluding level 4 as my resources were strained and there were already two dragon dice in the den. But I wanted to get that level up before the second delve. Go figure, level 5 did give me the third dragon die, but somehow, the enchantress emerged victorious. Yay! 6 XP, allowing her to level up.
The second delve also reached level 5, this time without encountering the dragon.
And the third delve also saw the beguiler and a crowd of three summoned companions defeat the dragon handily at level 5.
All bonus points added in, I reached 20 points, which is probably not bad for a first try. (Although I also think the enchantress is probably one of the most powerful heroes you can have since hoarding scrolls makes her unstoppable)
[b]Likes[/b] + Fast game - Fast to set up, fast to play + Well-hidden push-your-luck game - I am not that fond of push-your-luck-games, but this one does have enough steps and decisions to add more to the experience than just throwing the dice + Nice bits of flavour - Okay, there is not that much flavour in it, but there is enough to make it enjoyable.
[b]Dislikes[/b] - Ambiguous/hard to understand rules - The game's core rules are really simple, but the individual rules for heroes or treasures are sometimes difficult to understand. And re-checking things, I found that the overview card of the treasures describes the ability of dragon bait different from what the rule book says (and I used the dragon bait in one run in combination with the ring of invisibility to get past a level). - Not stackable - While the box is nice to set the mood of the game, I don't think I could put anything on top of it (^_^;; - A bit more flavour would have been nice - Like a background story for the dungeon (okay, it needn't even be as basic as the one of Proving Grounds of the Mad Overlord)
Yours, Deathworks

Hello!
As I mentioned in the Dungeon Roll entry, I went to the stores actually with a definite game in mind. And that game was Tokaido (æ±æµ·é). I had noticed the game when I last went to the stores to buy [thing=62220][/thing] (a very good game in my eyes) and I checked it on BGG at home.
=>Native language of designer: neither English nor Japanese => Good (the store only had the German version of the game) =>Solitaire variants available: 3 different variants suggested => Good =>A casual game => Very Good!
Sum: Go for it!
This time, I also checked the sleeve size beforehand and bought the proper sleeves right away.
Back at home, I found that the components were quite nice, although I was surprised that a game pointing to traditional Japanese aesthetics doesn't have a pink pawn (think cherry blossoms) or a white pawn (plum blossoms).
After punching out the coins and sleeving the cards (and deciding to go with Satsuki for my first game), I had to pick the solitaire variant. I admit that after reading the rules (first on BGG and then on paper), I was still a bit puzzled about where exactly the strategy came in (I had a vague idea but felt that seeing the scoring in action would help), so I couldn't judge the variants based on that. Since only one variant had the AI players function with all rules in place, I chose [thread=934988]that one.[/thread]
While the AIs did a good job keeping me from getting money during the first half of the game, they kept jumping ahead so far that I was able to get a lot of things. Thus, I got all three panoramas completed as well as having the most valuable souvenirs and the most encounters. Donations at the temple were a draw, and, funnily enough, the gourmet bonus was a three-side draw (each of us had 9 coins worth of food, but all with completely different combinations (^_^;; ).
In the end, I scored 101 points, Umegae 53 points, and Zen-Emon 51 points with neither having much to show for their efforts (although Umegae's start was quite funny, as he(?) initially picked the encounter field and met a kuge adding even more coins to the already impressive starting wealth.
The game is nice, but the variant as is is not really good at simulating other players.
[b]Likes[/b] + Nice artwork - The drawings are rather beautiful in my opinion and set a nice mood + Some good design choices with the box tray - How many boxes come with the tray being a bit bigger than the folded game board and then having dents so you can easily get the board out of the box without bending the box? + Interesting mechanism - With a more powerful AI, I can see interesting choices in there. The core rules are deceptively simple, but once players interact, things can get interesting. + Got the facts right - At least I didn't notice any big mistakes in the kanji and having all items named individually is also nice (especially since I am not good at food vocabulary - I rather eat food than talk about it (^_^;; ). + Lots of different items at the souvenir store - This actually surprised me as skimming the rules implied that it was a set collection mechanism. They cleverly based the set rules on the item type, allowing each card to be a different item + Lots of good design aspects - having a hole in the character cards where you can put a coloured chip to mark the player colour is really nice and especially useful for solitaire play. Having all card stacks (except for the bonus cards) on the game board is also very nice.
[b]Dislikes[/b] - Some bad design choices with the box tray - Sleeved cards won't fit into the spaces intended for the cards, which is a shame. But what is worse, why does the box contain 80% thin air? Seriously, the box tray is maybe five centimeters tall while the deepest space doesn't go beyond two centimeters, I think. - No pink or white? - As I mentioned above, I would have expected those two colours for player colours in such a game - Colour confusion - Speaking of which, the German rule book talks about cards with a brown back referring to the souvenir cards which have a back that is mainly black and do not contain any brown at all - Weak solo variant - The variant I tried was rather weak, but there are others and also suggestions for tweaking it. - Eater of table space - Especially if the AIs actually got better at getting panoramas and things, the table could get rather cluttered - What are the places? - With all that love for detail and atmosphere, it is kind of disappointing that the names of the individual locations are not given on the board
Yours, Deathworks

item.objectname: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) â Forgotten Souls
item.body:
ORIGIN STORY
I'm as bit late to the origin story game, and in fact the origin of the path that led me to this website goes all the back to the early 1970s. A friend brought his copy of SPI's Phalanx to school and I was drawn into wargaming. I subscribed to S&T, and in 1973 a momentous event in solitaire gaming occurred: the release of [thing=8326][/thing].
[ImageID=293526 medium]
[ImageID=974916 medium]
As far as I can tell, this was the first purpose-designed solitaire game released, at least in terms of the games we all play. I played the heck out of that game, despite a huge amount of errata.
Since then, I've been a huge fan of solitaire games, enjoying the First Golden Era from the early 1980s to the mid-1990s, when games such as [thing=1608][/thing], [thing=3202][/thing], [thing=1681][/thing], [thing=1669][/thing] and [thing=1425][/thing] were released.
As far as I'm concerned, we are now living in the Second Golden Era, and I couldn't be happier to see that solo gaming has now branched out into non-wargames.
I don't recall exactly how I heard about this site; my guess is that I followed a link from a specific game's BGG page. My first post was in August 2014, for [thing=147747][/thing], an interesting game that has since been surpassed in my gaming preferences by the likes of [thing=140519][/thing], [thing=149241][/thing], [thing=146791][/thing] and, in light of this post's subject, [thing=104162][/thing].
I like almost everything about this site. I like the structure, where game-specific info is attached to the item, and more general info is on the bottom. I like the new info I often pick up. And most of all, I like the game-centered, friendly atmosphere I find here. At times I feel like a refugee from Consimworld, where a few loud and nasty voices can drown out the rest. In terms of money, I'd say where this list has cost me the most was in making me aware of solitaire variants for games I had earlier decided not to get (e.g., [thing=124742][/thing], [thing=47185][/thing], [thing=103886][/thing]).
But on to today's post.
I had a great time last Saturday playing the first two missions in a [thing=164153][/thing] campaign with a friend and his two sons (they were the Rebels, I was the Empire). I had so much fun the next day I visited a local game store to pick up some mini-painting supplies, and while there I noticed on the "new" shelf this: [thing=170959][/thing]. Realizing that SW:IA and Descent 2.0, share the same DNA, I picked it up, but decided that before I played the second Descent coop expansion I should really play the first, which had been sitting on my shelf.
So I started a game tonight, choosing one character each from the core game and the two Descent expansions I own. I ended up with Grisban the Thirsty (Knight), Augur Grisom (Prophet) and Logan Lashley (Beastmaster). Not sure it's the most well-rounded of groups, but I figured this is a learning campaign.
[imageid=2419257 large]
The way the Descent coop expansions work is that you have a deck of Exploration card, with each card laying out a room and populating it with monsters. The card will have certain conditions and timers on it. You start Forgotten Souls on the Onset card, but after that they will be somewhat randomized in that three main encounter cards will come up in order, you're just not sure when.
[imageid=2419259 large]
The rules for Hero activation are pretty much the same as the core game, but the monsters use special Activation cards to determine what they do on their turn.
[imageid=2419263 large]
You can get loot when you kill enough monster "steps" (each space they occupy is worth one, so a Barghest gets you two steps). With three players, as soon as I kill five steps worth of monsters (e.g., two Barghests and a Zombie), I get to choose an Item. There is a Doom and Fate marker that travel down a track toward each other; if they ever meet, you lose. In my game, Grisban picked up a very nasty crossbow, which means I now have someone with a ranged attack.
[imageid=2419264 large]
My sense is that this will end up a puzzle solving game, as you often don't have much time to do all you need to do in each room and then make it to the next one (when you open a door, you flip over the next Exploration card.
I've just cleared the first room. Lashley's wolf familiar helped to take down the first Barghest, while Grisban made full use of his abilities to take out the final Master Zombie. By the way, it only occurred to me later that one of the zombie dog minis from Zombicide would be perfect for the wolf familiar.
[imageid=2419265 large]
The next room looks like it will be more of a challenge.
[imageid=2419270 large]
Enjoying this very much so far.
If FFG ever comes out with a similar coop/solo expansion for [thing=164153][/thing], you can bet that I'd do a Costanza and knock over an old lady to be first in line for it. :D

item.body:
Another one that doesn't get to the table as much as it should. Had an epic evening with this, in the longest game I've yet played. (Almost survived the second battle, against the Goblin Shaman. Yeah... almost.)
Took a ridiculously armoured Paladin and unstable Rogue into the fight, this time, drawn at random. Managed to level them up once, apiece, with a Black Poison and Regeneration skill, respectively.
First encounter was the Exploding Tomatoes, which I didn't find too taxing, at all... but it was the next, super tough, bunch of thugs that finally did for me. The Goblin Shaman is able to spawn reinforcements, as well as kill one of his own to embolden the posse. I managed to get them down to two grunts and the boss, but - in the end - the Rogue couldn't roll for an attack to save his life, even with a Dagger of Doom working its bonuses from the shadows.
:thumbsup: A fabulous adventure and a better time-based puzzle than the likes of Legends of Andor. The feeling is of my old D&D days, working to build up a party, but also having a few laughs with it. The fact that I find this so amusing, even solo, is testament to its quirky, knowing brilliance. :thumbsup: I actually really enjoy the combat, now. It's abstracted, but it's far cleverer than early reviews have suggested. I don't feel it's that far removed from a minis game - and the stacks of life tokens are making me hungry for [thing=124839][/thing]. :thumbsdown: Time to play. The adventuring feels brief to me, but the combat, especially on the tougher bosses, can really draw out. :thumbsdown: The expansion isn't out yet!

Picked up the [thing=166679]Gates of Arkham[/thing] expansion for this recently. Finally got a chance to break it out tonight.
Trish Scarborough and William Yorrick vs. Yog-Sothoth.
[imageid=2419425 medium]
A rocky start saw Trish pile on a few Elder Signs before being devoured in an Other World.
[imageid=2419426 medium]

[imageid=2419427 medium]
William's power to spend a monster token to add the red and yellow dice came in very handy, especially in this mission at Ma's Boarding House.
[imageid=2419428 medium]
The board was littered with gates in the late game.
[imageid=2419429 medium]
With two spots left on the doom track (and a mythos card that would fill those two spots at midnight), William acquired the last two Elder Signs just in the nick of time.
[imageid=2419430 medium]
:thumbsup: Interesting expansion that uses the base game components with new adventure cards to provide a very new experience :thumbsup: Adds new mechanisms and increases the difficulty :thumbsup: Having to choose adventures while they are face down prevents obvious min/maxing :thumbsup: More investigators and Great Old Ones, plus items, allies etc. that can be used with the base game adventures :thumbsup: If you were almost sold on the base game but needed a little more, this may do it for you :thumbsdown: If you really don't like the base game, it is unlikely that this expansion will change your mind :thumbsdown: 8 more Investigator Miniatures to buy to keep up (assuming you are using miniatures like me)!

item.objectname: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â The Dead Marshes
item.body:
I'm getting more into building my own decks from scratch (previous model was to "borrow" someone else's list and modify it) while working chronologically through the LOTR LCG adventure packs. I built an Elrohir/Elladan/Glorfindel (S) deck tonight, not exactly building for this quest in particular, but at least flipping through the encounter deck before making final card decisions.
It might be because I'm working with a full deck pool and this is a very early adventure pack (back when the card pool was much smaller), but I thought this was a pretty easy quest solo. I used A Very Good Tale three times in my first 5 turns (very lucky draw there) and I seemed to have good luck with the encounter deck. I pulled mostly treacheries and they weren't that nasty. I only failed an Escape test once.
Gollum had four resource tokens on him when I quested through 2b and made the final Escape test. I committed 12 willpower and the test revealed 8. I think the massive amount of allies I had out helped a lot. My final threat was 27. I enjoyed the quest overall.
I'm glad I'm going through the adventure packs chronologically. I think if I had played some of the current APs first, the Mirkwood series would probably feel somewhat disappointing. Either way, I'm still questing around Middle Earth, so it's all good.

Hello!
I have run another very quick session of Tokaido (about 30 min.), this time using [thread=938827]this variant[/thread]. It differs by making the dummies move a bit slower and removing money from the dummies completely.
The absence of money kind of simplified things as there was less to keep track of. I am wondering, though, how much it limited the usage of temples (in my first session Umegae was so rich as to repeatedly donate 3 coins) (^_^;;
The slower movement of the dummies really improved the experience significantly. They forced me to jump ahead a few times to secure important resources and all in all, I wasn't able to rush ahead with the panoramas.
In mid-game, I was able to finish the mountain panorama as the first (and in the end only) one. No other panoramas were finished (I admit that I also helped that by blocking one of the later sea panorama spaces).
I was kind of surprised that I did so well with the end of game rewards, although the gourmet bonus was really a nail-biting experience till the last inn as Sasayakko kept getting the most expensive meals (while Umegao preferred the cheaper ones). I also liked how I was able to collect rather fitting souvenirs for Satsuki, although the Manju in the end were among a not so good choice available.
Actually, Satsuki and Sasyakko were drawn until, as the very last step, the temple donations were checked. This was another strategic decision of mine - going for the last temple and donating exactly enough to be 1 coin in the lead (I needed my money for another souvenir, so I needed to minimize the investment).
In the end, Satsuki (I) won with 76 points, closely followed by Sasayakko with 73 points, while Umegae only scored 51 points. (Although I might have missed adding points once in a while during the session).
[ImageID=2419543]
This variant was real good fun. Removing the gold does not really reduce the feeling of authenticity of the game, while the shorter movement of the dummies makes them more challenging.
I may consider modifying the movement rules a little bit, though, in order to encourage usage of special abilities and also using the 'free' spaces that may appear towards the end (if there is one or more empty space between the last and the one before them).
Even though I rushed through it, the atmosphere was feelable (and I really liked the souvenirs Satsuki collected.
Although this variant also shows that while the game seems tranquil, especially towards the end-game, it is one of rather intense interaction and possible attacks.
Yours, Deathworks

item.objectname: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.body:
Hello folks, did you miss me? I missed posting here, though I read a lot of the posts. I had an almost two months long streak of gaming with people, instead of using my multiple personalities, so I've been absent for the only good reason there is.
Anyway, yesterday I took this off the shelf, for a quick initial scenario, to refresh rules and game flow. I recently bought the three first adventures from the Shadows of Mirkwood cycle, so this was a must.
Anyway, I lost horribly due to strong enemies entering soon, and no allies in sight. I used [user=xanalor][/user] killer deck, but it didn't matter, I got crushed.
A rematch is due today, I'll inform on how it went.
Feels good to be back!
My origins story is rather bland, I'm afraid. I simply saw on the front page one of the lists, clicked there, and got caught. This has cost me some money, and many sleepless hours trying to resist the temptation of buying more and more. Recently I was at a local FLGS, and [thing=146791][/thing] was there, on the shelf, luring me. And, during one of my costumary searches online, a Spanish retailer offered [thing=149951][/thing] with several expansions and promos in a very tempting package.
I didn't pull the trigger, but it costs me a lot of effort.

I setup my own learner's variant of this game.
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/3JDHLkq.gif[/IMG]
Yup, on my 17th play I thought I needed to play a simpler version. The version is: No dice rolling and no abolitionist cards, good or bad. Everything in the game is predictable except the order the slave market cards are revealed at.
I honestly think this is the game Mayer designed, adding in the dice and cards later to add in some variability. I'll tell you that to a nub like myself, the game felt almost identical to when playing the normal way, with regard to directing traffic and how it gets seriously clogged as the game goes on. I used the Preacher so money was no problem (as usual). I lost when too many slaves got lost in the late game (as usual). Setup to game end, 35 minutes.
I think I will use this variant indefinitely until I start winning regularly.
I also used the kickstarter slave catchers I just bought, for my first time. I'm sad to say I don't think they make the game better, just different. I also feel that they have the added con of sometimes blocking your view of cubes in a given location, due to their height. I'd rather they were Robinson Crusoe Player token size than the skyscrapers they are.
I've gotta wrap my head around this game already!

item.objectname: Where There Is Discord: War in the South Atlantic
item.body:
In early January, I was browsing Geeklists (though I rarely spend much time on them), and ran into the "2014 Peoples Choice Top 100 Solo Games" list. I wasn't sure if that had anything to do with the Dice-Tower, but I figured it didn't matter. I like Solo games, and peoples' choice sounds like a popular voting kind of thing. I'm primarily a wargamer, but I'm always on the lookout for a good solitaire game of any kind.
I had previously never realized you guys existed! Despite my regular posting to the "Monthly Wargames on Your Table" geeklist. Since I live in the jungle (southern Borneo...look up Banjarbaru and you'll get an idea), there are few gamers around (that I haven't gotten into gaming anyway). So, I solo game a lot.
So, I joined the guild, subscribbed to the new geeklists, and then became rather daunted by how much more extensive your reports are! However, I realized, I can probably post as much as I want and if people are interested, they can ask questions!
Here's my first post:
I borrowed this super-expensive game (a 1st edition, but still ridiculous) from my friend in Yogyakarta, Adhika. He has played only about 15% of his current collection. I'm sitting closer to 70%, but wanted to get this played so I could either remove it from my wishlist, or bump it up (a $200 game sitting more than halfway down a wishlist is just preposterous).
First, I discovered that the two board map backs were coated in mold. I took some vinegar and lightly wiped them down, then let them dry really well. The smell was gone when I started playing.
This is a game about the Falkland's War from the British perspective. I'll keep my report short, since there's not a ton to say. I got zero cease fire events, Foreign Support got hammered early and often, causing a tougher enemy. I advanced my taskforce too far too fast and took more damage than I needed (didn't realize the landings had to be done later). I was surviving ok, but was never able to add to either my domestic or foreign support, and 4 turns before the end, another one of my ships was blown up and domestic support for the war collapsed, resulting in a loss for me.
Assessment: :thumbsup:) You really get into the feel of the war! Historical events cause you to pull your hair out. Most raids are feints/duds (at the end of an attack, no one is dead). Lots of fear of Exocet missiles and what the Argentinians [i]could[/i] do. Great immersion (which is what I'm primarily looking for)!
:thumbsdown:) MEGA-OVERPRODUCED! Usually this is something that I don't even notice or care about, but, the board could have easily been half the size, with counters half the size, cards half the size, and money half the amount. One reason it is so expensive is that it's just so freaking huge! Also, it barely fits on my game-table, which is a big negative! My baby (2.5 years old) found it rather irresistible because I couldn't put anything between his line-of-sight.
:thumbsdown:) The learning curve was brutal. Everything was so easy, and then very quickly it went from great to dead. In hindsight, I can see ways that I could have played more cautiously (or gotten different events), but that was very unclear at the time. Also, the game has a great virtue which is that you can learn while playing, but you will likely miss some important restrictions/rules and will take a serious beating (like Operation Sutton not being able to be launched until the 23rd, or ships in the defense zone being able to detect and deter attacking Argentine vessels). I'm going to try again in March and see if I can do as much better as I think I can.

item.body:
I've been working my way through this series of games this month. I've played the first 3 games in the series, [thing=75292][/thing](x3), [thing=93867][/thing](x5), and [thing=101628][/thing](x2). I still have to play [thing=101629][/thing], and then I'll play the combined game: [thing=131874][/thing]. I've won as the Americans and Germans in every game, but, the Americans have won 60% total of the games, and in some ways I'm spending less of my "brain juice" on them in the first place.
Assessment: :thumbsup:) They are great! Accessible, short, and very easy, but still intricate, engaging, and part of a great series! I deeply enjoyed my plays of this, and since it can be printed out and created for very little PnP effort, this is a big hit!
:thumbsdown:) The game is basically a huge luck-fest because standard cards are the primary randomizer. Not just the card draws for combat (which is an issue of massing fires effectively), but since activations also come from card draws, sometimes a player can receive very few activations in a turn. Ultimately this may balance out, but there is usually a turn or 2 of heavy hitting and getting passed over time and time again can feel frustrating. In addition, sometimes one side can shoot 10 times at the other, and achieve no hits, only to be quickly destroyed by massed fires because a series of Aces are drawn. Usually this kind of thing doesn't happen, but when you play these games as much as I have, you start to notice bizarre occurrences.
:thumbsdown:) This doesn't make a very competitive game. Now, I played this solo, so it's not a huge deal, but usually you can tell who is going to win by the end of the first turn (because of beginning power of units or ability of the Germans to make progress before American Reinforcements come up. A short first turn is always a killer to the Germans. However, this can be somewhat mitigated by putting yourself in Peiper's shoes (the SS German Commander), and trying to think about how to overcome the American obstacles. The Americans have challenges and can try to do a lot of really interesting things, but most of their moves seem somewhat obvious (getting on good terrain, blocking the German advance, and cutting German supply when he passes), which sometimes leads to a less than stellar game experience. I have had a serious rally and win as the Germans once (my first game of The Bagged Peiper), and the lucky swinginess of it keeps the game interesting, but a lot of times you're just putting nails in the coffin. Luckily, it doesn't take much in terms of time to finish the job.

item.objectname: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.body:
Got in a couple of games last week, just now getting a chance to post them up here.
[size=10][u][b]02/10[/b][/u][/size] Setup for a solo game while Denine was getting ready for bed. Using the randomizer app, I had Black Widow, Captain America, and Rogue attempting to stop Dr. Doom from opening Portals to the Dark Dimension with the help of Hydra and a few Hand Ninjas. My team of heroes fought the good fight, but ultimately failed to stop Dr. Doom from opening the final portal. I think my main problem this time around was a combination of recruiting Maria Hill to up my recruitment points a few too many times, and barely being able to KO anything out of my deck. I think I only managed to KO one Agent and one Soldier the entire game, so my deck was way too bogged down to get any decent attacks in by the end.
[size=10][u][b]02/12[/b][/u][/size] Took another pre-bedtime crack at it, this time with Elektra, Iron Man, and Nightcrawler against Magneto, the Emissaries of Evil, and the Savage Land Mutates. The villains were attempting to Steal the Weaponized Plutonium, which calls for an additional villain group, so Magneto enlisted the Brotherhood as well. After my the debacle which was my deck in the last game, I focused on buying heroes for recruitment instead of Agent Hill. I particularly enjoyed Nightcrawler's card that gave me +2 recruit with the 'Teleport' keyword so I could save it for later, which let me easily recruit some high-cost cards mid-game. The heroes were successful on this outing, managing to soundly defeat Magneto while preventing any villains from escaping with the plutonium. Things were going so well, in fact, they actually delayed the final blow to Magento so that they could clean up the streets and recapture all of the plutonium that the villains had on-hand (and raise my final score). My penultimate hand was one of those beautiful combos of drawing and chaining chaining cards which resulted in a truly obscene total attack, allowing me to almost entirely clear the board. It's moment like those which make me really love this game.
:thumbsup::Combos! Really makes one feel like a badass superhero. :thumbsdown::Hard to KO basic/recruitment cards once you're done with them. I haven't played enough to know if this is universal or only with certain setups; in my first game, with the recommended setup, I had no problem KOing, but have been virtually unable to do so in the two games since. :thumbsdown::Needs more Henchmen groups, I can see myself getting tired of seeing the same half-dozen henchmen all the time. Then again, they are just anonymous fist-fodder.

It took me a week, but I finally finished another solo conquest. It's so night to have my [-]office[/-] Mage Knight room completed. I can have big games setup as long as I want with no risk of kids/cats interference. I played as Goldyx and did well finishing with 186. I can definitely tell I'm still a little rusty having this sit on the shelf for over 6 months last year. It took me until the end of Day 3 to reveal the first city. I did end up conquering both cities during the last night. At the expense of wounding 4/5 units.
I really dislike the fame/reputation track. It's too big for what it does. Takes up too much table space. And on top of that, if you bump it pieces slide. I decided to do something about it. I took an old dry/erase magnet board (about 1/16 inch thick). cut it a little smaller than the track and glued it to the back. I clued some spare pieces to magnets. Walla! My track is stand up reducing need for space on the table. I can actually move it and pieces don't slide anymore. item.objectname: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.body:
I've had the itch to play Mage Knight for a while now, so I decided to play a Blitz Volkare's Return scenario. Played on Heroic Combat Level and Tight Race Level. I've never played Blitz Volkare's Return before, so I was shocked to see I would only have 5 countryside tiles. I couldn't see how that could possibly be enough. I randomly chose Wolfhawk and started the game.
The first round went well enough. I took out a keep turn 1 and recruited a Thug turn 2. Volkare stayed to the west of the map, away from me, but he was really moving at a fast clip. He explored, revealing several monasteries, which I unfortunately could never make it too. I was worried the game would end before I got strong enough to even take on the city.
Round 2 saw me taking out a Mage Tower in the middle of the desert. My thugs were injured by an Ice Mage, but I healed them with the Refreshing Breeze skill. The thugs having 5 armor for a level 1 unit is very strong. The spell I got from the Mage Tower was Mana Bolt, as I had a Frost Bolt I had picked up a couple blue crystals from, so I figured I had crystals to burn. Meanwhile, Volkaire explored the non-city core tile. I recruited a peasant, and got into position to reveal the city. I also attacked a double orc ruin with my new spell. I wounded my peasants and spent 2 crystals, but gained 4 crystals and some fame.
Round 3 I revealed the Blue City. Unfortunately, I had to fight a dragon to get to it. Fortunately, it was fairly weak, only a Storm Dragon. I blocked it, (using Swift Reflexes for an effective 8 block) then was easily able to kill it. Then I went into the city and faced about the scariest thing possible, a Freezers in the Blue City! 5 Swift Cold attack is no laughing matter, especially when it has paralysis. That killed both of my units. Fortunately, I was able to kill all three enemies in one turn. Unfortunately, Volkare moved next to the city immediately after I conquered it, forcing me to declare end of round.
In the final round I spent my first turn recruiting Catapults, and was immediately attacked by Volkare. I killed two enemies in the ranged phase, then my newly purchased Catapults died to another Freezers! I was able to kill all but one of his units, thanks in part to a Howl of the Pack allowing me to play a card sideways for 7 attack! On my next turn, I rested, then moved to attack Volkare. I then realized that he was on a mountain, so I couldn't attack him. I spent 3 turns just discarding cards until he decided to move again. In the meantime, he had recruited another unit! Fortunately, I was able to kill both of them in the ranged phase, thanks to Agility.
Counting up my final score, I realized I scored a zero in both Greatest Loot and Greatest Leader. This was the first time I've ended with no Crystals, Artifacts, or Units! Despite that, I ended up with a respectable score of 194. This play really reminded me of why I love this game, and I'm eager to play it again soon!

Currently on Kickstarter, but has a full preliminary PnP. 52 cards, but that's nothing to the right paper cutter, 110 lb cardstock, and a box full of sleeves. They fit standard sleeves, as for Magic: the Gathering and Pokemon cards.
It's harder than it looks on first glance, and has a small table footprint and is quite fast. I think it would be perfect to take on planes or to waiting rooms with tables, moreso than many other games out there.
Basically the idea behind Project Dreamscape is to play cards, using special abilities to create chains of specific dreams together. Every card has two different abilities (and each ability is linked to a specific dream type). Being able to pull different card combinations to create links is vital, and I still haven't figured out how to score above 38 points.
I like it.

item.objectname: Escape: The Curse of the Temple â Big Box
item.body:
I've posted before about my initial thoughts on the game. Now that I've played several 2-player games, working through most of the modules, and a 4-player basic game, I decided to return to the solitaire experience and see what I could make of it.
I've been working on the variants described in this thread: [thread=1313932][/thread]
However, I've also started removing things--especially curses, plus some treasures--that either don't work very well solo or just don't interest me. For curses, I found that having 7 dice makes it stupid easy to get rid of a curse with a few seconds' work. To compensate for this, I weeded the Curse deck so I would be more likely to draw one of the physical curses or one of the incurable ones--my favorite is one of the Queenies that says that if you don't make it back to the safe room during the first or second countdown, you automatically lose the game. I also took out some treasures that I didn't care for, including the shortcut, which wastes more time than it saves. And I have decided not to bother with the two new characters for now.
I think that I've explored the possibilities of this game enough now that I can start working my way through the Challenges the next time I break it out.
item.comment:
Good idea about weeding the curses for solo play. I've always considered doing that (but never bothered, mainly due to laziness :)). The no-talking curse is obviously fairly useless in a solo game, for instance!
I agree, having 7 dice makes things a little too easy. I always play solo with 5 dice now, otherwise it's just too easy to win.

item.body:
This is a game that I've been wanting to try since I first got turned on to modern board games almost three years ago.
I used the official solitaire variant. At first, I was opposed to their solution for havng another player choose things for you, but once I saw how often that mechanic was used for choosing destinations and other things that couldn't easily be decided by dice, I chose to go with it.
I chose the familiar Aladdin for my first game. My three randomly drawn skills were Seduction, Weapon Use, and Bargaining/Evaluation...yep, sounds like the Disney version. Though poor, I felt the the Pull of the Sea.
From Mecca, I sailed south. My first day at sea, I encountered a terrible storm. I tried to avoid it, but my actions resulted in the death of every other person aboard, and I became grief-stricken.
Visited an island, saw some big snakes.
Sailed to Serendib, met a talking horse. Asked him to accompany me on my quest. He politely declined.
Traveled south of P'an P'an. There, I met a trapped 'Efreet. I decided to try to trick him--being grief-stricken, I didn't feel capable of bargaining. However, I soon learned that the senile 'Efreet couldn't remember a single magical trick to help me.
Having seen plenty of the southern seas, I decided to trek north across India and eventually reach the Mediterranean. I returned to Serendib, where I ran into a malicious band of mermen! I decided that if I honored him, he might leave me in peace. However, I was unable to pay the tribute they required, so they sank my ship. I drifted on an empty barrel until I washed up, lost, on an unknown island.
I sailed east, meeting an impudent prince. I followed him, hoping he would lead me to civilization, but he and his crew merely scorned me.
I reached land and examined my surroundings. I was in India after all!
Found an 'Efreet bound to a cliff. Tried to free him, but I was not pious enough.
Traveled north to Asia. Found an old musty tome, but it fell apart in my hands. Decided to take a pilgrimage and get over this whole grief-stricken thing. Lying in wait for a ghostly beast, I learned determination. Wounded by a hungry gooleh, I traveled to Samarkand, where I met a girl and soon married. However, she died a week later, and the locals wanted to bury me with her corpse! Too wounded to fight back, I chose to accept my fate. Drawing on my determination, I survived by slaying the others who met my fate and eating the scraps and water they'd been provided, until a secret exit led me to the fabled Valley of the Diamonds! Taking as many as I could, I soon attained princely wealth.
Traveling west to Shiraz, I encountered a toothless hunchback and decided to hire him. He appeared unwell, but I was lucky enough to avoid his illness. Discovered a crystal palace in Basra, but the guards turned me away. I became temporarily grief-stricken. I haven't mentioned this before, but every night I'm terrorized by the baying of a great black dog, making me quite good at enduring hardships.
At the end of my pilgrimage, in Mecca, I bought a crafty slave who drew unwanted attention to my wealth, leaving me accursed. Finally close to the Mediterranean, I hired the finest boat to sail to an unnamed island and complete my quest. Through my determination, I hired an enchanted beggar to help me lift the curse.
I now felt that I had tested my seamanship sufficiently, and sought a new quest. Hearing of a giant inhabiting an island to the north, I set out to slay it. However, I soon found myself in the Palace of 100 Closets. Passing through the 100th door, I beheld the Jeweled Fortress in Africa. As fabulous as it was, I knew it paled in comparison to the works of Allah, and I undertook another pilgrimage to spread this lesson.
At this point, I had already been playing (and typing this up) for over two hours, and it was getting very late, so I decided to call it a night. I took some pictures so that I can easily resume at a later date.
